reviews.review: Like a fairytale. I love and I mean, absolutely LOVE hearing the Big Ben chime. Makes you want to stop what you're doing and twirl around. I also had the privilege of standing right under the Big Ben when I gota personal tour of the houses of Parliament. I miss London..sigh!

Excellent attraction . Really great to see the clock tower in real life. It is right opposite Westminster station and easy to get to. Great photos from the river ferries and across the river or on the bridge. Try to be there on the hour to hear the bells. It's a very short walk to Westminster Abbey as well. The Palace of Westminster where Big Ben sits can only be accessed inside if you are a British citizen.

Wonderful architecture. Any visitor to Lindon should see the iconic Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, it is a stunning piece of architecture and should be seen both day,and evening,when it is even more spectacular.
Best time to visit is New Years. The sky is lit with fireworks on the stroke of 12 (midnight). Its an experience never to be forgotten.

Well worth the Climb. You have to write to your MP to arrange a tour but it is well worth it. Absolutely fascinating talk and amazing views from behind the great clock face. I did here they may instal a lift but don't know if this is true....otherwise about 300 steps!
Beautiful display of time.. Elizabeth Tower also known as "Big Ben" is a stunning display of time and at night, it is even more spectacular. Listen to Ben's bell chime well into the night.

Once in a lifetime experience. Walking on the bridge to see the this structure gives the feel of amusement as it stands tall with its beautiful design and vintage architecture. One of the must sees in london city ~

Amazing piece of architecture. The Big Ben looks significantly more impressive in person than in any of the many pictures you have ever seen. It's really possible to just sit and look to it for many minutes, which is actually what I encourage you to do: find a spot to sit down and relax on the Parliament Square Garden and take some time to appreciate the views.
Big Ben - worldwide know place.. London is the Big Ben image. thousands of photos are made here everyday . A good point to view it and the houses of parliament is the other side of the river Thames.
Big Ben . It is a very cool Landmark. Great to take a picture with it in the Background. It is also close to the London Eye. So if you in the area check it out.
Very pretty looks at night. The area of big ben and river at night is very pretty because of lighting and festival like crowd there.

Big ben is London. To many people Big ben is London! Big ben is the bell inside the clock tower. But people always mistakenly call the tower that.The Tower was renamed Queen Elizabeth II tower. It is always where the tourist throng and sometimes one has to be careful of pick pockets. As our guide advised us on a recent walk to Big ben. Over the years i have visited many times and i always take friends visiting to the Big ben. Its must see.
Cuz you have to. Walked around this neighborhoods a two times of the day. definitely better to visit Big Ben at night. The photos are better at night.
Must see!!!. Been there a hundred times but always a thrill to get a picture in front of it! Iconic IS the word! It's what every trip to London should include - listen for the chimes!!!

Must visit. Visiting London and not seeing Big Ben would be frustrating. The architectural view is just awesome. A few pics with Big Ben in the background is a must. Wonderful. London Eye, London Bridge, IMAX theatre are very near to Big Ben.

Sightseeing delight. Central London is a great place to spend as long as you can, many things are free if your budget is restricted and also walking, but plan ahead so you do not wear yourself out and spoil it.Big Ben is a good starting point and with easy walking to other venues that follow. FREE

What an eye full. While visiting London we stood by Big Ben as I've only seen it on the news it's really overwhelming as to the size... it's so nice to see where the clock chimes on New Year's Eve etc.. when it goes off it's a nice sound to hear ... Big Ben us something that people all over the world will know about and to see it up close was a real treat....

Big Ben ..... Beautiful . Now a visit to London must include a visit to Big Ben.... it's amazing so beautiful such wonderful craftsmanship in its construction.... the sight n chimes together is breathtaking

More lovely in person . I've seen this on television and films for years, but seeing it in person is just magnificent. Not to miss if you're in the area -- especially since you can't miss it because it's so tall!

Not open to the pubblic. Not open to the general public, although UK citizens can gain entrance by writing to their MP, should that worthy desire to be helpful. As an Icon, it is great to look at and listen to when you are visiting parliament. (DO take the tour of the Palace of Westminster next door.)

Iconic Must See Location. Beautiful at all time during the day but much prefer to photograph at night! The architecture is breath taking. Prep for many people to be about but most are on the same mission as you...to get a good photo with this iconic landmark.
As Advertised. Yup, it's a big clock in a tower. BUT, it's absolutely ICONIC, and a must do if you're in London. By the way........ it's hard to get a good picture with all the traffic. Good Luck.
Night shots are the best!. Skip the crowd and wait till the evening. The shots you'll get at night of Big Ben and the harbour is going to be astounding!
So much better in real life. Wow it is so much bigger than it seems in photos. A definite must when you go to London. Easy to get to on the tube.
must visit. london tour is incomplete without seeing this attraction and taking picture with it. I visited many times during my stay. love to visit again.
A Must See. If you are going to London you must see Big Ben. It is an iconic symbol of London. Just across the street is Westminster Abbey. Two great sites to see in very close proximity.

Iconic - Need your picture in front of it. The clock tower for the parliament building is an impressive, iconic structure. Recognizable through out the world, you cannot believe that you are standing right in front of it, that it is so large and has so much history. The building itself is covered with ornate carvings.....and it is in the heart of the old city - walking distance to so many things (Westminster Abbey, London Eye, Churchill's war room, the horse guards, Buckingham palace
Beautiful - especially at night. You must see this at night as the lights give it a more stunning look particularly if you want yo be in the picture.
I love Lobdon. Big Ben was one of the highlights in London. I really enjoyed being in London for the first time. Very tourist friendly. Everything is easy to find
Most iconic London landmark. You can't go to London and not take a picture of "Big Ben", which technically, nobody can see because Big Ben is the bell inside the tower. :)
Peter Pan's Clock!. My daughter went berserk when she first saw Big Ben. She kept demanding that we stop and wait for Peter Pan. She's adorable like that.

Got to see it!. No matter when in the city, Big Ben is a "must see" to get the feeling of London. Lots of tourists of course but that's part of it. Seeing this iconic building is always an inspiration.

Iconic. Easily visable from a wide area, it stands as an icon within the London skyline.
Beautiful building, even if the name 'Big Ben' actually refers to the bell inside it which isn't visable.
Impressive

Splendid view. The best view of London.. Just the sight of it can make you gasp for air of reality.. The architecture of this clock tower is magnificent and beautiful.. Just walk on the bridge from the London Eye and experience the beauty of it.. It's not far from River Thames, London Dungeon, and just a walk away from Imperial War Museum
Picturesque London. Viewed from street-side only. An imposing presence. A piece of sight-seeing that cannot be missed. Classic London!
A totally must see. A totally must see if you are in London. The Big Ben is impressive and you cannot really visit London and not take a picture of yourself with the Big Ben in the background.

Just what you imagined. connected to the end of the House of Parliament, Big Ben, chimes on the hour, half hour and quarter hour - a deep resonate sound. The tower at night is beautiful from either side of the Thames. See it at night and during day light - not to be disappointed either time.
Iconic. Worth a visit to see this iconic building and Big Ben, hear the chimes. and get photo taken in front of it.

A great photo opportunity. Amongst the most well known poster pictures of the city of London. Big Ben is the giant bell in the belfry of the Clock Tower at the Palace of Westminster. The Parliament & Westminster Abbey are just adjacent to this historic item. The night view is much more spectacular. Listen to the chimes - and recall its role during the Second World War - Big Ben's chimes were heard around the world on the BBC World Service radio. During the war, people from all over the world listened for Big Ben on the radio. The chimes meant that Great Britain had not been defeated.
Amazing. Very nice tourist atraction. Awesome place for photo lovers. Next time i wish to see it night, i heared it's quite impressive.

iconic symbol of London. Big ben was very close to our hotel so we sow it every day of our London visit. To me it's the iconic symbol of London and I enjoyed experiencing it. Trafalgar square,Big Ben, Westminster Abbey. Also crossing the bridge to see the view was very nice.

London & UK Icon. Visible from all around the river, the clock tower of the Houses of Parliament is one of those icons of London that is hard to miss. We were in the area in late afternoon and then in the evening and it always never fails to impress. That are of London with the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and The London Eye across the river are safe places in London day or night to stroll around.
Day out. It was the best and enjoyable day with my friends, visiting historical places,and got some souvenir and took lots of pictures.
Favorite. Possibly the best of London. Especially Westminster Abbey. I've seen it many times but it never ceases to AMAZE me.
AMAZING!. I was in total awe at the very first site of Ben. To hear the chimes when the clock strikes 12 was such a thrill. Loved it at night too. So beautiful!

wow. such a great construction, ilumination and all that schemes of making show of light is powerfull, i like it more in the night, cause it is spectacular, but for the day you can see the architecture make picture, not so much to do in fact but has an different second impact. enjoy!
Nice clock. A Nice big world famous clock! Big Ben was actually much nicer looking then I expected! I just looked at it, dont know so much about it. Nice to see it anyhow.
Great experience . A very magnificent tower. It looks great even when raining and we very like to stand and watch and listen to the bells

Sightseeing . This attraction is for sightseeing only...you can't just turn up & get inside.Very amazing building near Westminster bridge and on the bank of River Thames.This is where the House of Parliament & Lords are hold.Big Ben chimes every hour...

Extremely interesting. 2 hours went by very quickly discovering all about the history and workings of Big Ben and the clock in the Elizabeth Tower - one of the best historical trips I have done in London, but remember it has to be booked in advance through your local MP

Icon of London. The Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben (the bell itself) are the icons of Victorian London and the symbol that most people world wide recognize immediately as being in London, England. It is a beautiful piece of architecture at the heart of the city and is therefore a must-see when visiting London.

Great to see but looking is just about it.. Great to see it, brilliant photo opportunity. And that's about all there is to it. Great location in the heart of Westminster just by parliament and the cathederal.
Simply Big Ben. I love the big ben and its surroundings. There are many things to do in this area and is always busy with plenty of people coming and going. Big ben is a must if you visit London.

Big ben. Been here many times, but this time was my first at night time, and the lightning was very nice.
Each time being here I fall in love with London a bit more.

Great photo opportunities. . We visited the Houses of Parliament area a few times on our London trip both day and night.
We found the Big Ben tower very impressive and took several photos.
When lit up at night it is equally impressive.
Night view is amazing . Jewel in the crown of London, Big Ben looks beautiful during night time. If you are looking for an late evening stroll with your partner, best place to walk around
Excellent. Go up the tower for an unforgettable experience. I really loved it although it is a bit scary at the top.
Unbelievable beauty.. You can feel the historic atmosphere and memory when you walk around big ben. If u r travelling to london, never miss this spot, no matter the weather is sunny or rainy.

What Time is it..?. this location does not need a Trip Advisor collum..
very big tower and well maintained.
Lot of Tourist taking pictures..
Just a look from the outside. I only saw Big Ben from the outside, but boy was it awesome! really cool looking clock that you learned about in school and maybe sang a song about.
Nice area. Nice to see and experience, not too much to do ,it's just a very famous landmark.its in the a solute center of the London tourist experience so worth a quick know visit.

Greatly designed clock tower.... The big ben is the massive clock tower situated in the palace of westminster. The big ben has 4 clock faces and a gaint bell inside the tower. Its a must visit to see the historic structure and looks awesome during the night with the lighting around the palace of Westminster.
Majestic. the Big Ben and the parlment are just outsantind, this a true beauty to see when sightseeing in London

Go early! Right on the hour if you can!. Big Ben has four faces, I recommend taking a picture with it from the bridge facing London Eye especially when you're there early like 10am.
Reach there by the hour and you'll enjoy the magnificent bells ringing!
Beautiful in evening . Beautiful parliament building and clock. Definitely a must see while in London. Great architecture.!

Quintessential London. My wife and I toured around London for 5 days in early October. Our first day there, we started out without any idea of where we were going and stumbled upon Big Ben and the Parliament buildings. Such a cool looking landmark! It is right beside Westminster Abbey, and pretty close to the London eye. We got some great shots, and could have spent hours in the area. Loved it
Exactly like in the movies. I took so many pictures here from so many angles it is ridiculous. But it's a must and it's not that tall as I imagined. And it bangs at fixed intervals. It was awesome!

Iconic monument. An Iconic symbol of London. Who hasn't heard of it? London Eye, Westminster Abbey, Big Ben all are close to each other. Visible from far and looks majestic both during daytime as well as in the evening when its lit up. No trip to London is complete without taking pics of this clock tower.
London Sight- Good to See. We walked past Big Ben, good to see from the outside. It is fenced around the outside. It is close to Westminster Abbey and the Thames.
Yup. It's a clock.. Hail a cab with a fun, chatty driver. Have him/her give you a quick tour of the city to get yourself acclimated. Stop and take a picture. Done.
London's Pride. This is amazing and has been standing for years. The chime is actually Ben Ben. When it chimes you can hear it for blocks

Postcard picture perfect!. Iconic views, amazing history a must see while in London. Walking along the Thames, from a boat on the same river, from a hotel window, while on the London Eye... Day and night a sight and sound to soak in!

Big Ben is the UK's best landmark. When visiting London its a must have stop to Westminster. Amazing view at night.
Celebrate New Year's Eve in London with New Year's Eve fireworks near Big Ben and London's Eye.
At midnight, Big Ben's famous "bongs" will ring out, followed by the UK's largest annual fireworks display.
Icon of London. Not much to say about Big Ben. You can't go in it, you can only look at it from Trafalgar Square, or across the Thames. Ride the London Eye, you will get good pictures from there!

Cross the river for the best view . Don't come to London without taking a selfie in Westminster with Big Ben behind you. If you want the best angle with a bit of the river Thames and no traffic lights or lamp posts growing out of your head then cross the river and take you pictures from the London Eye end...

Beautiful . Beautiful, and at night it lights up. The clock chimes, sounds awesome
Big Ben is actually the bill inside the tower.
Iconic view. We always stop by the Elizabeth Tower when we are in London. It if fun to stand on the pavement at the foot of the tower when Big Ben counts the hour. The ground vibrates.

Must visit . Best place to take pictures👌👌
You can take a river cruise from there.
Amazing view at night.
Seeing Big Ben is a must.
Near london eye.

Very Intersting. The trip here was very interesting and is not what you expect when you think of a trip to Big Ben. It was extremely crowded and many people were being rude and loud but we made our way through it.
It is worth doing once but not twice!
Walk behind the Big Ben . Elizabeth tower or the Big Ben one of the best place to see it in London and it ring much as the hour ,like its came one a clock it ring only one time

Fantastic to visit. When visiting London its a must have stop to Westminster, sons girlfriend has never been to London and loved the atmosphere and surroundings taking lots of pictures and waiting for the clock to strike.
Definitely big. Absolutely stunning architecture. I always thought it wouldn't be that big in real life but it's huge, I was impressed but wished the chimes were even louder.

Beautiful and iconic symbol of London. Elizabeth Tower/Big Ben is about as iconic as it gets - probably only exceeded by the Eiffel Tower as a symbol of a city/country. It is a must-see, I thought it looked particularly awesome from Queen's Walk across the Westminster Bridge on the far side of the Thames. The area around the base is absolutely jammed with people, so bring some patience.There really isn't much to do once you have seen it and snapped some pictures, but it is a tourist mecca.

London landmark . Always walk by Big Ben when visiting London lovely at night time to beautiful building to admire lovely landmark to have photo with and also London eye in the distance another London landmark

Iconic - best views at night. Viewing Big Ben from both sides of the Thames is a must. Take a walk along the south bank for great views from across the water, this is especially beautiful at night. The walk over the bridge to take in the houses of parliament and parliament square where you will find some iconic statues.
Iconic. One of Londons most iconic buildings. Known world wide. Great for photos. Very busy surrounding areas.
An amazing spot . Big ben is awesome, especially its night view from the bridge. It simply superb. Easy access to public transport.

It's Big Ben, of course it's a 5!. If you are near the River Thames, you can't miss this London icon. Right next to the Parliment building and on the north side of the Thames across the Westminster Bridge. Great pictures from the Golden Jubilee or Waterloo bridges.

Breathtaking British Symbol of History. This was my first trip to London and I couldn't wait to go explore. However Big Ben was not on my list of top things to see in London. Based on pictures I saw online or friend's pictures, it didn't seem all that impressive. That completely changed the day I decided to walk all over London. I was on my way to the Westminster Abbey, unaware that Big Ben was across the street. When I turned the corner and saw Big Ben, I was completely blown away! It took my breath away and I then realized don't ever judge Big Ben based on a picture, but always in person! It is majestic and all things British! I was very lucky to see when it was cloudy and sunny! Do yourself a favor and go see Big Ben, you will not be disappointment one bit.
An Iconic and Impressive Building. A trip to London would not be complete without stopping here and listening to the bells toll. The work that went into building this is amazing.

Iconic London symbol. Beautiful historic building great opportunity for photographers to take pics in day or night
I always love see place in evening so that you can see day view and night view illuminated with light
A sight worth seeing. If you're in London you have to stop by for a visit. A gorgeous sight both during the day and evening. Great photographs to be taken!

Good place to visit. Always like to visit London and seeing Big Ben is a must. Every time I see it I think it looks smaller but I guess that's due to seeing bigger building everywhere like the Shard. It's also great to hear the bells ringing definitely worth a visit.

Showing grey whiskers!. The big guy is still dignified and proper after all these years but he'll undergo some lengthy repairs and upgrades very soon. When you see him you're near historic London, a stones' throw from Parliament and Westminister Abby.(You'll' know the Abbey by the lineups to get inside). If you still pine for the days when Britannia ruled the waves, you'll feel a rush around these iconic structures.

Must!. If you're coming to visit London you have to see the Big Ben! I must say I thought it was much bigger from the pictures but still it's a wonderful architecture that you must see. You can also see the London eye, st James park and walk along the river in south bank and go to the Tate modern.
Ding Doing, Big Ben is Beautiful. Go and See Big Ben in the morning, before 8:00 after that the crowds start to arrive. but make sure your there for when it chimes on the hour.
Fun to see! . Great at night especially when it's all lit up. Can only see it from the outside but it might be included in a tour of the Houses of Parliament- which we did not do.

Epic Selfie. Really lovely place to visit, right in the heart of Westminster. For no money you can enjoy the majesty of the houses of parliament and Big Ben, before taking a nice stroke along the Thames. Worth a visit and just down the road is the Imperial War Museum, presently displaying WW1 feature stands. Hope you have a blast and get some excellent photos.

It's a clock. Big Ben is actually the bell and not the clock on the end of the UK Houses of Parliment. However if you find yourself in London and you want to know the time it's great. Free of charge too, and every hour it goes 'bong! Bong! Bong!'

It's not that big and it's hard to get a money shot. I recently visited on a sunny September day, there always seems to works going on around houses of parliament or big ben, and literally 100's of people on a little strip of road. I would suggest getting out at waterloo or charing cross to view it from Charing-cross bridge. Thi way you get to take in the buzz of all attractions without being swamped with other tourists.

Amazing . It's mainly a photo opportunity. This is probably the most well known poster picture of London. It's an amazing design and to the right side of the Parliament, there are a lot of statues to explore. You will also find the Westminster abbey to the right of the parliament. It's a 5 min walking distance. It's an extraordinarily scenic location. It's a must see location but if you are holidaying in London you will have to see it anyway as most transport passes through that area. For those that are interested in exploring more closely the workings of British politics, you can arrange a free tour of the Houses of Parliament which is a must do activity as the interiors of the houses are amazing.
October 2016. Londons landmark and definitely a must see location. Amazing architecture. Amazing views towards river Thames and Westminster
Stunning. Just so 'BRITISH' hearing the chimes as we were right outside was fabulous. Great to see after 35 years since my last view
Fantastic. Big ben is a large historical place.it is located near to the parliment building.everyone should visit.
Can't miss - must see. From anywhere in London, you can see and must see the Big Ben clock tower of Parliament. Night visit is also a great view.

Just go it.. It's great to be up close and personal with the tower of London and to beat it chime on the hour - which every hour or might be. My 6 year old loved it. My 1 year old was asleep in his buggy (probably from excitement).
A must-see. Big Ben of course is a must-see on a visit to London. Fantastic sight both day and by night. You get a nice view of it from a walk along the Embankment by night

View from the bridge or park to avoid crowds. We loved viewing the clock and parliamentary buildings from the bridge then to the park opposite. Very busy on the other side of the street so get back a bit to avoid this.
Just amazing!!. The view at night is just superb. Great architectural details. Its one of my favorite spot. I will surely go back

Better than you think. We went by the outside during the day and at night - this is the place to take photo. Stand on the bridge and get awesome views of big ben, westminster, and the london eye and river. Worth seeing at night - it's gorgeous. Go when you can hear the chimes.

The quintessential landmark. "Big Ben" is not just arguably London's most iconic view, that would be too limiting a description and would not do it appropriate justice.Hearing the chimes especially in the late evening or early morning when all else is (relatively) quiet is equally as enjoyable (and in my mind is reminiscent of night-time news or NYE on television)Our view (September 2016) was sadly marred due to the extensive scaffolding upon the adjacent house of parliament.

Make sure you are there at the turn of the hour!!!. Take the bus tour (plenty of them) and make sure you stop at Big Ben and walk around. It is an amazing site, always crowded though. Make sure you take pictures with the London Eye that is near by.
finally. everyone should see big ben! is a great building in a great city! im happy i came in london! was fantastic
Amazing view. If you need a hotel near Big Ben, I would suggest the Park Plaza Riverbank hotel. This is a 15min walk to Westminster bridge which is where you will get an excellent view of Big Ben.

Amazingly stunning landmark. Big Ben is probably the most recognized landmark in the world, and surely enough at least the most famous clock around! It's a real icon of London and alongside the Houses of Parliament, makes for terrific photography both upfront and from afar. The architecture is amazing and the history even more so. I believe there are also tours that operate as a tour inside but for most its nice just to take a photo and carry on your trip. I definite must see.
Must See and Hear. Big Ben is very impressive in person and if you can catch it on the hour, you must! Great photos! I recommend to get hear via the hop on hop off bus.
Holiday trip. We were lucky enough to have a beautiful sunny day. Weather was perfect and the experience was overwhelming.
Coolest Clock. So great to take a stroll from Buckingham Palace to Parliament and Big Ben. This iconic clock does not disappoint.
worth visiting. Actually worth going over there. A well spent day out with family and alone if you wish to go.love the night lights. The on going work going was bit distracting.
Great monument. This monument is not the most beautiful in London but it's without a doubt the most representative of London's architecture.

historical artefacts. Despite being born in London, I took the pleasure in taking time out in absorbing educational british history and am glad I recommended it to family and friends. It has show much to learn from, not just a beautiful piece of art but its overall use of governing our country.

Excellent Architecture. Everyone would have seen the pics over the net but being there & actually seeing it is different. You can hear the bell sound at whatever time you visit. Aldo do pass by during day time as well as night when it is lit up.

Good to check off the bucket list. We just visited outside and did not do a tour. There is a high fence all around and with the mobs of people it is hard to get a good photo. Much smaller than we had imagined. Great to see an iconic landmark.
Beautiful at night. Beautiful lit up at night, very busy tourist area, dont think you get enough space to see it in all its glory.
Highly recommend. Visiting the big ben was well worth it. Would highly recommend it!! Absolutley amazing close up and far away. Especially when its dark. My wife and I were really happy we went.
Bellisimo . Classico England of nice fachada mucho still history very secure area of this amazingly talented people.
Magnificent at close quaters. Nothing brings you close to the magnificence of seeing the tower at close range. The detailing is fantastic.
Exactly what it says on the tin! . Brilliant! We visited this attraction on an hour to hear the bell sound several times. It was cool to see and hear. I would visit this attraction again
Breathtaking. To see it rise in front of you as you exit the tube is exhilarating......just beautiful. It is so big and you are so close to it
A must see if visiting London. Got some really good photos for social media with the partner! it really is a beautiful piece of architecture.
Must see in London . Visiting the Big Ben is a must do if you visit London. I would recommend going when it's dark as the lightning is really beautiful. Good for romantic moments (when it's dark).

Amazing for an antipodean. You have an idea of the general shape and outline of Big Ben. But when you see close up the intricate carvings, and hear the chimes for the first time, it's suddenly something else altogether.

Nice views from around the area. A ‘must see’ touristic point of London! You definitely can’t miss to see one of the most iconic item of the world! Located right beside the Tamisa, the place is perfect to walk by and admire the beauty of London at the same time! Definitely recommend it!

Tells the time very well. If you are in the centre of London and your watch has wound down and your phone is out of batteries, look up and maybe you will be able to see this big clock that tells the time very accurately. Bings and bongs every so often. Well lit at night, generally excellent design, works well even though quite old now.

Eye catcher . Like there was something new to say about Big Ben what wasn't already sad.
If you go to London you have to see the B.B. I visited during the day but also by night and if you have time, do just that, is worth it.
My girlfriend's favourite. She is a bit of a size queen and really likes big Ben. I also find it very impressive. It looks good close up and far away
Don't miss it. Big Ben is a great place to start your tour of the city. Although my wife said "it's not as big as I thought it would be. Don't miss it!

Its Beautiful !!. One of the iconic places. I visited on one of the cloudy afternoons, and the view from the bridge, beautiful clouds above, big buses moving around, its just amazing. The area around is filled with tourists generally, but nothing that would affect the visit.

So impressive. Coming out of Westminster tube, I was taken back by how big the tower and clock face is. In real life, it is a ginormous structure which so impressive. Being close up, you miss the Houses of Parliament but that takes just a short walk.

Big Ben, a prime attraction in London!. Big Ben is one of the best attractions in London! Major tourist attraction is place of British parliament with many picturesque locations & areas where you can take amazing pictures!
1990. How can one miss the Westminster Abbey and the Big Ben beside the Thames while visiting London. You just cannot ignore it.

everybody visits the clock tower. Big Ben is the bell within the clock. the clock tower is the Elizabeth Tower named after Queen Elizabeth. Every body wants to see and take a photo of the famous clock tower. Cross over the bridge and get close for a better view and photo. It is famous and magnificent.
Just an outside view!. I didn't go in, but just looking at it is enough it was amazing and free! It's really big and neat from all views!
Beautiful!. I can stare at BiG Ben for hours enjoying its beauty while looking at the busy streets of London with all those double decker buses!

You just need to go.... Especially if it's your first time in London. Big Ben is just so iconic. It's also very beautiful in person and a lot of what you'd want to see in London is just around here. The ding dong of it just reminds you of exactly where you are in the world and the history it is a part of. Loved it!
London Big ben. We went on coach trip to London ,we saw big ben and went sightseeing bus tour around London, had a good day and would recommend for travellers

Beautiful scenery . Must say it is a highly beautiful observation especially during the night time with your loved ones. Considering I'm from Scotland, I personally feel that those who wish to visit London, should 100% visit the Big Ben and have this experience for them selves.
real london. if you looking from distance you understand what i mean, is such a tourist area that is worth just watching it from distance.

The best Sight in London. Big Ben is probably the most common London landmark. That is probably because it is stunning. When you exit the Westminster metro station you see the magnificent building in front of you. Observe it from the bridges around, it is beautiful from every point of view. A must visit!

Holiday. Great viewing from the street to get reasonably close to it spectacular detail on it, looks great day and at night easy to find if you are at Trafalgar Square you can see it fro distance and than walk down the street to see it properly.

Smitten with Ben. My favorite site was Big Ben. Take the underground to Westminster and you will see him as soon as you exit the station. We were lucky enough to be there for the noon chimes. A don't miss in my opinion.

What's not to like about Big Ben?. Let's face it no trip to London is complete without a visit to see or pass the world famous clock. Easy to get to and it looks great in any weather, if you're fortunate enough to see it through a misty London fog it really gives you the taste of what London was like in the 'olden' days eg Dickens.

Postcard picture - pick your angle . Whenever near the Themse and with view on Westminster Palace, the clock tower (containing famous bell Big Ben) is visible or - best at full hour - to be heard.If you are in search of a perfect London postcard picture, make sure to have the tower in it (everyone knows immediately where you are, even though they may call the tower Big Ben). And do be bold and try different angles and views on the bell tower - from Parliament Sq, from the Abbey, from Westminster Bridge, from Lambeth or Vauxhall (footpath by the river) and, of course, from right underneath London Eye. Oh, and go at different times of the day (at least 2x) - it's worth it, as the atmosphere changes and so will your pictures (try to catch the evening sun).Do not be afraid to take funny pictures as well (jumping, hugging, leaning against, holding upright); there are so many tourists around you doing just the same! There are even great motifs of the bell tower to be found around Parliament Sq with red phone booths or - if traffic light helps you - with red double decker busses and black cabs in the front. We once caught all in one picture incl. the evening sun in the background.By the by, if you visit St. Paul's Cathedral - go up to the dome and take a picture from outside the dome in direction of Westminster Palace (the bell tower sticks out) with the surrounding sights like the Gherkin as well as London Eye and the bridges... A must-visit when in London for everyone!
Isn't as great as I thought. It's just a clock.....A very big one that will alarm every fifteen minutes...I went there on Sunday, and the streets around it are FULL of people...

UK citizens - go up to see Big Ben itself via Elizabeth Tower - BRILLIANT. UK citizens can apply for a FREE tour up the Tower. This is a ballot and a bit of a faff doing it way in advance but but it was soooooo worth it. Utterly brilliant from start to finish. Plenty of steps but easily manageable for most especially as it is broken up into chunks with stops for informative talks and information on the way and a sit down. The guide was superb. Photos not allowed which usually I find annoying but it didn't matter this time. Views from the top amazing. Watching the hands turn, seeing the mechanism for this and the ringing of the bells was fascinating especially the adding of old pennies to the pendulum to make micro changes to the time. Walking behind the 4 faces was fantastic but the icing on the cake was actually watching the striking of Big Ben itself at 12 noon (with earplugs provided)....how many people can say they have actually seen this with their own eyes? I will never look at the clock and tower again without remembering this 90 minutes of my life! I am not usually easily pleased or quick to shower unabridged praise onto something but this was simply one of the best tours I have ever been on. And all for free! I would go back tomorrow if I could but am too late for the ballot and also it is closing for 3 years very soon for repair and refurbishment so you will have to be very quick. But even if you have to wait 3 years you must go, as even this long will be worth the wait. I think you can tell that I enjoyed this very much!
A clock as an image. It is a nice tower with nice clock. Maybe too famouse, but from outside it is anly a clock. I take some pictures about it, but not enough good. For me: simple a clock.

334 steps to the belfry- fascinating! . I wrote to my MP via email requesting a tour back in April 2016. I was sent the relevant security forms to complete and within two weeks received a response with a September date and time. So be prepared for a long wait.Upon arrival for my 9am tour (arrive at least 15 minutes early to get through airport style security) at Portcullis House (building across the road from Ben Ben), I submitted my health declaration and handed in my bag, which was locked away securely.My tour was conducted by Richard Bray, who was excellent! The tour began by crossing through the tunnel beneath the road, which led to the clock tower entrance. The climb was split into 4 parts, which made it far more manageable, with the first part being the most difficult (approx 140 steps). We then rested in a small room whilst Richard provided a good historical account of the tower and how it came to be.A further climb led us to the mechanism room which was fascinating! Another small ascent led us to the clock face, which I loved before finally ascending to the belfry in time to hear the 10am chime.We were giving ear plugs prior to this to prepare us.The tour was absolutely fascinating and I feel privileged to have have had the opportunity to visit up close and personal. Highly recommend.

Fantastically interesting. We arranged this via Member of Parliament, in which case it's free for UK residents!You have to climb 365 steps up...and the same down, so not for the frail or infirm.Amazing to look inside this iconic landmark, you go up behind the clock faces, and visit the 'clockwork' movement, the guide gives you all the history of it all and you get to see how it gets regulated with old pennies!We donned our ear defenders and stood next to Big Ben (the bell) as it struck the hour...wow you can feel the vibrations in your chest!An unbelievable opportunity, which may be stopped in the not too distant future - book it ASAP.

We just completed a tour of the clock tower and Big Ben and it was brilliant, we had to enter via portcullis house where you go through airport style security, once in you wait to be greeted by a member of the team and you show your photo I D and proof of address etc, your issued with a permit to wear and then your led underground into the grounds of the Palace of Westminster, you go straight to the tower and make your start on the 334 steps! I was going to give you a blow by blow of the tour but I'll leave it for you to discover it for yourselves.  If like me and the party I organised to visit the tower your proud to be English/ British and love architecture and history then you can't miss this tour.I stood on the very same spot as William Wallace and King Charles 1st were sentenced.also where winston Churchill and various kings and queens lay in state in the great hall,Saw a debate in both the House of Lords and commons, and was right beside Big Ben when it struck 5.Awesome, extraordinary day!

Iconic landmark - see these tips from a local. Big Ben is perhaps the face of the United Kingdom, universally recognised by all. The nearest tube is Westminster, which has (fee charging) toilets and step-free access to the tube. Big Ben is actually the name of the largest bell within the clocktower that forms part of the Palace of Westminster. It is architecturally stunning and well worth a visit. My favourite view is from the opposite side of Westminster Bridge, on the riverside walk around the side of the hospital. Step free access is tricky there but achievable - you have to go down Belvedere Street, take a left towards the river at the level of the London Eye, turn left when you reach the eye and continue until you pass through the tunnel under Westminster Bridge. Have a look over the stone balustrade at the level of the steps and see if you can spot the tiny gnome carved into the embankment.Toilets and refreshments are available in St Stephen's Tavern. There is also a supermarket in the block Westminster Station is in.

A must! For anyone visiting London! . What a brilliant experience. Including our teenager! they were all in awe of Big Ben - well worth the walk which takes you past the cenotaph - very poignant.
Beautiful landmark. Parliament square and this national landmark it's obviously a must visit when visiting London, the chimes of Big Ben are a wonderful reminder to appreciate history.

Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. What a great day this was in London! Amazing. You can see big ben from everywhere.One of the iconic landmark of London. Amazing artchiture.You can't miss it when you r in london.

A Must See, in Person. Elizabeth Clock Tower, or more commonly known as Big Ben, is synonymous with London. Visitors are allowed to tour inside, BUT you must schedule an appointment and be a citizen. Best picture spots of Big Ben are on the South Bank side (less crowded), or on the river boat cruise.

good. The London’s timepiece .Originally, the Houses of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower, are commonly called Big Ben.its among London's most iconic landmarks and must-see London attractions. Technically, Big Ben is the name given to the massive bell inside the clock tower.Big Ben has each dial of seven metre. A special light above the clock faces is illuminated when parliament is in session. AndBig Ben's timekeeping is strictly regulated by a stack of coins placed on the huge pendulum. .It has rarely stopped in these years. The clock tower is 96 m and consists of a 61m high brick shaft.

Main London Attraction. Even though it's not opened for visitors it is one of the main attractions in London. The place is always full of tourists, especially the bridge next to it, as it is the best place to take a photo from. And it will give you chills when the clock strikes.

I enjoyed myself immensely even though I didn't get to go to the top of Big Ben, it wasn't a big deal for me. Just being in the presence of it was enough for me.

Big Ban. Big Ban is the main attraction for visitor who visit london. its the highest tower with clock and seems beautiful at night with lights around it.

Ben is Big!. Impressive- that show I would describe Big Ben! And to hear it chime was wonderful! We saw it both during the day and then light up at night. Hint- the bell is called Ben not the actual clock.

Big Bend: Many Ways To See. I have been to London several times, and if you are going for the first time, you must see this area (Westminster). The Abbey and Houses of Parliament are adjacent. Big Ben is the bell in the Elizabeth Clock Tower. Standing next to it when it tolls is amazing. However, it is not a lengthy undertaking. You will be able to get a good photo if in the area for the other attractions, on a Thames boat cruise, on the London Eye etc... Since you cannot go to London without going to Westminster, there won't be any difficulty seeing it. Immediately in front of it is a small grocery store (more like a convenience store) if you need to pick up a couple of snacks, drinks etc... There is also a good souvenir stand near the statue of Boadicea in her chariot. Caution: It is extremely crowded on the sidewalks in front of Big Ben. Watch your valuables.

World Clock. Big Ben is was under renovation during my visit, thus no tours allowed. When you get off the Underground you're literally across the street from this massive building. People were everywhere but that's what we all came to see...Big Ben. We were lucky enough to hear the ringing of the bells. Nice and it was free.
Great!. It's very beautiful to see it! Close to Westminster Abbey church, Westminster bridge and London eye! Everything is walking distance!

Iconic. A Must for any tourist to Britain and London. Contact your local MP for tickets, be persistent, it is an amazing London experience!

Traditional . It was great to see Big Ben in person. Also to hear the bells go off on the hour. Night time it is lit up it looks beautiful. Great views from around the area.

See in the late afternoon, the clock tower is golden!. I visited the tower twice while in London. By far the best time of day to see the tower is at about 6-7pm and before the sun sets. There will be a magnificent light from the sun on the tower that makes it look like the tower was just photoshopped into reality! It is stunning. Hard to get a great picture from nearby, the best place to get as picture if from on the London Eye!You cannot visit the tower or go inside it unless you are a UK Resident and Citizen. Before I went, there was lots of confusion all over the internet with people saying that you have to be an EU citizen to go up, or that you had to be a British Citizen, or that you have to have a UK passport, but the TRUTH is, you need to be a UK Citizen AND Resident.This is a great icon to visit, and does not take long to see! Beautiful at night. The iconic Big Ben! I liked it better at night with its bright lights. Must see in London. Just steps from Westminster tube station. Impressive architecture!

The heart of London. There's something about being near Big Ben. You are right where the action is - the heart of the oldest parliamentary democracy and near Downing Street and Whitehall. Destroyed in More Films than Any other European Sight!. in the middle of London. Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London,he clock and dials were designed by Augustus Pugin.5 August 1976: First and only major breakdown. The air brake speed regulator of the chiming mechanism broke from torsional fatigue after more than 100 years of use, causing the fully wound 4-ton weight to spin the winding drum out of the movement, causing much damage.Lovely place

A must see. throughout our childhood we have started hearing of the Big Ben clock and then started to imagine this sharp timing clock of a giant size. i never thought it was a true thing part of a building when i was 7 until i started to see photographs captured at the site. it is a place of beauty especially when free of tourist during the night time. i visited the place twice and looking forward to visit the site again and again.

Very interesting to see. "Look kids! Big Ben, Parliament"----The line from the famous European Vacation movie. We rehearse that line over and over, and it was very interesting to see this up close. It is awe-inspiring, and truly a great work of art. Highly recommend!

Beautiful tower, but overrated. The tower (Elizabeth tower, Big Ben is the great bell inside) is beautiful, but is smaller in real life than you would think. Best views can be had from a distance or from the London Eye.On a tour I heard that the tower will be covered soon for renovations.
This is London . This is London , It is big big !! It was great to visit here! Most important place to visit in London . I really enjoyed to stay all day at here . Everybody must go !!

We toured inside WA (long line/ very crowded), but we only observed BB and the HP from a distance. Crowded with tourists. Can't visit London without having seen the Big Ben. Not sure what all the fuzz is about, it's just a clock on some old tower, but its still nice to walk around and get the vibe :).
Stunning! . Stumning view, great location in the heart zone of London, the main attraction, i think.the atmosphere was incomparable.

High in the sky. The perfect place for a tourist to start their journey around London. The building is impressive close up and also from the bridge and across the river at the London Eye. The clock face is lit at night and offers some excellent photo opportunities.
Impressive building. Make sure you stop and have a look at this impressive design from all corners. Cross the road to contemplate the view over London eye as well.

Great photo opp. It has to be one of the most iconic photos seen round the world. We passed it at 11 and 12 o'clock and the amount of people that just turn to take pictures of it is unreal. Icon of London. To see the Big Ben personally felt great since it's like an iconic figure of London. I was able to have a photo taken next to a red the telephone with the Big Ben on the background.
Big Ben visit. A true part of British history and a truly remarkable and unique part of London. The chimes are beautifully haunting and powerful.
Worth the see. It was difficult to grab a picture of Big Ben with all the people surrounding it. What would you expect, it's London. Still happy I got the opportunity to see it.
Nice to see in real life. Good to go and look at as I've seen them on tele all my life and seeing them in person was a nice experience for me

officially known as the Elizabeth Tower. officially known as the Elizabeth Tower, But worldwide it is known as Big Ben. Big Ben is the giant bell inside the tower. Great photo opportunity. Great photo opportunity, especially at night when it is lit up. Also a tourist hot spot. When visiting be sure to visit Houses of Parliament etc while here.

Well .. its BigBang - everyone knows it, and you nearly came across automatically.. I think this is one of the attractions where there is not much to say about. must see place to visit when in London. The Big Ben is a nice place to visit when you are in London.It's such a recognizable place with a very nice surrounding area to walk through.

Big Ben. We arrive in the afternoon to London, after 8hrs of traveling from NYC. Crashed for several hours. When we woke up, to go out and explore the city for the first time, I cannot explain the excitement of hearing Big Ben striking 11xs. We ran to the sound! Then when we arrived, jaw dropping in its beauty. Never gets old hearing or seeing this clock!
Wow. Stunning when you come out of Westminster tube stop. Great view. Can get overcrowded but well worth a visit.

Beautiful building. I really expected this to be a let down, and glad that I was proven wrong. The building is beautiful. It's great walking around London and looking up at this iconic building. Big Ben? That's the bell, not the tower, right?. The number of people who have seen 'Big Ben' is less than you might think for what they've usually seen is St Stephen's Tower, which houses the clock and the bell named 'Ben'!That said, a visit to the Palace of Westminster (at anytime of day) is to make a landmark part of your life - to do it at night, combining it with the Embankment and the lights of the South Bank, the London Eye and the old County Hall makes it extra special.To hear the chimes - a feature of so many moments of British history - is always reassuring and, Londoner or not, something special.If you're visiting London then you have to make this a place to be sometime during your stay. There's (Boudicca, Boudicea or Boadicea - your choice of spelling) and the Embankment and much more around this site - all crying out to be seen - don't miss out on it.It's one of the sights of London.
Don't miss it. I recommend Big ben for all people visiting London, it's really worth to have pictures with Big ben background, it's London icon

It's Big Ben!. What is there not to love about Londons historic clock tower attached to the Houses of Parliament. It's even more beautiful when it becomes illuminated at night from across the river. It's lovely chimes ring every hour.

Surprisingly small!. Although a lovely building, it is smaller than you imagine. It's right next to the Thames, which is nice on a descent day, though it was quite muggy when we came (no sun!) and couple that with the hoards of crowds, it can get quite frustrating trying to navigate around here.
Love it. Had a wonderful day in and around here.. All wonderful all good .would definitely recommend. Some great history.
A must see. Always take our friends to see as it is a key landmark in London. Great for photos from the other end of the bridge or from a boat trip on the river.

Iconic Clock.. Big ben is right in the heart if London, next to parliament and by all the main office buildings including MI5/6 and across the river from the London eye.If you are are a british citizen, you can apply to your local PM to go inside and up big Ben.Many people come to London to have there photos taken next to big Ben or if you go and doing the London eye you are able to see it from great heights.
atill the same , and i love it. i visited London when i was 6 years old, i was impressed, now i am 46 years old , and still impressed by Big Bin t

Best at night to see, UK citizens can tour for free. I've been past The Houses of parliament and the clock tower which contains the bell "Big Ben" many times and its always best to see lit up at night with the best pictures coming from a boat on the river second to being on Westminster bridge which can get crowded. UK residents can apply to their local MP and get a free tour of the houses of parliament and so save the tour price. The tour is pretty good but does mean you can't choose to visit whenever you want which would be a problem for people travelling down but excellent for people who live close to or in London like myself. We did the tour and there is lots of nice ornate rooms inside and some large halls as well as the house of commons chamber. You can also visit this for free on other days but there is usually a long queue and there is extra security processes now.

London's Standout Symbol. No matter how many times I have viewed Big Ben and the adjoining Houses of Parliament, I still get a thrill walking around and marveling at this standout symbol of a historic city.Yesterday, I walked among South Bank from The Millennium Bridge to Westminster Bridge and across the latter in glorious sunshine.
Even more beautiful in person. Big Ben is more amazing in person than pictures. That area of London is so picturesque and well kept. Big Ben is iconic.

Do the Tour with the Tour Guide. The Tour with a guide felt a little expensive - 25 lbs - but it was worth every pence! The Westminster Palace was exceptional. The special attention to the sufferage movement was greatly appreciated by this professional female.

Iconic London. I'm not sure you can claim to visit London if you haven't seen Big Ben, the bell in the Queen Elizabeth Tower. Make sure to see it from all sides as the background seems to change its impressiveness. Day and night views also. It symbolizes London.

Don't miss the Big Ben but again you cannot really miss it as you the tower from anywhere in central London.. You have to take a picture of the iconic landmark, the Big Ben.

You're in London when..... Main attraction of London town. Happened to be near when the clock struck the hour. The big clock "bonged" big time and it was very pleasant. Best viewed from across the river. Westminster tube stop. Super busy area. Sainsbury across the way for a quick treat.

The world famous clock! Dong...dong.... A world famous London landmark, that is a must see when in this amazing & exciting city. Within the Houses of Parliament and right on the River Thames, this is a great photo opportunity for all you budding photographers and tourists out there. You can't come to London and say "ah shucks, I didn't have time to see Big Ben". Make the time! (Pun intended). Dong...dong...on the hour. Count the dongs and it will tell you the time.

Big Ben. We travel to London and upon arrival caught one of the hop on hop off buses which brought us to Big Ben the bus was over crowed and took 2 hour to travel 6 miles through the London Traffic The area around Big Ben was very Busy with Tourist which was good for the area

Impressive . Impressive sight, a true British icon. Absolutely worth a wander past while in London, however be prepared very busy area!

Big Ben. We used the underground metro and arrived in Westminister station. Big Ben is literally across the street from the train station. The eye is within walking distance too!

London Icon. Big Ben, officially known as St. Steven's Tower, is a London Icon. It's part of the London skyline and without it, something would just be off. It's a huge picture stop, people taking pictures all over the place. If you're visiting London, be sure to take pictures yourself.

I have many, MANNNNY pictures of Big Ben...pictures taken during the day...at night...from the London Eye! The architecture is amazing, the history daunting, and the experience is unforgettable!

The Heart of London. . .. If you are in London in the Westminister area it is hard not to see Big Ben from many different views. It is so iconic that when viewed you feel truly English. The best picture to take is actually down the street of Great Geroge across from Parliment Square. There is a proper red phone booth there and you can get a great pic of Big Ben. Also, walking across Westminister Bridge will allow views of Big Ben and Parliment for an amazing picture. Fun Fact: the clock & bell is actually 'Big Ben' and the tower it sits in is called the Elizabeth Tower. You can also take tours of the tower.

London Icon. You'll never miss this. Once you arrive at Westminster, Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben on top will be there to amaze you. Then you can say that you have been to London. Well, to say the least.
Do not miss it. We reached the Big ben location in the mid of the day when the bell went out to declare that the time is 12 PM it was a lifetime experiment

Everything you want in a large clock. In the long run its just a big clock however its a very iconic and good looking clock!We saw it at noon so got to hear big ben chime its full amount. The area around it is manic with all the tourists but still worth a visit. We ended up walking past the houses of parliament to Lambeth bridge to cross over the river and back down to Westminster bridge. Was nice as it was a little quieter and you can get a few more shots of it without loads of other people about

Architectural Masterpiece..!!. After getting out of the Westminster Tube Station...I was asking to someone "where is the BigBen.? He told me to look upwards...after seeing upwards ....I was stunned to saw the world famous BigBen...it was in front of me...I was ashamed of me that I was standing in front of BigBen and asking about BigBen...it was a very high rise clock tower.... Amazing... marvelous... unforgettable experience of my life..

renound London Skyline. No visit to London is compete without a visit to the Parliament Building and Big Ben. You must visit when the bell is chiming, a wonderful experience. The tower is not as tall as I expected but still very impressive.
Famous icon. Probably the most well known London icon. Whether you visit the inside or not, it is definitely worth taking some pictures there. Bring a camera with a good zoom.

Big Ben looks great!. We took many photos there, it looks maybe better than what i read about it in my school books !!I would recommend not to allow cars pass through the Westminster Bridge during high tourism seasons of visitors.

As stunning as advertised! . Near Parliament, The Abbey, and the London Eye. ....Big Ben is centrally located. It's stunning. Plenty of photo ops given its proximity to everything. ...Only locals can tour the inside, but the exterior is exceptional. Must see!Take the tube to Westminster Pier.

How many of you know this?. Big Ben? well unless you are very, very lucky you will never get to see it. That is because the name Big Ben refers to the 12 ton bell used to strike the hours and NOT the tower which houses it, that was re-christened the Queen Elizabeth Tower when the monarch became the longest reigning one. When Parliament is in recess (that's on holiday to you and me folks) there are tours available of the Houses of Parliament, both Commons and Lords combined. Tickets are available from the ticket booth that is normally found on college green opposite the House itself, the guides know their stuff and I was struck by just how small the commons is, and you can see why its a tight squeeze when all the MPs are sitting. Although I have only given the attraction 3 stars that is because I am referring to the Bell, the tour of Parliament is well worth 4 or maybe even 5 stars.
Iconic. Just seeing the tower makes you shout, London baby .....even though the bell is Big Ben ! Looks great from the river or bridge .
History of British . The history and a giant history of Britain can be felt here. Best time is 12 clock, so you can listen the hour bell in whole.
Very big clock to be honest. It's a bit of a let down I have seen bigger clocks and the face isn't as impressive as it could be I soils appreciate more leds or something at night you know?

Worth viewing. It's the perfect spot to observe everything around - the Houses of Parliament, St. Paul's Cathedral, Parliament Square, London Eye, River Thames - everything is beautifully visible when you stand near the Big Ben!
amazing Experience. It was nice to see Big Ben and heard it rang at 12nn. Amazing architecture and preserved art and clean facility despite of number of people that visit the place.

Iconic London. Elizabeth Tower/Big Ben is what most people visualize when thinking of London. Don't miss seeing it in different lights: morning, afternoon, night if possible. Make sure to stay until the top of the hour to hear the magnificent Big Ben. Definitely worth a stop to see with an especially nice view from the bridge across the Thames. Of course it's in an area of Westminster with all kinds of places to see; Westminster Abbey, the London Eye, City Cruises, etc. so you will get many sightings. The Tube and Hop On Hop Off busses have stops in this area.
Impressive!!!!. Jaw dropping experience! Impressive architecture, I felt transported in time. One of the favorite places I visited!!!

Overcrowded in summer - visit London in spring or fall, or even in winter !. In 1984/85, I visited London my first time after I had finished my studies of management and engineering at a Tachnical University in Germany.I made a training for stockbroker in NY City and I visited London in 1985. I passed the broker licence exam, but I didn't work as a stock broker, because I had to 'persuade' people to burn their money in options and commodities.After passing the broker licence exam I travelled all over the USA and Great Britain. That was my first visit to London. I enjoyed to visit many places, one of the favorite places was Big Ben. I can really recommend to vit it, but you should avoid the visit in summer - too much overcrowded!Visit London in spring or fall, or even in winter! London ir really worth to visit it again and again. You won't regret it.

OK, Big Ben is quite unique, so every tourist has to go and take a photo and maybe hear the gonging; I'll give you that. You're probably going to pass it a dozen times or more during your stay in London because so many other attractions are right in the neighborhood (Eye, Parliament, #10 Downing Street, Churchill's War Room, Westminster Abbey, Buckingham Palace)Enjoy your trip!

We enjoyed the walk up the Tower and being able to be the other side!. For so many years having driven/walked past Big Ben and looked up at the Tower, it was a great feeling to be inside the tower and learning the history of the Elizabeth Tower and to touch the clock face! to walk up the stairs (334) and stand beside the bells as they chimed the hour. Looking out to lots of familiar landmarks , 360 degrees! it was a good sunny day, so that helped! There are a lot of stairs to climb inside the tower and not suitable for those with very young children. Need to pre-book the Tower tour. These tours are only open to UK residents and booked through your local mp. Refurb works due to take place so may not be open for much longer, for a little while. We visited sometime ago!

Amazing structure= awesome photgraphs. Getting to see Big Ben after living in the UK for 21 years was an iconic moment in my life! It was an absolutely fantastic view, I could have stood on Westminster Bridge all day just watching it. It's busy day and night but that just adds to the importance and beauty. The hourly dong was so loud!! You can walk to Buckingham palace and St James' Park from Big Ben in 10-15 mins and it's an enjoyable walk as you recognise all the areas that you've seen on the telly so many times! The London Eye is also a 5 minute walk (along the Westminster bridge) from Big Ben, you can see it very clearly when stood next to Big Ben. The only thing I was surprised about was its size; I was expecting it to be A LOT bigger!!!
The most beautiful part of London. This is my favourite place in London, great location for take sensational photos, just in front of it or from opposite side.

Remarkably beautiful!. Very impressive clock tower at the north end of Palace of Westminster. Don't forget to take your camera - this tourist attraction offers incredible shots! how to see big ben and have a good view and good photo shot. Going to Big Ben and seeing this iconic building is a task..... so many people crossing and the hugeness of the clock is so massive as it takes a real photographer to get the whole image. The secret is if you go down the road you will see the bicycle lane and across a small landing area- this is the area you go and have your picture taken, no photo bombers and you get the whole view and enjoy it from there. Another tip is see this clock at night but get ready to spend time since 9pm it is still bright and only around 10Pm that it starts to get dark, and then you see the view of the parliament at night - what a view to watch for- patience is a must,,,,,,,,,
