4 Best Photo Spots around Big Ben. 1. Left sidewalk of the Westminster Bridge across Big Ben As this is the best spot, it is always crowded with tourist, especially past 9 am to an hour after sunsets. Avoid back light by taking picture in the morning to early afternoon. As the sun sets behind Big Ben, taking pictures of Big Ben from this side in the afternoon (within 2 hours before sunsets) could be frustrating to non photographer which only equipped only with camera phone. (dark results)2. From London EyeYou can get full aerial view of the Big Ben and the Parliament House by taking a ride on board the London Eye Capsule (regular ticket: GBP25/person). Take the far right corner of the capsule for best view (if there're other tourists occupying this very spot, politely ask for your turn). Try to take picture during Blue Hour (30-1hr after sunsets) to get beautiful bright blue sky color in the background and that's also when you can picture Big Ben and the Parliament House with their beautiful lighting on.3. Right sidewalk of the Westminster Bridge in line with Big BenThis spot won't give you full background of the Big Ben and the Parliament House, but still give you a good iconic shot of Big Ben. This side is not as crowded as the side across Big Ben, so quite convenient during tourist rush hour (from 9 to sunsets). You can get a good picture with London Eye in the background too. There could be back light within 2 hours before sunset.4. The Parliament SquareYou can get the perfect pictures of London icons with caption like "Too Much London in One Picture". From this spot you can have Big Ben, the Parliament House, the London Eye, the iconic London black cabs and red buses all in one frame.Happy photo hunting!

The fat Ben!. Do you know it is the biggest four clock tower in the world? Not only that but did you know its name is Queen Elisabeth tower. The Big Ben refers to the biggest bell. Few weeks later the Big Ben broke so it had to be fixed. After few weeks it broke again. It was never fixed so now big Ben has a distinct sounds that is called under toned, you can year it.

"The History of Big Ben". One of the best place you must visit in London.its the same think if you visit Greece and you don't visit Parthenon,chief temple of the Greek goddess Athena on the hill of Acropolis at Athens.The History of Big BenThe Palace of Westminster was destroyed by fire in 1834. In 1844, it was decided the new buildings for the Houses of Parliament should include a tower and a clock. A massive bell was required and the first attempt (made by John Warner & Sons at Stockton-on-Tees) cracked irreparably. The metal was melted down and the bell recast in Whitechapel in 1858. Big Ben first rang across Westminster on 31 May 1859. A short time later, in September 1859, Big Ben cracked. A lighter hammer was fitted and the bell rotated to present an undamaged section to the hammer. This is the bell as we hear it today.

London Landmark. I cannot recommend this visit highly enough. It is a fantastic opportunity to walk to the top of the Elizabeth Tower and stand beside Big Ben as it chimes. The tour starts with a short warning about health and general fitness so if you do not feel fit enough to walk up approximately 330 steps or you suffer from heights then this is probably not the tour for you. That said, the walk is taken in stages and the guide was excellent at making sure everyone was ok and taking it at their own pace - this isn't vertical rush! The guide was excellent at talking you through the history of the tower, its inception, building and development through to the current day. While it was a history lesson it was accessible and interesting. Having stood outside parliament many times and watched Big Ben chime, to be able to stand behind the clock face was an incredible experience, to then stand by the bell as it chimed mid-day really was the icing on the cake. You get ear plugs and a warning that the bell is about to chime so don't worry. I would recommend that you leave yourself some time after the tour to have a look at the first floor of Portcullis House and the incredible paintings of some of our more notable MPs and PMs - something you would not otherwise be able to access if you were not on this tour. I would also recommend travelling light, you are not able to take photos or bring anything with you on the tour. There are lockers where your belongings are kept safe. Arrive a bit early if you can so that you can visit the toilets as there are none while on the tour.
Iconic London. This truly iconic landmark is up there with the best London has to offer. No trip to the capital would be complete without a visit to see this.

Icon of England. An icon of England. You get an idea of how it can be before seeing it, but once there, everything is overtaken as imagined. To spend at least a little time each day for the duration of your stay in London. Unforgettable.

An Icon of London and one of the most famous clocks in the world. Take the tour!. Big Ben is actually a nickname. It's really called the Great Bell. There are many other facts and figures you'll learn when you visit. You need to arrange this in advance through your local MP. . In my experience, my local MPs office got back to me in 2 days and organised a time to suit my party. Info you need to know: All visitors allowed onto Elizabeth Tower/Big Ben tours must be UK residents. No exceptions. Visitors must be over 11 years old. Visitors must be able to climb all 334 steps unaided without assistance. Visitors with heart-related illness or who are in the later stages of pregnancy will not be allowed. Visitors must arrive with sensible footwear, or they will be declined their position on the tour. It's a fantastic experience. Well worth organising. And much to do in the Westminster area. Iconic symbol of London.. An instantly recognizable symbol of London, you can spy Big Ben from any number of vantage points in the city, both close up or far away. But, you owe it to yourself to view it up close to get a sense of its scale and to see some of the details of the clock and tower. Plus, it’s magical if you’re standing right there when you hear it chime, either at the top of the hour or on the quarter hour. It’s a deep, resonant sound, reassuring in its nature. While many people think of the entire structure as Big Ben, the name really applies to the bell in the belfry.

Book a tour of the Elizabeth Tower - free through your MP. I applied for a free tour by writing to my MP back in Sep 2015, I got my appointment for 9 march so it does take a bit of time but is free and the only way you can climb the tower and actually see the bell. You must arrive at the scheduled time promptly. The tour takes about 90 mins total. There are about 337 step but you don't take them all at once, about 3 stops at rooms at different levels of the tower with the most steps at once being about 100 I think. You are not allowed to take photos and there are two guides (one in front, one behind) so no chance to take any photos unless you want to get in trouble! The tour guide is very knowledgeable and we stopped at one room to talk about the history, then another room where we were level with the clock faces and another where the main machinery of the clock is located and then the last level where the bells are - you get given earplugs as you arrive to hear the bells chime at top of the hour, it was for 15:00 for our tour. The views at the top are pretty amazing as you can see all around London, though it is very windy! Wonderful experience made better for the fact that our MP was on the tour and had some time before her next meeting so took us to see Westminster Hall and we got to sit in the House of Lord and House of Commons - a great afternoon.

It's a clock. It's big. It's called Ben.. Having been Grade 1 listed in the 1970s has ensured that this enduring totem pole, dedicated to the priapic ruminations of Victorian architects, has stood the test of time by being constantly maintained. It is "Gothic Revival" in design, so if it was next door to your house it would probably creep you out at night time, not just drive you mad with it's constant donging (see architects ruminations above...). Can be viewed from the car, a taxi, on a Boris bike, on foot, on your parents' shoulders and from the back of a police van (if you are one of the long-standing protesters outside on the pavement). It faces the famous 'democracy' lawn for the UK, but then Parliament passed an Act in 2012 banning the public from blocking the pretty view across the grass which resulted in long-term, anti-war protester (10 years) Brian Haw and his badge-laden Woody Allen hat being moved on. Sadly Brian died in 2011 in Germany. I do miss not seeing his tent as I pass in the morning.

An iconic landmark.. The Elizabeth Tower, aka Big Ben, is among London's most iconic landmarks – a ‘must see’ for anyone visiting London.Big Ben is the name given to the massive bell inside the clock tower, which weighs more than 13 tons (13,760 kg). The clock tower looks spectacular at night when the four clock faces are illuminated.Each dial is seven metres in diameter and the minute hands are 4.2 metres long and weigh about 100kg. The numbers are approximately 60cm long and there are 312 pieces of glass in each clock dial. A special light above the clock faces is illuminated when Parliament is in session. Big Ben’s timekeeping is strictly regulated by a stack of coins placed on the huge pendulum. Big Ben has rarely stopped; even after a bomb destroyed the Commons chamber during the Second World War, the clock tower survived and Big Ben continued to strike the hours. The chimes of Big Ben were first broadcast by the BBC on 31 December 1923, a tradition that continues to this day. The Latin words under the clock face read DOMINE SALVAM FAC REGINAM NOSTRAM VICTORIAM PRIMAM, which means ‘O Lord, keep safe our Queen Victoria the First’. In June 2012 the House of Commons announced that the clock tower was to be renamed the Elizabeth Tower in honour of Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee.The Palace of Westminster was destroyed by fire in 1834. In 1844, it was decided the new buildings for the Houses of Parliament should include a tower and a clock. A massive bell was required and the first attempt (made by John Warner & Sons at Stockton-on-Tees) cracked irreparably. The metal was melted down and the bell recast in Whitechapel in 1858. Big Ben first rang across Westminster on 31 May 1859. A short time later, in September 1859, Big Ben cracked. A lighter hammer was fitted and the bell rotated to present an undamaged section to the hammer. This is the bell as we hear it today.The origin of the name Big Ben is not known, although two different theories exist. The first is that is was named after Sir Benjamin Hall, the first Commissioner of Works, a large man who was known affectionately in the house as "Big Ben". The second theory is that it was named after a heavyweight boxing champion at that time, Benjamin Caunt. Also known as "Big Ben", this nickname was commonly bestowed in society to anything that was the heaviest in its class.The Elizabeth Tower is not open to the general public although UK residents can arrange a visit by writing to their MP, but bear in mind there are 334 steps to climb. It is not possible for overseas visitors to tour the clock tower.

Well worth the wait. You have to book through your local M.P and as such unfortunately only open to anyone who is allowed to vote in the Uk general elections.Normally have to wait 6 months before you can go.Having said that it is well worth the waitYou meet in Portcullis house and are taken by your guide through an underground tunnel to the Elizebeth tower.You walk up around 100 steps then you have a seat and the guide will go through the history of the tower and also of Big Ben.You then climb another 100 steps and get to look around the clock faces of big ben.You then go and see the clock mechanism and the guide explains about the process and how they keep the time correctly.Highlight of the tour is climbing to the tower and standing next to Big Ben and the other bells when they have the hourly chime ( you are provided with ear protectors - same things you get in airplanes ).It is loud but the views are amazing.You then climb back down again.My teenage son was thinking that it might be boring but he thoroughly enjoyed it and I did not know what to expect and was very pleasently surprised as to how interesting it was.
Must see in London. Who wouldn't like to have a photo with uncle Ben? :) Awesome historical monument full of respect and tourists, of course.

Iconic Landmark. You simply cannot visit London and miss seeing Big Ben. Many mistakenly believe the actual clock tower is Big Ben, but it is actually called Elizabeth Tower. Wonderful experience. I was lucky enough to plan this visit on the same day we were going to have a private guided tour of the houses of parliament.This is a very well thought out tour and does involve climbing lots of stars, but there are a couple of floors on the way up where you stop for them to explain the various areas.You actually get to stand behind the clock faces and your also shown the clock mechanism. Obviously ear plugs were given out by the tour guide, who did a fabulous job of telling us all the various bits of the clock towers history.I still smile when walking over Westminster Bridge, knowing I had stood behind the clock face

Great tourist attraction!!. Just be prepared to jostle for position when it comes to the selfie stick brigade. Well worth it however to see this wonderful historic sight.

Not sure what to expect with 334 steps to assend. Well we were all a bit in trepidation of this outing, as we are all over the age of 65. You have to sign a disclaimer, for health reasons, and the guide makes sure you realise what you are about to do. Firstly, we had to gather at Portcullis House where we were surched (airport style), and then lead to a waiting sight. We had to leave our handbags in a lock up as up as you are not allowed to take anything with you, not even your camera. They are very precise on timing. We where then lead through a tunnel and arrived at the Elizabeth Tower. We started to climb the steps quite quickley and after 114 of them you get a break and a sit down to catch your breath. while the guide explains the building of the tower etc. The next lot of stairs is quite something, but at a much slower pace, and stops on the way up. Eventually you get to see Big Ben. an amazing sight, and a little worrying as to how loud it is going to sound, but the guide has already given us ear plugs, and all is fine. To hear it is something realy special, so go on have a go, you'll not regret it.
Love it. Large and nice attraction . Unfortunately, it was under renovation when we were there and it was also not allowed to enter the area. Certainly worth a look
Brilliant!. After seeing Big Ben for years on TV it was brilliant to be able to see it in the flesh. The structure if phenomenal and definitely worth a trip if you are in London.
Exciting!. This is another exciting place to see / hear the Big Ben. Quite crowded area. Good to see this popular landmark in reality.

Surreal. After coming from NZ you always wonder what seeing Big Ben will be like and safe to say its worth the trip. If it's a sunny day head over the river towards the eye. There is a pub on the river bank which is a good spot for a beer and wait to hear Big Ben ringing

Amazing landscape with Big Ben towering above London; certainly worth a visit.. Big Ben is one of the most iconic sights in London. You can get a good picture of it from the bridge or from the river (if you are doing a river cruise). It is certainly worth seeing this attraction during the day and also at night. The view is stunning.I like to combine this attraction with a walk; starting off at the Oxo Tower, past the aquarium, over the bridge towards Big Ben. Then around the back of the Houses of Parliament to the left, then over the road to Westminster Abbey.It the weather is good you can pop up to Downing Street (via Whitehall) and then into the back of St. James park and have a lovely stroll through the park towards Buckingham Palace.

Londoners only - Book a free tour of through your MP!. One of the first things I discovered when I moved to London was all London residents can book a free tour of Elizabeth Tower (which houses Big Ben) by writing to their local member of parliament... After going on the waiting list I went on a tour in November and it was well worth the wait. You arrive at Portcullis house by Westminster tube station and go through security and get taken under the end of Westminster Bridge (this part was pretty cool) and get to see the cloisters around the end of the Houses of Parliament before climbing Elizabeth Tower. Our guide was really passionate and full of interesting anecdotes about the tower, the bell and its history. I won't spoil the trip but essentially you get to see behind the clock faces and the inner workings and eventually get to hear the bell being struck on the hour. You aren't allowed to take photos, which was actually quite nice as no one had their smartphones out at every corner. Make sure you wrap up warm if you're going during the winter months as it can get quite cold! Especially at the top! You have to be reasonably fit and healthy too as you have to climb hundreds of steps.

Big Ben . Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London, and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower.The tower is officially known as Elizabeth Tower, renamed to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II in 2012; previously it was known simply as the Clock Tower. The design for the tower was Pugin's last design before his final descent into madness and death, and Pugin himself wrote, at the time of Barry's last visit to him to collect the drawings: "I never worked so hard in my life for Mr Barry for tomorrow I render all the designs for finishing his bell tower & it is beautiful.Despite being one of the world's most famous tourist attractions, the interior of the tower is not open to overseas visitors, though United Kingdom residents are able to arrange tours (well in advance) through their Member of Parliament. However, the tower has no lift, so those escorted must climb the 334 limestone stairs to the top.

If you can manage the 334 step, DO IT!. Everyone knows this is Big Ben but actually that is the name of the humongous bell that is housed within the Elizabeth Tower. While millions of people each year view the outside of the Elizabeth Tower, hundreds of people each month climb the 334 stone spiral steps to the top of the tower to hear Big Ben struck the hour. You also get a chance to see a spectacular view of London and see what goes on behind the clock dials. It is fascinating that the mechanics of the clock are still adjusted using old pre-decimal coinage. The tour is FREE - but there is a catch. Tours are usually booked up around 6 months in advance and one can only make a booking through a Member of Parliament. The set times are 9 AM, 11 AM and 2 PM Monday to Friday throughout the year and I believe there is a further tour at 4 PM from May to September. It may sound a hassle to get tickets, but I promise you it is well worth it. If you don’t know the name of your MP, go on to the House of Commons’ website and use their search facility. I am unsure whether there are facilities for overseas visitors to climb the stairs and see the actual bell that is Big Ben. I should warn you that the 334 steps are not for the fainthearted or those with a medical condition. There is no lift!

Our 2 lady guides were excellent, both were knowledgeable, friendly and amusing. You do have to be relatively fit to climb the many stairs. We were fortunate enough to be inside the tower to watch the mid-day strike, so experienced the largest amount of bell strikes, which was very special too!You have to write to your local MP to be able to do this tour, but I would recommend and advise everyone that is able to, to do it - awesome!

Amazing from the inside!. It takes a bit of organising, but you can get on a FREE tour of the Tower by applying to your local MPs office. The down side is that you can't choose when you visit, you are just allocated a day and time slot. We're Londoners, so it was easy for us, but so worth doing. You climb over 300 steps to get to the bell tower, with stops along the way to catch your breath, but the view from up there has to be one of the best in London. Unfortunately no photography is allowed. Our guide was really friendly and very informative. We were there for the 10am strike which was something to see, hear and feel! One of the BEST things we've done in our own city.

great free visit. the best value visit ever.we contacted our local mp Mel Stride who set up the visit through his aid,she met us at Portcullis house adjacent to the house's of parliament,and led us on a fascinating tour of the tower,clock workings and bells.we then walked into the parliament building to see it working.A must do visit if you are going to London

Big Ben Up Close. A visit to the Elizabeth Tower ( which houses Big Ben the bell and the Great Clock of Westminster) was arranged for me via my MP. This was a fantastic visit with excellent, friendly and highly knowledgeable guides. Their personal timing meant that we were next to the clock mechanism to see the three quarter chime running then next to Big Ben as it struck the hours. A bonus was that our guide then introduced us to the splendour of Westminster Hall. Obviously high security here so no cameras allowed.

It's an International Icon. Having a few free hours on a Sunday morning, I took the 15 minute walk from Leicester Square to see Big Ben, Downing Street, Parliament and Westminster Abbey. Big Ben - home of the 'bongs'. A visit to London just wouldn't be complete without taking the time to admire the Westminster Clock Tower and listen to its iconic Big Ben, housed within.There is nothing more British than hearing the chimes of Big Ben reverberate as they ring out over the Capital. It is astonishing to think the bell, which weighs over 13 tonnes, was cast on 10th April 1858 and has been providing the background to London life ever since.In my view, hearing Big Ben makes any visit to London more memorable.

A treat for the eyes; don't forget the camera!. This is indeed the centre piece attraction for all first time visitors to London. We would recommend visiting the area during spring and summer, with plenty of options to spend a fun-filled day. The London Eye, the Thames cruises, 10 Downing Street and Westminster are all a 5 minute walk away. The multi-cultural colourfully attired crowds that throng the bridge and the banks of the Thames would interest most observers. By the end of the day, weather permitting, you should have several great photos for your FB, memorable moments sprinkled with a glimpse of grandeur and surrounding splendour. When evening sets in, the lights of London provides another fantastic oppurtunity to get stunning photos and indulge in selfies. Finally, a walk to Piccadilly Circus should whisk up an appetite to indulge in the multi-cuisine delights available there.

Big Ben - lots of steps but worth it. Most people know that you can take tours of the Parliament building but that does not include going up the Elizabeth Tower to see the actual Big Ben bell.However UK residents can apply to their MP to be included on a tour. These are quite limited and the numbers are small but it is worth trying - it took about six months for my permit to come through.There are over 300 steps so you need to sign a disclaimer to say you are fit to tackle that. There is an extremely informative guide who gives more information in the two rooms on the way. When you reach the bells it is amazing and there is an incredible view of London. We arrived just before mid-day and equipped with ear defenders were able to watch the bells in full action. Better still, it's free.No photos because you have to leave cameras and phones at the start of the tour. Very tight security.

Hallmark of London. While it's the icon of London, there's not much to do besides taking a quick picture with the clock and bell before moving on. The attached House of Parliaments is worth a visit if you're into political history. Best views of this landmark are on the other side of the river, so cross the bridge for a good photo op. To get here, the nearest metro (tube) station is Westminster on the yellow, green, and gray line. If you plan on using public transportation more than twice per day, buy an Oyster Card (not a Visitor Oyster Card) for 5 pounds, then add 6.40 pounds per day since this is the daily cap for unlimited public transit use in Zones 1-2 (these zones encompass almost all tourist sights like Big Ben, Buckingham, Kensington, London Eye, etc). The 5 pound deposit is refundable if you go to a counter at any tube station before returning home (otherwise you'll have to request a refund by mail).

I believe one can pay to go on a tour through it, however I was pressed for time and did not look into it thoroughly. The best picture is from the sidewalk heading down toward the river, which is where most get there shots. Tim led our pacey tour and was very informative. We did stop at different levels on route so we didn't do all 334 in one go. Standing inside the clock faces was really somethings as was of course the chiming of Big Ben and the 4 other bells. Still can't believe it was free. I forgot how little clothes shopping there is in the area so turning up ultra early was a bit of a waste. I head back to Victoria station at a good pace and made it in 20mins. London's most recognisable landmark. What is London's most recognisable landmark? For the majority of Londoners and visitors alike it is surely the 'Elizabeth Tower', the Clock Tower of the Palace of Westminster, which houses the great bell known as "Big Ben". The tower has only been known as the 'Elizabeth Tower' since 2012 to recognise the Diamond Jubilee (60 years reign) of Queen Elizabeth II but many people still refer to the actual tower as "Big Ben". We had arranged a guided tour of the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament) but the tour did not include visiting the interior of the 'Elizabeth Tower'. Nevertheless, it was really exciting to be standing so close to this most famous of landmarks. Our tour guide also gave some interesting information about the tower during the visit of the Houses of Parliament. What surprises many people is that the tower was only completed in the mid-19th Century following a major rebuild of the Palace of Westminster. It was built according to the plans of the architect Charles Barry and a neo-Gothic design by Augustus W. N. Pugin. In some respects, the views and opportunities for photographs are better when standing a little further away from the Palace of Westminster. The suggested locations to take photographs are either from Parliament Square, along Whitehall from Trafalgar Square, the Embankment or from Westminster Bridge.Views of the tower from any of these nearby locations are excellent. Listen to the chimes of "Big Ben" and you know you could only be in London!

A beautiful building. . Walking from the London Eye across the bridge to the foot of the Big Ben is an experience I have had a few times. Weather does make a difference and this time it was pleasant and not too crowded. I am struck (no pun intended) each time I set my eyes on the wonderfully constructed building - so old, so intricate, so striking, so stately, so wise. The building seems to speak to me from the past and I truly love how it stands out without being arrogant or imposing. I couldn't help the sad thought that it was built from colonial wealth and from the suffering of so many who toiled under its oppressive hierarchy.

Other than Seeing THE Icon, There’s Nothing Much to Do Here. It’s easy to get to Big Ben – take the train/tube to Westminister station, and when you reach the station, follow the signs. On exiting the station, one immediately comes as if face-to-face with it, and goes “Wow!”. Lots of tourists crowd just outside the station to take a selfie with Big Ben, so there could be a bit of jostling for the best views. But that about all that you can do – unfortunately, you can’t go into the tower to visit it or learn about the mechanism of the clock. However, when you reach Westminister station there are numerous other attractions, so do roam around a bit. But be wary of the shills their ply their trade along the bridge next to the station (they try to entice you to play their find-the-ball-among the cups game, but remember that the people who are “winning” money are their own mates).

Something different. We arranged, via our MP, a visit to the Elizabeth Tower (we had also previously visited The Houses of Parliament). It was important to take the required ID etc. to be allowed on the tour. We were given a brief intro before starting our walk up the winding steps to the tower. The steps are in a winding spiral staircase but very manageable unless ill or infirm. Our guide (Christine I think) was very good and we had a welcome stop on the way up which included a sit down and a talk on some aspects of the history of the Tower. The talk was interesting and it was then up to the clock. It is quite strange to be on the inside of the clock faces. We then saw the clock mechanism before our final ascent to the bell tower. We were there at noon so had the full 12 bells (ear plugs were provided)! Although a mild day, it was quite windy so I would recommend keeping a jacket on for when you are slightly open to the elements. I do not like heights but there were no areas where I felt too uncomfortable, as there are no really exposed places, so don't let any fears put you off of having this experience. The tour lasts about 75 minutes and afterwards there were opportunities to use the loos and have a look at some of the art in Portcullis House

Coming back down one level, you can see how it all works - exactly the same from when it was built, using Victorian coins!

An Icon. When in London it has to be seen, it's a sure sign your are indeed in the english capital, it still amazes me even after seeing in many times over the years.
Unique Visit. I would thoroughly reccomend contacting your MP to arrange a free tour of the clock tower. It's a very exciting and unique opportunity to see such an incredible landmark!

Big Ben Is One of London's Icons!. Big Ben has always been one of the identifiable icons that says London! While some clock towers in Europe are more ornate, it is a must see and is easy to view and located in Westminster.

Brilliant Tour. This is a must do experience. Climbing the tour with an enthusiastic and well informed guide we experienced the 3 o clock 'boings', saw the incredible clock workings and had the chance to explore Westminster Hall at the end of the tour. Thoroughly recommended although you do need a reasonable level of fitness and a head for heights!
An Icon. What can I say, London wouldn't be London without this iconic clock tower and if you only look at it from the outside then its worth every penny of which you don't have to spend anyway.

One of London's icons. This is a beautiful building and great to see in both the daytime so you can see the amazing architecture and also lit up at night. Definitely one of London's most iconic buildings.
Lovely view!. Excluding the crappy weather on the date of my visit, overall a nice attraction and well worth to visit if in London!
Awesome Place. The place is really awesome, very nice building and view. London Eye and parliament square are very close to it.
Iconic. It's impossible to go to London and not walking through the Westminster area were the Big Ben is located. I really recommend this.

You can't visit London without seeing Big Ben. As a tourist, Big Ben is a must-see. It's not something that takes a great deal of time to see, but do take the time to see it from different sides and be sure to take plenty of pictures.There are also other attractions around it, so see more, it you have the time.Enjoy the statues in the park as you enjoy looking at Big Ben, even if that's all you do.
More impressive during the day. Went both day and night.Lights are so so at night. So definitely go during the day! The architecture is much more wow which daylight.
my favourite place. Memories from this place which I remember fo ever!!!You should go with underground Westminster it is very easy
Nice attraction!. Lovely place to see but if you ask me, I wouldn't want to live anywhere close to Big Ben as the bells would start driving me crazy after a while!

You must see it!. Big impressive building in the heart of London. View from Thames river and Westminster abbey. Big Ben sounds very nice. One hour for take a photos, many shops near and toilet for 50 cents.

Impressive clock. The building and clock are definitely worth checking out.
For me it was just nice seeing it in real life rather than on the movie screens and it really is an impressive structure.
Make sure you hang around for the bell chime as it is one of those things you have to hear that gives you a sense of nostalgia.
Really beautiful.. Went with my cousins to see this at night very impressive. The lights around Big Ben really do it justice.

You cant go to London and NOT see this guy. Such a majestic building to look at. Fun to see during the day or at night when its all lit up. I recommend watching the sunset behind it from the opposite bank and watching all the lights turn on :) So pretty!
An Iconic Site. This iconic site in London comes alive at various times of the day. The gold trimming standing out against the dark December sky's. Great views as you walk across Westminster Bridge.

Magnificent view!. Love the place! Will recommend to anybody visiting London - it's not only signature point of greater Lindon but also interesting place to see and learn about. Also wonderful walk by the river Thames with this magnificent view - great for photos which will stay with you forever!
Amazing Place. Never get tired of walking around Parliament Square and taking pics of Big Ben. Probably one of the most photographed places in London

Iconic symbol. Visiting Big Ben is a must for me every time I come to London - it is magnificent during the day and during the night! And to me it is an iconic symbol of London - I remember it since the first English textbook at school.
Photo worthy . Nice clock tower along with the parliament. Photo worthy but not sure what's more. Across the London Eye and good for a photo.

big ben is a site unmatched. the house of parliaments big ben tower is a architects wonder. perfect design and beauty.
standing there is a feeling unmatched... simply bliss
my best and most favourite london memory
No way. It is inconceivable not to visit big ben synonymous with london and hear the iconic toll, hurry cause renovation on the way, so you will not miss it...

amazing but rained. this placed is amazing...justsad that it was raining but really worth a visit but day and night. The big red bus was great for hopping on and off nearby and and easy walk from the stop.

Worth the climb. Finally we got around to booking a Trip to see the top of Big Ben or the newly named Elizabeth Tower and we were not disappointed, the trip lasted approximately 75 minutes. the female guide was excellent, she was pleasant and told us exactly what would happen on the trip. As we climbed the stairs she was explaining everything about the tower and its history, approximately half way up we stopped for a well earned rest and sat whilst she spoke about Big Ben and its history, we were also given ear plugs for the 3pm chimes. We stopped again at the clocks and we could walk around and see the hands moving around the outside, Once at the top she gave us ample warning of when to plug our ears. Right on time Big Ben went into action. The views from the top although it was a cold day were stunning.Well worth a trip to the top, very educational and the female guide made it all the more interesting. We booked in advance for vetting, take two forms of id one being a photo id.Well worth the climb up and down!
Big one. Big Ben was bygger than I expected. Impressive and a must if going to London.Was there a bit late, and no guided tour was available. Anyway, just cool to be there for real :)
Beautiful at night. Great place to be at night. The view is amazing and the atmosphere of people hurrying around is good.

Roger Miller's Vision. Because it is iconic, you won't want to miss it. Because of its presence and location you won't. Great photo ops from Parliament Square, and Westminster Bridge. We also got good shots from our Thames cruise
Must see. Beautiful to see at night. We stayed at the Hilton Westminster so it was a close walk. They eye is close, and several other landmarks, tube stops, etc. beautiful open, clean location.

Most iconic. This is the simbol of London, the real name is Elizabeth Tower and just the clock is Big Ben. You can see asWell very close the houses of parliament and Westminster Abbey. Station: westminster
Empire style. Seeing the incredible tower, with the clock ringing at every 15 minutes you can fill the Great Britain.

This IS London . I think to most people around the world , when they think of London , they think of Big Ben or St Stephens tower or Elizabeth tower ...Big Ben is the actual bell in the tower itself , its iconic and great to see people visiting it and looking in awe , i live a few streets away and on still nights you can hear the bell being rung , the area around Big Ben is creepy of a night , i can imagine a ghost popping out from somewhere ! Lol ! When you are visiting London , make this the first place you visit ! Also the area is quite pricey as are all shops near tourist sites worldwide so buy drinks and snacks from supermarkets , ive seen a tin of coke sell for 1,60 which is extortionate , and exploits people not used to the currency or price of things (even 1,60 by London standards in a rip-off)
The Aifel Tower of London. Big Ben is the symbol of UK. When you think of the English Capital, the first thought the Big Ben and the second Fish and Chips! You must do both to taste London!:)
wasn't as tall as i thought. it was a little bit of a disappointment, I thought it would have been taller, nice setting but its nothing special, worth a visit if your in the area.
WOW. Ding Dong, this attraction it totally amazballs, been here many years and I have been to see it many many times ... it's well worth including it in your day out

Awe Inspiring!. Visited Big Ben with my family today, which we were very much looking forward to. However, the experience was so much more than we could have imagined. Catherine, our guide, was superb in informing us of the history, how it was built, how the bells were winched up by hand, and how the clock has evolved over its 150 year history. It was quite an emotional experience standing right by the bells struck the hour. We felt very proud! We then visited Westminster Hall to soak up even more of the history of this country.

Iconic landmark. This is the symbol of London and I suggest you try to see it from all angles. Stand beside it, take a photo from the bridge and go on the London Eye just to name a few options but see this amazing structure from all possible angles!

Iconic. How do you even rate this? I mean its one of the most iconic buildings in the entire world. It was amazing to see for the first time, we've all seen it 100 times in movies and on TV but its just not the same as in person. Right up there with seeing the Eiffel Tower for me, just wonderful. How does somebody rate this a 1? I mean how jaded do you have to be?

Beautiful. This Big Ben tower is one of the most important place i want to visit when travel to London & it's really beautiful. Walk around to take photos or just take a good seat & see the daily life. It's a very amazing experience!

Icon in London !. Big Ben is so famous that every visitors should go and see it once! It's so large and stunning! It's linking with the parliament and u can't even take off your eyes when they are light up!!Highly recommend !!!!
Big Ben. Such an amazing place. This place is always crowded. Big Ben is a nice place and has all the major attractions nearby also easily accessible.
Cute. wonderful building. i miss to visit the building at night. Walk to there and enjoy walking tour in London.

Go for a picture. There is nothing special about the Big Ben and there is not much to do around.
But for the sake of doing it, and having a little memory- go there and take a little picture of yours.
Enjoy!

Must see!! . It's Big Ben and a must see while in London for the first time. It's a short walk from the London Eye so either walk by before or after. We walked by after out eyeskate and London Eye ride. It's a beauty in person.

Spectacular view at night. Spectacular view at night, lit up to show the magnificent structure in all its glory. Seen during the day, it is an historic and mark, and can be heard (when not being repaired) for miles.
huge and beautiful. it's ana amazing building and it's more huge than I thought. very recommended. a lot of beautiful architectural details can be see only from closer look.

Great tour. Requested a tour of the Elizabeth Tower through our MP. Guide was very knowledgeable. The tower has a lot of steps but the climb is broken up by stops and interesting talks. The highlight was being next to big Ben when it struck 12 (ear plugs a must!). If you live in the UK ask your MP for the tour its well worth it.
London's Icon. A must see monument, very nice spot to take pictures along the Thames, just across the London Eye. Would visit again on our next trip.

iconic. Big Ben tower (even though Big Ben is actually just the Bell) is probably Londons most famous symbol and as such the area around it is very very busy with tourists. Easy to get some good photos of it.
one of my favourite monuments in London. I've only seen it from the outside but it's absolutly impressive and beautiful. The surroudings are also very nice, which makes the experience feel magical.

Iconic. Big Ben just as iconic now as it was as when I was a child, first thing you see along with the London Eye when you roll in to London Charing Cross on a train - looks every better close up.. Love London!

Purely Sightseeing. Big Ben is such a London icon that you have to make time to see it. Westminster Tube station comes out right at Big Ben, so it's really easy to get to and then Westminster Abbey, the Houses of Parliament, The Thames, The London Eye are all within easy walking distance.

Grab a coffee and relax. Grab a coffee (there's Cafe Nero nearby) and take a 15 minute break in Parliament Square, the open green in front of the Houses of Parliament. This is the perfect place to enjoy the sight of Big Ben close up and a nice place to relax.
Love London! . Busiest street in London, watch your pockets!! Beautiful views, breathtaking, well worth a visit . Would love to go back

Definitely a sight worth seeing!. Make sure that you come here to take a look even if it is just for a few minutes to take a look. There is a tube station that drops you off right between Big Ben and Westminster Abbey so you can easily check out both of the great sites with little time used.

Great for a picture. If your near the houses of Parliament or the London eye its hard to miss Big Ben.
Its great for a photo and adds to the atmosphere of London when your in this specific part.
5*****. great view of big ben over the bridge, great a night with all the lights, nice for groups of tourists, very much an enjoyable day

Big Ben. Overated big clock, not sure its really needed as people seem to wear wristwatches these days. Plus looking up at the clock may cause you to have an accident as you cross the busy London Roads. A really silly idea...imagine the size of the battery too thats neede to power it. Another consideration could be "Is it waterproof?" to deal with the English weather. Piffle I say!

A. Icon of London. A must photo place. A few good angles to take photos with the Big Ben. The perfect places will be quite a distance away in order to have the whole tower in the picture. The best time to take picture will be in the evening where the lights are on and the sky is still visible.
It's OK. It's a big clock that you can see from miles away. Always nice to see a landmark up close but doesn't get any more interesting as you get nearer

A must see when you are in London. The Big Ben is of course world famous. And to see it in real is of course great. But the good thing is, its in the heart of London, next to many other must see attractions. In the evening is even better to visit.

Worth a visit. A fantastic sight and well worth a visit.
Sunday morning it was quiet but the real hustle and bustle was Thursday evening when you really felt the atmosphere.

near Big Ben Christmas eve. several years ago I was near Big Ben on Christmas Eve and what an experience that was . Im sure that the tower was visibly shaking when the BIG Bell began to toll. A VERY low note indeed . It started at midnight and went on for at least an half hour. If you happen to be in London at that time don't miss this one !!
New twist on a classic. Big ben always looks good but the amount and quality of lighting used to enhance the entire area is incredible. It's beautiful at night because of this.

Beautiful . Looking along the river Thame it holds great photography potential. The sunset behind the attraction was beautiful. London is known for this great attraction and makes people stop straight away for a photogenic photograph. Truly great too see and something you would want to see whilst in London.
Iconic for London. Take a tube to Westminster station and take escalator up - you will find you just next to Big Ben.Take your time to enjoy this marvelous piece of art and take few pictures :)
A must see!. Gorgeous building! We just had lunch in the park across from it and enjoyed it's lovely view! Be careful of the scammers and the pick-pocketers outside!

Iconic. What more can you say than Iconic? Dominating the skyline and ready to chime straight through your body - Big Ben is one of the classic landmarks of London, and UK. Granted, it's quite packed with tourists, but well worth seeing in person. *Be sure to watch your bags / pockets in the area - like with any tourist area - the pickpockets are about.
Beautiful!. Beautiful and breathtaking structure! went there with my son and baby, conveniently located across a tube station. an icon to London city :)

Clock tower not worth a visit if you are in a rush. The clock tower or Big Ben is iconic but was not much up close. There's not much you can do as the place is pretty much gated so a picture of it is really all it's worth.
Love this historic site.. Love to visit, but there was a big protest on climate change. Always more enjoyable when these types of things aren't going on.
A must to see if visiting London!. Love hearing the clock strike.... Again, one for the Historian!... Costs though if a tour and guide is what you are seeking...
Very impressive.. Best way too see Big Ben is via river cruise....you can get some great photos as the boat pulls up. Big Ben is one of the stop offs if you want to get off or on.

Great monument. A truely iconic structure, this is one of the most famous places where one can take a selfie or a picture for a postcard.
Theres a reason why this place is so popular for the crowd. Inspite of all the crowd, one can often find peace on the banks of thames with a spectacular view like this.

nice visit and a must see. This is of course aa must be seen in london
by sunny day the place is really busy and packed of tourists,
I've love walking around there,
Very nice and authentic

Amazing and astonishing. If you haven't seen Big Ben, better you go and try to be there at night where the lights are magnificent. The town is huge more than you imagine from the pics. You can enjoy many attractions around.

Tourists . Big Ben is full of tourists from every where in the world, there's different kind of coffee shops,Theaters,museums around, It is so amazing to see so many different options of Cultural diversity!

It's tower with a giant clock. The big ben is not very different in real life than in photographs. The view around it is very scenic and the entire area is a huge tourist attraction. One of the must see places in london but nothing overwhelming.
Spectacular. Great iconic building, it just screams "London". Extremely busy area, but fantastic views. While we were there Big Ben struck 11.00, great to hear the "bongs".
London trip. Much taller than we expected, worth a look for the architecture. Not much to do if going to Big Ben alone, would combine with Houses of Parliament and Westminster

A must see for any Visitor of London-Stunning. It is something that everyone must see in London, and is very close to restaurants and other tourist attractions. You only really need 30 minutes to see it but every second is worth it!

smaller than I thought . A building to see when in London, right by the river on the the side your walking along and wow there it is, the most famous clock in the world . it's so well constructed as part of a magnificent building although smaller than I thought, a must to see in London

Big Ben is London. Wow, many years of seeing Big Ben on TV, as well as the Houses of Parliament & then all of a sudden I'm on the top of a tour bus taking my very own pictures of them both. [The houses of Parliament and the north clock tower which "Big Ben", the bell, is in.] The view is really neat from the top of a bus. I understand that you can actually purchase a tour to go inside the clock tower and see the actual bell that is "Big Ben", but I'm opted to get me history through reading, as I only had 4 days in London & many things to see & do. I.E. you can't see the same London from the top of a tour bus as you can see from a pod on the London Eye, so I'm going to get off the bus to do this. Don't let this distract you from the excitement of being in London and seeing The House of Parliament and Big Ben
Excellent clock. I cant imagine anyone being disappointed by Big Ben - it is exactly what you expect. A massive iconic clock.
London Icon. Despite seeing numerous photos my teens were still thrilled to see BB in "real life". Glad we beat the scaffolding going up to give Big Ben a spruce up.

Visit the most powerful seat for democracy. What an outstanding building. Explore the workings of parliament and watch as MP and Lords mingle and go about their daily business.Amazing how close you can get to the Lords and the Commons and worth having lunch on the terrace pavilion if there is a function on.Great day out!!
Part of the sightseeing tour . Must see if your out sightseeing a major uk landmark, great to get a few photos of, very busy area but worth the crowds! Can also see from the sightseeing bus
Excellent. Good selection of shops, a bit small but has everything you need. Really nice M&S and interior plaza.
Big Ben pictures. It is always crowded at most time of the day but if you manage to get there early on Sunday morning, before 9am, then it is quieter. Before 8am on Sunday's is even better.

Beautiful from close by! Must see!. The Big Ben is a magnificent building, wonderful architecture and a must see while in London. There is a metro line that stops right below so it is perfect if you don't want to walk or the weather isn't that good. While there you can also visit the London Eye.
The obvious pride of London. Beautiful and Gigantic Working Clock Tower, time-keeper of England. Also nice views can be captured whilst walking towards the building over a bridge nearby.

Lovely view of history . This place just looks amazing in real life .. When Big Ben does the bell .. It's a an experience you have to see
Well worth to see in real life

BIG BEN!. This is London, London it is and the 'heartbeat' of London.
The only snag! Too crowded for my liking but to be expected because this is one of the place to be.

Iconic. What else can you take a picture of and have everyone know where you are in London? I think the best spots for snaps are 1) In the London Eye 2) on the Westminster bridge (to the east, facing west) and 3) at the north end of Westminster Abbey. There will be a lot of people around you taking snaps as well!

Visited Famous Icon "Big Ban" London August 2015. I along with my dear wife and host visited this unique icon adjacent to Houses of Parliament. Big Ben is famous and its name is enough to understand that it is in London and adjacent to Houses of Parliament. In this area you can spend as much time as you can easily. I will recommend the visitors of London must find some time to visit this famous Big Ben.
Iconic Ah Ben. What does London get associated with the most? I believe it is Big Ben, and it is really an imposing sight to look at.Picture perfect !

The most beautiful place in London. I've been here for three times with different Friends. This place has something magical and romantic.You can spend hours and hours on the near bridge and remain to contemplate such Beauty. I reccomend it to everybody

An icon, truly one-of-a-kind. The houses of Parliament are beautiful to behold, even on a rainy day, and Big Ben is truly an imposing sight. Interesting factoid, Big Ben is actually the bell in the tower, the tower itself is called "Elizabeth Tower" since HRH's jubilee. No surprise to those in the know, but apparently I am not part of that group. An iconic symbol of London, nay Britain itself, and a perfect spot for a selfie or self reflection.

Ohhhh Ben!!!!. As always Ben will be your most loyal companion throughout London! He stands there as a truly English gentleman shinning at its best, reminding you know every hour that you are just an intruder in his territory!!!
Wonderful to look at to see the time :-). Passed this on our way to the London eye which we decided against due to it being foggy and instead opted for the sea life centre :D
Nice in the dark. Great all day but beautiful by night. Really recommend to pass by during evening/night time, then you get the right feeling.
Sunday Morning at Westminster. Just took selfies like all the other tourists. Walked across Westminster Bridge and went to the London eye

Brilliant! . I cannot recommend this tour enough. What a privelege to stand behind the clock faces and right beside the old boy himself as he tolls. And all for free plus getting your MP to actually do something for you. Great stuff!

True London icon!. If you think of London or see images of London, you see Big Ben. It's definitely the true London icon.
It's a majestic structure rising above the Houses of Parliament, easily visible from many parts of the city.
A must visit for anyone visiting London for the first time.
Amazing to see in person. We visited Big Ben during the day and at night. It was so pretty up in the London Eye. Must see if you are in London.
Kids loved it . We went in November and took my nephews they loved it! They loved how close you can get to Big Ben and all the culture surrounding
Big Ben. Big Ben is just near the Westminister Station..its a very old tower with a clock built in typical english style.

An iconic landmark!. Just like the other reviewers, we stopped and took a number of photos of Big Ben! There are so many locations along the street where you can get good photos. You don't need to stop traffic to do so.Whether it is in the daylight or nightlight, a selfie with Big Ben is a good one to have. Our family especially liked the night photos. Great lighting!
Great Place to see in London. Big Ben is good place to see and it is near to London Eye, Abbey. Great view of this place from London Eye in evening.
Big ben. rite on the river..all houses of parliament. morning too much crowded. nice to visit in night time..

London without seeing Big Ben not a chance. We stayed just over the bridge from Big Ben and for my two daughters it's an iconic part of tourist London,you can grab pictures from all around Westminster but this is sometimes made difficult by the people on the bridge trying to con members of public out of money with the find a ball game,don't get pulled in people they are very clever with slight of hand... But you will encounter them whilst visiting this impressive clock,more impressive when it strikes and chimes.
Great site!. Looks and sounds great, not good for young children, we just admired from outside, good picture opportunities day and night.

Great experience. Well have always seen in pictures and a dream come true to see this lovely standing tall Ben. Made sure I had a view during day and night and it was an amazing experience. The entire area is amazing to walk around and yeah expect the place to be crowded all the time.
great. great city great place to visiti. London is very nice and it worth it to visit big ben during your stay there.
Mandatory Selfie. You can't go to London and not see Big Ben. It was truly amazing and I enjoyed my time there! Yes I took a selfie.

Stunning building day and night. This is a must visit. Walk over the bridge from the Southbank and the view is fantastic. As you get close to the building you will notice the beautiful detail of the building, and wait to hear the sound of Big Ben. If you get a chance, see Big Ben at night, all illuminated, this is another stunning picture. If you are lucky, and the sky is clear and the moon is in the right position, you can see Big Ben with the moon behind it, awesome!

When in London, you have to visit this place. It's a cliche and very much just a landmark, but it is something you will definitely visit. It is at Westminster, with a tube station right there. The walk across the Thames is beautiful and the tower is majestic.

THIS SPOT IS A MUST ON YOUR TRIP TO LONDON. This attraction was really very cool to see. It was a very majestic structure, and it was thrilling when the bells chimed and could be heard for miles. This tower is extremely impressive, and that is coming from a native New Yorker.
Wonderful building. Just to look up to Big Ben from the exit of Westminster Station is a must! Another example of wonderful old London architecture.
Beautiful building!!. Amazing building, iconic staple of the Houses of Parliament, looks beautiful in the day and at night, and of course free if you just want to see it from the outside!

A great photo opportunity. We didnt go in but we got some lovely photos outside. The Palace of Westminster is enormous. It is heavily guarded at the entrance for the Politicians and Government officials. The architecture alone is beautiful. There are huge crowds around there taking photos etc.,
Loved Big Ben!. Was one of the highlights of our trip to London, so glad we finally got to see it! Although a little cloudy and rainy that day, was glad we got to see it finally.

Big and beautiful . A lovely looking building. There as soon as you step out of the underground station. Got some lovely views of it on the london eye. Actually heard Ben chime too like I said beautiful. Shame it houses a load of idiots.
the great Ben.... always a great view, and always buzzing with tourists. the clock looks astonishing. I heard that it will soon be covered with scaffolind for maintenance.
The Big Ben indeed! . A must see in london too.. Cross Westminster bridge and view the parliament from different perspective

Beautiful building with stunning details !. Your London visit won't be completed if you don't visit the the Big Ben. The tower building is beautiful and the sound of the bell is highly distinguished and well known worldwide. It's located alongside Westminster Abbey, very visible when crossing the bridge or from London Eye side. I you are a couple, it's highly recommended to enjoy the scenery of Big Ben while taking a night river Thames cruise.
Amazing sight. This is such a fantastic sight, you can't really believe that you are seeing the real Big Ben Awesone

A must do!!. Before heading home called in to see Big Ben, especially as he moon was so bright in the sky. Plus I do think that Big Ben does look nicer at night.My daughter wanted to see Big Ben as it is an iconic part of London. She stood looking up and was surprised when it chimed for quarter to six. I then had to explain why it does that. It doesn't take long but you can then go on to Westminster bridge and get a great view of London and parliament. We'll be going back as the aquarium and London Eye are calling us so we'll stop and check the time.
You Can't Miss It. If you're in London--you walk to see Big Ben--it is as simple as that. One of the most beautiful, intricate and elegant sights in the entire world.
It is what it says on the tin. It's a pretty attraction, and worth a look. If your by there you can get to Buckingham palace just down the road. We didn't see any parking around there though.
Big Ben!. What can one say when in London Big Ben is a must see. My wife has never been the London before, so she enjoyed all the landmarks

Must-Do. Big Ben is definitely worth the visit, as one of the most recognizable icons of London. Many people will recommend seeing it at night, which is lovely, but I would suggest doing it in the day if you want to really see the architecture of Big Ben and the Parliament Building. It's gorgeous when you can see the reflection from the buildings into the river. Given that it's right next to the London Eye, it's very convenient if you want to see both of those things.
Must see. Definitely must see in London! Nice building right next to the houses of parliament! Right next to the Westminster Abbey

Everytime we go to London the first thing to see is... . The Big Ben of course. :)This time was rainy and vold but always wonderful.As my husband say only when we are near the BB we feel we are in London.

Not one to miss. Big ben and the surroundings are the heart of london, You cannot go to london without seeing big ben, its just one of those things you have to do! Its right near lots of food places and london eye etc, also a tube station directly opposit, so its worth the trip with the other stuff around it too!

Very interesting.. Nice cafe with hot and cold food, beer and wine. Very interesting with lots of history.In the afternoons if the houses are meeting you can get a ticket to go in the spectators area and watch.

Big ben. The big ben in Londons central district was a breathtaking view, with light chiming through the hundrendth foot of century old tower clock. We strolled on river thames before we could hear the ding dong bells of the big ben. It was a lovely experience.
Worth a visit. If you're going to London you've got to go and give Big Ben a visit, lovely tourist attraction very pretty when it's lit up at night
Look kids Big Ben. Have to see this at least once. It is attached to Parliament so it's hard to miss. Take a night bus ride and see it lit up at night.
Amazing building. I love looking at Big Ben when ever I go past it, it looks amazing when the lights are on it during the night. It's a must see when in the area.

Visit the clock face if you can. I was lucky enough to come on a tour here which came to the clock tower. We were given ear plugs and when big ben started to chime we could both see it using our very eyes and feel it - it vibrates like crazy. It's very cool to be able to come and walk around the four clock faces and very rewarding, but it's a hike to the top!
Great Attraction. House of Parliament and Big Ben is a great attraction for anyone visit London .Don't miss going there .

identification of UK Parliament House. Big Ben is one of major land mark of London and well known worldwide as identification of London/ England. At new year evening new year started with big ben bell. worth to visit.
Such grand beauty. Timeless and beautiful. Love hearing the bell chime. Even after living in London for 3 and a half years its still one of my favorite places to see!
Very beautiful. We currently visiting london, and if you have time go see big ben at night. It is great for pictures.

It's the clock heard round the world.. Always thought Big Ben was the whole thing, tower and all. But no. A masterpiece of time!. Big Ben is visible from many parts of London and in particular from along the River Thames. We travelled by the tube from Paddington to Westminster Underground Station, on a Saturday morning with the primary intention of visiting Westminster Abbey.Before we headed for the Abbey, we fought our way through the massive crowds in the area, on to the Westminster Bridge. It was from this location that we thought that you could get some of the best angles for taking photographs of Big Ben. The real difficulty was actually in finding a clear spot on the bridge from whence you could take your photos. Any idea of having your companion appear in the photo, in the foreground, with Big Ben as a back-drop were soon forgotten. It was just impossible with the huge number of people on the bridge. We were astounded by the lengths that some people were willing to go to, to have their photos taken with Big Ben, in the background. Some risked their lives by standing and posing in the roadway section of the bridge whilst cars, buses and trucks sped past them.We simply made do with taking photos of this iconic landmark without anyone appearing in the photograph.

I exited the Underground and There it Was. We took the Underground from Heathrow to Westminster. When we emerged from the Underground, I turned around and there was Elizabeth Tower, ready to chime. Impressive!

Ding, Dong Bell. Big Ben is a clock. You cannot miss Big Ben. It is mammoth. It is historic. It is impressive. There is nothing small about this clock.It was built as part of the Houses of Parliament. When you see one, you see the other. The clock is just as ornate, beautifully designed, and crafted.The sounds are just as huge -- ding, dong, ding, dong. Actually, it is more "dong" than "ding" because the decibels are low. You can hear them from afar. The bell strikes on the hour. If I am not mistaken, it strikes once every quarter hour too.Tourists flock to see this clock. Be ready for crowds. It is, however, a happy place because everyone is so very excited. Images of Big Ben on television, movies, and postcards come to life.When the British conquered other countries in the old days for the British Empire, they built replicas of Big Ben. I have seen copies of enormous clocks like Big Ben in parts of Asia that the British colonized. These clocks also dominate the cities with their sizes and sounds.

Worth a look. Yes, it is a lust a clock in a tower but to the British it is iconic - it's chimes introduce the news on the BBC and it is probably one of the best known landmarks in London. The most incredible monument I've ever seen. Big Ben is obviously one of the most well known monuments across the world. I've seen it in pictures my whole life, and honestly I didn't expect much from it. After all, it is just a big clock, and America has plenty of clocks. However, when I saw it, I was awestruck. I don't know why I fell in love with it, but the architecture is beautiful, and it's incredible to see both in the day and the night, although I prefer admiring at night in its majestic lighting. I even cried a bit when it was time to leave London, which is definitely ridiculous and not all of you will do the same obviously. Maybe I love it because I can imagine Peter Pan flying above it or it's so huge and chimes every 15 minutes and London knows how to light up a monument, but whatever it is, it's clearly a must see and, for me at least, it deserves all the attention it gets and is not overrated.

Tour inside the Elizabeth Tower. I contacted my MP (UK citizens only) and requested a visit to Big Ben and the Elizabeth Tower. Visits must be booked about 6 months in advance and you have to complete a security form online to be checked ahead of your visit. 2 types of ID are needed on the day, 1 photographic (passport/drivind licence) 1 paper (household bill/bank statement). I asked for 4 places on a tour. We were met in Portcullis House by 2 ladies from the visitor service, security checked and taken to the Elizabwth Tower. There are 334 steps but you stop twice on the way up and are seated for 2 very informative talks about the history of this iconic building. We stood inside the clock face and even watched Big Ben strike 3pm ( with ear plugs in ). This was a unique and very special experience. It was well worth the wait for our visit. Our guide Monika Rubens is both informative and entertaining, a real asset to the visitor service. After we descended the tower Monika very kindly took us into Westminster Palace, gave us a talk about its history and told us how to access the Houses of Commons and Lords. So my friends and I popped into both houses as they were in session. A brilliant day out.

No access, no welcome.. It is disappointing that even exterior access to this iconic building is restricted and no effort is made to interpret or introduce the site to visitors. A dirty tunnel leads from Westminster tube station to some steps and dark iron railings through which glimpses of the tower can be had as well as a row of chained up bicycles at its base. Climb the dirty steps for a view the tower from the pavement, not a very good view or a convenient vantage point. The clock tower is purely for show, it is heritage orientated and draws lots if tourists, but there is nothing here when you arrive, it is all locked up, not even a guide book. It is more famous and iconic than interesting anyway, unless you like Victorian spiky buildings. It typifies the Gothic revival fashion of the mid 19C. Howver George Gilbert Scott's St. Pancras hotel, built in the 1870s, is much better, more restrained and less confusing to the eye. The clock tower was claimed by Charles Barry who designed the new houses of Parliament but was in fact designed by his 'assistant' Pugin (who also designed Alton Abbey, among many others, sadly now a badly maintained ruin in a theme park in Staffordshire).It is not to my taste but if you like the overwrought quasi-ecclesiastical Gothick revival style then this is the very place to come. Just don't ask for a guide book.

An Icon for a Reason. The Elizabeth Tower (aka Big Ben, though this actually refers to the bell) is a punctuation mark for the beauty and stateliness of the Houses of Parliament complex. A masterpiece of ornate yet subtle decoration and gilding, it faces the Thames and backs up to Parliament Square and Westminster Abbey. With binoculars you might be able to read the script on the bottom of the clock face "DOMINE SALVAM FAC REGINAM NOSTRAM VICTORIAM PRIMAM (Lord keep safe our queen Victoria I)." Make sure to HEAR the Westminster Chimes at the hour and listen to the hours marked out by the bell whose unique sound was created by a crack soon after it was first sounded in 1859. The views the Elizabeth Tower from across the Thames or from above (in the London Eye) are inspiring, but a view down Whitehall from Trafalgar Square and the steps of the National Gallery is an unanticipated pleasure. Don't overlook the statue of Boadicea (Boudica) and her daughters across the street at the north end of Westminster Bridge. Queen of the Iceni and ancient British tribe, Boudica resisted the Romans and paid the price, but is commemorated on the plinth as their superior with the words of Wm Cowper, "Regions Caesar never knew thy posterity shall sway."

magnificent view,......fabulous architecture,...incredible sound of Big Ben. strolling along the Embankment....nearing the unmistakeable tower of Big ben is a delight....this iconic clock tower never fails to take my breath away..no matter how many times i've seen it,...I was once fortuneate enough to be invited bymy local MP for a tour of parliament....MAGNIFICENT EXPERIENCE!!!just incredible to see inside this wonder of a building....the commons..the house of lords..if you ever visit, be sure to rub the foot of the statue of Sir Winston Churchil...for good luck...theres a beautiful chapel.....that left me speechless as i certainly wasn't expecting to see a chapel there,...atmoshere? well i just can't put that into words, you'll have to visit to see for yourself,..enjoy a brilliant experience here!!!

Big Ben magnificent. Great place big Ben historical piece of history it was very busy here and palaiment square is very busy well worth the visit to see the world famous clock
Amazing!. Wow! What an amazing structure! So glad I got to see it! The detail on Big Ben is amazing. No trip to London would be complete without seeing Big Ben at least once!

Memorable!. Big Ben is a symbol of London, and it is indeed majestic! We visited Big Ben during the day and we decided that it should be worth visiting again, but during the night, to see how it glows. I must advise you, it is worth visiting at any time, but at night it's magical! From a distance it even looks like a full moon. If you're in London for a short period of time my advice is go see the Big Ben at night, there are no tourists running around taking pictures or selfies, there is just you Big Ben and the amazing Thames River, the feeling you get is uncomparable!
Tour. This was one of the 25 tour stop on The Big Bus Tour-great fun!The guide was very knowledgeable and funny.

Excellent all around!. We got the London Pass and proceeded to the entry only to find we had to "double back" quite far to get the tickets. that should be mentioned in the Pass book! I had watched a show on Public TV prior for background which helped to understand the differences vs our system of government. We really enjoyed the tour! surprised no one (besides ourselves) tipped the guides..that seems to be "going away" but she did deserve some token of appreciation as she was so good.

thanks I miss you. shime of big ben. The London icon that you know before you even see it!. Big Ben (actually the name of the bell inside, not the clock or tower!) - is really impressive at any time of day, but especially at night when the clock is illuminated. bigben. as it is the biggest pandelum watch of the world situated at parliament street in london the surrounding of it was also cool

It's must. It's an iconic monument of English culture, if you are in London you must go. Like Eiffel Tower in Paris or Liberty statue in NY.

Tour of the Elizabeth Tower - Big Ben. Fantasic tour inside the tour finishing with seeing the big fella getting a few whacks at 3pm, great knowledge by guide and amazing to see the workings, there are over 300 narrow stairs so the tour isnt for everyone but if you get the chance to go the moment you realise you are behnd the clock face will stay with you forever - no photography allowed though, would have loved to have taken a pic behind the faces and the 'workings' and of course of the main attraction Big Ben.

How can you possibly "rate" Big Ben?. This is a nonsense, phoney rating, along with "ratings" for other great and famous London attractions. Honestly, just go and enjoy yourselves, take the inevitable pictures and forget about rating stuff (apart from perhaps Madame Tussauds, which is the biggest rip-off in town). Anybody in agreement with me?

Great London attraction. We went for a day out in London to celebrate our son Graduating from University. We had a varied age range from 3 - 56. So had to entertain all ages...a must on any London trip is Big Ben. The grand children were fascinated to know that it's the bell and not the clock that is actually called Big Ben.
Beautiful Architecture. a must place to visit for the travelers coming for the 1st time in London a great place with lots of history , crown jewels amazing simply amazing

Must see. Big Ben is one of the most prominent symbols of the United Kingdom.You have to stop here to take at least one picture. It was so great to experience this in real life.

Landmark everyone should have a chance to visit. Excellent landmark and a must see. Location near majesty other great sights like westminster abbey. Love the place at day and night. Will be crowded though. Not sure whether you can go inside, don't think so.

It's the London I dreamed of as a child!. Every time I see Big Ben I get that feeling. That shiver down the back of your neck. As a kid I thought London was this massive exotic place and Big Ben was the symbol. Having lived in London many years now and being somewhere in my 30s, Big Ben is still incredible. Few thoughts:1) It's always busy 2) The view you get as you come out of Westminister Tube is the best one.3) If you cross the bridge (away from Big Ben) and turn right and down the steps, there are a few benches there which give you a great few of the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. A London Landmark. Big Ben is so stately, stands near Parliament and across from Westminster Abby. This must see landmark is near the Parliament and Westminster Abby. Also the London Eye is nearby.

London cannot be separated from Big ben. Big ben is the landmark for London. Whenever, you visit London you have to visit this place as you will get great pictures, and it is world known. Be ready to walk a lot and have good shoes.
Iconic Landmark. Only saw this from the outside but it is one of the beautiful buildings of all time. I wish you could go inside !

And the London Eye which is just across the river. Big Ben is a must see while in London and it's next to other famous attractions so plan a day for this area of London!
Wow. Absolutely gorgeous close up and from A far. Absolutely iconic. You can't miss seeing it from anywhere in London, but seeing it close up.

Big Ben. I have been to London many times, but have never seen big ben before (only on the TV) I was surprised I thought it would have been bigger..

Best of Big Ben. I applied to my MP for a fee tour of the tower to see Big Ben. I had to wait a couple of months, but it was well worth the wait. My husband and I had a small group guided tour that included standing behind the clock faces, a close inspection of the mechanism and standing by the bells when they chimed 5 o'clock. If you are a UK resident, email your local MP to request a tour, complete the security information and you could be on your way to the top.
A Favourite of Tourists and Londoners alike. One of my favourite sites in all of London! Everyone loves the classic picture, make sure to take it when there isn't scaffolding up!
