Got to be seen. Again it's just one of those sights that has to be seen. There is just something about being there and seeing Big Ben for yourself.
Must go while in London. One of main attraction while in London and easy to access. Unfortunately, heavy rain when we was there.

Big Ben is the bell, not the clock. You definitely know you're in London when you're looking at Big Ben. It's quite an iconic landmark, and brilliant to look at from all perspectives, day or night, in rain, or in sunshine.
A familiar landmark. It was exciting to finally see Big Ben is person. It is an icon of London and must be seen in person.
Awesome. It was worth seeing. History in London is everywhere. Time keeps on ticking into the future, make sure you see Big Ben when visiting London.
Stunning. Always takes my breath away very proud to be English and a tourist for the day in my own country. A beautiful building. We should all be so proud of our heritage.

Tourist attraction . Very nice attraction .. great to take family who are here on holiday. My family was amazed. I think they should offer something near by however to provide customers with more of an experience

No brainer - you HAVE to see Big Ben!. It's a given - you can't visit London and NOT see Big Ben! Seeing Big Ben, and the Houses of Parliament, and the Westminster Bridge in person was better than I expected. The area is historic, and beautiful in any kind of weather. My suggestion is to take your time, view everything from many different sides and angles, take lots of photos - drink it all in! The colors and details you can see in person made it special. I went during the day, and I also saw the area at night on a night bus tour. It's beautiful all lit up. Don't miss this!

Brilliant history. I saw Westminster from down the river. It is a beautiful gothic masterpiece. When she sings her liberty lark you can feel the weight of history of this tremendous building. The tour is also excellent and very informative.
Hey it's free. What can I say. It's free. And for free, it's worth seeing. There isn't much around here but you can go for a walk and see other buildings.
uk trip. wow, wonderful landmark in London. lucky to see diffetent view during during.day & night. incredible sight seeing trip in UK.

ICON! Go on a blue sky day if possible. I love Big Ben: 'Look kids, Big Ben, Parliment..' said by Chevy Chase in European Vacation... been to Big Ben myself twice, what an icon. I am from the US and love DC, NY, and San Fran and I put Big Ben right up there with Empire State Building, the Twin Towers (while we had them), and the Golden Gate Bridge. I am a city lover and Big Ben is the icon of London even over St. Pauls, Buckingham Palace or the newly London Eye, or even over Tower Bridge. To stand in the outskirts and take pics of Mr. Ben is amazing, pic a grey or blue sky, it really doesn't matter, you will be in awe just the same. Ben...you're the man!!! xoxoxo
Beautiful. The beautiful clock tower of London, of which I have seen only pictures since childhood- it's beautiful. But I realized that the Big Ben is leaning a little, it's not straight.

It's big clock. What did you expect. You gotta go once. It's a big clock. The architecture is great. Wait for it to ring if you are close enough to the time it rings. You should try and view it from across the river to get the best view.

Awe inspiring visit. What a fabulous interesting icon.So lucky to be allowed to visit( you have to apply via you m.p.)Must be fit as it's a real long climb.The guides are excellent,helpful and knowledgable.Wow what a view from the top,unbelievable to stad behind the clock faces!

Interesting and attractive icon.. I visited this monument as part of a day tour in London. Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower. The tower holds the second largest four-faced chiming clock in the world (Minneapolis City Hall having the largest)
Beautiful. Saw the Big Ben pretty up and close (from the Westminster bridge). It was beautiful! Definitely worth passing by.

Wowww. A rare example of ingenious design from the base of the structure to the clock face its self the attention to detail is unreal. Along with the sheer size and scale of Big Ben it also adds a sense of culture and heritage to london(if not to the whole of britain) and is a perfect example of what brittish architects can come up with.

A Journey Through Time. We had a few days in London this August and decided to book a tour round the Houses of Parliament. It is well worth the visit as it actually brings to life all that you see on the tv. The guide was excellent and the time just flew by. It was fantastic to see in real life all the history that you have only heard about. You travel from the 9th century up to the present day and see all the different architecture from over the centuries.
Must See!. London has a lot to offer, but this is something you need to walk by while you are out and about. The architecture is beautiful!
Wow. Great and impressive close by! A must see in person the details are amazing and it sounds wonderful too

Family Vacation. There's no trip to London without seeing Big Ben up close. It is breathtaking up close. Be sure you get lots of selfies with Big Ben. From here stroll down to the Thames for a river cruise. What fun!

Big Ben is the Clock Bell. This spot was starting point for my tour. The guide was very clear that the name Big Ben refers to the bell, the tower is called the Elizabeth Tower. Either way, its a London icon, especially to hear the bells ring as you walk down the street. Definitely a must see while in London.

My first "I'm in London" Moment!. This is the moment it really hit me: wow, we are in London! This is a landmark you begin hearing about as a child, so it's a can't miss sight to see! We learned from a tour guide that when they built the Jubilee line on the tube they unsettled the foundation, so Big Ben leans about a quarter inch more each year - you can easily see that it isn't perfectly vertical. Interesting info! Make sure to be around when it chimes.

"Grand" doesn't even come close. A definite must see.. Big Ben is probably one of the most iconic landmarks of the London skyline. It has to be on a bucket list. Seeing it up close is far too cool to put into words. The architecture of this magestic monument is something to behold. It was definitely a highlight from our recent 4 day trip to London. For a unique experience, take the tube to Westminster station and exit the station at Westminster bridge. You come out at the foot of Big Ben and it really puts the incredible stature of this beautiful bell tower into perspective.
One of the most visited attractions in the city. We never tire of the charm of Big Ben chiming in London. We always walk by the clock when visiting London.

Wow. I see Big Ben on tv every day when I put the news on, but nothing comes close to seeing the real thing! Seeing it in the distance is amazing let alone being right next to it. Big Ben is a huge part of London, it's a must see for all visitors to this beautiful city.

An Icon of London one cannot miss. Located just at the centre of London, the Big Ben is visible while walking around. You should not miss taking a photo here after visiting the Westminster Abbey and the London Eye.

A must see just because it iconizes London . Nothing special about it when you come to think of it logically. . But since its one of the most important icons of london you have to see it.. There are good surrounding areas to walk and you can see the surrounding with many more attractions while walking. .

Dream of My Daughter.......!. Big Ben is a dream to see once in a life time of every children i could say from around the world....and being there was so amazing experience of the life....We really enjoyed being there and spend a good time around...

A must see if you are a tourist. Come for the hourly chimes late morning.. Obviously all tourists must come and take a photo of this icon. If you do then come just before the hourly strike to hear the chimes and also come late morning as you get more chimes! The problem with coming here is that Parliament Square is so busy with loads of traffic so I would suggest heading to the River embankment to take your photos or to the nearby bridge.There is nothng to see in Parliament Square itself but loads of things around it. You can visit the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Hall at certain times of year. There are so many tourist sttractions nearby that I could not list them all but would definitely walk through St James's Park or walk along the South Bank of the river towards the City - the walk to Tower Bridge is probably only an hour but is one of the most beautiful in London and there are loads of sights to see on the way..
Awesome!. Loved it! It's bigger and better in person then in photos. Can't go to London and not see it! Plus it doesn't cost a thing (other then getting there) . Very cool!

Very iconic. As we alighted from the boat ride (down the Thames that we took from London Tower), we walked up the stairs near London Bridge and quickly realised it was the Big Ben when we got to Street level. The intersection is very busy with tourists clamering to take photos. It is a very iconic monument and the clustered govt buildings around it looked just like the post card. I guess one would have to walk by this place without which a visit to London would be incomplete.

Mesmerizing Area. Beautiful tower with huge clock, looks very impressive and the sound of Big Ben is awesome. Combination of Big Ben, Parliament house other buildings make the area very beautiful & eye catching.

For the sake of visiting London. Well they said you're not in London if you did not visit the Big Ben. The title pretty much sum up my reason to came here. If you take the exit from Westminster underground station, you will see Big Ben right in front of you. I did not realized it at first but there i go, passing trough so many tourist and looking for a perfect angle to take a shot of this structure and i suggest you to take a picture in the bridge because you could take a single Panoramic shoot of London Eye and Big Ben in the same time.

London Skyline classic. Great to meet the most famous clock in the world which is has now been renamed to honor QEII as the longest reigning monarch. Must wait to hear the chimes which sends goosebumps all over.

Must See!. You haven't seen London if you haven't seen the Big Ben. I recommend walking towards Victoria Tower and Victoria Park too, away from the biggest crowds of people and stare in amazement at all the beautiful architecture.
A stunning icon.. Well worth the time to walk completely around the block to see this icon from all sides. Ensure to ask the gate Bobby for a photograph - they are very accommodating.
Beautiful iconic structure. Beautiful iconic structure. Great to hear Big Ben toll every 15 minutes. Lots of construction in the area made it a bit difficult, but worth the visit!

You know you're in London when.... You exit the Underground at Westminster and you see Big Ben towering over you. We didn't go in this iconic landmark but it is a thrilling sight nonetheless. For that "I'm here! I'm really here!" thrill, make Westminster your first stop. Be forewarned: as you exit the station, there will be throngs of tourists snapping photos. Join them. :-)Don't miss Westminster Abbey while you are there. Walk across the bridge for breathtaking views of the Thames.

Most Recognizable Sight In London!. When I am in London, Big Ben is always a sight line for me! Our hotel was very close to it & lots of other sights are in the area! I think this Winchester area of London is ideal area for home base.
Grand!. What a landmark, towering over the city. You have to stop for at least one picture, and then you hear it chime. Was a wonderful site to see and hear.

STANDS OUT. The first day at London, i took the wrong turn and visited Talfigar Square looking for the Big Ben, next day after a wrong turn, and there I saw it (Big Ben) it stood out and was a sight to see, at a distance not to close though. Was a sight to see
Solo trip. Stayed at d Tune Hotel at Westminster- the Big Ben was like my alarm clock in a good way- when the bell rings- its nostalgic- I know I'm in London!!!

bigben. Really enjoyed this it's more reall when you are sTanding under it so much to see great day out have Fun

Big Ben. It is one of the most popular landmark to visit when you come to London. Also there is near London Eye and Buckingham Palace. It is easy to go there by tube.

Beautiful . Big Ben is the nickname of the bell inside the clock tower, now known as the Elizabeth Tower.

Must see. You may not miss this one when you're in London. There are several places from which you have beautiful view on it. Hope you have nice weather when you're there. That makes it more beautiful.

Wonderful day visiting big ben. Beautiful stunning British architecture at its best.it really has to be seen in person to believe it's beauty.

Something you must see. If your in London, Big Ben is something you have to see. It is pretty much an iconic piece of British History that should NOT be missed. Groovy. From Oxford University's British Slang 101 course. Words to describe this:Blimey!Brilliant!Blinding!Hunky Dory!Ace!Cheers!Up for it!

Must see . The must see attraction in London. Its just simply majestic. It brings me a feeling of a Great Britain always. A majestic Big Ben as we studied from books.

Iconic. A sound that is familar to so many of us from around the world! I very much enjoyed the story of the building of the clock and it's bell etc. Take the tour if you can. If not, enjoy it as you spend time in that area of the city. The sound of it chiming is something to hear first hand!

Iconic...must see.. It was just like I've always imagined. Big and clock-y. Lots of great places to take pictures. There are classic red phone booths between Westminster Abbey and Big Ben to get some fun shots. It's also gorgeous from across the Thames river.

Classic London. This is a landmark for all time. It's classic gothic architecture and a sight to behold. It is part of the London Skyline and a major tourist attraction. A walk along the Thames and the view of Big Ben and Parliament are essential sites one must see and enjoy its' magnificence and glory.

Love seeing it. Such an iconic piece of British history. Always fantastic to look at, have seen it on the city tour bus aswell as by foot via embankment under ground station. Built by the victorians, big Ben is actually the bell inside the tower
Got to be done. It's always interesting to see a landmark you have seen on TV hundreds of times. The whole complex with Whitehall, parliament and Big Ben is impressive and worth seeing.

big clock - and bell. well if it's big clocks you're after, you can't say fairer than this fella. Ben is a cracker. but don't worry about getting bored of looking at the time high in the air... there's more! there's also the bell. if you are a fan of bells I recommend going to visit Ben just before 12... and my are you in for a treat!

See and Hear Big Ben at Night. After running around all day, trying to take in as much of London as we could, we took a ride on the London Eye. Afterward, we had dinner then headed over the bridge to the other side of the Thames. It was very dark by then, and Big Ben was illuminated. I noticed it was almost ten o'clock, and I asked my husband to wait a couple of minutes. The clock chimed loudly, and I was elated. Hearing Big Ben was my favorite event from visiting London. Don't miss it!
Must see. This is a must see when you visit London what a spectacular sight it isn't what you expect to see it's so much better up close

A truly outstanding landmark. I've always seen the pictures of Big Be, but standing in front of it was inspiring. and the chime was nostalgic. The building itself has great architecture and history. Big Ben. Beautiful Architecture.

impressive. It was exciting for me to see the real Big Ben while I always see it in the movies, TV and so on. It is an impressive building!!

Must See Day and Night!. Bug Ben is the iconic London landmark. It was beautiful during the day but the crowds were very heavy. We came back at night and Big Ben was lit up and more accessible.

Tour of Big Ben. The tour inside Big ben is fantastic. You climb 334 steps, and on the way to the top, you learn its history and how it works. During the tour you see the mechanism of the clock and see what happens at the quarter hours and on the hour. The highlight is definitely being in the belfry when the hour strikes. To be next to all 4 smaller bells chiming in order, and BIg Ben itself strike the hour is something else. Definitely a bucket list experience. Thanks to the guides they were wonderful. They brought the experience to life! Just to remind people it is only available to UK citizens, and has to be arranged through either your MP or a member of the House of Lords.
Family trip to London. Stood on the bridge as the clock struck twelve. Perfect timing and what a sight. Thought it would be bigger though

September 2015. You cannot miss this iconic site in London - it's huge!! Big Ben, of course is the name of the bell that strikes the hours. A 'must do' for first time London visitors. The best FREE activity in London, and arguably the most famous clock tower in the world.'Big Ben' is actually the name of the largest bell in the tower and not the name of the tower itself (which is called the Elizabeth Tower).You have heard of Westminster Chimes? Well, THIS is where they come from...listen to the full display each quarter hour with the hour 'gonged' out by Big Ben himself on the hour.

a must see. The clock tower is nice during the day, but amazing at night from the top of a double-decker bus. Close to many major amenities and sights, and near public transportation.

Big Ben at Noon. The Elizabeth Tower, commonly known as Big Ben (which is actually the bell inside) is a must see when visiting London. Beautiful architecture! . The infamous Big Ben! Beautiful architecture and has so much history! A London Essential - just see it and tick it off your list. .Ok. You've come to London, you have a list of things to tick off. This is at the top of the list . . .But . . .But you can't climb up it.But you can't visit any part of it.But you can't do anything except see it and tick it off.So don't bother going too near - just look at it from, for example, a Hungerford footbridge, or South Bank near the London Eye.That's it. Been there, seen that, ticked off..

Loved it. What's not to love about this stunning part of our history. In a very cool part of the city and just stands out as a reminder of how great London is. We seen a few M.Ps knocking around as well.
Day Tour in London. Is a must place to visit when you are in London. Including the other places of interest around the Big Ben. You feel lost in admiring the beauty of Big Ben
Nice historic area. As a local I would advise all to visit the city. A landmark known by all. The area has lots of shops to visit

Amazing, moving, informative tour. Must do!. Booked onto a tour by writing to my local MP. Bit of a hassle to get a date as clearly it is very popular and the tower climb can only be done in small groups.Airport style security, absolutely no cameras, phones etc which was a bit sad not to have a photo of the day. Would even have paid for an official photo - there's an money-making suggestion for them!The tour guide stopped us at various points on the climb and told us stories and facts about the tower that were fascinating. At the top we got to hear the 5pm chimes (ear plugs provided!) and it was honestly amazing. One of the most memorable moments for a long long time, and quite moving to boot - felt myself welling up. Highly recommend!

Very interesting. Most of these reviews seem to be from people who have simply looked at Big Ben from the outside, but it is perhaps a little known fact that you can go up it. For UK residents this is free of charge if you arrange it in advance through your MP. I think there is also a paid for option at times.This is well worth doing, you not only get to see it but there is a guided tour as well which gives you lots of interesting snippets of info – like the time that someone working in the belfry was so shocked by the bell striking that he swore loudly – as the chimes were being broadcast live on Radio 4! I think now they only broadcast them live at times when there will be no-one working. For our visit we were supplied with ear plugs. You get to go right up in to the belfry and walk around right inside the clock faces. Definitely worth doing.
Even bigger than I expected.. We only walked past and took photos, but Big Ben is much bigger than I expected and was very impressive!

Unmissable Big Ben. London's Big Ben really is unmissable. The architecture is amazing, we walked all around the area & enjoyed seeing the tower from lots of different angles. We went at about 1pm on a warm summer day & the streets around the tower were very, very crowded with foot traffic.

Has to be seen when in London. Friday 14 November was a beautiful day for walking around taking in the sights and the Houses of Parliament (Palace of Westminster) and the clock tower was glorious in the sunlight. Be careful trying to get the photo as its easy to step out onto the road to try get the whole picture!

Look kids..... It is a very crowded area so be prepared for some pushing or nudging. Also, if you are planning to get the perfect shot with or without your loved ones, expect to have a few strangers in the shot. It is an iconic landmark worth a glimpse and of course, then you get to say the line "look kids, there's Big Ben and Parliament"
its history. well if you havent seen big ben you havent seen london. best to walk across the river to get good views

Great to Listen to it Again!. One of the highlights in London that cannot be missed!Big Ben, the voice of London, has been telling the time to the second since 1859.It is an iconic building and actually it is not the clock but the Great Big Tower.I always enjoy hearing the sound of it every time I am back to London.

Tour up to Big Ben . Had the privilege of going on the tour up the Elizabeth Tower to see Big Ben . What a really great experience the guides were very friendly and told you every thing you wanted to know about the tower and bell . To see behind the faces of the clock and then to see the hammer strike Big Ben is a sight that will stay with me forever . Unfortunately because of security no photos are allowed on the tour
Visiting Some London Attractions in July. Great iconic London attraction to visit. I visited it on a sunny day in July. Photographing it was awesome from the river Thames.

The time to see it all. I would have loved to go up but you can't. It's a wonderful sight, though. Make sure you hear it's renown chimes. An Amazing Sight!. Stayed in a hotel right near Big Ben. Listening to the chimes was awesome. We were told by a guide that Big Ben is actually sinking! It is actually starting to tip just slightly. This magnificent clock tower is something everyone should see. Westminster Abbey, Parliament...this is the best of London. We walked around here for hours.
London must. Always a must to see. England icon.See it fon the London Eye and then take the bus over the bridge.If you ride on the top level you get an amazing view few see.

Big Ben is a Bell not a Clock!. The story behind the bell is fascinating! It was made by the same company that made the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia. It is cracked just like that one too! The maker of the bell suggested a ringer for it and the installer of the bell into the tower chose a much bigger ringer, and that resulted in the bell getting cracked!
Nice to see it in person-. Ben Big is not the clock as everyone thinks-its the bell inside the tower. Impressive building nevertheless.

Worth the three month waiting list.. If your a British Passport holder then this is a must, if your not I'm sorry to say you are unable to do this tour. Don't just be one of those tourists that stands outside on the bridge and takes photos, get yourself onto the Parliament website find and get in touch with your local MP to book a trip inside Elizabeth tower and walk up the stairs to the bells and be there when they chime on the hour.You will stop a few times on the way up and you will even be stood behind the four clock faces. It's then up and outside to see all of the bells and watch as Big Ben strikes.I would have loved to add some photos to show you but unfortunately you are not allowed to take them.
Yes... I got Chills. This is spectacular. So massive in person. Must see. Views from all around the city and it never gets old.
Amazing attraction. Kids loved taking lots of selfies here. Lots of buzz around that area with it being near to many other attractions.

A true iconic landmark. Worth seeing, but then again it's hard to miss. Learned that Big Ben was named after its designer. Turns out Ben was his middle name. Apparently his first name was Richard.

Still keeping time !. Seeing Big Ben "in person" and hearing the chimes was something I had looked forward to for years. It is amazing in construction. The Bells of Big Ben. We have a friend in London who showed us around, he told us Big Ben is actually NOT the clock but the bells...so interesting & had never heard that before. Of course, we still called the clock Big Ben.

one. Number one in the Europe!!! Big clock for all England!!!

BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG BONG. Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben are the most iconic aspects of the Palace of Westminster, although Westminster Hall and Jewel Tower have a much longer history.Big Ben refers to the Great Bell, of course, not the tower or the clock but most tourists call the whole tower Big Ben.You should try to be nearby when the Great Bell chimes 12 o'clock but this area is so noisy now that the best place to hear this is from a boat on the River Thames.The bell was cast at Whitechapel Bell Foundry east of the City of London on Whitechapel Road and that place hosts tours on Saturdays led by its owner, but advance booking is essential.From memory I believe that the original bell was cast in northern England but cracked so badly that it never took its place here. Even its recast replacement cracked because the original chiming hammer was too large, so it had to be repaired although the damage is still visible. This explains why the sound of its 'bongs' is slightly off-key.For the benefit of 14 September reviewer/s Andamy of Los Angeles, it isn't just a clock and the chimes are not just chimes, because this most recognisable London icon is officially the most popular landmark in the United Kingdom. It has also been named as the most iconic film location in London - it is very often seen in establishing shots.I see this many times during the year and will review again once I have taken a tour (when you have to ascend 334 steps to the belfry). Only UK nationals may take the tour, by contacting their Member of Parliament or a Member of the House of Lords. Be prepared to wait several months, though.

You can teach an old dog new knowledge.. Learned that Big Ben is not the name of the tower or the clock but it is the name of the bell that rings in the tower. Everyone has assumed that it is the clock so I learned something new.

What's in a name?. At the base of each dial is an inscription in Latin that means "O Lord, keep safe our Queen Victoria the First". Victoria was, until recently, the longest reigning monarch of the UK. Our present Queen has just taken the record from her. One of the Towers of The Palace of Westminster is named after Victoria, The clock tower is now named after Queen Elizabeth (since her Jubilee). These names seem appropriate. But, I guess is that the clock tower will continued to be known as Big Ben. The clock is renowned for its accuracy. The specification is that at the first stroke of the hour, it should mark the change of the hour within an accuracy of one second. The dial is unique in that the Roman Numeral for ten, X, is greatly distorted and embellished. The designer didn't like the letter X. Look closely at the dial and you'll easily see the unusual gothic type letter for ten. If anything can be called 'iconic', it is Big Ben. Visitors cannot get into the tower, except British citizens who are able to arrange, through their local Member of Parliament (MP) for groups of constituents to take the climb inside. If you plan to get close to the palace (Houses of Parliament) to see Big Ben, consider taking a walk over the Bridge and down the right hand side walking along the embankment a little (in front of the hospital). I think this is the best view of the palace and a fine view of the river. It's hard to credit that at one point in its history, the river was so polluted that the MPs complained about its sink when debating.

It’s the bell, not the tower. Many overseas visitors, and probably most UK residents, often refer to the Elizabeth Tower as Big Ben when in fact it’s actually the nickname of the Great Bell housed within the tower. Its distinctive sound is the result of a repair to a crack in the bell back in the mid 19th century. No matter where in the world you may be, the sound of Big Ben is easily recognisable. The general public are not permitted in the tower, but it makes an excellent photo opportunity. As an iconic symbol of not just London but the whole of Britain, it is therefore a 'must-see'.

It's "Time" to Make a Visit. Twice now I have participated in the tour. This has to be arranged by contacting your MP, but the tour itself is free. I love London and its history. I like to see how things work behind the scenes and this did just that for me. Three hundred and forty odd spiral stairs isn't for the faint hearted, don't look down, but when you're up and in it's amazing. Out in the belfry - the view is amazing of London, plus the of course centre of attention itself, Big Ben. We were up there for 11:00 when it struck. We were given ear plugs and advised to push them in. You're a bit sceptical I suppose and think 'it can't be that bad surely'... Put them in. Bell strikes, the whole tower shakes and the shockwave in the air from Big Ben is quite amazing, emotionally moving in a sense if you're into that kind of thing. Once done and dusted, the descent, again, don't look down. Amazing. It's a rare opportunity and a privilege to have as demand is so high. If you get the chance you won't be disappointed.

A London Icon. Always lovely to see when visiting London. I have some information for those wanting a tour of Big Ben.Tours are generally fully booked 6 months in advance. Demand is high so early booking and flexibility regarding dates and times is strongly recommended.Tours are at set times of 9.00am, 11.00am and 2.00pm Monday-Friday (except Bank Holidays).There is also a tour at 4.00pm from May to September.UK residents should contact their local MP or a Member of the House of Lords whom they know to arrange a tour. There is no charge for guided tours booked in this way.It is not possible for overseas visitors to tour the clock tower.Children under 11 are not permitted on Elizabeth Tower tours. Groups of 14 students must be accompanied by two adults.

Great tour . You can get a free tour if you request this with your local MP. A great way to spend an hour. After going through airport style security and being signed in, we were led by our friendly and informative tour guide up the first 100 odd stairs through the Big Ben tower. We then stepped off into a side room where our guide gave us a few facts, and was more than happy to answer any questions. Then came the second lot of stairs. We were then stood right behind the Big Ben clock face, and were allowed to touch the glass. It's amazing to see and be told how this works, and on our further flight of stairs we went into the control room and saw all the cogs moving. A further few flights of steps took us right to the bell tower, with amazing views and watching the bell toll 10:00am was such an experience. I would recommend it to anyone! Our tour guide was fantastic also and really enthusiastic.

Don't set your watch by it, and not actually called Big Ben!. Another of the "must-see" attractions in London, although there isn't much to do other than look at it and take pictures of it. What people usually think of as Big Ben is actually not officially called "Big Ben" -- a nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Westminster Palace, although it's often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower. Officially, what people usually refer to as "Big Ben" is actually called the Elizabeth Tower.Just an interesting tidbit -- you should not use "Big Ben" to set your watch... A couple of days after we visited, the BBC pointed out that the chimes (heard every 15 minutes) had lately actually been as much as 6 seconds slow. After the report, mechanics corrected the clock to be within 2 seconds of the correct time (considered "normal parameters"), and will continue to do so when needed, by placing pennies on the pendulum or removing them to fine-tune its speed.

The bongs are quite sensational. Quite literally 'big', the formidable giant clock is unavoidable both visually and aurally to anyone standing in Parliament Square and facing south. The exquisite thrill of hearing a succession of 'bongs' on the hour is well worth the wait, and in the interim one can buy essential items such as House of Commons branded biscuits and Canesten anti-fungal cream from nearby shops. Statues of Gandhi, Mandela and Churchill lend a certain weight to the lawn opposite the clock, though beware the relentless traffic that encircles this historic grassy nirvana!

Up the Tower. As a British Citizen I am lucky enough to be able to go up Elizabeth Tower and see the Majestic Big Ben Bell in person, all thanks to local MP who we wrote to. Very Cool. There is no bad picture of Big Ben. Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London,The tower is officially known as the Elizabeth Tower, renamed as such to celebrate theDiamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II (prior to being renamed in 2012 it was known simply as "Clock Tower").The tower holds the second largest four-faced chiming clock in the world.The tower was completed in 1858 and had its 150th anniversary on 31 May 2009.The tower has become one of the most prominent symbols of the United Kingdom and is often in the establishing shot of films set in London.
incredible structure.. Excellent structure and one of best and well known tourist spot for clicking pics. the sound of the Big Ben resonates every hour it strikes.

Amazing Experience- Don't Skip This You will be Sorry. I can't say enough good things about the tower and the parliament of London. First off, the view is breathtaking. Big Ben is a big boy!! I was absolutely amazed at how stunning this looked over the water. I just wanted to sit and stare at it for days. To be honest, I never anticipated that I would be this fascinated with a clock and the Parliament. I thought the Eiffel Tower was going to do that. Nope, it was this, and it was absolutely mesmerizing.. The tour inside the Parliament was nice. The statues were gorgeous. I found this more interesting than the Eiffel Tower. Additionally, there is so much history in that building. Everything looked grand. The men with machine guns guarding the building were intimidating, but it did not take away from anything. The gift shop was high, which was expected. I will l warn visitors that Big Ben is not available to non-citizens of the U.K. I asked and was told this. Also, Big Ben is the bell, not the clock.
Contact your MP for a tour. Tourists will be stuck outside Westminster tube taking photos, but British residents can actually request a tour from their MP. Just contact them and ask for an invite.

ding dong. it is possible to climb up the tower to see Big Ben which is the bell not the tower. need to book on the Parliament website. Good to follow up with a visit to Whitechapel bell foundry where the bell was made

Try to time your visit to be there at 12 noon. In order to visit Big Ben it is necessary to apply well in advance through your local Member of Parliament. You will need to bring your passport along on the day. A long climb up the steps inside the clock tower will bring you to the room at the top where you can see the mechanism and listen to explanations of the history and workings of the clock. Big Ben itself is the large bell that chimes the hour and when the top of the hour approaches you will be invited to stand next to the bell with your fingers poised to stick in your ears as primitive volume control. The quarter chime bells strike first then the anticipation mounts and finally the deep sonorous BOING of Big Ben itself. Awesome, especially at noon when it will strike 12 times!
Worth a look . The clock is taller than people think and it's nice to see it lit up at night. Visit on a sunny day for the best view as it was quite cloudy when we visited

Big Ben is really big!. On our trip to London by air, we stayed for 3 all too brief days, prior to sailing the Atlantic on Queen Mary II back to the colonies. One of the highlights was Big Ben. It took our breath away when we found ourselves in front of BIG BEN! And he is really big. After visiting the Tower of London we boarded a cruise boat which stopped at Parliament / Big Ben. It is a wonderful trip on the Thames and I would reccomend approaching Sir Ben in this way!

The sound of Blighty!. This is one of the "must see" parts of London - a clock tower at the end of the Houses of Parliament. It is visible from some distance away, particularly if approached by walking down Whitehall (which itself has some "Blighty" type moments to experience.) The sound of the bell chiming is iconic and recognised worldwide as a symbol of London and Britain. Hearing it first hand is highly recommended.Best photos are often found across the bridge on the south bank of the Thames - during most of the day the areas on the ground closest to Big Ben are very crowded with hundreds of other tourists trying to get a snap. But images from down below don't look quite right - so get away from it and use the zoom for the clock face if wanted. Alternative shots are perhaps found by looking down Whitehall.

Get booked on now!. Usually when you live somewhere you don't do the touristy things, but despite living in London for 7 years I've seen an awful lot of what the tourists do and this is one of my all time highlights (along with the Duck Tours and climbing over the 02!) It's a bit weird having to arrange it through your MP and you may have to wait a while - we were lucky and got the dates we wanted due to a cancellation but we spoke to someone else who had been waiting 2 years! Our tour guide Catherine was really knowledgeable and funny and her colleague Lindsey was really kind and friendly. We learnt about all the secrets of Big Ben being made, and looking out from behind the clock faces and seeing the bell being struck on the hour was amazing! The health and safety guidelines probably over-egg how hard it is. In fact the steps are really modern and all even, and there is a solid handrail throughout. You walk up very slowly and there are opportunities to rest on the way up and down. I don't think many people know you can do this (and you can only do it if you're a UK resident) so it felt like quite a privilege to do this!

A sonorous experience at Parliament. Not quite the view you get from the London Eye, but this one is rather special as it is the home of the Great Bell and Clock that boom out at the beginning of some BBC radio news broadcasts. And it is also the highest part of the Palace of Westminster and the Houses of Parliament. It is an historic tower, but not one for the faint-hearted or sadly for anyone of limited mobility as there is no lift and every visitor must climb the several hundred stairs to reach the clock and bell chamber. You will pass the cell where any troublemakers around Parliament could(can) be held to cool their heels and tempers, but the real supreme moment of the visit is the clock and the great bell. If you happen to be there at the turn of the hour, you get the special excitement of the deafening chimes from the bell. A daunting climb it is , but well worth the energy to get up - and coming down is much easier.
Everyone should go once!. You simply have to go on a visit to London.Very busy but the building is British Architecture at it's best!

Iconic landmark of London. When you think of landmarks, Paris has it Tower Eiffel, Berlin has the Brandenburg Gate and London has Big Ben.This is as popular as Tower Bridge for all travellers, and probably more photographed.Forget the politically correct title of the Elizabeth Tower, its been known as Big Ben since its construction and will always be known as Big Ben.It has to be the starting point for all visitors to London, from there a short walk through St.James's Park takes you to yet another iconic building, Buckingham Palace.It has featured in many films which people will remember most notably 'The 39 Steps', where you get an idea of the inside including where the tower took its name, the bell itself.It is not always open to visitors, but if you are lucky you really should take the opportunity to see inside. It is however the outside that people will remember, and a good spot for a photograph is about half way across Westminster Bridge.

Classic Icon of London. Big Ben, the bell housed inside Elizabeth Tower, chimes on the hour (there are other bells heard on the quarter hour). You don't have to have voted for them - just ask your MP for a ticket!. I pretty much always knew that all you had to do was ask your MP to send you a ticket, but it took a while until I got over the fact that I wasn't buddy buddy with my constituency MP. But after sending an email to their office my MP's really efficient PA replied within minutes (i the evening) and I soon had a booking.It's quite a climb up the tower, but there are stopoff points to rest. You get behind the iconic clock faces, get to the clockwork mechanism, and up to the bells. You get ear plugs and stand right next to Big Ben as it rings out, and you really feel the vibrations in the stonework. The views are terrific out the balustrades, and when you're back on the ground you can look up and see exactly where you were, near the top of this World icon. Definitely recommended.

In all her glory. In all my trips, I think Big Ben remains my favorite. Every day at noon, just hearing the clock chime.... still gives me goosebumps. Such a spectacular sight!
Beautiful sight. Did not go up in Big Ben, but the sight and the sound of it sounding the hours off with bells is very impressive.
A must!. I was fiven a great and sunny day so all my pics were superb. The area is a must for all tourists! Tons of tourists but everything is so big that nobody disturbs you.

Evening might be the best time to visit this.. evening being (730PM in Summer)!!!

Majestically tall. The Big Ben stands tall in the Trafalgar Square and dominates the skyline in spite of it not being the tallest structure around. I only saw it from outside as I was not sure if they allow the visits inside the parliament house, which Big Ben is a part of. But again it is best viewed from a distance to take in the whole structure.
Tourist attraction. Great to go and see whilst in London. Lots of opportunity for some fabulous photos. Near lots of tourist attractions
Parliamentary sessions. Interesting visit for debates in both Houses. More people in Visitors Gallery than on floors of Houses, and all in the Gallery awake !
tower. wow! what a site for your eyes to see what a gorgeous piece of history sounds amazing and looks great!
A Magical Place. Part of what makes London so special. Visiting this whole area is like a step back in time. A magical place full of history. Never tire of seeing this part of London..
Beautiful!. Big Ben is much larger & magnificent in person. It was nice walking around it & getting photos, but you do catch a great gllmpse of it on the London Eye.
Marvelous Piece of British Engineering. It works and is a sight to behold at night situated by the Westminster Bridge and the Thames River. Big Ben is the Bells inside.
It's BigBen.. It's Big Ben, I mean why more is there to say? If you visit London you have to see this iconic landmark. It's just awesome!
Amazing. What a beautiful tower! You won't be able to stop looking at it from many different angles. Totally recommended
A must. A must see for all, walk over the bridge for better view to take photos. A busy part of the city with lots of tourists but still a must !
Big Ben at noon.. Got to Big Ben just as it struck noon. My last visit to London it was under renovation so I was happy to be able to enjoy it this trip
Aussies in London. A definite must see if you're in London. Spectacular workmanship went into these buildings. Great for photos.

Big Ben - A must see for picture taking. I didn't get to go inside but the outside view is spectacular. I took tons of pictures. The view at night is beautiful! I think that only locals can get a tour but I was perfectly happy with my photos.
Got to See Big Ben. What is to say? Big Ben is one of the icons of London. A thrill to see it. We walked by and also got a closer view from the top of a tour bus, which I highly recommend.
A must see when in London at day as well as night time.. A must see when in London at day as well as night time. A true land mark that cannot be missed. At night time even more beautiful.
Take your photo, move on. It's a photo op, It's beautiful all lit up at night. You see it, smile and move on, check another thing off your list of places you "must" see in London.
A must see. Big Ben is something that everyone must see. It's historical significance is interesting to learn. My hotel was close to it so I had the pleasure of seeing it out my hotel window.
Beautiful. The Big Ben is beautiful. We had this lovely view from our hotel window and enjoyed it. It is a must see whilst in London.

It's hard not to be impressed.. I was unfortunately extremely ill the first few days of my trip - which just so happened to be the entirety of my time in London - but no matter what state you're in, seeing Big Ben for the first time is just so magical and iconic - exploring and experiencing is truly the best medicine. Visit Big Ben, watch the Thames flow by and reflect on the good things in life. Do it at least until the bells chime.

Beautiful, Day and Night,. You cant go to London and not visit this site. Its beautiful. We went in the daytime and at night and both times were great. There are other landmarks close by so you will get a lot done walking around. The bus service in London is great so we went from our hotel in Islington to Big Ben by bus.
Amazing . Always I dreams to see and listen to the most attractive place to visit in LondonI enjoyed the experience and I will repeat coming every time I visit London
Big Ben. Big Ben is spectacular. Worth seeing...This is a city icon that is a landmark in the skyline of London.
What a clock!. Amazing being so close to this wonderful clock and hearing Ben the bell. Very impressive and a nice surprise to see it right in front of you when leaving the tube station.
Great for pictures. Don't spend more than 10 minutes here. It's usually crowded and noisy. The place is great for pictures though.
Just like the Pics. This was just what I expected.. With our selfie stick we got a really great shot of us with it in the background.
Big Ben. Everybody who comes to London must walk past Big Ben and here the Bells.I think I have taken more photos than I can count from every angle. Also a video of the bells a must
Family Vacation.. Very nice. Quite large. lovely pictures. Great place to visit. Great history. Included in our tour. Lovely old building.
Westminster. Big Ben is actually the bell in the clock tower at parliament so you can't actually see Big Ben. The Houses of Parliament and the clock tower are wonderful.
Hmmm. Nice clock. Looks just like the pictures. Not much more to say about it? Still a must see when you are visiting London.

its big ben :). What can I say? It is big ben, you should see it just to say you saw it. In the end it is just a clock tower but if you are in London you should not miss it or what are you gonna tell the folks at home ? :)

It's famous.. It's in all the tour books so it must be really cool. Right? Maybe there is something wrong with me, but after 8 seconds of looking up at it, I was ready to move on. But that's me. You may want to stand there for 1/2 day! Anyway, it's famous, so you should probably see it while you're in London.
big ben. love it, so pretty and tall, many tourist, so watch your stuff. ggret for photos. wait till the hour is up and listen to the chimes
Great views of Big Ben from the Thames.. The most beautiful building I have ever seen. I was able to see several times during my visit and I was somewhat mesmerized. Very imposing structure.

No better way to say that you are in London. What is more classic than seeing the tower that everyone calls Big Ben. no matter how many pictures that you take, it is still beautiful to behold! I liked the view from the other side ot the Thames, across Westminister Bridge. The 315-foot high clock tower is actually called the Elizabeth Tower and Ben is the 13-ton bell that you hear ring all the time. You cannot, sadly, go up the tower though.

Beware of pickpockets.. Big Ben is a must see in London and it is in fact a beautiful building. You can take great pictures of it from every angles.However there is always a lot of tourists around so it makes it the perfect spot for pickpockets. We spotted a couple that was just going from one side of the road to the other, in the crowd, over and over again.We noticed them because while I was crossing the street with my wife the guy was coming directly at us and and he shoved me when he passed between us and the girl was passing on the other side of my wife. I was alarmed immediately but we had nothing loose that could be taken from us easily so we were fine. But since I found it very suspicious we went a little further and looked back at the scene where we saw them repeat their little game a couple of time.So just be careful in the area.
A timely icon. After seeing Big Ben in pictures, the clock lived up to its many images. I won't ruin the narrative of local guides who went into the clock's pedigree.

It is impressive outside and intresting inside. You can walk around the Parliament and just get an impression of this magnificent building, or add a guided tour inside the Parliament. Highly recommended due to the very good guides and interesting view of the Parliament procedures. You learn about details that are not familiar to the public. It is very much recommended to order tickets in advance.
A must do in London!. You have to see the Big Ben! It's architecture is gorgeous. The pictures you can take are incredible! Definitely come here!

Most Iconic Landmark of London.. When my relatives from India came in Britain, they went to London and after a brief tour, we went to see Big Ben, the most iconic clock tower in the Houses of Parliament. The best way to go is by London Underground and get off at Westminster Station on the District, Circle and Jubilee Line, because when you come out of the station Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament is right there in front of you. Not only can't you miss it but the position is also good for any photo opportunities. We also stayed around the area for a few minutes but there is a souvenir shack nearby and it is only a short walk to Westminister Abbey, another well known iconic place in London. Much of the restaurants and takeaways are further up north to where Big Ben is located, so it is best to take a pack lunch or eat before you go and visit. Because it is most popular, expect a lot of people both local and foreign to be all over the place. Apart from that, Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament are a great place to see both day and night and no holiday in England would be complete without seeing them, so if you have time to spend even for a few minutes, this place is well worth a visit.

Great Timekeeper. We checked out Big Ben from the road and managed to be around the clock stuck 1pm. It is an iconic statement of London so worth checking out. Further stroll down the road leads you to the London Eye so there is a lot of things to see around this part of town.
Clock tower. Big Ben is not actually on show as it is the bell within the tower, not the tower itself, which most people think it is. It is a striking landmark that can be seen from quite a distance.

Always Fascinating. I just love the architecture and the overall feeling of looking at the Big Ben. I mean, since we were little we learned about this big clock in London!To be near the clock when it chimes is quite an experience. For some reason, I always want to see and go near the Big Ben every time I visit London :-)
Big Ben isn't as big as you think. But, it is still an impressive structure and an icon of London. You can get great photos of it if you do a River Thames tour, or the road above Westminister Station
Okay. Not that big. Interesting architecture, but really I found it was just a place to look at. I was a bit underwhelmed with the reality, but I suppose my expectations were blown up by stories.
Truly beautiful pictures dont do it justice. Amazing from across the bridge, on the Thames and standing right under this magnificent building and clock
What time is it?. We stayed within walking distance to Big Ben. The public transportation was awesome. Don't leave London without eating the fish and chips...which we call fries in the US

Perfect. We were lucky enough to get tickets from our MP to climb the Elizabeth Tower, BIG BEN.This was such a truly magical experience. Each one of us feels like we have had an exclusive trip. Richard was a great guide and getting to see behind the clock faces was remarkable.The views were stunning and then we were stood right next to the bells as they chimed 12 midday. They were so load i could feel the vibrations all through my body.Thanks

one of the best. one of the main attractions in London is Big Ben, the clock that has a cracked bell and makes an unique sound when it sings the exact hour. it is very looked by tourists and photographers.
The Best. Everytime I go to London the thing I most look forward to seeing is the Big Ben. In my opinion the best clocktower in the world. :)
Big Tower. If your in London as a tourist, you've got to visit Big Ben. Obviously. Get there early for some better images. Oh and get off at Westminster.

A great part of London's architectural history. 12 o clock midnight or midday is a good time to get here as you hear the maximum chimes of Big Ben. Take your selfie against this majestic backdrop and keep walking over the bridge to the south bank or north towards St James park. Look for politicians under the canvas canopy on the river side!
Big Ben and Parliament Square. I always feel like I'm on holiday when I cycle this route, don't miss St James Park around the corner and then obviously you can see the palace

A towering presence. One doesn't need to make a special effort to see this Westminster landmark that is visible from boat tours on the Thames and from most parts of Westminster as you tour other sites. Mind the traffic and foot traffic of the hordes of tourists doing the same things you are.

Surely this is on your London bucket list?. Your in London! Its kind of the thing you must see!! Very self explanatory really!! It does look a lot nicer in real life than from photos and movies. If I could recommend anything it will be to turn up early 8am or earlier before the tourists show up to get some unobstructed photography
Big Clock. Always looks impressive, no matter what angle you see it from. Nice to be on the street next to it. Try and visit it in winter, it looks so much better lit up in the dark.
Great place but beware..... I loved seeing this icon but beware of the gypsies! They will snatch anything valuable from you that they can get.
Its a giant clock. Iconic yes, and you can see it from all over. But not really a destination onto itself. Its more of the decoration that makes up the London skyline than an attraction.

Giant Clock. If Giant Clocks are you're thing.......
After one picture from one side of the river to the other it becomes tiresome jostling with the other tourists for that perfect snap of Big Ben.
Just go early on a week day done.
Must-go on any London trip!. This is a must visit on any London trip. Must visit in day and night separately to marvel at the true beauty of this architectural magnificence!
The symbol of London. Nothing beats seeing and hearing the distinctive "bong" of Big Ben. It holds so much tradition. It is much larger than one would think, too.

Every clock collectors dream. Big Ben is the ultimate clock, seeing it in person is a wonderful experience. As a member of the National Watch and Clock Collectors Association, I have an interest in all timepieces. This is a must see for any avid clock fan.
The most attractive,it's very nice... Big Ben it's the most attractive thing in UK and in the world i think,it's beautiful especially if you have a good weather..lot of walking..but worth it!!
I'm in London!. I could see it from the window of my room. his was really nice because it made me feel in London at once. I love when the sun is shining and we listen to its sound at midday.

World renown landmark. Don't just see it during the day.
Make a second trip at night to catch the Ben lit up, and so you can hear the bell toll more times!
A classic and not to be missed!
Great!. Loved looking at Big Ben tower from the river boat and walking around. Parliament wasn't in session so I didn't go inside.

Big, beautiful Ben. Big Ben is known and recognised the world over. The clock tower itself is beautiful. its heartwarming
to see this popular landmark and to hear the chimes
as they ring out over the city.

Beautiful Symbol of English democracy. Such a beautiful building and a symbol of the English nation. My favorite view is from across the Thames...pretty accessible considering the world situation. Its nice to cross the Thames on the bridge and get many different angles in your photography. Close to so many other landmarks.
People know where you with Big Ben in the background. Classic shot, people know where you are with Big Ben in the photo. Day or night, it's worth a look .
Bold and beautiful. A trip to London without seeing Big Ben is like completing a puzzle with one piece missing. Make your own postcard pictures with Big Ben in the background
nice. On my guided tour we checked out what is known as Big Ben and found out Big Ben is actually the biggest bell but most people think it's the clock. Something nice to see.

True icon of London. Absolutely breathtaking site, should be your 1st stop to get true taste of London! Be prepared, this area is extremely crowded, so bring your patience. There is a little park to the side of parliament building, which is good spot to enjoy the view and remove yourself from the chaos on the sidewalks. Have your video ready for the tolling bell at the top of the hour. The beauty + detail along the building facades is gorgeous.

A magnificent architecture, wonderful. Despite coming here many times but I still very interested and attracted. The quaint, elegant, beauty, all gathered in one architecture. If you are a lover of art, you should definitely visit this place.

A magnificent architecture, wonderful. Despite coming here many times but I still very interested and attracted. The quaint, elegant, beauty, all gathered in one architecture. If you are a lover of art, you should definitely visit this place.

An historic building but not many things to do.. A very beautiful building but you can just look on it from far. I stayed at park plaza westmunster bridge hotel that is right next it so it was beautiful to wake up and see it every morning.
London Icon. London icon. This is a place that everyone must see on a trip to London. There is nothing to do inside it, but simply seeing it from a few blocks away is nice.

Beautiful buildings!!!. This place has to be visited, with time, walk around from all corners. If you have binoculars you can find incredible details in every inch of the buildings. The clock alone has incredible beautiful details done long time ago.Walking along the Thames bank is awesome too but I would recommend to do the visit in the morning (during the summer) because you will have the sun light in the right place.

A Landmark from London. The Big Ben is one of those spots in London that you cannot avoid seen if you visit the city for the first time.My mother was visiting the city for the first time, so my husband and I decided to do a tour for the main attractions. The tower clock was commissioned after a fire at the Westminster Palace in 1834. It started working in 1859 and became a symbol of London.Because of that and because there are other important attractions nearby, like the Houses of Parliament and the Westminster Abbey, this area is full of tourists and not easy to navigate. Prepare yourself for that.
Iconic. We had been many times to visit it during the day but had never seen it at night- one word- wow! Coupled with the London eye, it makes a lovely photo.
awesome...thrilling...exciting..historic,,,. huge clock with the correct time..you have to look high to see the face and time..Amazed at the Parliament building on the river Thames
Gotta see this. A must if going to London. We walked around it which was enough for us. Hearing the bells was great to.
Sight seeing tour. Brilliant,we took our granddaughter for her 14 th birthday,she really enjoyed all the sights Big Ben,Westminster abbey,river trip up the Thames,Buckingham palace.she loved it all
THe greatest building of London. Big Ben is i think the most beautiful buliding in London. In lovely condition, pictures are great from this place.

it is a BIG BEN. Big Ben is a historical symbol of London and great sight to make picture at... but you need to prep yourself and prior of visit, please read some material about it, its history and so on... other than that it could look to you as big watch tower...

Must see but can be VERY crowdy. Definitely takes your breath away when you see it for the first time. But it is also one of the crowdiest tourist attraction in London and tourists start arriving at 8am in the morning some times. Here you can really feel the hustle and bustle whenever something "big" is taking place. It gets a bit chaotic whenever there is a staged protest or great sporting event, such as Tour de France. But clearly something on your list when you visit London.

Amazing. We were in London on our layover to Dublin and got to get out briefly and see a few sites- Big Ben being our first stop!! WOW AMAZING> breathtaking! We even got to hear Big Ben strike 12 noon!! One of those once in a life time things! A must see amazing place! Pictures don't do it justice!

I wish I was there now.. Everything you ever dreamed about the Big Ben is true.It was right off the Westminster tube stop, and three times larger than I'd envisioned. It was beautiful. Go on the hour and record him, you won't regret it!

A must see!. Such a great sight for all visitors. We always knew where we were by looking up and seeing Big Ben. The bridge across can get very crowded when trying to get a photo op. Best to stay on the side of Big Ben.
Iconic symbol of London!. Perfect background while visiting London; great landmark to use while trying to find your way around the city; very close to other attractions.

Big Ben. Very impressive building with a tube station situated opposite. Within walking distance from the Londin eye and other attractions. The pavements around Big Ben were incredibly busy so may be a prime spot for pickpockets.

The Big Big Ben. One of the Londons famoust attractions Big Ben can't stay unseen.The clock, which Big Ben is,is one of the most photographed clocks in the world.Why? Come and see,you shall take a photo too ;)

A wonder to behold. An London Icon you do not want to miss. It was amazing to Big Ben in July. It was a rainy day,but the best pictures was taken with The Eye framing Big Ben in the background. I took pictures during a bus tour.
Breathtaking photo op!. Beautiful, unbelievable experience to see this monument. My daughters gasped at its sight. Wonderful, obligated photo op while in London.
Excellent architecture. Be there around 11 the ben strikes. Excellent piece of architecture and worth the visit. Even night view is excellent.
Simply Amazing. It is hard to go in Central London and not to see Big Ben. It is an iconic symbol of London and you must visit it at least once in your lifetime. you would not regret it

It Doesn't Do Much. As an inanimate object, Big Ben just kinda chills there. I didn't get a tour (expensive and wasn't too interested) but looked at him for a while (3-4 solid minutes I'd say). However, he was easy to access and close to other landmarks (Houses of Parliament, Thames, Buckingham Palace, Hyde Park and the miscellaneous little park opposite Ben himself). He was also close to the underground, so great in that regard.

Iconic- wait to hear it chime, then you know you are in London. It's the clock not the tower- don't get caught not knowing that. It chimes just like it should and it MAKES you feel like you are in London.

Compulsory visit for anyone visiting UK.. Almost compulsory visit for anyone coming to London and I'd be surprised if anyone visits UK who doesn't want to see Westminster and Parliament. With this comes probably the most iconic landmark in the country - Big Ben. I visit London on business maybe monthly and at least 6 times a year go close enough to Westminster. Never fail to be impressed.

Gorgeous.. As you come out of the Westminster station this is the first thing you see and it is breathtaking. That is the first thing I did when o came to London. I was completely blown away by it. Big Ben is gorgeous. If you can, definitely atop by and see it at night, its worth it.

Simply amazing..... As much an iconic symbol of London as Buckingham Palace, the Tower of London it remains a must do part of any London tour.We took the time to view this amazing icon from the London Eye, river cruise and from the Westminster bridge.Simply amazing....
Beautiful. Definitely one of my highlights in London seeing the Big Ben! The gold and clock and architecture on the building is amazing!

It Watches the City. It is hard to go anywhere in Central London and not see the presence of Big Ben. On arriving in Central London, there it stood, watching over the city. It is the landmaker that will guide you everywhere.

Big Ben and Parliament Square. The history and architecture is amazing! The huge crowds everywhere was frustrating, especially when groups of people just stop in front of you without any concern for people walking behind them. There are many things to see and do in London, but this area seemed like it had the biggest crowd. Even more so than Buckingham Palace. As over crowded as this area was, it's still a necessary stop to see. Westminster Abby is totally awe inspiring with it's amazing architecture. House of Parliament was interesting.
Great Britain at a glance. Every trip to the UK MUST include a trip to see the Elizabeth tower. Beautiful since all the smog was cleaned off, wonderful to hear big ben sound again.
Such a beautifull sight. Such a beautiful sight during day and night! Ofcourse this is an iconic landmark, make sure you travel around it by bus or on foot.
Iconic watch of London!. yes...and its really really big....great architecture, recommend a walk from the parliament building across the bridge to the London Eye...
Iconic London Building. It is one of the places you must visit in London, so it is just as you can expect. Note: the Big-ben is ne name of the bell, it is not the name of the tower or the clock.
Historic building.. Big ben is near the parliment house and westminister abey. it is a lovely building stading uip as a symbol of British Financial system.
Incrível !! / Fantastic. If visiting London the first time this is a place you cannot miss! You have to expend at least 2 or even 3 hours walking around the corner.
Iconic watch tower of london.... well, if you're not going to see (and listen to) the Big Ben while in London - it's as if you've never been there, right?!
The most famous clock in the world.. Just part of Westminster Abby, but no trip to London would be complete without seeing it. Quite impressive.

Amazing of Course!. It's Big Ben! Of course it's amazing! As with everything in London - get there early! Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey, London Eye, Dungeons, Horseguards Parade, Trafalgar Square and more all nearby.

Great to take pictures. Beautiful architecture, recommend a walk from the parliament building across the bridge to the London Eye. For a longer walk - keep walking along the river to the London Bridge. Beautiful!
Well worth seeing. Every time we visit London we always ensure we make time to see the typical tourist attractions, well what makes London London! And this is one of them........well worth.a visit!
Must See Attraction. It's a very well known attraction in London. You cannot miss this attraction. I heard the bell strike at 10 am. It was Amazing
Must See. Very crowded corner at Big Ben. But worth seeing. It is across the street from the houses of parliament.

Absolutely astounding!. As one of the world's most renowned landmarks, Big Ben doesn't disappoint. Go on the Queen's Walk and stroll across Westminster Bridge on your way to see Big Ben up close. Make sure to take tons of photos. You'll never see another sight like Ben Ben! Grand, beautiful and breathtaking, it's one tourist attraction in London that you CAN'T afford to miss. If you aren't strapped for cash, I recommend taking a ride on the London Eye and catching a view of the city skyline with Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey from up high before you go across the bridge.
Must see. Who hasn't heard of Big Ben? We walked around it and the area, so interesting, theirs a great little pub just across the road from the clock tower, small but great fish and chips
A real rappresentative element. Suggestive especially at night, but I prefered the London eye in which I promised to myself to visit asap.
Big Ben. Everything you would expect. Magnificent experience that will leave us with memories for a lifetime.

beautiful must see…!!. a beautiful place to see.. a must when in London… very impressive and close by lots of rester aunts and other things to see.. a great part of town.. if you have a afternoon..walk the thames river down to the london bridge.. a amazing walk.>!!!

Hard to miss, and easy to admire. The way it rises up over the city, the Thames, the new buildings and the old charm, Big Ben is one of those mo'numents that helps you realize you're not in Kansas anymore, Toto. Clearly, it's worth seeing. I would like to have researched if it's possible to take a tour. But, with all there is to see and do, admiring it from the bridge is pretty sweet.
Big and not a miss. Must see, in it's glory. Very well looked after.clean, big and very pleasing to the eye. Don't miss this

Interesting. There is always more than meets the eye. The name Big Ben actually has more to do with people connected with the chimes, than the clock it's self. The maker was a guy named Ben. View the city with a guide to get the most out of your touring.

Nice enough. I know this establishment is a landmark and all but I expected it to be somewhat taller and even my girls who are 4 and 6 didn't look too impressed. Of course it holds a lot of history and it's always good to have a big ben photo among your holidays pictures but it kinda felt like ticking off the box and moving on to next site. I would recommend it though ,it is one of its kind

Big Ben is great. Big Ben is an impressive sight when walking across the river. During the season the area is crowded, but if you go there during the evening it´s less crowded and the sight is even more spectacular.

Beautiful, But Hard To Get Entry. The Big Ben is a very well known landmark. It is indeed very impressive, and it was fun to go there with my family. The only thing I disliked was that you had to book an appointment much ahead of time to go inside. I really wish they had made it easier to go. Though this, it was super cool to go and just see it. It should definitely be one of your 'to-dos' in London.

Magical. I actually did the tour of Big Ben booked through my MP and went right to the top of Elizabeth Tower and saw the bell strike 3pm with my own eyes (and ears with the help or some ear plugs) I walked around all 4 clock faces and it truly was one of the most magical experiences of my life. London's most iconic landmark truly is magnificent.

Historical View. We saw this from afar so, I cannot give it much higher ratings. We were on the hop on/off bus tour and that day it rained. That aside, from afar, we did get decent pictures of it and the tour guide gave interesting information.

GET A VIEW UP CLOSE. This is an icon that shouldn't be missed. I strolled by early in the morning to enjoy the view before the area got crowded. Though it's visible from quite a distance, it is well worth your time to get a look up close.
Cannot miss to visit. A beautiful spot at night as well as during the day. I recommend walking across Westminster bridge for marvelous view.
an iconic site. The sight of Big Ben always makes the heart happy. It epitomises the British spirit in some way, standing proud and solid.

IF there is a flag you can visit!. if you see a flag flying on top of Victoria Tower, you can visit a debate at either the Hose of Commons or the House of Lords. You have to go through a short line and security, they give you a batch and you are in. No pictures allowed inside but it is nice to see the process. The building itself is beautiful. The Westminster hall survived the 1834 fire the wood work is amazing. You can have a great view of the Big Ben tower form the Westminster bridge.

An Icon of London. We were so excited that we could see Big Ben from our hotel room. Nerdy, maybe, but it's a London icon that we'd only seen in movies and TV shows. Everybody who visits London should stroll by at least once per visit. Be prepared for crowds during the day!
Awe inspiring. Wow this place takes your breath away! From exiting Westminster tube, it rears up in front of you and all you can see is people taking photos!

A must see!. A beautiful spot I recommend visiting at night as well as during the day. For good photo opportunities I recommend walking across Westminster bridge for marvelous views across the Thames.
As beautiful as it looks. Big Ben is just gorgeous! There are so many great ways to take pics, on the bridge or across the water. It is also so pretty at night!

Must see icon. Don't miss if you have not been here. A perfect experience- A Walk across the Westminster Bridge to view the Big Ben, British Parliament and West Minister Abbey is a must do for visitors. Approach from Waterloo station via London Eye. Best view is from London Eye or WM bridge

Finally - with my own eyes. Although I've been to London several times (for work), I've never actually been standing next to Big Ben or watched form almost any angle from the hop-on-hop-off buses. It sure is a beautiful sight with The Parliament and Westminster Abbey in the background.

Watch of London. What can we say about Big Ben.. It is one of the most famous landmark in London and when you're in London it is a must to take picture with Big Ben. Taking pictures is enough for me but for those who would like to climb to the top of the Big Ben you will need to pay £18 if I am not wrong. It is attached to The Parliament Building just besides the famous Thames River. Now it is known as Elizabeth Tower for celebrating the Diamond Jubilee for the Queen. Book a tour from your MP - You won't be disapointed. If you are a UK resident you can request a tour of the Elizabeth tower - be warned there is about a six month waiting list.But, its well worth the wait - Really Amazing! 334 steps take you to touching distance of Big Ben (the bell) in the bell tower over 90meters up above the London streets.Fortunately you don't climb all the steps in one go - you have two pauses where your host will tell you something about the tower and its history.For me the highlight was in the mechanism room, watching the cogs and pendulum move whilst the clock chimed a quarter, but being in the bell tower whilst the clock struck 12, and seeing the huge clock faces from behind was pretty amazing too.No photos are allowed at all - but you will remember your visit anyway.Seriously enjoyable and not to be missed. Huge thanks to our tour guides Monica & Phil.
Must see icon. Impressive as expected. Don't miss if you have not been here. Recommend to access by foot and visit London eye after.

Iconic & Awesome Mantleclock. I took my son, Ben, to see Big Ben for the first time. We had a great debate about what Big Ben actually is. I think it is the big bell but it is now commonly the reference to the clock and the clock tower itself. We left convinced the big bell, officially known as the Great Bell, is nicknamed "Big Ben" after the chief engineer of the tower whose name was Sir Benjamin Hall. Oh and the tower is the Elizabeth Tower !?!??? Anyway I dont really care ..... it looks absolutely magnificent and makes a great sound.

Busy Business District to Visit/Sight Seen . Watch out for fast-paced locals who seem to be annoyed with tourists wandering around, taking pictures, figuring out how to cross busy streets or taking the buses, subways (aka "tubes"). A lot of bus stops to all directions even you are in the right station (directions, correct "letter" of stops). The $5 BP Oyster card + preload fares (aka top up) is way to expensive comparing to other European countries day pass or pay as you go fair. We each spent $10 BP for the Oyster card + prepaid fare, and used maybe $3 BP worth of busy, slow, stuffy, no A/C bus rides. Walking was a lot faster. London Dept of Public Transportation needs to think of a better solution for tourists.
