London's Big Ben. The Houses of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower, commonly called Big Ben, are among London's most iconic landmarks. Technically, Big Ben is the name given to the massive bell inside the clock tower, which weighs more than 13 tons (13,760 kg). The clock tower looks spectacular at night when the four clock faces are illuminated.The Houses of Parliament's iconic clock tower is one of London's most famous landmarks. Don't leave London without visiting Big Ben!

You can't miss it. So iconic for everyone from New Zealand whose parents used to listen to the nine o'clock BBC radio news, before TV came along. The chiming of Big Ben's nine notes would usually sound as the cups of tea would be brought along to sip as all tuned into the world news from London.

good. excellent food and friendly staff. food tasty and people working were warm hearted. There was one time they took 1hour and 20 minutes to bring my order, so they gave me discount and free dessert and drink as part of their apology

Ding Dong the bells are ringing. Booked the tour through our MP, received paperwork and instructions through the post. Arrived at main entrance which is on the other side of the road to Big Ben (Portcullis House/entrance), security searched, ID documents checked and security badge given, bags had to be put in to locked storage. Instructions where given an away the tour started. Very enjoyable, had about three stops during the tour with lots of information given, would recommend. You can take water with you, you are not allowed to take photo's during the tour. We were there for 12ish to hear the Big Ben chime, had a good view of the sights of London from the bell tower. Our guide was very knowledgeable but seemed to have a speech impediment making it slightly hard to understand. There is a shop but this is not at the entrance to access the shop you need to come out of the entrance and turn left and left again and it is at the end of the building on the corner undercover (not very signposted). No toilets at venue you have to use the ones at the underground.
Never fails to give me goosebumps!. This was our 3rd time visiting London and seeing Big Ben, and every time it amazes me! Do not miss seeing Big Ben if you are anywhere near London!

Big Ben (http://www.bigbenfacts.co.uk/history/index.html). The illustrations on this page were created by students at St. George's Primary School in Camberwell, London, as part of our "Happy Birthday, Big Ben!" project. These illustrations were previously published in a booklet about the history of Big Ben.On 16th October 1834, the Palace of Westminster was destroyed by a fire. A HUGE fire. Londoners came out to watch it, and legend has it, Charles Barry (whom we’ll meet in a moment) was passing by in a coach and stopped to watch for a while.There were so many spectators, they actually hampered the firemen’s efforts to douse the flames.When the flames were put out, there wasn’t much left. Only Westminster Hall. Parliament had nowhere to meet and they had to cancel their session.In November 1835, 13 months later, they set up a committee to re-build and they held a competition for designs.More than 400 designs were submitted by more than 90 architects.In the end, the committee chose the design of Charles Barry, but here's a little secret: His original design did NOT include a clock tower! They asked him to revise it and to add a clock tower, of course with a clock inside!Working with his trusty (but somewhat highly strung) assistant, Augustus Welby Pugin, Charles Barry added a clock tower to his design, along with four faces, and really big bells!But Charles Barry, quite rightly, asserted that HE was an architect, not a clockmaker. So he asked Benjamin Lous Vuillamy, clockmaker to the Queen, to design a clock.By this time, it was 1841, so you can’t blame Charlie for wanting to get on with his project. However….ALL the expert clockmakers across Britain were upset that he had asked Benjamin Louis Vuillamy to design the clock, without so much as an open competition.One clockmaker, Edward Dent, wrote to George Airy, Astonomer Royal, asking him to recommend him for the job. Of course, George Airy did so, and, as a result, the committee decided that George Airy should write up a list of requirements for the Great Clock. They asked him to choose the design and the clockmaker to boot!George Airy was really excited about his job, and he wrote up a list of requirements that had never been seen before. It was a long list, but the most important requirement was this:"The Great Clock should be so accurate that the first strike for each hour shall be accurate to within ONE second of time."Whew! Nobody had EVER required a clock to be that accurate. Much less a clock in a CLOCK TOWER, with FOUR HUGE FACES, and such LARGE HANDS!The expert clockmakers stopped grumbling and started whinging. They felt George Airy's specification was IMPOSSIBLE! They thought it could never be done.One man thought it was worth a try. His name was Edmund Beckett Denison (who later became Lord Grimthorpe). He was a cantankerous sort of fellow – a persistent, single-minded kind of chap who didn't take "no" for an answer.Here’s my favourite part of the story: Edmund Beckett Denison wasn't even a clockmaker! He was a lawyer! Clockmaking was his HOBBY.So here’s this AMATEUR (albeit a very intelligent amateur), telling all the EXPERTS, "Yes, it can be done."Edmund Beckett Denison set his mind to the task. Perhaps CANTANKEROUSNESS has its benefits.He worked with Edward Dent, the clockmaker, to design the clock which would become the Great Clock in the clock tower at the Palace of Westminster.The key to the Great Clock of Westminster is the ESCAPEMENT. In fact the key to ANY turret clock is the ESCAPEMENT. The ESCAPEMENT is the part which regulates the going train of the clock, and allows the energy to escape to the pendulum. Without an ESCAPEMENT, a wound clock would unwind uncontrollably. In this case, Edmund Beckett Denison designed a "double three-legged gravity escapement." The escapement works with the pendulum; each swing of the pendulum opens one of the gravity arms, which in turn regulates the GOING TRAIN.Well, all that time, while the clockmakers were grumbling and then whinging and then jealously watching Edmund Denison and Edward Dent achieve the impossible, the clocktower had been under construction.And the Illustrated London News had been following the story like stickiness on marmalade:"The history of this already famed Clock dates as far back as 1844.... The escapement used by Mr. Denison is a remontoir, or gravity escapement, being more independent of the causes of vibration for the position this clock will occupy."(You can read the WHOLE STORY as reported by the Illustrated London News on the page called BIG BEN's STORY.)Of course, the Great Clock needed bells. Big bells. One bell for the hour, plus four bells to chime the quarter hours. They wanted the bells to chime a tune based on an aria from Handel’s Messiah. It's the famous "Westminster Chime" that you hear just before Big Ben strikes the hour.So they asked foundries to submit a cost for casting all those bells, and Warners of Cripplegate won the contract.The first bell cracks!They cast all five bells. The big one was cast on 6th August 1856, in Stockton-on-Tees. It was transported to London on a steamship, because the bell was too big for the railway. It came up the River Thames on a barge, and then was loaded onto a carriage drawn by 16 white horses and brought across Westminster Bridge.It must have been quite a sight – all those horses! Wouldn't you HATE to have to clean up after that!The clock tower wasn’t quite finished, so they hung the massive bell in the yard and every so often, they’d hit it with a hammer to test it.The Big Bell was SUPPOSED to be called "Victoria", after the Queen, but Londoners being Londoners, they nicknamed it "Big Ben" and the name stuck.There are two theories who “Ben” was. One was Benjamin Caunt, a bareknuckle boxer, and the other was Sir Benjamin Hall, who was the Commissioner of Works during the construction of the new Palace of Westminster.Now, where were we? Of course, we were hitting the bell with a hammer to test it.Wouldn’t you know it? On 17th October 1857, the bell cracked!You can imagine the controversy, with Edmund Beckett Denison pointing his cantankerous finger at Warners and Warners pointing their grimy fingers at the guy who held the hammer and the Illustrated London News pointing their journalistic fingers at EVERYBODY.Big Ben is deliveredThey broke up the bell – smashed it into a lot of tiny pieces – and hauled them over to Whitechapel Bell Foundry where, on 10th April 1858, they cast a new Big Ben. A bit smaller this time, a mere 13 and a half tons, it took the second Big Ben TWO weeks to cool down! They tuned him and finished him and when he was ready, they put him on a cart and hauled him back to Westminster. Londoners cheered him all along the way.Guess what! The clock tower was STILL NOT FINISHED. And when they did finish, they discovered that Big Ben was too big to fit up the shaft into the belfry. The bell is wider than it is tall. What a mess!Fortunately, someone figured out that they could turn him on his side, put him in a cradle and pull him by rope up to the belfry. It took a team of men THIRTY hours to get that job done.With all the bells in place, they installed the Great Clock, and it started working in May 1859. And on 11th July 1859, Big Ben chimed the hour for the first time. At last!But our story does not end there. On 1st October 1859, disaster struck! Big Ben was cracked by the hammer strike, and they couldn't move him out of the belfry. After all, the Great Clock had been installed below the belfry. So to remove Big Ben, they would have had to remove the Great Clock and ALL the mechanisms.So Big Ben was silent for a number of months while the arguments ensued. Yet again, there was A LOT of finger pointing and blaming each other. Edmund Beckett Denison thought that Whitechapel Bell Foundry had cast an inferior bell, and Whitechapel Bell Foundry thought that Edmund Beckett Denison had designed a hammer that was too large and well, there was A LOT of finger pointing.Ultimately, George Airy came up with a solution: Turn Big Ben a quarter turn, so that the hammer will strike a different spot. And that's just what they did - turned Big Ben so that the hammer strikes a different spot. Even today, when you visit the belfry, you can see the big crack in Big Ben. We think it adds to his charm!Our story does not have an ending, because Big Ben and the Great Clock are hard at work every single day. Even now!They’ve marked time throughout the reigns of 6 monarchs, the tenure of 25 prime ministers and the visits of countless tourists who show up at Westminster just to admire Augustus Pugin’s fantastic decorations and to hear Big Ben chime the hour.

Please if you get a chance to go on the Big Ben tour, its well worth it!!you have to apply via your MP and then wait for a date and time, I was lucky and got a cancellation and waited about 2 months( what's more it totally free!!)Basically you ask for an invite by emailing to your MP and state you wish to visit the tower and then wait , you have to be a British passport holder and over the age of 11( have to be accompanied by an adult), no photos allowed and tour takes approx. 90 mins and you have to be fit (lors of steps!! this sounds all a bit long winded but it is well worth itthe tour was brilliant very informative and fantastic views of the city of London as well as being in the Bell tower when it chimes and stand behind the clock face is pretty amazing ,every time I see it on the TV ,I shout I've climbed up there and some thing to say you've done and not many people have go on applyTim

grandaughter marvelled at the clock. this was a brilliant experience for my 2 granddaughters aged 8 and 6, the 6 year old just kept repeating 'I cant believe it , Big Ben. I didn't think that it would be so big' lol

History and THE landmark of London. Yesterday Big Ben struck 4pm. I have passed this monument many times but when the clock strikes the hour you hear it and you check your own time-piece. It attracts tourists and languages from around the world. It never disappoints
The Londn Icon. It's a must in London, everyone has to see this in London, it's a safe place, as there is close the houses of parliement and Downing street.
Big Ben. Everyone has heard the Big Ben. Ding dong. Perfect photo opportunity and you'll always get someone ask if you can take their picture.

So iconic and majestic. What an iconic image. To see it in person was breathtaking. I learned that actually the bell, not the clock is Big Ben, but to look at the clock when the bell is chiming is awesome. The view of Big Ben from the London Eye was spectacular. This is a real focal point of this area of London.

See it quite often yet inspiring. Living in London Big ben is not new or one visit wonder - yet it symbolizes the skyline of London better than any other skyscraper will ever do.. it is a memory of London since childhood and not going away anytime soon.. do visit to see this magnificent tower and of course plan accordingly to hear the big ben chime away..

Fantastic architecture and a thrill to see up close. I had a few hours to kill and did a quick walk from the London Eye over. It is a gem and worth the walk over the bridge. Wish I had more time to explore but was not disappointed

First parliament visit. First of all - contact your MP. Be patient & you get the chance to visit for free. When you arrive through portcullis house - it's just like an airport departure lounge with X-rays searches etcBut once you start the tour up 300 + small tight winding steps it is soo worth it. Best views over London & a guarantee of that iconic sound sight & feel of the Westminster chimes & Big BenNot a trip for many. It can be an exhausting climb & a scary descent. But it is a joy to remember forever. And then go watch the commons in session. Allow plenty of time you won't ever regret it

Great day out visiting the clock tower. It was a fantastic tour of both the houses of parliament and also the famous clock tower and its big bell! I am a local Londoner and i really would recommended it to locals and tourists alike.
Fantastic site. There isn't much to say, it's just unique and the second thing that makes you feel at London. The first are red bus. :D

Ding dong!. Always a welcome sight as you emerge from Westminster tube station. Every 15 minutes and on the hour without fail you will hear the chimes of the bell....Big Ben! The tower of course is St. Stephens And is a great photo opportunity. Have a laugh with the tourists and ask soneone for the time while standing at the bottom :)
Can't say anymore than has already been said!. A must see when you visit London, tho it's hard to miss.LOL! Easy to find off the number 87 bus line from Vauxhall.
Stunning view. This is a must see for visitors. It is a grand site to see in person. I highly recommend riding the London Eye to see better views.

very big ben. We came out of the train station, and could not miss it !! Wow. The architecture is amazing. And the more you stand and look at it the more amazing it seems. And being with houses of parliament is great.

Iconic symbol of London. Being a Londoner one tends to take this venue for granted , but having recently walked by , the amount of tourists it attracts makes this the Iconic symbol of London along with Tower Bridge.A must visit for all visitors to London. The view is free too !!
Very tall clock. I really enjoyed seeing this historical landmark. It was cool to see since it is so many movies and is world famous.

Unique.. There is not an other place in this world with such a magic and beauty than the Big Ben..I also find it very romantic, if you are thinking on proposing your girl, that would be the spot..good luck and take plenty of pics.
Icon on the Bridge. The Big Ben is itself very large & as it seems in picture. it looks even larger .From the bridge towards London eye... its a good walk,
a wonderful expereince to take the trip to the top. fantastic to see the workings and be so close to Big Ben when it strikes. Worth trying to get on the tour.
Great. Very impressive. Good tour. Close to train station and other attractions. Easily accessible. Good coffee shop.

Always Stunning. Whenever I am walking around the Westminster area and I look up and see this clock I am always mesmerized by it since it is so beautiful. Make sure to be near the clock when it chimes on the hour.
Grandiose. Coming out ou the London Unrground you can imagine the awe of seeing the big clock tower reaching for the sky as you remain jaw dropped on the side walk.
Wow, must do event. Wow, it's amazing experienced to visit London city & to hangaround in these areas. You can take lots of amazing pictures with various background to share with your friends.

Oh, Ben!. I have seen the famous clock tower so many times, but it still beckons me to take more photos! I always try to be there at the top of the hour so that my students will hear the famous Westminster chimes and that unmistakable gong! Not another one like it!

Iconic Site. Big Ben is a must see if you go to London. I went to see it near the Westminster Abbey side of it. We went in the morning, so it was not very crowded. And to those who says "it's just a clock" clearly do not know the history behind it. It was built in 1858, and it's simply amazing to me that it was transported by horse and carriage a few miles and then over the London Bridge-being that it weighs over 3 and a half tons. So when you go to London and see both the Big Ben and the London Bridge, imagine what it would have looked like in 1858.

Big Ben - so much around. Tourist to London cannot leave the place without seeing Big Ben. View from every angle is good with building glitters in gold color, nice overall architecture and famous clock at top. If you are at the other side of the West Minister bridge to Big Ben, you get an amazing full view. In the same premises, you can see statues of leaders of Mahathma Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, Churchill and Abraham Lincoln. Walk few 100 metres to view West Minister Abbey. There is another building nearby - which I guess is Dean's yard and it is also very beautiful. Downing Street then to Buckingham Palace and Trafalgar Square can be reached by walk. You also get good views of Big Ben from London Eye and Trafalgar Square or National Gallery. During the New year celebration, this is the place above which world famous fireworks happen. Nearest station Westminister. If you walk down across the Westminister bridge towards London Eye, you will have lot of eateries.

Wonderful experience. Was lucky to go to the top of Big Ben courtesy of Cllr Gordon Birtwistle MP his staff arranged the visit we were in the bellfry when it struck 5pm an experience not to be missed must be fitish to walk up the 315 steps

It's Big Ben, What Did You Expect?. Not sure if I'm supposed to be reviewing the bell, the clock tower, or the entire building, but most people associate the Big Ben with the tower, I guess. Both the good and the bad here is that it's exactly what you expect, and have seen on countless photographs of London. There is little more to add in terms of what it is, looks like, etc.One real tip though: come in the afternoon. You will want to take pictures for sure, and there is one direction where you can stand and take pictures: the western direction. In the morning, when the sun is in the East, your pictures won't come out very well. That or you will need to squeeze into the sidewalk next to the bridge and take a picture near an iron fence.

Crowded but a must. A well visited and much spot on on time landmak of London and the Thames River. With all cameras pointed at him is one of the most photographed place. Nice to see you again Big Ben .It can get really crowded arround but with a selfie stick problem solved!
THE Amazing Big Ben. Amazing architecure, beautiful landmark, something you can't miss in London. Amazing, like the whole city!

One more thing checked off my "must-do list". Ever since I was a child, I have always wanted to see Big Ben. I must have taken about 100 pictures from various angles while I visited. I would suggest viewing it in the day and evening. It is a completely different view during the night and day.

bing bong. it is an icon isn't it we were so priviliged to see this wonderful and historic monument in the flesh as it were. As expected packed out with visitors from all around the world, good old England.
One of the best places. What can I say? Nothing can compare to the beauty and the monumental sculpture of this building. Simply the best!

A point of reference that sounds lovely every hour. A iconic visual, an important landmark and a graceful structure. A stroll around the Thames, a feel of the parliament, the leisure along the streets are all enjoyable.
Lovely Clock Tower. Beautiful architecture and very well preserved clock tower, never seen one so attractive. The carvings were very emaculately done.
As Big Ben Tolls. Great visit regrettably the intersection is such a busy place that during the day you just can't appreciate the bells.

Wow. We didn't do the full inside tour but just the view from outside was breathtaking. The train station is across the street which is convenient & if you got down just a bit there are some wonderful pubs.

My Favourite Thing to See in All of London. Probably the most recognizable attraction in London, but it is also my favourite. It's nice to take a walk along the Houses of Parliament to see the rest of the building, and I always enjoy hearing Big Ben chime.

Big Ben's Big Picture Opportunity. Big Ben is another iconic building that looks great during the day and after dark. Last year I took pictures of it while cruising on the Thames and this trip we photographed it as the sun was going down. It is a superb building and a central focus for all tours to London. I'm sure you will enjoy the opportunity to see it.

A London classic. I have never before been so taken by a clock. it's a wonderful thing and epitomises London to me...sitting next door to the magnificent Houses of Parliament, it's a true London landmark.
wonderful. It is very wonderful especially when it sounds. When you go there in the Westminster bridge definitely you will enjoy
A timeless classic. Big Ben is a sight to behold from the land, from the river, or from the London Eye. What a beautiful, historic structure. Don't miss it.
was Amazing. i loved after have wanting to see it my whole life the wait was worth it you should definitely go when you gan was worth the 23 hour flight
Love the chimes. We were lucky enough to be right at Big Ben when the chimes rang out. It's so wonderful to finally see some of the things you read about in travel and history books.
What a view. Architecture was amazing. I would go back and just stare at it. I loved it. Just wish you could go in.

Now I know what it feels like to look at London from the Queen Elizabeth's Tower - holding the Big Ben Bell. See the 4 clock faces, the small clock and the really big bell. What's not to like. Hearing the hour stuck whilst being alongside the bell shakes your soul
Nice. We had a great view of the big ben because of Adrian and our private car hire, he took us around London, fantastic

Pretty cool but still just a big clock. Big ben is cool and i understnad all the history but still it is just a big clock and the tour we did was crowded, i enjoyed more looking at it from the outside, wthout all the crowds of people

admire the view.. This is one of the best icons that any tourist should visit, If you come a long way and don't visit this place then there is something that needs fixing. be sure to see this before you go go. there is some great pubs just across the way so you can sup pints and admire the view.
That's Big Ben Alright!. For someone who dreams of London, the first time you see it it takes your breath away. And the second, and third....So iconic. Wouldn't be a visit to London without it!

ITS A CLOCK!! (And a GRAND ONE at that!!). Everyone thinks Big Ben is parliament, just as they believe the Tower Bridge is the "London Bridge" (as in the children's rhyme)! Silly Americans! This clock is incredible, and just across from it, along near the Westminster Bridge there is a massive bronze statue of Boadicea the Celtic warrior Queen! Don't miss it. Check out info here: http://www.londonarchitecture.co.uk/Building/762/Boudica-Statue.php

Great Visit and Tour, One of the Must See's When Visiting. Of course is the iconic landmark of London, so every visitor needs to visit for photo's and such. Is very interesting to walk around and look at the facility and the sheer size of it. Is usually very crowded with sightseers and traffic is very busy around, so need to be careful and watch for people and cars, is best during nice weather, as you can roam around and see more.

Worth a visit if in London. Everyone needs to go and see Big Ben if they are in London. The street on the way to Big Ben is littered with people taking photos with the famous clock in the background. If you ever visit, this is a must!
Bong! Bong! Bong!. Love love love Big Ben! From seeing this famous piece of historical architecture from the hotel window to visiting up close and personal. Captivating!
Excellent. This is a very nice tour although pretty crowded......... Big Ben is an incredible place with extremely interesting history... love to visit ....recommend...

Go and get your pic it's a must. London..... Home of a million touristy shots and this is up in the top 5 Not to be missed.... Iconic and terrific .... Hang around if it's close to the hour hear the old chap bell

Wow. Go and sit on the grass outside Big Ben in the sun it's lovely, and when it strikes it's lovely. Lots of sight seers and people taking photos, but the roads around Big Ben are very busy so stick to the crossings please
Big ben. I saw big Ben from outside, as I was on my way to London eye.I don't know if we can go inside the building or not. May be I will give one more visit.

Awe inspiring. It's just beautiful to see so much history. The architecture is divine and the bell tolling on the hour brought a smile to our faces every time. A must see for a London visitor in my opinion.
A must see!. An iconic location to go and take a few pictures when in London. It's something that I have wanted to for years!

Clock Tower. Big Ben is a very recognisable landmark in the centre of London. It is one of the many icons of London.The Elizabeth Tower is the name of the famous clock tower in which the clock and the big bell are situated..the name big ben actually refers to the bell and not the clock as most people think. Tours are only availabe to UK citizens. However just to look at the clock and tower is a must and ofcourse get a selfie with it in the background.
must see even if touristy. a place that you just have to see. it is the quintessential bit of London. call home when it is about to strike 12 lol its just great

Awesome. Seriously see this icon at night. Amazing. Big Ben is an icon of London. If you have time see it at night from the other side of river and then walk across bridge and get photos on the way of bridge. Amazing.

Impressive and majestic. Maybe it's one of the favorite tourists' spot in London. Its majestic tower along with the parliament makes this one of the most visited spots in Europe. I love the architecture and the place it's located, not far away from the Westminster Abbey and along the Thames, just a few hundred meters from the London Eye. A must-see in London!

Famous tower and clock. It would be really fun to get inside, but unless you are a British citizen you cannot do that. Otherwise, you can enjoy from all different angles outside. My favorite one if from the south side of Thames to the right of Westminster Bridge. No crowds there and you get a nice view of Big Ben and Parliament.
Just Wow. It had been a long time since I last visited London and Big Ben is still as breathtaking and makes me proud to be British.

Surprisingly quieter than expected.. Having travelled to Middle eastern countries and experienced the call to prayer several times a day, I expected to chimes of Big Ben to echo around the streets of London creating a similar feeling of joy. Surprisingly though the actually "dongs" are not that loud, to say you have the hourly, half hourly and quarterly "dongs" you don't hear it that much unless your very nearby.It's a magnificent building and a must visit. Good luck getting a decent picture of it though. My attempt was poor lol

A must visit. Big Ben is one of the most popular places to visit in London, take the underground to Westminster Station and it is 2 minutes away, a great photo opportunity, you surely will not be disappointed, go see for yourself
intresting. Really interesting I have always been interested in big Ben and it is more breathtaking when you actually see it I would recommend to anybody
Good to see u, Ben. Had a guided tour of Parliament and lots of opportunities to see Big Ben. Obviously u just see it, no need to buy tickets or anything...

In the evening sun the tower looks golden . Must see, good to combine with London Eye, House of Parliament.
Big Ben is the bell, the tower is the Elisabeth Tower. Good for a quiz question.
In the evening sun the tower is amazing. You can not visit.
great. the hallmark of the city . just excellent. more than I expected. don't miss it. totally recomended. just great

Favorite of London. I love big ben. Went in the day and the night, both show a different but equally beautiful side of ben. Its much bigger than I thought it would be, and the whole area is great to see many specialties of London.
Beautiful. The icon of London. It is lovely! You can't go to London without visiting Big Ben! Lovely location also. Great place to walk around and stop as you like.

Big Ben and the Elizabeth Tower. Such a familiar scene, and a visit really brings it alive. A one hour tour of he Elizabeth Tower which houses Big Ben can be booked through your MP. You go right to the clock and the bells. Highly recommended.

London, England. I enjoy viewing the Big Ben Clock from a distance. It was so crowded on the Bridge that day; you could barely move. I could not get close enough to go inside the Clock. I not sure of the fee.

Beautiful. beautiful tower and clock. What can you say? It's everything you have read about all your life. We took pictures from 20 different angles. Don't waste the time trying to get close. Get far back and zoom

Went at 12 especially to hear it chime !. Iconic landmark of London ! A must photo opportunity.....can't enter it though.
Just behind this is the Houses of Parliament.
What's not to like?. I like everyone I know called Ben and this bell is no exception. Go and listen to it strike 12 and try and find some politicians to put two hooves up at.
Flying visit. Only saw this massive building from the outside but wish we could have spent more time there truly spectacular
Great . My son was fascinated with big Ben every time he saw it on TV and was delighted to see it up close great

Seeing Big Ben. Amazing to see Big Ben and estimated abbey my husband very impressed as his first time to London .
We stayed nearby where we had a view from our window
Quite hard to get in abbey with queues

Go At Noon. As many have said Big Ben is worth seeing. If you go around noon you can get an amazing video of the bells sounding for the longest amount of time. Can be busy in the afternoon but around noon usually isn't that busy. Also a very quick walk, not even 5 minutes, to the Churchhill War Rooms and Westminster Abbey and London Eye.
Must see. Must see amazing chimes every hour New Year's Eve must be amazing here. Lots of tourists and stalls around to buy gifts must visit.
On a sunny day. Go here on a sunny day for great views and photo opportunities. I believe it is only open to uk residents? Best to check out the website before hand.

Big Ben - every visitor needs a selfie with Big Ben.... Because is such an icon of London, a visitor simply must stop briefly at Big Ben for at least a photo... Near by are the Churchill War Rooms, Parliament, Downing Street, West Minister Abbey and many other attractions. Unless you are stopping for other interesting attractions, this really is just a quick stop.
Really pretty. We were bummed because if you are not a UK citizen you are not allowed inside. Aside from that its a beautiful thing to picture.
Trademark of London. I would say this is a Trademark of London identity. Thousands of people visit this place every day, take photos, spend time to view its beauty and creature.

Big Ben Shines on the River. This is a must see on any Tour. If you start your morning with a two hour tour at The Tower of London, follow the Thames westward as it meanders past St. Paul's and the London Eye. You will see and Hear Big Ben and then continue on the Westminster Abbey and Trafalgar Square.

Wish they'd open tours up to Non-UK citizens?. Fantastic clock tower - no mistake, but we all know the name "Big Ben" is actually the BELL - not the tower yes? You can actually climb the tower and get up behind the clocks riggings - but alas not if you're a foreigner like me, so it's long zoom pictures from the ground.... again and again......

Clock of the clocks!. Some of the reviewers on here may not appreciate this iconic land mark in London, some may think it is disappointing, some may think otherwise, well for me, it is awesome!I had the privilege to visit the Elizabeth Tower, aka, Big Ben Tower. This tour was arranged through my MP Kate Howe and it took just 6 months to take place, that's how busy they are.To have the experience of climbing 356 stone steps into the clock tower, listen to the chimes and bangs of each hour was just great!It is 156 years old and the bell inside the tower is actually called Big Ben 2 as the first one cracked and had to be melted into another bell.If you do live in London, ask your MP to book a visit for you, it does take time but let me tell you, it is well worth the wait.

I never cease to enjoy the site of this tower. . In August 2015 I took my friend, who was visiting from Australia, to see this tower and the adjacent sites. As a Londoner I always enjoy returning to these truly historic locations but it was great to see an overseas visitor take such joy in viewing this famous building and enjoy hearing the world famous chimes. If possible, visit in sunlight so thatcher can see the hold at the top of the tower glistening and in its full glory. Exit at Westminster tube station to see this building and if possible aim to be there on the hour to hear the full set of chimes.

Loved it. My family and I visited London simply because our 4 year old daughter wanted to see Big Ben in real life! I was worried we would get there and she would be disappointed, after all its just a big clock! But luckily I was wrong, she loved it! We took the tube to get to Big Ben which is directly outside the exit of the tube station, it was brilliant walking out and the first thing we see is Big Ben towering over us. Made our daughters day :)

Iconic part of London. truly a major landmark for London and the UK. Does not under perform. Truly iconic. Nothing to dislike, just look and think what has gone on there for so long. All the history. Of course Big Ben is the bell not the tower, but everyone thinks of the tower.
Iconic London. Great for a photo opportunity (although really difficult to actually get!). If possible see at night and day as you get a very different view.

A classic . So I have passed Big Ben countless of times via the Big Bus Tour or just living in London. However there is nothing like coming right here to see exactly how grand the clock is and how beautiful the architecture is.
W O W. Houses of Parliament if you get a chance to have a trip around with a Guide it is well worth the cost, Big Ben is well worth seeing and photographing
The Big Ben. One of the wonders of London and UK. You cannot go to UK without seeing the Big Ben! It is so magical and we cannot miss a selfie with it! Tic Toc Big Ben!

A Must See. A must-see iconic site in London. It's hard to believe how large it is until seeing it in person. We saw it as part of a bike tour and I'm glad we did; it was neat learning fun facts and history of the famous Big Ben!

Big ben. What an extraordinary building. Big Ben was spectacular. Parliament building was really cool looking. Especially if you are into architecture. The way they did it really makes it nice looking
Everyone Loves It!. If you are from the UK, contact your MP for a tour inside the clock. It is even more interesting! Outside, it is iconic.

London IS the Big Ben. "Big Ben" is the familiar nickname for the Great Bell of the clock tower (hight:100 m) at Palace of Westminster. A must to see. Beautiful view from Westminter bridge.
Tube stop: Westminster.

A must to visit when in London. Note that Big Ben refers to the Bell inside the clock tower not the tower itself, which is actually called Elizabeth Tower. Whilst there you can also go and visit Westminster Abbey. The interior of the tower is not open to overseas visitors but UK residents can arrange tours through their MP but these have to be arranged a long time in advance. Most visitors are content just to take pictures from the outside.

Big Ben. You can see Big Ben almost from every were so you can take some nice pictures. The attraction is nothing spectacular but is one of the symbols of London. Worth visiting night and day. The metro station is next to the building,
Big clock.. Don't go to London expecting too much from Big Ben. If you are an architect and nerdy maybe the buildings can really turn you on. But at the end of the day, Big Ben is a big clock.
Disappointing.. I found this highly disappointing. You can see more of it on tv. It's something you see driving by and that's all you'should do.
Have to take photo. Either on a bus or from the road or from a top floor cafe. Classic London. Much better if sun is out. Looks dull without light reflecting on stone
One of the most beautiful buildings in the World. I love this building so much that every time I go to London I need to stand across from it and just enjoy contemplating it.....it's unique!!
Seeing Big Ben is totally amazing!. Stayed downtown London, not far from Big Ben and it can be seen from all around the city. So worth the trip to see such a historic icon.

Beautiful History!. Words cannot describe seeing this building in person. You don't realize how big and beautiful it really is until you are there. We walked up in the afternoon so the sun was shining right on the clock tower making it seem almost magical.

Iconic and world class. I live in London and seeing Big Ben (which is the name of the bell) is one of my favourite London landmarks. Very awesome and great for photo opportunities. Try walking across the bridge and down by the London Eye for stunning shots of Big Ben with the Houses of Parliament, stunning. Can get very busy.

Amazing. Cor what a bell, Big Ben is what an amazing clock tower many steps which are small so need to be careful.
Poor Emily your got we women the vote but it's a wonder you were not driven mad by the enormous bells.
Well kept a true feast for your eyes.
steeped in history. Amazing architecture, be sure to look up or you can miss the beauty around London. We took a sight-seeing tour then a boat which took us up the Thames...all for one price.
My daily walk home. Walking past Big Ben on the way home from work is a truly impressive experience. Despite working in the area I can't help taking regular photos. Beautiful!
Iconic. You have to see it. It is THE sight of London - and the bongs go right through you. A fantastic view alongside the river.
Great for selfie photos!. There is an area of grass which is the perfect spot for taking selfie photos with Big Ben! You won't be the only one :-)

Must see when in London!. A must see when visiting London. The best place to get the most amazing picture with Big Ben, Westminster and a typical British phone booth is opposite Parliament Square. Best angle.

Gothic in Globalized Setting. The foot traffic is crushing, especially at the bridge,which is also the entrance to the Underground. The clock is worth gazing at, especially through a camera telescope lens.The curio-shops and their owners are exuberant sellers and do not have the British reserve, which makes the entire scene unreal - easy to lose sight of the British setting and mistake it for Carnival

We climbed to the top to hear the bell.. We contacted our local MP who arranged for us to climb to the top of the tower and listen to the bell being rung at 13:00. It was a fantastic once in a lifetime experience. The only thing I would say is the climb is a bit scary up a spiral staircase with a low barrier. We made it up to the top, got a certificate and climbed back down.

Great photos from every angle. It doesn't seem to matter where you stand, as long as Big Ben is in the background, you're going to get some great photos. If you walk past on a Sunday afternoon there are hardly any crowds.

Icon for London people. a little bit disappoint as it is in fact just a normal clock lol. However, you should see it once in your lifetime. The surrounding area is quite crowded so it is hard to take good picture during daytime

Great. Can't go to London and not visit Big Ben. Fab view from a distance, can take some really lovely photos. Make sure to visit day and night if you can, its very different in the dark. I have never visited London before until May half term even though im from the UK - its nice to see some iconic buildings you see on TV. Very busy around this location with all the tourists and of course the London eye being round the corner. I recommend seeing this at night. I don't know if you pay to go right up near it, we just walked along the street.

London's icon. Big Ben to me represents all that is London, great architecture and history. If it's your first time to London, travel to the Westminster tube station, when you walk out Big Ben is right in front of you.

European Wonderland Travel. This was a great looking tower with four clocks all around at ninety degrees to each other. It is imposing as there are no tall buildings blocking its view from the River Thames side. We had a better view when we crossed the Westminster Bridge to the other side for pictures.
Crowded. I was there early May and many many tourist. Other times might be better. Close to walking distance to other attractions. Very good.
So impressed.. great photo shots. Impeccable architecture. I loved this and the imaginative photographers who were doing selfies, whilst pinching the top of Big Ben...!!!

Can't miss it!. What better way to start your visit in London than visiting Big Ben. We caught the tube from Green Park and as soon as you come up from underground, there it is, in all its' glory! It is a photo op just waiting to happen. You can hear it chime from pretty far away and it is a great landmark for orienting yourself around that area.
Big Ben. Nice architecture. The whole structure is simply magnificent. If you want to take a nice picture of it, you will need to stand a distance away in order to capture the beauty of it.

Lovely architecture. Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament are designed really well and are an iconic sight to Britain. This building can be seen from the bridge near by and is lovely to take pictures of. Me and my family went down for a short break in the autumn and it was lovely to see at that time of year though I'd only imagine it'd look better in the winter. Overall it is a must see when going to London or visiting the UK just because its so iconic.

An Icon of London. Well, I can say that its not as tall as I thought, but it's an amazing site too see either from the bridge or from the park. If you have time, sit on the grass and take it all in. Its a must see when visiting London.

Can't miss the clock!. What would be London without Tower Bridge and Big Ben!? Absolutely MUST SEE once you are in London.Be careful. Amount of the tourists might be a bit too much for somebody who doesn't like crowd, but it's London's nr 2 hottest attractions!

A great British icon. What's more to say....a very touristy place. Make sure you are there when it rings and take lots of pictures. Avoid those who are in fancy dress and try to take pictures with you - they will ask you for your money later on! Also, if you're a first-time tourist, go twice. Big Ben at night is different from Big Ben in the daylight.

Icon of London. Location: Same building with House of Parliament (Palace of Westminster).Train: Westminster StationAt first I thought Big Ben is an independent clock tower. After visiting, I only realised it is part of House of Parliament, which was off limits. The magnificent clock was still nice to see from outside the gate. If you do notice, the Gothic-styled clock tower does not bear "X" for 10, instead it has "F" on the clock face. The clock still works and chimes every fifteen minutes. A true icon of London that one would not miss.

Best to get a few shots . When you come out of Westminster underground station, Big Ben is right in front of you, the perfect moment to start taking photos. The area around Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament can be packed with tourists, so best to keep moving while taking photos. We did a loop around the square and back towards the station.

Classic clock. No comparison to BB ! Enjoy it from afar whether on land or river. Most people look for a great photo location and we had ours from the grass area next to Wesminster Abbey and Parliament .

Elizabeth Tower. ***English review below***Zweifelslos DAS Wahrzeichen der Stadt. ABER: der Turm, den man da sieht, heißt nicht Big Ben! Es ist der Elizabeth Tower, dessen schwerste Glocke Big Ben heißt. Hieß früher Clock Tower, im Zuge des Diamantenthronjubiläums 2012 aber umbenannt und ist Teil des Westminster Palastes.No doubt, it’s London’s landmark. BUT: the tower’s name is NOT Big Ben. It’s Elizabeth Tower whose biggest bell’s called Big Ben. Used to be called Clock Tower but has been the Elizabeth Tower since 2012 due the Queen’s diamond jubilee. It’s part of the Palast of Westminster and a must-see.

Big Ben is the bell which provides the 'bongs' on the hour.. There is a reason it is called 'Big Ben'. It is officially the Great Bell of Elizabeth Tower (the former Clock Tower was renamed Elizabeth Tower in honour of The Queen on the occasion of her Diamond Jubilee in 2012). It is the bell which sounds the famous 'bongs' on the hour every hour.The name 'Big Ben' now also means for most people the clock with its four huge faces, but if you believe it refers to the whole tower I am afraid you are wrong.The reason for the name? Some say it is after Benjamin Caunt, a famous Heavyweight boxer but most agree it is after Sir Benjamin Hall who, as the first Commissioner of Works, oversaw the installation of the bell.This does seem likely as his name is inscribed on it. The bell is over 7 feet tall and over 9 feet wide. It was cast in 1858 at Whitechapel Bell Foundry (which I am due to visit and review soon) and weighs over 13 tons. It replaced an ill-fated earlier bell cast in Stockton-On-Tees which cracked beyond repair during testing.I saw the tower and clock from the front top deck of a routemaster bus yesterday evening and it is tastefully lit at that time of day. I was also close up to it during a recent private visit to the Palace of Westminster. British citizens, after applying through their Member of Parliament and waiting patiently for several months, may take a tour involving the climb to the top of the tower to see the bells and the interior and workings of the clocks.

You "have to do" this one but you need to look around carefully to make it worth the trip. Big Ben is actually the bell at the top of the tower so you can't see it, but you can see the Elizabeth tower named after our beloved queen. The Palace of Westminster itself is an Iconic building, photographed from every angle and when you see it yourself it will look familiar for sure and maybe a bit disappointing as you already know it. BUT don't give up yet, like all of London, there are hidden gems waiting to reward the detective tourist. Walking over Westminster bridge to the South bank of the river Thames is worth it for the different view. Better is to try walking to the right hand end of the Palace of Westminster (where the Lords do their Lording over the rest of us) where you will find the Victoria Tower gardens. This pretty little park contains some amazing statues from the British past. There's the Slave Memorial (the Brits started and ended the slave trade) and the statue of Emmeline Pankhurst leader of the Suffragettes movement which secured the right to vote for women. Or the statue by Rodin of the Burghers of Calais. What a story, around 1347 it is said that England's King Edward III, after a victory at the Battle of Crécy, besieged the port of Calais in France, Philip, the King of France, ordered the city to hold out at all costs. He then failed to lift the siege, and starvation eventually forced the city to beg for surrender or die.King Edward offered to spare the people of the city if any six of its top leaders would surrender themselves to him to be executed. He demanded that they walk out wearing nooses around their necks, and carrying the keys to the city and castle and 6 of them actually did it - would anyone do that today I wonder... It was this moment, and this poignant mix of defeat, heroic self-sacrifice, and willingness to face imminent death that Rodin captured in his sculpture. By the way, there are other casts of this same scene - would be a great project to research all of them. . .Right in front of the Palace of Westminster is another green space called Parliament Square and if you can brave the traffic to get over there you will find more interesting statues from the history of Britain. Look out for the big man with the walking stick - accompanying him you will also find Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Ghandi, Jan Smuts (father of South Africa) and many more characters from British history whose names we honour and remember for their contribution to our country.Located at the start of Westminster bridge, over the road from the bell tower, ladies shouldn't miss the 1850s bronze sculpture commemorating Queen Boudicca (also known as Boadicea), queen of the British tribe known as the Iceni, who led a savage but unsuccessful revolt against the Romans in AD 60-61. An interesting local legend has it that Boudicca is buried beneath platform 10 at King's Cross Station - right next to that other famous platform there . . . .Note also in this area the beautiful Westminster Abbey where you will find the tombs of the Kings and Queens of England - how small they were. Look also for Poet's Corner featuring Robert Burns, Lord Byron, Charles Dickens, George Eliot, T. S. Eliot, Thomas Gray, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Samuel Johnson, John Keats, Rudyard Kipling, Jenny Lind, John Masefield, John Milton, Laurence Olivier, Alexander Pope, Percy Bysshe Shelley, Thomas Shadwell, William Shakespeare, Alfred Lord Tennyson and William Wordsworth to name most of them!Take a quiet moment here to imagine over a thousand years of history flowing around this place.If you have energy left then walk along Whitehall to Trafalgar Square and eat in the outstanding National Gallery. What a great day this is.

The Clock. Big Ben has all ways been an attraction due to the history of The Parliament Buildings, But the clock its self has a very interesting history including the look of it and its actual dimensional allusion.I actually worked on the clock some time ago and got to know it reasonably well, for example did you know that each elevation if you draw a strait line across it, is nearly 4m in depth to the face , a very deceiving appearance to say the least. The clock actually works each face individually despite the fact the time faces are all ways correct to the centimetre, the timing used to be with old one penny coins , with a 24 hour watchmen ,who used to sit in the face room of the tower, with ear defenders for the Bell LOL.

BIG BEN. Big Ben is superb iconic and a great photo shot for the UK. Lots of things going on here - Night time is a must as it lit up with various colours on the tower.

beautifull in sunny day, rainny day... Always. This is probably one of my favourite buildings of London, soo beautiful! and doesn't matter where you are you can take a very nice picture of it, LIKED it!

Wonderful historic visit. It was an unique experience to visit Big Ben at Westminster. There are a small number of tours each week for UK residents only. You have to book via your MP. The guide takes you 334 steep steps up the spiral staircase (so you have to be pretty fit to do this!) to the top of the tower where you are taken behind the four dials of the clock, to see the movement and to see the bells. You hear the clock chime and strike the hour and are provided with ear plugs for this! Our guide was one of the clockmakers who maintains and services Big Ben clock and he gave a very detailed account of the history of the clock and its manufacture and mainenance. It was a privilege to go behind the scenes. Excellent visit. I now want to go again.

The little known fact.... Big Ben is actually the bell, the tower has a different name. Go on a sunny day and see the Thames river stretch out before you. Westminster Cathedral is next door where Kate and William got married.
ben. big ben is awesome. we travelled from there up the river to the tower of London & back again. we walked all around that area before going to the Palace. we had a fantastic day

Don't miss. If you like the whole sense of democracy that Britain conveys, a visit to the tower which houses Big Ben the clock, along with a visit to Parliament House of Commons is a must. Like everything in London, there is a cost, but you can see where the high cost of maintenenace for amazing structures like these is required.Nothing beats a family photo with Big Ben in the background or a look at the House of Commons, the home of Democracy.
One of those things. Big Ben was just what you would expect - one of those places you always wanted to see for real - landmark of London and very exciting to view

Walk across the bridge and take a photo. Walk underneath the towering clock and do the same. Walk, that's the key to enjoying this part of London. Packed with people from all over the world and locals going about their day. I found it quite satisfying.

Trip to top of Elizabeth tower. If you are British resident you can write to your local MP and ask them to arrange you visit to Elizabeth tower. I had to wait a month to response from Mp and then another month for arranged date but it was worth it. Many people see big ben but not many knows that you can go on top for free. Only about 10 people go with you and guide. You will be told whole history and how big Ben works. You will even see and hear it from the inside. My favourite part was to touch number 6 and now i can show off by telling people i touched it whilst they didn't even know it's possible. However, i didn't like steps to the top and i am not complaining that there isn't lift but stairs are so plain that if i didn't know where I am then i would think that I'm climbing some council tower block. However, worth a visit for amazing views and seeing clock and bell from the inside.

Big Ben - Synonymous with City of London. Cross seeing Big Ben off of my bucket list!! Impressive site on the cityscape of Westminster! Easy to get great photos from numerous angles.I was astonished to learn that Big Ben is actually the nickname for the bell that is in the clock tower at the north end of the Palace of Westminster. The Clock Tower is officially known as the Elizabeth Tower, renamed in 2012 to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II. The tower holds the second largest four-faced chiming clock in the world and was completed in 1858. Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament set scenically along the Thames River. Very impressive and in close proximity to Westminster Abbey, the London Eye, and Thames River. Loved this beautiful area when on a walking tour of London.

so beautifully done. last time in lyndon one of the most impressive attractions that i have ever seen..

nice scenery. it was nice however was not amazing, i mean, nice view and all but thats it. i liked the fact that you have very good transportation to get there from like everywhere in london, its clearn allright, and has lots of places to eat nearby.

Elizabeth Tower - Big Ben. Went up the tower on 18 January 2013 - it was a very snowy day but being intrepid we made it anyway. Snow was coming through the openings and settling on the area near the bell. Made for a different viewpoint. Although it's a long way up the guide stops regularly on the different levels to give information about the tower etc. No photography. Cameras and loose objects are all placed in lockers as if an object were dropped it could kill someone lower down the stairway. I would recommend. A long way up but any reasonably fit person could do it.
A must see. Great place to take pictures and right in the middle of many historical attractions. Beautiful views of parliment, and in the heart of the city.
Big clock big time. At night this place turns beautifull and romantic I been here with a guy I meet and was lovely,romatic..Amazing place in night

Great place to visit if you don't know what time it is. It's a great big clock, I hear it is fairly accurate. A lot of people trying to get places around it so, I dunno, maybe they are late for something.

Queen Elizabeth Tower and Big Ben. An interesting tour which I took with my daughter which had to be booked with our local MP. Over three hundred steps which you have a break half way up and get the history of the tower. Very good guides and would recommend to take ear plugs as they had run out of free ones.Did have to wonder if they used the defibrillator which was in a window on the way up. Great views from the top of the bell tower and stood next to Big Ben for the 11o'clock chimes.

Iconic but could be more.. Big Ben is well known and as such is a must see. Only thing is, it is a clock, albeit a famous one. I spent all of 5 minutes on Big Ben. Took pictures but with so many people in the area to take a clean shot.Note that we cannot climb up the tower if you are NOT a UK resident. This was a bummer.So we non UK people are left just to take pictures on the outside. A must see but not much of a big deal. Could be filed under must do but once.

Proper London landmark. Yes it is a big clock, but it's quite possibly in the top 3 of landmark thing to do in London.Great photo opportunity, nice area surrounding, better go at sunset. Do not miss it, it's like going to Rome and skipping on the coliseum.

It's not called Big Ben!!!. The Queen Elizabeth Clock Tower is what the clock tower is actually called. Our tour guide informed us of this (to the amazement of the whole group).It's unfortunate that you can't go inside the tower and do a visit unless it's organised by your local MP (which rules non-UK residents out!)
Wrong name. You can not see Big Ben - only hear it. Big Ben is the bell which strikes the hours. The Tower was St Stephen's tower, now called the Queen Elizabeth tower.
Photo op. Because who doesn't need a photo of Big Ben for their profile pic! Walking the city it is impossible to pass by without snapping a few photos.

Iconic and quick. One of those must have photographs and so easy to get to using the tube. Plus once you are finished with Big Ben you can easily navigate by footto many of the other postcard landmarks as well.

Visited the Parliament, climbed the bell tower as the clock hit 12 noon.. I visited the bell tower with a group I had taken to London in April several years ago. Big Ben is the name given the very large bell in the middle of the tower . There are smaller bells in the four corners of the tower. We were there in the bell room when the clock registered 12 noon. Our guide told us to stand by the outer walls and we would hear the bell (Big Ben) which would be heard in many locations around the world. We did, and it was truly an amazing experience.

Big Ben what a beautiful sight.. A visit to London would feel strange if I didn't go and see Big Ben, whether it's on foot, by London Bus or by boat from the River Thames or walking towards it from a stroll along Westminster Bridge, it's got to be done. I've visited Big Ben many times since my early teenage years, and each time is more special to me, with memories of my family past and present. Big Ben you are very special.
Surprising Detail. We discovered that " Big Ben" is NOT the name of the clock but the bells within the clock tower that chime periodically.

It's beautiful!!. I had always wanted to see the Big Ben in person. When we went to London to see this beautiful land mark it was so beautiful and much bigger than what I thought. One of my favorite land marks!! Can't wait to go back and see everything again. London is absolutely beautiful!!

Larger Than Life. I could see Ben from my hotel lobby and it was impressive.
After a few steps I was at the base of this icon. Wiggle your way around the throngs of tourists vying for selfie space.
Take the time to walk around all of the public spaces and if you are able, do the tour.
Amazing. The best and important clock tower. You can see it from many places in London, but to see it closer your eyes... Amazing!
Tick tock!. How can anybody say anything negative about big ben?! It's what makes London, London! Great to be stood right next to it as it starts chinning :)

Nice bell tower - but nothing more. This is a must see in London. In reality it is not more than a very nice bell tower. Unfortunately there is no chance to climb on it. However the entire area with Westminster, the abbey, Downing Street and Scotland Yard is worth to have a nice walk.

One of My Favorites. I am not really sure why Big Ben is one of my favorite landmarks in London, but it is. Maybe it is its size, maybe it is the location. But whatever the reason, I still enjoy seeing it even after my sixth trip to London.
Loved it. The colour of the building glistens in the sunshine almost gold in colour, it was great to see such a world wide renowned iconic building in a great area steeped in history

BIG Ben. The shear size of Ben is absolutely breathtaking. If you happen to be there at midnight like we were by chance, the lights of Ben turn off with the chimes going so loud you can feel them in your chest. It was truly an amazing experience and one I will never forget.

beautiful. Wounderfull site. Just waiting for the bell is worth the journey. I suggest going in winter to the ice staking ring then on the London eye where you can over see big Ben and the beautiful Christmas tree next to it .

Big Ben is just the name of the bell.... Right at 5:00 pm and Big Ben rang out the hours...Although Big Ben is the misnomer given to this tower by most...it is actually The Elizabeth Tower, the famous tower of Parliament. Big Ben is actually the nickname of the bell housed within the Elizabeth Tower - and Big Ben's official name is the Great Bell.Anyway, get there and see Westminster Abbey, the House of Commons, Palace of Westminster and even glimpse the London Eye from Westminster Bridge. Tube station right there!
Big Ben Stands Tall. The sight of this huge clock so high in the sky is most wonderful. Thames River so close by. Wonderful sight and the cost is FREE

A real landmark not only of London, but of a civilization. Big Ben is great and impressive. When you pass by it, be it day or late evening, you feel that it is not a common clock tower, but a unique eye witness of British and European civilization.

Impressive. Make sure you are there on the hour to hear Big Ben chime.
It is something you should include on your trip to London.
Big Ben is impressive to both see and hear.
Awesome. Came round the corner and there it was. Stunning building. Only seen on TV until now...so much history and architecture in this country to visit.

It's a clock and immense!. its a clock in a tower. Beautiful to look at and you can see it from far away. An iconic building in London. Next door to Westminster Abbey. There is nothing to dislike about Ben.

Iconic. You cannot visit London without gettin a photo of this!
Big Ben is amazing! I love the liver birds clock in liverpool just as much!
Get there just before the hour and hear the bing bongs
Amazing
Stereotypical London
Excellent photo opportunities
Amazing. Impressive! I took more pictures of Big Ben than of anything else, I was like I made it here and that was it. This is the first place I came to see upon arriving in London

Must See While in London. When you think of London, one of the first things that probably comes to mind is the historical landmark, Big Ben. I was blessed enough to visit Big Ben while I was in London, and I believe that it is something that you have to see.

Well worth a visit. My husband and I visited the Elizabeth tower a while ago, you do have to plan in advance, an achievement to climb all the steps, though not as difficult as I thought it would be. very interesting to see the working of the bells and the views, but wonderful to be able to walk around behind the clock faces, amazing.
The London Landmark. It's hard to miss this sight. Stop and take a photo. Its located next to Parliment, and a short walk from Westminster Abbey and the London Eye.

Excellent!. A national treasure! Something you dont want to miss if you're in the city of London.
Sensational. Absolutely astonishing. And its even better at night time, or early evening!!! It cannot be missed, a must see in London.
Annual trip. A wonderful museum, in a wonderful location. Have visited many times but need many more visits to see and appreciate everything there. It feels very user friendly too.
wow. we have never been hear before and we loved it the hole area was nice there was lots to look at and the hole experince was wow for us
this is london. Even when you were born in london is an amazing place full of life. The area is really nice Trafalgar Square, London Eye, Thames... just walk and enjoy

Grandios Building. Every one knows the mighty clock tower. It is very impressive to stand in front of the tower.
Insider tip:
You should visit this place in the morning between 8 - 10 o'clock. During this time it is not crowded there. You can use the possibility to take some really nice photos without hundreds of tourists on your photo.
Historical Landmark. Children cannot fail to be impressed by the iconic Big Ben! To see it in all its magnificent glory is very exciting.
Love. This was a must on our stop to London. We didn't go inside, but I felt it was okay that we didn't. I think it was very picturesque.

Stunning architecture.. Walking out of Westminster tube station to be greeted by Big Ben was a great experience. It's an iconic world building, and to see it up close gives you the full appreciation of the scale and detail of the architecture.

Iconic tour. we booked a visit through our local MP( I think this is the only way to gain access) which can take a couple of months to come through and you cannot choose your date precisely, but it is worth the effort to get the privilege to see Big Ben from the inside.Every time I walk past there now I always see all the crowds taking their photos and think "I have been up there"
Must see because it is the media icon. Whenever there is news about London, Ben ! appeared on TV screen, even if it doesn't attract me but it is one of the must see items before I died.

Must see in London!. A must see when visiting London. Amazing to finally see in real life what we have always seen in pictures. Many historical sights around the same walkable neighourhood. Walk around to see the fine details on the tower, building and clock. Remember to take lots of photos!!

Tourist spot. Nothing much to do around here, Other than it is just a tourist sot. Lots of tourists all around taking photos of the big ben at various angles. Iconic landmark so a must visit as well. Go when the weather is good
As expected, but a must do!. It's a must do! The best is to take a pictures next to the London Eye. This way you can capture most of Big Ben in a picture

Wonderful achitecture, amazing experience. The magnificent structure is opposite the Houses of Parliament and is one of the many fantastic landmarks in London.I was lucky enough to be given the opportunity to venture into the 154 year old tower. It was a steep 334 step climb to the top but well worth it! The clock is uber accurate and I was surprised to learn how simple the mechanics were behind such accuracy.A tour inside is must for every UK resident! Unfortunately, the tour is not available to non residents.
Take a picture..... Well - what is there to say: Snap a picture and get on with it. Do it the same day w/ Westminster Abbey, Downing Street 10 (nothing to see there besides a long range photo)

One of the things you must see up close.... The view is just breathtaking in this area with the river, london eye and other historical architecture all to be taken in during the walk of a few short blocks.

Historical part of london. Honestly i visited big ben due to its fame, and yes indeed the tower has good amount of details in its design, but i didnt find it very interesting. The experience for me was "a memorable photo shoot" thats all!!
Everyone should see Big Ben. This wonderful landmark should be visited by all British people. This famous "clock" is a must when visiting London!

Amazing in person. Went to the London Eye....a must see and must do in itself. Not being from the area I was surprised there was so much in the same area. Big Ben included. Smaller then I thought was made up for the big experience in seeing this up close and in person. History of many types and of many many years is present here and should be appreciated by all.

Plenty of Clock. Sound mate, plenty of clock there. It was about time that I went. Thought I'd better chime in with a review so you don't hear it second hand elsewhere. Don't be alarmed, this ain't no wind-up.

beautiful. loved seeing this iconic structure in all it's glory! very easy to find and to get amazing photos. great facts about the whole Thames river if you take the Red Rover City boat and the pier dock to board is right across the street from big ben

Nothing more than a display!. Well, it's located in the heart of London and surrounded by the fantastic other landmarks but on its own I was highly disappointed with Big Ben. Though it's nothing less than what should we expect but I was expecting much more than what we've seen in Bond movie. Its good if you just want to hang around in that area!

Magestic. Being at Big Ben was a wonderful experience. You know you are in London and all the fabulous history that surrounds it. There are so many great places to take photos of it, from all different viewpoints. We were lucky to be there on a clear, sunny day, allowing for some grand photos. The area is a bit crowded but very safe, festive neighborhood. There is a spot that is suppose to be the most popular photo taking spot near Big Ben and that is by a single red, traditional London phone booth. I was told it's the most photographed phone booth in London because you get a great shot of the phone booth and Big Ben in one shot. Sadly, this was pointed out to us after our visit, by a double decker tour bus operator. Nevertheless, we got wonderful photos of this glorious monument. Only UK citizens are allowed to go up, so that was not an option for us.

This is the time. great overlooking Westminster bridge,you can see the London eye and the Houses of ParliamentBig Ben, is also great light up at ugly, as is the London eye, and ahpgain Houses of Parliament, all in the same area of London, on the river Thames, well worth a visit

It was surprising!. When I got there I wasn't expecting the Big Ben. I actually took the subway to go to my London Eye experience. Went out of the station and started to go up to the stairs when I suddenly saw that imponent, beautiful monument. It was very touching for me and I felt inside the movies I've always wacthed on TV. The tricky part is to get a nice pic as the place was crawded and there is a very busy road crossing by.

Great photo stop!. Right next to Westminster Abbey. When you exit the tube, things are a bit crazy right at that intersection. You can't walk around the whole thing, so don't try like we did :) A great view is also from across the river, as you can see the whole thing.

You have to go see Big Ben..... I am giving Big Ben 5 stars just because I feel it is an attraction everyone needs to see while visiting London. It is free, you can take some cool pictures and move on. We were glad we saw it, and we have some great pics to show for it. Go check it out, it will not take you long and it will be worth it in the end.

nice place. Beg ben is nice place. I miss one thing. my grand son wanted to see it from inside. he wanted to see how the bell mechanics is and how it works but unfortunately there is no tour for visitor.

The big one. BIG BEN is the bell ,not the clock ,but we all associate the whole building etc as BIG BEN.This structure is probably one of the most photographed buildings in London ( quite rightly ) ,and is recognised throughout the world as Great Britain ,This is a MUST when in the capital.

Big Ben is the Great Bell Inside the Famous Clock Tower!. I want to help travelers out here. To experience Big Ben you would need to listen, for it is the great bell housed inside the famous clock tower which is part of the Houses of Parliament. It is a very busy area filled with tourists taking photos. We did the photo shoots and HEARD Big Ben and were happy to have experienced BIG BEN!
City's international symbol. Very prominent and well preserved. Makes a great picture to remember London by. Seen from both banks of the River and from the London Eye.

Wonderful iconic landmark. Beautiful view of Big Ben from across the Thames or viewed by boat. . Stunning to see and worth a visit. This is a popular attraction so get here early or late for some great sunset shots.
Great!!!. Worth every pic you have seen over the years. Splendid architecture !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Historic Sight.. Good piece of history. I have seen this picture for so long and to actual visited and take a picture on my trip was priceless.

Tick rock what an attraction. You only have to stand outside Big Ben for five minutes to witness hundreds of people taking photos of this magnificent attraction. Looking up with the sky behind is a treat, especially if the sun is setting, magical.
Very impressed. I was very impressed with Big Ben and I would highly recommend that you put it on your list of things to see whilst in London.
a must photo stop. although it started drizzling during our visit, it didn't stop us from taking that perfect picture moment in front of this worldwide historical landmark.

A must-see. Big ben is massive as well as outstanding. You'll enjoy in the daytime but its real beauty will unveil at night. During the day, you'll find a good spot on the trafic circle just in front of it to enjoy its view while being sat or laid.Just think to bring your meal if you come at midday. There's only one pub to eat. It is quick full and not really good value for money, even if the place is okay. Also, you'll find a supermarket just near the pub and just in front of Big Ben. But as you can guess, prices aren't the cheapest ones.
Not great. An icon of the London landscape, it's a must visit but move on quickly. It's at an extremely busy junction so get some quick pics and plan your next move
Beautiful. I loved the architecture in London. Everything is very classic and castle like. Like nothing you will ever see in the US.
BIG. It is all you would think it is. We stood and looked for a very long time. Listened to the chimes often.
Great to see. Was great to see as only seen before on TV had family photo with big Ben and children enjoyed seeing it to.

Loved Big Ben. Absolutely loved it - amazing to see. There was nothing I didn't like about it and would recommend it.

Childhood Refrain. The Big Ben is something that we ay have grown reading about, and hearing a lot about, from our childhood days. In that sense, a visit to this landmark is a redemption of sorts. The Tower itself is obviously impressive, and does full justice to its name and reputation
Big Ben. Beautiful old architecture. Just a walk across the Thames river. It does not Matter what your interests are this sight will take your breath away.

First thing to see in London. This was our very first stop when we got to London since for us, this is the no. 1 icon of this beautiful city. where time was born.... amazing architecture... grandiose... and a perfect back drop to click photos....view from London eye is great... a must see attraction in London!

a must , you did not go to London if you did not visit. as must popular turist attractions or landmarks it is always crowded but worth the wait , i recomend walking in the sorrounding areas

If you come to London, you will come here by all means. This area where historical buildings form a line is London itself.

A Great Landmark. Don't miss it! If you go to London without visiting the Big Ben, it would be very unwise!!! Its history and location is really captivating.
