So much detail . It's much better seeing it in person than on TV or a picture of it. So much detail and wasn't what I expected it to be! Would recommend to visit!
Smaller than you thought!. Nice to see but smaller than one would think. Wouldn't go out of my way to go but you get a good view from the London Eye.
Thrilling. A must see, a famous landmark or London. Try to be when its on the hour to hear the thrilling bells.

The Great Big Ben. You always stare the picture the tower from movies or picture, don't you? Yup, The Great Bell Big Ben. The Landmark of the England. Big Ben has become one of the most famous symbols and icon of the United Kingdom. Beside, the tower is often in the establishing shot of many films set in London from Hollywood to Bollywood. HahaThe clock inside the tower was the world's largest, because it was installed in the middle of the nineteenth century and is still the largest in Great-Britain. Unfortunately the clock tower is not publicly accessible. However, If you're looking for views over London, the London Eye, the Shard or the Monument are currently the best options. You can use the sightseeing bus to visit many places in the town.
A Really Nice Clock. It does stand out, and is iconic. If you have never seen it before it is a must go! As you walk up the stairs and you see it in front of you it does take your breath a way.

Good Atmosphere and great architecture. I have been there on my business London trip and enjoyed the city in the weekend.Big Ben is at the end of London Bridge and near to parliament house. Nothing special except the great architecture and beautiful atmosphere. A lot of tourist enjoys during weekend and visit this place. All the places, London Eye, London Bridge, Tower Bridge, Big Ben, Parliament house, Thames and many other
fantastic. this is a must see take a walk on to london bridge and admire the view, we even were there to hear the bells which is great to hear

Spectacular. A truly spectacular sight, we arrived at the tube stop for Westminster and walked up the steps and saw Big Ben, wonderful sight gleaming in the sunshine. Walk away from it over the bridge and get more great photos from a different angle. Well worth visiting.

a popular landmark. The tower and its clock are an institution. The entire area is really nice, where the House of Parliament, White Hall, many government buildings are located, and on the other side of the River Thames, where the London Eye wheel is place.

Westminster Bridge. Who can go to London and not see Big Ben. It is located adjacent to Parliament and Westminster Bridge. It can be seen from up and down the Thames and it is easy to spot London Eye.
Family time.. Seen this from Open top bus and if you are quick enough to get a good picture of it back and front. Buses stop in and around it. hop on/off.

Amazing. Yes one may have seen it umpteenth time in movies, pictures or videos but nothing can beat the experience that one can get watching it in front of their eyes. Lovely view. This makes for an amazing picture at night time when it is all lit up! It is worth taking the time to get a perfect shot from across the river!! You won't regret it!!

The Big Ben walk. The river Thames is the divide between the Big Ben, The Houses of Parliament and where one starts walking. There are benches along the walk to savor the moment and glimpses of the wonderful architecture so English and so imperial in nature. Look straight and London eye stands tall. The entire walk and view is memorable and a memory to cherish !

interesting historical experience. very interesting especially for people in london as tourist,history,culture,politics.ambiance,nostalgia everything in one place,,,,visiting London big ben is a must visit place

Impressive structure. We obviously tied this in with all the other tourist attractions in the area. The kids were quite excited to see it and we timed it well for hearing the chimes (which do sound very impressive). If you are in London this is a must see.

The Iconic London Landmark. Known throughout the world, Big Ben is a must for all visitors. Do go inside if you have the time. Worh a visit.. Good attraction indeed! lovely and cosy, and the bells ring so clearly :-) worth a visit even though it is always full of visitors :-)).
Fantastic View. This is one of the places that we had to go visit for the kids. We were very delighted and the kids were ecstatic.

Trade mark of london. Most of the time there is just too much people around as this is one of major attractions in London. Considering the period when this was actually built, it still is one of world greatest buildings

Huge!!. We were heading to have a look at Westminster Abbey, and got off a bus, then turned a corner and there it was!! Glorious sight. Probably one of the most photographed sights in the World. No wonder! This is the 3rd time I seen, and it never ceases to Amaze me.

Must see while in London. Big Ben was one of the attractions in London that we had to see and we were not disappointed. Charismatic View. We always see Big Ben in the TV and pictures, you will have a fantastic feeling when you reach there and have a close look. The whole Westminster Palace is a historical master piece of design and engineering work.

One of a kind. We enjoyed our visit to London and seeing Big Ben, amongst other sites there. It was a very busy day but we're still able to enjoy the atmosphere. Btw, on Sunday you can park on double yellow lines.
Very beautiful!!. I will never forget the first moment I saw the Big Ben! It is really beautiful! I can't explain by words... only be there and you will feel the same way!

Impressive Building .... ... although that's the name of the bell!

Iconic still. It was called BB because the bell ringer was named Ben, and hopefully it can tell time accurately. Great photo op.
A must to pass while in London. They should have infoboards of the bell and tower on the sidewalk do we could read about the history and correct names on "Big Ben".

Beautiful as expected!. It is indeed grande and beautiful as expected and as seen on the TV or pictures. The view is much better from the other side of the river which can capture the entire building.

You must see this if your in London!. I visited London for the first time so had to see Big Ben! Its a must! The area around it is so busy with people taking photos but it is definitely worth it. Fab architecture!

BIG ?. Need to change its name to medium Ben. I have to ask who would call the clock tower Big. The police need to move in and remove all the tricksters on the Bridge, that old game of trying to find the ball underneath the three cups.
Amazing. this building has amazing history and amazing architecture it's a big bit of art and it tells the time

Fantastic architecture. to stand and look is an amazing thing to do at this site. The building and clock tower is amazing. Try and see it at not as well. We could see the clock tower all lit up from our hotel and it was a feature in the skyline.

You have to.. If theres one place you have to have a picture, it has to be Big Ben. When the bell chimes its sends goosebumps down your spine. Fantastic monument.
I really had forgotten how beautiful London is.
Grand as expected. Big Ben was as magnificent as all of the pictures show. An iconic figure in the London Landscape and something not to be missed.

See it, but use other attractions to do so. Big Ben is an Icon. It is a must see. Walk by it as a detour to St. James Park. It is really not a sight unto itself.
Big Clock. Really big clock...just walked past it, but from the outside very impressive. Has some history behind it.
Astounding!. Big Ben is an incredible structure. I thought it was an incredible building and then I saw it at night when it was all lit up and it was stunning.

Watch out for people wearing costume. When you take pictures near this area, some people who wears costume will approach you and pretend to offer you taking pictures with them. Then they will ask (force) you for money in return.

Walk a little far to see the beauty of Architecture. Big Ben is surely the number one visitor spot for me. The architecture is so wonderful that its difficult to blink eyes. Walkable distance to few other sightseeing and easily accessible through tube.
I love you. I just love big ben, not really a lot to say other then its a privilege to see it outside my window every morning. one of my favourite land marks in London
Big and benny. This site was as expected: iconic, great photo spot, swarming with tourists. Only stay as long as you can stand the crowds.

Its 7'O Clock, Happy New Year. I just reached at evening 6:59 Pm infront of the Ministry of West Bridge and sudenly the Bell from Big Ban's famous watch made a new experience for me. Its fantestic to visit this place. The night view from London Eye to Big Ban is marvelus.
Noon. We were there around noon.It was amazing to watch the clock striking 12 at noon and hear the ringing sound of the bell.

Great big clock and it just looks all quality. Big Ben looks brand new. The colours in the clock and the gold and black on the dial looks stunning. I need one for home?
Iconic. No visit to London is complete without seeing this iconic image. It does not disappoint as it is very impressive.

The most photogenic clock in the world?. Big Ben, seen from your hotel, starts every day right, and reminds you that you're in London. What picture with Big Ben turns out badly? Old English style--the symbol of London-UK!. Visited back in Sep-Dec 2009! It was a snowy-rainy day when I visited the Big Ben! Then southeast of the HoP is the London Eye! Ferris Wheel next stops turning. Also love the arcade near the London Eye Museum! Visited in SEP-DEC 2009. Westminister Abbey.

Standing out from the crowd . This is such an iconic building to see and visit and to hear the chimes as the hour turns is incredible. This building is such a great piece of work and really helps define london.
Get the camera out. St Stephen's tower is worth the tube ride, just to take the photos. Tours are available, although sometimes tricky to get hold of.
The most iconic London Landmark. Try to be next to big ben to hear those amazing chimes on the hour, this is one of the most iconic land marks in the world - an absolute must see!

A great piece of edifice in the midst of the City. This is something that UK tourists shouldn't miss. If you wanna have a greta picture, better stay on the side of London Eye and you'll get a perfect angle. Since this area is full of tourists, if you wanna have a great shot with Big Ben as background, better be patient but its truly worth the wait. If you wanna buy souvenirs, along the way there are some stores that sells souvenirs at reasonable price. But if you wanna have a real bargain, go to Piccadilly Circus. :-)
Amazing!. It's stunning, as everything in London is. It's Worth visit! London is a beautiful and amazing city.

Walk around and take feel of great history. Best place to take walk. You can start walk around 4 PM (During summer) in this area and plan to visit Big ben, Westminster and then either you can go to Trafalgar square or you can take walk around River Theme.
Gorgeous. Should take pictures at the traffic light as it's not super crowded. Other than that, what a landmark!
Breathtaking!. So neat to see when you emerge from the tube station! Best photos are from across the bridge. You'll be in awe at how big it is!

Couldn't stop taking photos!. So amazing to see in person. A tourist must see when visiting London.
Did't realise it was right on such a busy street however its viewable from either side of the River Thames so makes for a great pic wherever you are.

Hmmm. What do you say about a clock?. Well, it was interesting to find out the clock is not really Big Ben. It's actually the bells inside the clock. But how can you go to London and not see Big Ben? Or whatever the clock's name is.

Still the world's best timepiece. What strikes me most about Big Ben is commuters' inability to use it to check the time! Whenever I walk to the office in London, I always glance up at it, and yet I see hundreds - thousands - of other workers checking their phones for the time instead.Big Ben reminds among the most impressive structures I've ever seen - I'll never grow tired of seeing it on the London skyline.

Do not go home without this picture!. It is like a visit to Paris (must get an Eiffel Tower Picture); you cannot go home without a picture of Big Ben. Westminster, Parliament, The Mall, New Scotland Yard, Horse Guards, Trafalgar Square, Thames Embankment for instance ... and you must include a pint or two and pub lunch at The Albert!

Come to get more picture if you love picture.
A tourist must see. Obviously if visiting London you must make the effort to do a "time check" or even a selfie with this in the back. (:
A London landmark worthy of a visit and photo. Great to see it both day and night from either side of the River Thames. Be sure to be around when the clock bells chime!
Amazing as on the photos. To see Big Ben live is always a breathtaking moment - during day or night. There are always a lot of people and take care on your personal belongings.

Stunning. After seeing this iconic monument so many times in so many movies, its amazing seeing it for yourself. There are many ways and angles to get and see this also place. Big Ben is truly cool & the landscape of London would be forever changed without it!. We stayed very near it & I found it happily telling me the time, just as it was intended to, over 150 years ago. Who knew that with the advent of mobile phones, we'd all forget about wearing time pieces on our wrists & then but be grateful for clocks on various buildings (found throughout London & on various key buildings all over the UK) & they would happily all serve their original purpose, once again.

The Bells, The Bells.... Arguably the most famous sound in London and perhaps the most famous British landmark too. Even if you don't go inside the Houses of Parliament, you have to view them externally and hear Big Ben mark the hours (and the quarters) with its deep resonant tones.Once you've taken your compulsory photographs, cross the road and settle down with a "pint" in the front bar of St Stephen's Tavern. This is the pub traditionally associated with the House of Commons and has lots of interesting pictures and memorabilia. They still have the Division Bell used to warn MPs that they have just a few minutes to scurry back across the road to vote on important matters!You can't avoid hearing Big Ben as it's only across the road. And it's a much more comfortable and relaxing way of listening to the bells. And there's so much more to see within a stone's-throw of BB. Westminster Abbey, 10 Downing Street, Horse Guards Parade, Churchill's War Rooms and many many more. Head for Westminster Station on the Tube and you're there. Help yourself to a large portion of (mainly free) British history!

Excellent tour steeped in history. I arranged this tour through my MP, and you can go up the Elizabeth Tower. The tour guide was excellent, and standing right next to the bell of Big Ben when it struck on the hour was absolutely mind blowing (they give you ear plugs don't worry)! I was worried about all the steps, but they break it up, and you stop at the different levels on the way up, so you don't feel too tired or dizzy from the spiral stairs. The whole tour was excellent and I would highly recommend. Please note these tours can only be arranged through your MP and you do have to be security checked and cleared before you come so you can't just book at short notice. Get on the waiting list and enjoy when your time comes up though!

I Will Tell You In This Review How To Climb To The Top Of Big Ben !!!!. All the other reviews on here tell you of the splendour & iconic Big Ben/Elizabeth Tower. I will tell you something different. Read this review though & I will tell how to climb the 334 steps to the top for free. 1) You have to be a UK resident 2) ID confirming your name & address 3) Fit & healthy 4) Age over 11 Then all you need to do is write a letter to your local MP. You will get letter & confirmation back to you in the post from your MP. There is approx a 6month wait as they take 3 groups per day to the top in groups of 16. It is not a difficult climb. It is taken at a good pace with regular stops. Where you get given info on the history & building of the tower. You reach the top timed so that you are in the bell tower to hear the chimes. You walk behind each clock face. All in all an awesome experience. Give it a go. I will never forget this experience.

Big Ben. If you come to London then this is a must to see and look at. The 62 meter tower is called Elizabeth Tower and contain a bell which you will hear chime. Sadly ONLY UK residents can climb the 334 steps inside the tower to hear the bell chime.Elizabeth Tower tours are currently free of charge. UK residents should contact their local MP or a Member of the House of Lords whom they know to arrange a tour.Tours are now fully booked up to the end of July 2015Bookings for August 2015 will be opened on 2 March 2015.

Remember it's just a clock tower... But not!. Ok bit confusing on these reviews. Some hon on about Parliament as a whole and others about the Tower. A symbol of time and one seen each year to welcome in the new year.It has four faces and to get the full effect go see it at 11:45am and wait till 12:15.Not only do you see it and Parliament in all it's glory from the outside but you will hear the chimes.The sound created by the cracked bell is unique and warms the heart.This chimes you will hear are the sound of time. Elizabeth Tower. Whilst in London we had to go and see the Elizabeth Tower which is the clock tower that houses the bell which chimes the hours and is known as Big Ben.The tower itself is called the Elizabeth Tower since it was renamed to commemorate the queens diamond jubilee.This clock tower is iconic and must be one of the most visited tourist attractions in London, it was certainly very busy even during the middle of the weekWell worth a visit

Climbing Elizabeth Tower to see Big Ben. I was lucky to be allocated tickets to climb the tower and see Big Ben strike. Tickets are only available for British nationals and you apply via your MP. There was a group of about 20 on our session. Bags are checked airport style and locked away. Phones and cameras are not allowed in the tower. Our guide was great, really knowledgable and amusing, there are a lot of stairs, but broken into 3 levels with a stop and things to see on each level. You see the workings of the clock and at the top walk around the 4 faces of the clock. An amazing feeling! The tour is timed so you experience Big Ben chiming the hour. You are given ear plugs for this and it still vibrates your whole body. A fabulous experience and worth going on a waiting list to do.
A great visit. You absolutely must see this if you are a visitor in London. It's a beautiful piece of work and well worth the visit as you have the House of Lords right next door.
Lovely to admire. Lovely to admire at night.... really is a spectacular clock ,,,,,,, set your camera to night mode and remember and take pictures

Big Ben at Westminster. Well let's get things right. Big Ben is actually the largest bell inside the clock at the top of St Stephens Tower which is attached to the buildings normally referred to as The Houses of Parliament. This isn't a lecture so, in a nutshell, you can't ordinarily see Big Ben per se but you can see the clock faces just fine; you can hear the chimes on the hour for the 'bongs' ;and the phrases for each of the quarter hours too. All pretty much as heard on BBC TV and radio for 1800 and 2400 hours local. Big Ben and the tower do not lie on the Greenwich meridian line which is perhaps five miles to the East, from which absolute time is taken, and so Big Ben probably sounds microseconds later. Like I say, this is an essence of the story for a bit of fun and is not a lecture. A charming victorian building, an iconic centrepiece for London and a bit of photography to say that "I was there.' Shouldn't take long to see it, and arguably best viewed from one of the river buses most of which call in at nearby Westminster pier.
Big Ben. Great architecture and really looks nice of an evening all lit up!One of the great attractions of London.A must visit!!

A major attraction, inside and out. As a London resident I am ashamed to admit that I only went inside Big Ben very recently; I should have done it before. Seeing the clock-hands from inside the tower and standing about a foot away from Big Ben when it chimed (with earplugs!) were amazing experiences.

Best viewed from Westminster Bridge. The worlds most famous clock tower and symbol of London. If you have grown up in the UK the unmistakable 'bongs' of the nightly TV news or ringing in the New Year couldn't be more British. It gets pretty crowded as you exit Westminster underground station as everyone has their first glimpse of the tower. One of the better, less crowded places to take a photo is on Westminster Bridge. Here you can wait for a red London bus to zip past and have Big Ben in the background. Make sure you are here on the hour to hear the bells, there is also a mini chime every 15 minutes. The tower was renamed the Elizabeth Tower for the Queen's golden jubilee in 2012. Big Ben is the bell inside. There is a legend that if it ever rings 13 times, the lions in Trafalgar Square will come to life. Tours are available to UK residents only. There is a 6 month waiting list and you have to apply via your MP. The tours are free.
Impressive. What a majestic sight overlooking the river. No wonder the tourist flock here! Night time flood lights give a special atmosphere and are great for photographs

Beautiful and stunning. Such an incredible piece of architecture! Fabulous to see and recommend to everyone! Despite the cold and windy weather, the sight was grand and full of tourists but didn't stop us from enjoying the view.
Beautiful Site. This is one of the most famous sites in London. It is a great photo opportunity. The area is pretty busy so be prepared to spend some time in this part of town.

iconic Clock Tower-Big Ben. the most Iconic clock in the world.The clock tower as it is originally known.Next to Westminster Bridge,it is mandatory to see this huge towering structure once by day--- and then again at night.It has a charm of its own,I did not go into the tower because of entry fees,but a look at it from the London eye is also very captivating.

Amazing!. Incredible architecture, much better than the one on the 10 O'clock news;-)!Only trouble is - so busy! Get there early to avoid the hoard of tourists.Not been inside but I believe they do tours, imagine you'd have to book early.Next to Westminster Bridge, Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey etc so can do it all in one foul swoop.

You can't beat Big Ben for a London landmark!. A treat to see & needs to be seen by day & again by night when lit up with the Houses of Parliament & the bridge. Crossing from South of the river it is an impressive & emerging from the Westminster tube station it towers above. A trip to London is not complete without a sight of this (& try & see it from the London eye too!)

A wonder at dusk. We walked past Big Ben around dusk and he was an impressive sight! We didn't go inside because it didn't fit in our budget, but a walk around and a snap is a must when visiting London.

Unfortunately, the Clock Tower is not open to tourists. The chimes can be heard every quarter of the hour.

Please note its name is Elizabeth Tower.. 'Big Ben' is the nickname for the Great Bell which strikes the hours, and this glorious campanile, formerly known as The Clock Tower or St. Stephen's Tower, was renamed 2 years ago in honour of the present Queen. The other, larger and taller tower at the other end of the Palace of Westminster is the Victoria Tower.For so many this building is THE symbol of London, on a par with St Paul's Cathedral or the Tower and Tower Bridge.If you have binoculars you can get a closer view of the marvellous decoration at the clock level and above.On New Year's eve at the chimes of midnight the tower makes a wonderful backdrop to the New Year firework display centred on the river and the London Eye.

great!. Well, no need to say, if you are visiting London, go to Big Ben :) it is the symbol of London, of course everyone goes :) if you want to take good photos you should visit both at night and day. what else can be said? great !

what more can you say, its big ben. Make sure you take it in from across the river as well as close up, its only a walk across the bridge

It's a clock.. Well, technically Big Ben is the bell, but, you know what I mean. This is London's equal to the Statue of Liberty, or the Taj Mahal, or St. Basil's, or the Sydney Opera House or... basically, it's the big iconic landmark. It's the place where you go as a tourist to say, "Wow. Now I've seen London."Though, I mean, this realization usually takes about five minutes total to have, and once you've gotten over it there's not a whole lot else you can do here. As far as I know, only permanent residents of the UK can request tickets to get inside of it, and otherwise it's on a busy street with a lot of people taking selfies. Once you're done looking at the clock, I'd recommend heading down to the Thames and walking up and down the bank for a bit, or going to Westminster Abbey. Again, I'm not saying don't see Big Ben... there's no reason not to... it's just not going to be that entertaining for that long.

Bell tower. We have had a walk round the Houses of Parliament from there we walked up all the steps to Big Ben a great achievement not good if you have a problem with mobilising. It was a great experience

Awesome. London is a beautiful city, mostly because of historic landmarks like Big Ben. There's not much to actually DO near it other than take pictures, but it's also nice to enjoy the sunset on the water and around that area.

Big Ben.....Worthy Landmark of London. The moment you see the majestic Big Ben Tower you realised why it's been so favourite to all travellers. truly Majestic... More important it add values to surrounded places. Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock towerThe tower is officially known as the Elizabeth Tower, renamed as such to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II (prior to being renamed in 2012 it was known as simply "Clock Tower"). The tower holds the largest four-faced chiming clock in the world and is the third-tallest free-standing clock tower. The tower was completed in 1858. The tower has become one of the most prominent symbols of the United Kingdom and is often in the establishing shot of films set in London.

Good view from the southbank. Even tho I've been to London sightseeing before (self-guided), I never realised until I was on a guided bike tour which took us on the south side of the river, that the usual view you see of Big Ben on TV is from the south bank of the river, with the Houses of Parliament to its left. So, walk across Westminster Bridge and along the bank a bit, and you'll get the best view of Big Ben to photograph. We also got another good view by accident one evening of Big Ben and Parliament all lit up by night as we travelled by a standard red double-decker bus from near the Imperial War Museum to Trafalgar Square (only about 1.50 per ride) which goes across Westminster Bridge as part of its usual route.

Wait for it to chime. We saw Big Ben in the distance on the current visit as we travelled down the Thames on a River Cruise. BB is located opposite Westminister Abbey near Westminster tube station and Westminster pier. The sound emanating from the clock when it chimes cannot be forgotten. A deep, powerful BONG sound. The general area around the Houses of Parliament, the Abbey and the adjoining park is very photogenic. There is usually a demonstration opposite the entrance to the Parliament, photographers capturing the drama and a crowd going through the area. Lots to see, lots of atmosphere and of course, the wonderful chimes of Big Ben every 30 minutes. And ... to it is all free. On two previous visits to London, I entered Parliament for Question Time and stood under Big Ben on New Year's Eve. This tiny spot in London has many memories of previous visits.

A proper landmark. It is one of the places you DEFINITELY have to go see if you're in London. Still surprises me how many people don't know Big Ben is the name of the Bell in the clock tower and not the tower itself.

Must-see (and you will).. This building isn't called 'Big Ben' for nothing. You will notice the big clock tower from far away. No London visit is complete without a snapshot of this iconic and historic building!

A real experience. I arranged a trip to the Elizabeth tower for my Friday cycling group - but we went on a Thursday! I managed to book for a group of 16 and for an 11 start meaning we got the full 12 'bongs' - worth waiting a few months for. It is important to note that only people with UK passports or who are resident here can go and you have to apply via your MP. You can go on your own or any number up to16. The main leader/tour guide was truly inspirational - there are over 300 steps but you do it in 100s, with a stop for a chat and to look at the mechanism on the way. Finally reaching the top with an extraordinary view of London from inside the bell tower and to be there as it strikes 12 is just too good to be true. But the real icing on the cake is to then go inside the clock face and walk round the inside - just like in the 39 Steps!!And it is free!! A must for any Londoner, visitor to London from the rest of the country or to anyone fortunate to be resident here.
Must see!. World icon. You can not go to London and not see the Big Ben, and of course pose for a photo or two. The Big Ben is also very central with lots of other sights close by.
Go see it at night!. I love night photography and I took amazing pictures from the other side of the bridge. Definitely a must see.

Classic touristic point of London. What else to say of this worldwide landmark? The Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London, and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower. Famous for it's nickname, Big Ben, it's called Elizabeth Tower to named in tribute to Queen Elizabeth II.It's definitely worthwile visiting two times in the day, one in the morning/afternoon with sunlight and in the night to see it's lights.Lots of people packs up the streets real close to it taking pics, selfies and videos.Good thing about it is that it's close to many other cool places to go, such as Westminster's Abbey, London Eye, London Sea Aquarium, and many other.

What can I say... It is Big Ben. We really enjoy the history and the stories you get when you take a tour of big ben. It is worth taking a tour instead of going it alone. This is a wonderful place to take children. We had a daughter read some books and it made it that much better.

Must See. Big Ben is a perfect place to walk by as wondering through central London. No visit is complete without it. It is a short walk from Buckingham Palace, Hyde Park, the River Thames, London Eye, et. It is definitely worth the walk.
What an iconic building. I love visiting my own city. today was big ben and surrounding area. What can you say its just amazing.

Great for holiday pictures. We first drove by Big Ben on the Big Bus Tour, but didn't stop to get out. I regret not stepping out on a clear day because when we visited later around New Year's, the area was very crowded and beginning to be blocked off. Very beautiful architecture I would recommend stopping by briefly, even just for pictures.

WOW !. If you really want to experience the whole experience of Big Ben - then a tour of the tower itself (Elizabeth Tower), is a must and the only way this can be done is via your local MP - there is no charge - but at least a 6-9 month wait to get onto the tour itself. Open to British citizens and a security clearance. You climb the 354 steps on the spiral staircase inside right to the top of the tower. You must be fit and able to make the climb. Then to stand behind the clock face/s and then the last final steps on up to the final level to the home of "big ben" - you are up close to when the big Ben and when the bell chimes. Views out from this level are really fabulous. You see the mechanical workings and how the whole bell system works - all very interesting. The tour guide was so informative with history etc., and it was an amazing experience and well worth the wait to go. So glad we have visited.
tour London. Very impresive ! I was expecting it a little bit higher ! It was a nice experience and it has interesting architecture

Big Ben ?. A beautiful gothic building but not really big any longer. Yes I know that Big Ben is actually the name of the bell. It must have been so impressive in the Victorian age before it was dwarfed by newer and taller monstrosities of architectural "design" like the Shard and Gherkin. Needs an extension in height. Iconic and beautiful but diabolically overshadowed. An object lesson on why City planning cannot be left to self Interested, myopic and greedy politicians and mayors but should be overseen by Prince Charles !

Enough said. Big Ben is amazing it says it all so many people from around the world visit this site. And now I no why. This place is truely amazing. It's breath taking its every bigger in real life. Easy to find. And lots of friendly guards to talk to get pics with amazing

Tours only for UK Residents. The famous Big Ben tower, formally known as Elizabeth Tower is an unmistakeable landmark located in Westminster as a part of the houses of parliament. Frozen in Time. Elizabeth Tower, or Big Ben - we see it so many times. As someone who lives in the faraway Asia, visiting the site has always been my intention. Fun fact: It's actually called The Tower of Elizabeth, renamed during the Jubilee year. It's the bell inside that is named 'Big Ben'.

Symbol of London. I can say my dream came true when I saw Big Ben. Actually it seemed that the clock can be seen from everywhere (central part of London). Very beautiful, as described and was expected.

Take a Walking Tour of London!. I love walking through new cities while on vacation so this was definitely on my list of things to see. It is right on the River Thames and close to many other attractions so bring an umbrella and take a lovely stroll!

write to your m.p. - amazing. Being a Londoner i have seen Big Ben from the street many times, a friend of mine recommended that i email my m.p. To request to climb the steps of Big Ben, or I should say the Elizabeth Tower (baring in mind the largest bell is actually Big Ben). Anyone who is a resident in Britain can request to climb the 334 of the Elizabeth Tower via their MP, and it is free! It was an experience from the time we arrived at Prospect House, where we went through airport style security, then waited for our tour to start. There was 12 of us on the tour. We went underground to get to the Elizabeth Tower (so called after our Queen), there are 3 or 4 stops on the way up the stairs, we stood behind the four clock faces of Big Ben, then climbed further to where the bell called 'Big Ben' hung, we got there for the 12 midday bongs. The climb and the talk were fascinating, our guide had an amazing amount of knowledge regarding Big Ben, and the Elizabeth Tower. This is a day that will always stay with me. I found the walk up relatively easy as there were a few stops, however I had to concentrate when coming down, not quite sure why! I strongly recommend that you all write to your M. P's to get your free tickets to walk up.

Beautiful Big Ben!. Well worth the visit, also just a stone through from London Dungeons and the Aquarium so great for a day of activities and sightseeing. Breathtaking view at nighttime, all lit up. Good Evening Big Ben. Previously we saw the Big Ben during the day from the other side of the Westminster Bridge. This time, we took Jubilee Line to Westminster Station to see the Big One at night. It was really beautiful. Note: The exit from the station towards the bridge is crowded at night. Watch out for pickpockets. We had a couple of individuals masked like clowns approached our son in a group. They placed their hands over his shoulder, shook his hand whilst the others tried to pat for mobile phone and wallet. Fortunately our son was really alert. Since they are masked, London Police will not be able to help due to inability to identify the criminals. There is also illegal betting and gambling on the pedestrian pavements. Do not join in the game as these are criminal syndicates. Do not be carried away by what you are doing. Be alert ! London has changed much since our last visit 15 years ago. It is now more colourful and demographically different but also complicated and confusing. After the visit to the Parliament and the Big ben, travellers can walk towards the Buckingham Palace and even as far as Knightsbridge.

The London Icon. Big Ben in the heart of London is the iconic image of the city. Located at one end of the Parliament buildings, the Elizabeth Tower is home to Big Ben, the bell that rings throughout the day. You can visit the Elizabeth Tower if you are a resident of the United Kingdom; however, if you are a visitor to England you can only see the outside of the Tower. Visiting Big Ben can be done at all times of the day but the least crowded is early morning, especially on weekends or after 7pm when it is lit up in a very nice green color. The best pictures can be taken from the Waterloo bridge so the entire Tower is in your pictures.

Nice !. Big Ben is the UK’s most popular tourist attraction. Big Ben chimes every 15 minutes and the sound can be heard for a radius of up to 5 miles.Whenever Parliament is in session, the Union Flag is flown from Victoria Tower.

Fantastic tour and incredibly informative. Excellent tour - lots of steps to climb but well worth it when you get to the top. Guide was excellent and explained the history of it all. Was at the top for the 5pm chimes and heard Big Ben at close quarters. A must see/must do.

Best place to view.... Best place to view Big Ben is from a bench across Lambeth Bride in front of Lambeth Palace. get there about an hour or so before sunset and watch the clock face get progressively brighter as darkness falls over the city. Wait for the clock to chime 5 or 6 o'clock. Then either keep sitting there or start walking the southern embankment as it twists and turns east toward tower bridge, or stroll the other way, west of Lambeth bridge, to a great barge bar called Tamesis Dock.

It's the Big Ben!. You can't miss this attraction. It is within the vicinity of Trafalgar Square, the Eye and Westminster Abbey. Tips: I took photos from junction near the bridge. Gives a wigged view of it. And try wait for the bell while you are there.

Iconic. Can't be missed when visiting London. One of the exit tunnels from the Westminster underground station led us to the surface right underneath the tower, it was awesome. Do not miss an opportunity to see Big Ben (technically named the Elizabeth Tower, Big Ben is the bell) from all sides and at different times of day. It is lit well at night glowing gold and green.

Excellent sightseeing. The very nice architecture of the Big Ben at Westminster was excellent to see, even after seeing it for dozens of times. Children like this sightseeing in particular as a feature of London. It is at a central point in London close to the Houses of Parliaments at Westminster and to the side of the Thames river where the Westminster Pier is. Opposite to it on the other side of the bridge and the river there is London Eye and the Aquarium. Close to the Big Ben is the Westminster underground station. The Big Ben is one of the Top sightseeings in London. It is excellent even without climbing inside it.
Great. Amazing architecture. Worth seeing. The history behind this place as is with most of London is truly amazing.

Big Ben tour and its free. Been up Big Ben twice now. You have to book via your MP so that you can get security checked and clearance to do the tour. Access is under the road and of course there are steps 200 or so. There is an age limit too which I think is 12. First you go so far up and stop at a room where the guide gives you information about the history of the tower, the bell and the clock. Then you go up to the clock mechanism which is fascinating. The pendulum is weighted with old pennies. Then it's up behind the clock face to the bell. The tour is timed so that you reach here on the hour. Earplugs are provided. This is the best tour in London. The two ladies who acted as guides last time I went were great. You can also go into Westminster Hall and see where Guy Fawkes and William Wallace were tried.

Just a fantastic sight. I never get tired of walking past when I'm in London. Dear know how many photos have been taken, there are always hordes of people!You also need to walk down Millbank to see the other side of the Houses of Parliament. Stunning.

Iconic london. Given it an excellent rating as it is so iconic. Great photo opportunity but mKe sure you take photos from various angles and across the Thames or from the bridge. Lots of other Westminster attractions nearby makes ia visit to Big Ben appealing as well.

Nice photo stop, but there are more interesting things in London.. As always when in London, you'll always want to do the walk around the palace to St. James park, and from there you can get a nice view of the Westminster Abbey, London Eye and the parliament buildings which house Big Ben. Remember you can't see Big Ben from the street because Ben is not the building, but the large bell inside. Some of you didn't know that I bet...Anyway, London's a great place to walk around in nice weather, but even if it's a bit cold and rainy it's still surprisingly enjoyable... I guess if you're a tourist, maybe not a local.Have fun and Enjoy!

Exceeds expectations. My expectations for Big Ben were " a big clock.".....". BIG DEAL. I was pleasantly suprized by the regal appearance of the clock. The clock is located at the corner of the Palace of Wesrminister which enhances the clock's appearance.
I would recommend visiting Big Ben which I'd located conveniently near the London Eye.

A Knockout. Nothing says "London" like Big Ben. It's a knockout to see in person, no matter what angle from which you spot it. We particularly enjoy the view from across the Thames - it's spectacular for photos, particularly if you are lucky enough to get some dramatic light with contrasting shadows.

Surprised at the sound. Big Ben has a very deep "bong" which we had not expected since we had thought it was more like the chimes we hear in mantle clocks. It almost reverberates through your body it is so powerful. Be sure to get there on time since the clock is quite accurate.
Beautiful. I visited Big Ben during our stay. I had always wanted to see it in person. It was a beautiful!! I can cross that off my bucket list.

Brilliant. We've seen it and heard it thousands of times on tv, radio and from street level, but to be standing next to Big Ben when it strikes is just an awesome experience! Getting tickets is a bit of a job, as you have to be 'invited' by your MP or Member of the House of Lords, and that can take some time to sort, but it's worth the hassle, and it's free to go up! The climb is done in 3 or 4 stages, with a rest to view different areas of the tower, and standing watching the clock mechanism and being behind the clock faces makes you forget all the stairs! We got into the belfry at 4.55pm, so just enough time to put the earplugs in, and then off it goes!A fantastic opportunity to visit one of the worlds best known landmarks, and the whole trip takes around 90 minutes, so not too rushed. We'll certainly never forget the experience!

What can you say?. One of the most recognizable landmarks in the world, and deservedly so! It is amazing to think that it has been in place for so many years and even avoided being damaged during the Blitz.
Awesome. Visited London for a long weekend and it is truly memorable. Big Ben is awesome standing tall and majestic it really is a sight to be proud of.

MUST-SEE!. If you're in London, you MUST see Elizabeth Tower/Big Ben. It is just breathtaking to see this icon in real life. While doing the "Westminster walk" I just looked up and "BAM" there it was - had to hold back tears - it was just such a blessing to be able to see this in real life. It does not disappoint.

Everyone loves Big Ben!. Big Ben is the symbol of England and all that is English! It stands majestically between the Thames and Westminster and represents Parliament. Be sure to wait for the clock to strike - it gives me goosebumps!!

Visit of a lifetime. I've been to the top of this tower twice, once with family and once I took some students. You need to book well in advance (months) by contacting your MP and your choice of dates may be limited. At the time we visited it was free, but I think I heard there are plans to charge in the future? You have to be a UK citizen and security checks will be done both before you visit and on arrival. I almost don't want to say too much, because I don't want to spoil the surprise, but you can walk behind all the clock faces, watch the bell chime (go for the 12 o'clock visit, it is fabulous), the steel structure vibrates as big ben rings, see the mechanisms etc. The views are fabulous across London and the speaker/guide is fantastic. A trip I will never forget. Everyone should visit. (They do warn about the number of stairs which worried me as I'm not fit, but I was fine and you get to stop at various points through the tower.) The only downside is you aren't allowed to take photos.

Big Ben London and Park Plaza County Hall. Big ben clock tower is a most visited tourist attraction in london. i heard that it is known for best sounds. i visited park plaza near the big ben... i have just spent 2 nights at the Park Plaza County Hall, and it was excellent. Its newly opened so everything looked great, the room, was large (we got an upgrade), with Kitchenette, seperate living room and it had a great view (Although rooms at the front of the hotel would look over a building site, of another Park Plaza). Breakfast included was also very good, supposedly continental, but I took a huge full English from the buffett and no one said a word :) All the staff were very friendly and helpful and location is great. you should understand one thing that you should plan early before visit the big ben. i was prepared before go there because in this regard i visited a site to know about big ben, http://spirittourism.com/pleasure/monuments/big-ben-top-tourist-attraction-london/

It is what it is. Nothing much to say other than something to tick off the tourist box. When coming to London it is on almost everyone's list of "thing's to do." Just go and get it over with - there are much more things to see in London!

"Land mark of London". Big Ben Speaking of London. Would not there be anyone seen on television or book before you see the real thing. A large clock tower of Westminster Abbey hotel, people who live in that range sound of the bell of Big Ben can be heard seems to have been a Londoner born and bred in the past. I think standing on the banks of the River Thames, and look up at the Big Ben already familiar through the media, that it has come to London to be realize that acutely.

A Big Clock!. Big Ben is the affectionate name given to the great bell of the clock tower of the Houses of Parliament in Westminster London. It is huge building and is an Iconic part of London's Skyline. Definitely worth as a visit as it is right on the River Thames. A beautiful setting for lovely pictures. It is close to the Westminster Abbey. Highly recommended.
Big Ben!. Doesn't take long to see, but it's well worth a visit as its so famous! Does get very busy around the area with lots of people taking pictures!

Ornate clock. It doesn't take long to see, but it's well worth seeing it if you are only in London for the day. It's in a central location although it can be very busy with other tourists taking photos.
Nice clock.. This attraction is close to a lot of others, so its worth a look, but don't expect to be overwhelmed.
Underwhelming. Don't expect much when you see it. I almost missed it. It's great for photo ops though. You can see the London Eye from there.

London's iconic attractions. Big Ben is one of the most memorable attractions for London. I was lucky enough to actually climb inside years ago when I was in the girl guides. I have enjoyed seeing inside and out and it can get noisy when it chimes! The only complaint I have is that it's on a main busy road so getting a decent photograph provides a challenge.

Iconic big clock made for photos. Obviously, you'll want to visit this landmark just to take a few pictures and video. There nothing much to see for the clock itself unless if you're a UK resident in which case they have a special tour for you. The best spot to take pics and videos is probably close or on Westminster Bridge, although the area around there is quite crowded. Another possibility is on Parliament Square, although Big Ben will be quite far in the distance. The best time to record video, especially of the hourly chimes, is obviously to go when it will chime (and strike Big Ben) the most based on the hour of the day - i.e. late in the morning at or before 12 noon and late at night at or before 12 midnight. It's a bit disappointing to hear it chime at 1 PM. However, it will play chimes at 15, 30, and 45 minutes after the hour as I recall.I didn't visit Big Ben at night, although I can imagine how special it would look during that time of day. It's not worth a trip in itself, so just take some pictures when you go to Westminster Abbey, Palace of Westminster (Parliament), Churchill War Rooms, County Hall, etc.
Better than expected. all I did was look at it and take pictures, but more impressive than the photos I had seen. near the London Eye, so you can do other things in area too.

Much Better in Person, Pictures Do No Justice. What else can I say other than seeing this iconic landmark is so much better than pictures or video. By far this is one of the best architecture buildings I have seen. Best of all, it is free and the kids will enjoy as well. Make sure you are there at the top of the hour.
Fabulous!. Its so impressive seeing Big Ben right in front of you, we walk around it during daytime and again at night which is magical because of the light effects definitely a place not to miss.

A Must!. You have to visit Big Ben...actually that is NOT it's real name...at least not what you are looking at in the picture. The bell that you here on the hour, and only on the hour, is what is named Big Ben. The other bells you here are not Big Ben. The picture with the clock at the top of the tower that we all call Big Ben is actually called "Elizabeth Tower." Anyway, this is an absolute must see.
Must see!. You can't visit London without seeing the Big Ben. It's beautiful and very impressive. I liked it most at night, the lights just give it something magical!
Fantastic. Well worth a visit! This was my first time seeing Big Ben and I would defintely go back. Awesome location and amazing building.
Stunning.. The gold at the top of this clock tower is absolutely beautiful! I never realized how fabulous Big Ben was...definitely worth a walk across Westminster Bridge to appreciate it.

Queen Elizabeth Clock Tower is the official name. Big Ben as it is known to most people is big and grand and sticks up in the skyline for all to see. You do not have to look too hard to find it as it towers above the city streets. The clock face is there for all to see. A trip to London is incomplete without seeing Big Ben and the Palace of Westminster.
Beautiful. This building is pretty amazing, well worth a visit. There is a nice bar near the London eye very close to Big Ben and its well worth sitting outside to enjoy the lovely view

Walking around the area. We took off to visit the area of Parliament and Big Ben after seeing them from The London Eye. Central London is so walkable. These buildings are beautiful and hearing Big Ben chime was great. We stopped in a great pub for a bit of lunch and a pint and then walked around the area some more.

Obviously, you have to go. Remember - this is going to be packed with tourists most of the day (so, go early or late) and since it's packed with government buildings (and tourists) there really isn't anywhere decent to eat (or use the bathroom) unless you walk a solid kilometer away from Big Ben and then you can start finding some options.Just a heads up to ppl with families who might think "oh, we'll just hit that up and grab some food and a restroom" .... nope. As with all things travel-related, it's always better to go see it AFTER you've eaten and refreshed, than to try and hit that same attraction while grumpy and hungry! :)
something you have to see in london!. if you're in london, you have to visit the iconic big ben and parliament. taking a river cruise down the Thames is good too, and you don't have to walk so much.

Great to See. Big Ben, or more correctly the Elizabeth Cloak Tower, is totally worth seeing when in London. If you can time it around noon you get a truly amazing experience as the bells ring!Of course, anywhere around here is very busy. So, if you can get there early, you will get much better pictures with no heads in the way as you try to take a panoramic shot. Also, don't forget to walk around the area and you can get pictures of Big Ben hidden behind trees and popping out the top!

Great attraction . A must see when in London it looks even better at night easy to get too using the underground aswell, there is a great spot on the bridge across the way to get pictures with Big Ben
Great Attraction. Breathtaking, everything I anticipated and much more.The weather was perfect just a great day for sightseeing.
Style. big ben is an icon. A must see from any angle.. We saw it standing next too, driving by and from above in the London eye. Still a stand out!
Lovely Landmark. you can't miss this beautiful clock tower. It's especially beautiful as the sun is setting, during th "blue hour" when the sky is darkening and the stone glows golden.
Ancient, magnificient, royal. It stands hight and royal. Reminder from many movies and a great lanside. Goid object to show to London's visitors.

It's Like Meeting a Friend You Have Known for Years. What can you say about this iconic structure on the Parliament building? The sun was shining just perfect today as I walked around and took dozens of photos. It is a beautiful tower and clock and I waited around an extra 15 minutes just to hear it chime. I've seen it before, but each time I get a kick out of appreciating it in person.
Still big & beautiful. Liked everything, disliked the crowds! Being squashed in & not as easy to get close to anymore. Never used to be so many restrictions- sign of the times though - sadly
Ben. I love the Big Ben it's great seeing from all over the city , an iconic monument that is London . U alway take pictures of it .

A wonder not too be missed. Big Ben was my favorite part of my trip. Seeing it for the first time I couldnt believe my eyes! Just the size of it alone is amazing then to focus on the detail that has gone into making it is spectacular. Its easy to get to and worth the visit.

Cool. As we all know, this is an iconic simbol of City of London. it is actually very interesting building with awesome architecture. Actually, that stands for the whole complex of Houses of Parliament. If you ask should you visit, of course you should. This is like the main simbol of London and whole UK.

A must see point. There is no way to feel indifferent to this monument. Even if you don't want to pay for an internal tour... just walk near it will give you the dimension of it. To be perfect, the police could be more present to flush away the pickpockets!!!

A must go!. Great sights, impressive with all the view of the clock tower, the house of parliament and that historical feel. The area is full of people trying to catch the fascinating sights and those looking at souvenir stands. If you are visiting London, definitely a must see.

One of the world’s most iconic landmarks. Having seen so many photos of Big Ben, and at least one hour-long documentary focused on it, I thought that seeing it up close and personal would be anticlimactic. I was wrong. From the moment that it popped into view I felt privileged to be gazing upon one of the world’s great iconic landmarks and realized that there is no substitute for seeing it up close and in its historic setting.
BigBen. A must to see in London, next to The port for ride boat, close to the aquarium and the London eye . The best time on sunset time !! Great pictures

Beautiful!. It was amazing to see first-hand something so iconic and beautiful! There are some breathtaking views as you get closer to this area of town, but standing right underneath it, it really blows your mind.

Technically you are looking at Elizabeth Tower :-). In my opinion, this is definitely a "must see" if you are visiting London. A great place for the perfect photo op.FYI, Big Ben is technically the name of the bell, which is inside the Elizabeth Tower.
Beautiful view. Nice old buliding showing the nice architecture,around area is nice view including the river and the London eye.

Imposing & beautiful. Big Ben can look very different depending on time of day, sunny vs. cloudy, etc. It's surprisingly tall, so your pictures will also vary a lot depending on distance from the tower. One of the top "must see" attractions in a city filled with so many.

cant go in but you can pull up alongside of it. it is truly the most beautiful site in London, and the Brits wont let you go in!!!! oh well, you will surely see the outside many times , so don't worry. Many buses go there and close to Waterloo train station. Close to the eye (Ferris wheel) and Parliament and West Minister Abbey.
Like you see it in the movies. Ooh the famous Big Ben, you can see it in tour (only if you are british) but from the outside is more than enough, the street is really crowded.
A must see for every London visitor. For anyone interested in London and british history a visit at Big Ben is a must. If possible make a visit in the evening possible.

Surprisingly interesting. My husband organised this and I must admit that I hadn't been looking forward to it but I am so glad that I went. The tour was informative and interesting, the guide was engaging but not tediously so and the climb was not too bad, there were three stops on the way up and down so it was very doable.We went up to the belfry to see Big Ben itself and were given ear plugs for the midday bells and then we went down for a walk behind all four faces of Big Ben, awesome. Great experience and fantastic architecture of the clock tower and great views from the belfry, do it.

good place to visit. while in london you must go there. its a nice river side and good outlets around there. You can get great photos of it from most angles and also from places like the London EyeIf you plan to go into parliament house be sure to check in advance
Imperdible. This place is a Must during your stay in London. You can take a lot of pictures from all angles. One of my favorite places
Quintessential London. How can you not go? It's one of the most famous landmarks in the world. If you like history, don't miss it. It's beautiful.

Stunning architecture. The architecture is stunning , the Houses of Parliament show you the true history of london, it's worth seeing these by foot as will as taking a boat ride to see a different perspective of the place.
You have to go. You cannot go to London and not visit Big Ben and Oxford street!! Its like a requirement. Its majestic

An imposing building!. Big Ben and Parliament house is what you think of when you think of London and they are truly iconic. You can get great photos of it from most angles and also from places like the London Eye. Definitely somewhere to go if you're in London. If you plan to go into parliament house be sure to check in advance if it's open to the public. You can organise a guided tour in advance which is well worth while. As with a lot of places you will need to go through security and large bags are not permitted, and they don't have anywhere to store them there. Even with tickets you may have to queue for sometime outside so be prepared.

Worh a photo stop. We all know what Big Ben is a great landmark of London, So it is must see while in London although I thought it best viewed from the Thames on a boat cruise or on the other side of the Thames River right opposite the Parliament Building, You can try and get a photo taken while on the Bridge or closer to it, But that is near impossible due to that part of London been so busy with workers and Tourists. Or you can just admire it from wherever you can and listen to the Clock Chime, It is much better seeing it in person rather than in books or photos on the Internet !!

Big Ben is a Symbol of London. Big Ben and The Parliament Building is an iconic symbol of London that can't be missed! The detailing of the building is very impressive! A great place to take pictures is over on the bridge. There is a lot to see and do in that area. Take a boat on the Thames, the London Eye, take a picture by the Lion statue across the bridge by the Marriott. Fun area to spend some of your time.

No need to make a special trip.. It is right next to Westminster abbey and you don't go inside anyway so take your time and walk past this iconic place. Listen to the clock chime. Also you can sit across the themes at an eatery near the London eye and see from a good angle!

Amazing. I have lived in London for 15 years. This is the best tour I have ever done. It was fantastic. The tour guide was fabulous. It was fascinating. You get to go up the 334 stairs to the top stopping a couple of times on the way. You get to sit in the room where the actual mechanics of the timepiece is, go behind the clock face and then right to the top to the actual bell to hear it chime. Absolutely fantastic and can't recommend it enough. I went up there by applying for a free tour sponsored by my local MP. It took about 3 months to actually wait but was DEFINITELY worth it. Do it!
Glittery. Big Ben looks like it's glittery gold in person. There's a lot of people in that area so it's hard to get a good picture but the building is beautiful.

Awe inspired. I would say most attractions are normally less than what I expect or hope for but what I like about Big Ben is that it doesn't need to do or be anything more than it is to be impressive. Just take wonder at all it's influence in movie culture.

See it just before sundown on a clear day. Seeing Big Ben with my own eyes really brought home that I was in London, in a way the other attractions did not. This building seems taller than it really is; it really does stand out. If the weather cooperates, go see Big Ben and the Parliament buildings in the evening, an hour or two before sundown, on a clear day. The colour is magnificent.

There was better to see in the area. Unless your planning a trip out to westminster abbey i probably wouldn't waste my time trecking it, the tower looks the same from most points in london, and if you get on the london eye you get a pretty good view.. don't get the slushies sold near by.. they are more syrup then slushie.

A London icon. After seeing so many pictures of Big Ben it was amazing to finally see it in person. It has such a commanding presence, an attraction all of its own, and when the bell rings it comes life, a must to see.
Great veiw. I passed a whole day sarrunding nere to it, from evert where it has a charming veiw, spacialy when the evening comes and light beem started, good

Symbolizes London. For a lot of tourists the Big Ben along with the Parliament Building symbolizes the city of London - and wouldn't say that an impression very far from reality - as the Big Ben is indeed an iconic landmark - one which can't be missed when you are in London.The closest tube station for it is the Westminster station on the Jubilee line - you step out of the station and the Big Ben is the first thing that you really see - literally.The best views are though from the Westminster Pier(Bridge) and you can soak in a bit of Thames feel too.AFAIK most people can only see it from the outside as going inside requires special permissions etc. and is accessible for UK citizens.
Just what you would expect. You can't visit London without visiting Big Ben... It's just a must. We really enjoyed the walk around especially with the river near by.

Iconic!. Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament are to London as the Eiffel Tower is to Paris. It's a true icon in every sense of the word and it has to be on your must-see list when you come to London. Big Ben refers only to the bell inside the clocktower and only UK citizens can view it (after only being approved by a member of parliament I believe). Tourists can tour Parliament itself though or you could do what my fiancee and I did and that's simply take in the beauty of such a gorgeous structure. I can't recommend this enough!

Big Bennnn.... When I was a child, I used to listen to Big Ben watch everyday when my father turns on his fat silver radio to listen to the BBC. This time when I went to London I planed to reach Big Ben by 12:00 pm so I can hear the clock ticking. It's the same sound, but this time my feelings were different, I'm hearing it for real not from the radio. I recommend any body coming from outside UK and have the same experience I had with my father when I was a child, not to miss the feelings when he/she hears it for real this time. At the same time you will be standing with London eye behind you for a good picture background.

Amazing Bell. Amazing view of the Big Ben, it was impressing to see it from the bridge.and waiting for the bell ring. a few walk behind is parliament house with very interesting architecture. wish to come back here someday.
Amazing Place!. I have seen Big Ben multiple times.I love the fact you can see it from multiple locations and obvious must be see this beautiful place.

Amazing as always. I have seen Big Ben multiple times and it never fails to amaze me. I love the grandness of it and the intricate details. I love the fact you can see it from multiple locations and at no charge. An obvious must see!

Amazing Trip through history.. Went to the houses of parliament and also big ben. Got the trip arranged through my local MP. The trip is free and is well worth doing. You go through a tunnel from the other side of the road to big ben and get to go up the tower up a spiral staircase. We were fortunate to be up there to hear the bell ring. We also got to look through the gaps of the big clock to the streets below. Well worth a visit.

A London Classic. I found out that Big Ben is not the name of the famous clock, it is not the name of the Houses Of Parliament, which is the building it is in, It is actually the name of the bell that is located inside the tower and which chimes for the clock in this famous tower on the Houses of Parliament. There is nothing I have ever heard that sounds like this magnificent bell. The tower and the Houses of Parliament are truly beautiful pieces of architecture. I think almost everything about Westminster is amazing.
Yes, it was impressive and costs nothing to view. I was impressed with Big Ben and it is must see sight of London. Thank goodness it is actually free to view.
London. You see a picture of this clock tower and everyone knows it's London. Great piece of architecture. The clock looks brilliant during sunset.

An True Icon. We did not have the chance to go inside, but being able to view a landmark of such renown was truly amazing! A fun surprise was being able to see it from many other places we visited in London.

Absolutely magical!. I would like to start my review by stating an interesting fact. Big Ben a nickname for this world renowned clock. It's official name is the Great Bell.Like another reviewer mentioned, no pictures or television images can do justice to the magnificent grandeur when you feast your eyes for the first time on the Elizabeth Tower, which houses Big Ben, and the houses of parliament. It is absolutely breathtaking and truly beautiful.I can second another reviewer's comment that we were moved and touched to hear the bells triumphant sound up close and personal!A must see for a wonderful and moving experience and everlasting memories!
Viewable from many parts of London. Wonderful for taking pictures and seeing the Parliament building up close with many historic statues!

Awesome!. We saw it as we were walking towards the Westminster Abbey and it was just, well, awesome. As we passed by, it struck 4 in the afternoon and the bell sound rang four times as well! There's no way you won't pass by this even by chance, it's right by the Parliament Square :)

Big Ben, Larger Than Life.... As I came off the London Underground to Westminster, I was in awe at the magnitude in size of Big Ben. It was truly amazing in all its beauty to see it in person for the first time! A must see in London!

Beautiful structure. Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben is actually the bell inside) is beautiful and intricately decorated. The Houses of Parliament are also very ornate. Definitely see them while in London- it's hard not to if you visit the main tourist attractions. My favorite view of them is actually from the Eye looking down on them and seeing Westminster Bridge, Big Ben, Parliament and the iconic double decker, red buses. Wish I could have see the inside and the bells.

Awesome. Our guide, Tony, hurried us to the Elizabeth Tower. We couldn't figure why he was in a hurry. Well it was a minute to 10:00 am and Big Ben started to strike. What a sound. You can hear and see it on TV, but it does not come close to seeing it in person.

Awe inspiring. You cannot help being moved when you see the Elizabeth Tower and hear Big Ben ringing out inside.It's got to be the most famous building in the world and it's fascinating to see that and along side the rest of the Palace of Westminster, Parliament Square, Westminster Abbey and Whitehall all around.The architecture is wonderful. Although very busy, it adds to the atmosphere. There is so much around this area there is no reason not to visit and see this amazing landmark.

World's most famous clock. Big Ben and Houses of Parliament is a must during your stay in London. With self guided (audio tours) available only on Saturdays, getting to see the Parliament, the House of Commons and House of Lords is great!! Historic building with the world' most famous clock. And if there is a session in progress, and if you are into politics, you can enter for free. The only thing I disliked was the fact that visits are only available on Saturdays, other than that, a great historic place to visit in London!!

Thee Big Ben . Definitely one of the most recognisable land marks in the world so its a must see. Very impressive up close the first time you see it. Also its close to other famous attractions so you can't miss it.
One of the greatest landmarks ever!. Whenever I come and visit London, always have to go and see Big Ben! You must see in person to appreciate it in all it's beauty! Absolutely beautiful!
London. The beautiful sound of the big ben bells gives you its wellcome to London. It is the real symbol of London

A Must for London Tourists. Let's face it - it's a bell housed in a large tower on the shores of the Thames - but it's London in a snapshot! Westminster Tube station, exit and look behind you! Magnificent in sunshine, imposing in the rain. A fabulous London landmark!

Big Ben towers over you. I happened to be working in the Westminster area and decided to have a walk around. A must do!. Probably one of a photographers dream and other people's if you love taking pictures. A Huge clock that looks on to the river Thames.
Love it!. We were lucky enough to have a view of Big Ben from our hotel balcony, and I couldn't stop looking at it! Loved to hear it chime, and it is very photogenic!
You have to see it. You cannot come to London and not pay a visit to this lovely area of town and the compulsory pictures with the Big Ben
Maravilhoso. Incredible, wonderful, excellent view, important to know, part of the main history of British Kingdom, it is the image of historical London.

An Icon Of London. Why visit London if you don't walk or drive by Big Ben an Icon of London. Walking along the Thames River you get the perfect view. You can also see Parliament and a number of other sites in the area.

Gorgeous.. The view is gorgeous.
If you go to LONDON, this is one of the best places to visit and take some pictures.
Must see. Everyone goes to London says they have seen big ben. Its a nice area around there with plenty to see and do.
Worth a visit. A trip to London isn't complete without a stop at Westminster to see the Abbey, Parliament (Palace of Westminster) and of course Big Ben. It is a marvellous sight.
Great clock. Big Ben is a must see while you are in England, a great part of the English history and a sight worth visiting!!
It's the Bell, Not the Clock Tower. London's equivalent of the Colosseum, Eiffel Tower or Statue of Liberty. Next to the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey, and rather difficult to miss.
Looks bigger than in most pictures. Big Ben. or Elizabeth Tower, seems bigger than I thought it would be. Just a quick photo op before moving along.

What else says London better than Big Ben?. It seems like I always experience problems whenever I visit London. First it was my visit just before the Queen's jubilee so a lot of streets were closed. The surrounds are very picturesque, everything is clean and this is definitely a place worth visiting if you are in London. There are plenty of photo opportunities and yet, Big Ben din't seem as big once you see it in person but it is nevertheless a very impressive piece of architecture.

Up close and personal. What a sight. What a London icon. Big Ben up close and personal is a must see. Big Ben is the name of the clock not the tower and chimes on the hour.Did this on the Big Bus Tour.

Big Ben revisited. Second visit to Big Ben for the year. Nice place for photoshot as it is one of the main iconic structure of the world and well known in the world. Only downside is the hygiene which can be quite bad on a busy weekend where litters are left behind by tourist which was make worst by the fact there is not litter bin on the pedestrian. Besides that, having con artist on the pedestrian can also be a sore eyes.

great photo opportunity. Big ben is an incredible landmark. The best place to take a photo is from Westminster bridge with big ben one side and the London eye on the other, its very busy around this area at all times of the day so if you want a good picture, prepare to spend time waiting for the perfect shot!
THE CLOCK TOWER. The world famous timing device is the Big Ben.The famous chime which rings around the world.A must for tourist.The Westminister area is a popular tourist spot

The Royal Big Ben. The Big Ben holds a very beautiful architecture. I would describe it as being made of ‘royal colours’, with a distinct character of its own. A lovely beautiful building that gives a persona of calmness and leaves one in awe at first sight!

Big Ben is for real. Always good to see something that you have seen so many times but not in person. Make sure you make use of the photo opportunity. An interesting fact is that Big Ben is actually the name of the bell housed within the tower associated with the clock. The last time i visited this attraction was actually in 2004, but i don't imagine it has changed

Big Ben is Beautiful. There's something so strong and reassuring about Big Ben.I really didn't think I'd admire a landmark as much as I did seeing Big Ben close up and from many vantage points including up high in the sky in the London Eye (oh, that rhymes) and on a jet boat in the river.Perhaps it had something to do with this impressive and iconic landmark being recently cleaned (just last week) by a group of abseiling guys with long-handled mops.It's looking superb.

Must see in person. If you are in London, you must go right now to see the Big Ben. The whole area is filled with indescribable aura. The historic nature of it and then seeing it up close. It is not to be missed when in London
great sites, visited london many times its worth visiting. I love London , has always ben my favourite destination and I will visit it again when I have the chance. For me its the centre o the world
Marvelous! I even bought the miniature of it.. a must see point of interest in london, very close to westminster abbey and london eye. you can easily reach it by tube or the double decker.

The most important English Landmark. Big Ben [which is the bell not the tower} rests inside the recently named Queen Elizabeth Tower is the most iconic landmark in the country. Everybody in the world knows it! it stands there like an unofficial Guardian of London. it can be seen for miles and miles in all its grandeur !. and when it strikes the hour everybody know matter how many times you have heard it automatically looks up . it is one of the sight and marvels of London that you just have to see

Beautiful architecture and so iconic!. Went to see Westminster Abbey, the tower of Big Ben and the rosy red cheeks of the little children! Ok so now you know I like Roger Miller songs. Big Ben is such beautiful architecture, so centrally located and has a magnificent sound. Right near Big Ben is Westminster Abbey, The Eye, Thames River, Parliament Building, Parliament Square and other fun things to see and do.
