Must see. Simply beautiful, historic elegance. Must see if new to London. I'd recommend viewing from up close and then from afar.

exciting marvellous, there are no words. i liked everything, everything is so ordered, clean and you feel safe in the city.i remeber the sounds of the bell, that was one of the most shocking moments. i looked at it with wet eyes. i felt so happy of just looking that clock and tower.
The famous Big Ben. It was breathtaking, had a great time there with the family and friends, Such a wonderful place and historical site to be visited again and again.

I can see why they blew it up in v for vendetta. absolutely terrible I would never ever go again im glad they blew it up in v for vendetta. its just a big clock and the whole experience left me unsettled.

The "MUST DO" of London.. When BIG BEN (Elizabeth Tower) came into our view it left us with no doubt that we really were in London.
It looked magnificent at the end of the Palace of Westminster and the bells chiming were nothing short of regal.
A very satisfied tick on the bucket list!
A Fairy Tale City. London is my favorite urban city, full of enchantment and royal buildings. No one who visits Europe should miss this classy and glamorous place...

Climbing Big Ben. Wow! What a privilege to climb up Big Ben! You see behind the clock faces and hear the bell chimes in the belfry. Had a great tour, the lady tour guide was informative and the history behind the clock tower is fascinating!Only UK residents can apply by contacting your local MP. This might take 6 months until you can take the tour, but well worth the wait!!

First time ever into. I have been around this area for many many time. But this time I took chance into the building. An impressive tour. A lots of histories. A chance to learn British political system as well!Super!

Gotta love Big Ben . When visiting London, one really must go and see Big Ben. A beautiful iconic sight. We were lucky to be there at midday to here the chimes. It is very busy here but well worth it.
Big Ben london. Big Ben is amazing just so huge and with the Houses of Parliament it is something you got to see if you go to london..

Reliable clock. Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London, and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower. The clock's movement is famous for its reliability. The clock has become a symbol of the United Kingdom, particularly in the visual media. When a television or film-maker wishes to indicate a generic location in the country, a popular way to do so is to show an image of the tower, often with a red double-decker bus or black cab in the foreground.

Majestic and Elegant Symbol of London!. My husband and I stayed in the Trafalgar Square area of London last week from Aug 16-22 and enjoyed seeing Big Ben and hearing it chime every day we were there. When you're in central London anywhere near the North or South Bank of the River Thames, you can see it towering watchfully over the city. You can see it from the streets, from the river, from the London Eye and many other places. But, I think it's best viewed walking across Westminster Bridge. Standing beneath it on the street is especially impressive! It’s gorgeous - massive and elegantly dressed in gold, with its enormous hands and beautiful chimes that sound every 15 minutes. It is especially impressive when its stately bell sounds on the hour. Big Ben is one of the most beloved and enduring symbols of London and is not to be missed while you're in town.
Iconic building!. Very busy but a must see! Lots to see in the area. Great photo opportunities . Houses of Parliament, Downing Street, St Paul's can all be seen at the same time .

Classic London. Like a visit to Paris isn't complete without a visit to Eiffel Tower a visit to London isn't complete without a visit to the Big Ben, well maintained, and stunning views in the night with all the lights. A must visit sight!

Fantastic Experience. My Grand-daughter challenged me to climb the Tower with her as a 75th birthday present.Not at all difficult despite some apprehensions about the physicality of the task. A tremendous experience that I never thought I would do in my lifetime. It was emotional and one of those long lasting memories that will stay with me for the rest of my life.HIGHLY recommended
Yes. It was one of the most important history of UKThe views is greatThey really took care of their historic

An English institution. A visit to London would not be complete without a visit to the famous Big Ben, going a few minutes before the hour strikes to listen to the beautiful sound that chimes from this magnificent institute.

beautiful !! must see!. Okay so you can't go inside, but you can take some beautiful pictures of it. Big Ben and the Parliament are BEAUTIFUL. The detail that was used building this building are amazing. This is a must see. It tends to be very crowded in this area, so be prepared.

The day they cleaned big ben. We decided to bet a cab to the embankment near to The Houses of Parliament. We did not go in but walked around as much of the outside as we could. The clock tower with big ben on it struck as something out of the usual. There were men abseiling down the faces, to clean them. We could not believe our eyes. Quite a talking point, but unfortunately I had left camera at Hotel. Still a fantastic area.

Must See. No visit to London would be complete without a photo shot in front of the clock tower. Any picture with Big Ben instantly looks like a post card. For added value, take a photo by one of the red phone booths with Big Ben towering above.

Take a pic and move on.. Was rather disappointed when we first saw The Clock Tower. It was smaller than I imagined it would be, but regardless I took my picture and left. There's nothing else to do. Big Beg is the name of the bell inside the tower, and you can hear him ring which is fine and dandy but you can't go into the tower unless you are a UK resident which is disappointing. Pretty much see this tower from anywhere along the south bank so you don't even need to get all that close.
Stunning to See. One of the most recognized clocks in the world, can be seen from many places in London but up close is the best.
Big icon. It is one of the biggest icons in London, a must see. There is loads of crowd walking around but you will be able to take a few nice shots.
Loved Big Ben. Very Beautiful! Took pictures across the river with Big Ben behind us, turned out great! Of course up close ones, too! Wish we could have gone inside it!

a must see. You exit the Westminster tube stop and there it is. Be sure to arrive close to the hour so you can here the clock. A short walk from there to Westminster Abbey.
Beautiful!. Big Bed is beautiful to see both day and night. It is right across the street from the Houses of Parlament which used to be Westminster Castle. Both are an impressive sight.

If you go in the direction towards Buckingham palace there is some of the red telephone boxes that you can get a photo in with Big Ben in the background.

just as it looks!. Bug Ben is one of those landmarks all children know about and it doesn't disappoint. Make sure you stay for the bells to chime

I love Ben.... Big Ben is one of those things that when you visit London you just have to see him. If you are a resident of the UK with the assistance of your MP you can see the "real" Big Ben which is his bell. Plus, its free!!! Need to book in advance for the tour as it is quite popular. If you are like me and not a UK dweller...then we get to see him on the outside. Take loads of photos, go both day and night for the full effect. Westminster Abbey, The London Eye and other attractions are nearby so see Ben and his friends.

A big clock!. It's a big clock. By looking up at the clock you can tell the time accurately and free of charge which is brill. It saves wear and tear on your own watch which is also a huge bonus. You can't make a day of it really but it's good. Almost as good as the clock in the middle of Bangor. One disadvantage is it's rather tall so if you wear glasses you might need to wear them - or if you forgot them - squint.

Bong for your buck. The best things are sometimes free. You have to apply via your local MP and therefore be a UK resident, but it is well worth building a day trip to London around this experience. The climb up the 334 steps is no problem and our guide was very enthusiastic and informative. You get to look at the clock and bell mechanisms and go behind all four of the clock faces before climbing up to where the bells are. It is all timed so that you are right next to Big Ben as it strikes the hour (ear plugs provided). Great view from the top also but the only negative point is that photography is banned.

Everybody Loves Big Ben!!. I happened to walk by last year, it looked pretty at the end of the bridge. There were so many people around which made it difficult to get a clear photo etc but it was still nice to see :)
Worth a look - one of the "landmarks" of London!

Awsome. We were lucky enough to have a tour inside Elizabeth Tower and climb the 334 steps to the belfry to hear BIG BEN chime at noon. Thank goodness they supplied ear defenders. We walked behind the clock face and saw how it was lit by candles so many years ago

Incredible visit inside Big Ben. I took a tour inside Big Ben and was able to stand behind the clock face and then up at the very top at midday for the bell ringing. It was an amazing experience, very friendly and knowledgeable tour guide and brilliant views from the top of the tower. I would highly recommend a trip up Big Ben to everybody!
Great to visit.. An imposing structure this is a must see on your visit to London. Try & time it to hear it on the hour.

A must see!. Make sure you see it at night all lit up it's spectacular! Everyone likes to have a picture taken with Big Ben in the background! And there's nothing quite like the sound of the striking of Big Ben!
fantatic. Have been watched on TV and movies .. when you walk from londay eye .. you see it and it lives upto expectation Worth visiting for a walk around

I'm in London . Yah, you get the true feeing of being in London the moment you come to see it, don't miss taking a picture of yourself, choose that corner were the Big Ben and one of those old red telephone cabinet are your background,,, you will love it

Excellent. As my friend from England will say...

Pics or it didn't happen ;). This is one of those places where you want to take a picture of yourself, standing in front of Big Ben to prove to your disbelieving friends, that YES, you really did go to London. The London Eyecon!. Yes its a clock but its an old clock with history and you have to stop and see it just for a moment if you are in London. This seems to be the one tourist thing that locals even have respect for. Its "brilliant" and classic London.

Brilliant. Big Ben is one brilliant piece of architecture. It gives power to London, as it is one of the most beautiful attractions, a must see. Every detail of the building claims for a photo, for a closer look and for a Wow.
BIg Ben. I know its only a clock ,but if you haven't seen it before and its your first time in London, then its worth a visit.

The best of Big Ben. There no actual way of getting into the Big Ben, however just the sight gives you the thrills. We did a day view and well as the night view. Never stops to amaze you . One of the reasons I visited London was to see this marvel up close. To many 5's to do !. What a fantastic city. 5 stars all over.. If you've heard of it.. Go see it.. There all great !Photogs delight.. Lifelong memories.. So glad I'm alive during the digital age, so I can get as many as I want
Amazing. Seeing big Ben is what London is about. Fantastic sight where all tourists get a taste of London. Near to tube line and also food and other local London attraction's.

Absolutely amazing!. We managed to secure tickets for the Big Ben tour through our MP to coincide with our anniversary weekend. My husband is a big fan of all things clocks and watches so he loved it and so did I. The tour lasts about an hour and a half and our guide was very knowledgable and even showed me where my work was when we got to the bell section as he used to work there too!You go through an underground tunnel to get to Big Ben which feels so 007! There is a statue of a unicorn in the tunnel too which I thought was awesome. We were in a small group and did the "climb" in 4 stages. You get to see all the mechanical workings of the clocks and the bells and you go behind the clock faces. Then you are by the bells when it tolls on the hour. Afterwards our guide took us to another area that is open to the public (can't remember what it is called but it links to all the Parliamentary rooms). Amazing tour and a must do for every British citizen! Especially as it is free lol
Little Ben. Big Ben is not as big as you might expect, but it is still iconic and well worth a look. No trip to London would be complete without a picture.

Lovoe the veiw of it from everywhere. You can literally see it from so many different views. If you take the tube to the right station, it's right when you get off. Loved seeing this, although I didn't go in.

MASSIVE. Awesome to see in person after seeing it on TV for so many years! a must see if your in the area, well even if your not! make an effort to check it out. How they made something in such detail so many years ago is beyond me!

Choose the right time to tour inside. Every summer there are a few weeks foreign visitors can book guided tour inside the parliament. It is an amazing experience. The tour guide is excellent. You can stand right in the benches where lords and MPs debate. Highly recommended. Must do in London.
Iconic. A trip to london wouldn't be complete without stopping for a photo in front of Big Ben. It's very busy with tourists.

Big Ben is a Big Hit. What a sight it is! It is the icon of London from both yesteryear and today. It can be seen for miles. I just stood there staring at it for quite some time. I took several pictures to remember it by and was lucky enough to see it from the air as I was leaving London in the airplane. WOW! Please make it a priority to go by and see it.

Great architecture. Big Ben is in the vicinity of parliament and also Westminster Abbey. So, you can do a lot while you're in the area. It's really just a great architectural beacon which the English love. Looks great on photographs.
Iconic. What can you say? It's beautiful. I would recommend the view from across the Thames. The entire area is beautiful. Take pictures from the bridge with family in foreground.

history. This is such a great place to feel history.It has such an amazing story behind every corner, if you are to go have a good chat with the staff they know it all and are very good at their jobs.

Beautiful. We arrived at Westminster by ferry from the Tower of London. This area is very crowded. The architecture is grandeur. The most exciting part, sitting on the ferry, waiting for our return trip, we had the most impressive view of Big Ben and it was 6pm. Lovely to hear Big Ben toll!!!!
Stunning. The building is stunning when close up. beautiful building. Its free as well .Every thing is in walking distance

Icon of London. The icon of London is well worth seeing. It's located right in the centre of town alongside the Thames so you can't miss it.

Bet you didn't know the tower is tilted. Yes it is, it leans slightly to the north-west and the tilt is visible to the naked eye so no, you're not imagining things the tower really is tilted.One of those sights you just have to see up close and personal even though you've seen it countless times in photographs and the movies.

Great landmark. It's anther great. Landmark make us stop for a minuet and approach ute and respect the design and level of civil engineer they had years and years. Ago. It's a great place and a wonderful landmark . Glad to had the chance to see .

Magnificent building and a must for visitors. The palace of Westminster is a treat to the eyes a stunning piece of history, if your in London its a must see attraction, great all round, not for those who cant or don't want to climb stairs.

PERFECT. brillaint and most special building in London, a MUST view and pictures have to be taken :) a brilliant bulding for all the family to enjoy as we are a family from ages 9-32years old #BigBenRules

Incredibly impressive. Iconic landmark, hugely impressive, the clock chime just adds to the sight. Looking a little old and worn in parts but I guess he is worn and old. The ornate and sheer enormity of the architecture is astounding. Be prepared for hoards of people and no opportunity for a photograph without anyone else posing in it. A marvellous landmark worth seeing.
Great to view from outside. Beautiful to look at but huge crowds in July. We had no interest in climbing the stairs. I concur with another reviewer, watch out for pick pockets!

A must. Never been to London well then Big Ben is a must!It a great building and even greater at night. Have a so many different picture at Big Ben after dark that's it not even funny. Just an amazing object to photograph!

Great experience thanks to my MP. We were invited by our MP to climb Big Ben via the education service of London. What a brilliant experience but not for the faint hearted, 335 steps of a narrow spiral staircase, we stopped twice in a side room on route to the top, each time being given a visual and verbal account of the history of the building and Big Ben the bell. When we reached the top we had a short wait for Big Ben to strike 11.00am precise to within a second!!! You really need to do this tour contact your MP and ask the experience is well worth it , the mechanism has been there from day 1 a fantastic piece of history!!! Very informative take a bottle of water and a good pair of shoes for a very very good experience

My buddy Ben. I've been in London 3 times and you always have to go and check the old Ben. Although next time I have to try to be there at night... If you have a change, be there when it strikes. It's easy access by tube and you can continue a nice walk to Westminster Abbey and then through St. James's Park to Buckingham Palace.There is always lot of fellow tourists, but at least you have someone to take your pic for you.

London's iconic image. Recognized around the world representing the beauty of London architecture, Big Ben delivered as we saw it in person. More than just a working clock chiming the hours away, this is a must see in London. We were impressed by the intricate detail. The crowds were huge on a hot July afternoon. We jumped off our Hop on Hop off bus tour to take photos and enjoyed a cruise on the Thames as well for a different view. One caution, beware of pickpockets. We saw one get caught on the bridge.

Impressive and Iconic. It was a very surreal feeling walking out of the Westminster Tube Station and seeing Big Ben and Parliament standing before me. An impressive clock tower for sure, I was surprised at how beautiful the structure actually is...very detailed and intricate. There are few landmarks more iconic, and nothing says London more than Big Ben.

Best tourist attraction in London. This tour was just amazing! you do have to wait about 4-6 months for it, but it's worth it! our tour guide was very informative, and the whole tour was timed perfectly, we made it to each level in time to see the whole process of Big Ben and the workings of the clock. Watching the bells chime at 5:00pm was incredible, and actually getting stand behind the huge clock faces, and even tap the glass, was brilliant. So glad I came across this, and so glad we did it. Now every time we see the clock and hear Big Ben it will always bring back fond memories. Only for UK residents though folks!

Day and Night, different views. Well, you might only go over there either in the daytime or night. Do visit it in the night, get someone who understanding night photography, you will see the different faces of Big Ben.
Its a clocking work of architecture!. A must see london iconic sight. Best seen @ night very easily accessible. The detailing is magnificent.

Beautiful in the evening. Hotel was just across the Thames from the Tower and we loved the view. It's crowded nearly all the time on the bridge; best in the late evening or the early morning. Beautiful architecture.
wow. big ben is a must see attraction when your visiting London, if you can get there at new year, even better as the view is spectacular

Like all the other clock towers just a bit bigger.. If you are in London you have to see this, it is probably the most famous landmark. It is a clock tower and that is all it is. The architecture is nice, 10 minutes is enough to see it from the outside.

A must-see. Perhaps the most iconic landmark in London. This is a great view whether on boat or land. It is very impressive to be right there. You can make half a day touring the Houses of Parliament and seeing Big Ben up close. A must-do.

The Palace of Westminster & the Ringing Bell. As I'm sure you've heard Big Ben, the Bell is in the bell tower of the Palace of Westminster - the building. The building itself is beautiful, and most so at night as the sun it setting or after sunset, when all lit up. The heart of London. The mother of Parliaments. When I'm on my way to work I always go pass this place and I feel o bit of Britishness in me. I'm from the USA and I love coming through this place with my bike.All the tourists that I go pass are so happy, taking pictures of Big ben and themselves with Big Ben inh the background.This is why I love London. The people along with the fantastic attractions make London number 1.

It's Not London Without Big Ben. If you want to feel like you are really in London, you have to go to Big Ben. Walking out of Westminster Tube Station and being right underneath gives you the most impressive first impression. The bells can be heard in the surrounding area and it's magical. I got to experience New Year's Eve there and it was breathtaking.

A Must See. Big Ben is a must see in London! The size, beauty, and details are absolutely amazing! To get a great view of Big Ben be sure and ride the London Eye or take the City River Cruise for amazing views. It is one of those things you just have to see and take in!
Iconic Landmark. It is a historical land mark an the building housing it is a marvelous piece of architecture. Memories of London cannot be complete without the chiming sound of the Big Ben.

always on time. I once had the unique pleasure of celebrating new year's eve under the tower , away from the crowds in the square. If you have a parliamentary pass I recommend you do this as it is a total pleasure.

Beautiful. Amazing, wonderful, awe-inspiring, jaw-dropping. We have nothing that even measures up to Big Ben in Australia. So much more beautiful than I expected. I just stared up for about forty minutes, mesmerised. It is London! Go and see it. And you can also check it out from the Eye, but nothing beats it as up close.
Iconic. First time in London, have to see Big Ben. The view was great and held up to the expectations. On a plus there was a piper on the bridge in full dress and just made the experience.

No 1 british landmark. It is an amazing piece of architecture! You can 't leave London without visiting Big Ben . You can't stop taking photos of it. You have a good view from the top of the "London eye", but don't miss a night visit to it , also. It's lit up and very impressive.
Amazing. It was so much more majestic than I thought. We actually went to see it twice. We just stared at it for quite a while.

London Landmark. You can't visit London without passing through the House of Parliament and looking up to have the first view of the Big Ben :) it's really amazing specially when you can have multiple view of it and the best of all is from The London eye...

Big Ben & Parliment. Architecture of both landmarks are amazing.
Big Ben is amazing all lit up at night.

A London Landmark. Big Ben. The name alone conjures up images of bowler hats, brollies and Burberry. It is synonymous with Buckingham Palace, Trafalgar Square and the Crown Jewels in that it is representative of all that is British. No visit to the U.K. and indeed, to London, is complete without a jaunt to see Big Ben. Follow it up with High Tea at either Harrods or Fortnum and Mason's for a perfect end to a typically British day. Cheers.

Big Ben...Surely must visit when in London!. If you are in London and have not come here to visit this magnificent and awesome BIG BEN iconic landmark, you are as good as not visited London! It is lovely and is architectural design is so beautiful that is beyond words can describe. Unless you visit here and see it personally, no way any pictures or photos of Big Ben can "wow" you!This landmark is always at any one time full of visitors and tourists and so if you to have a good spot for photography, make sure you act fast. When the hour comes, it does chime soundly and pleasantly and its such a great feeling to be able to hear in front of you.Surrounding the Big Ben is the River Thames, the Parliament, and the famous London Bridge. So you can spend a couple of hours here, moving from one landmark attraction to another. The city sightseeing bus has a stop here and if you purchase a day's pass, you are also entitled to take a free ferry along the River Thames and its another unique feeling and angle to see this Big Ben and the surrounding nice buildings and monument structures etc.You will be amazed of the Big Ben and so its definitely worth the time and effort to be there!!!
Icons. Big Ben is one of the most notable icons in London and is simply a must. It is breathtakingly beautiful especially when you hear it chime.

AAAAAHHHH...Big Ben..... Big Ben is amazing...and so glad that I FINALLY got to see it in person! This is a London-visitor-MUST-see...and quite frankly, I can't imagine how you would miss it unless you were on an alien-visit-from Mars or something...and didn't leave your spaceship!

MUST SEE!. OK, if this is not on your "things to see in London" list I'm not sure what else is...Big Ben is just something you must see in person. While there, you can see Parliment and the London eye all at the same time. If you are taking a bus tour-get off here and take a good look around You won't be disappointed. The architecture is simply amazing. You will regret passing on this!

The classic "been there" London photo opportunity. Its crowded on the pavements around Big Ben, but there is plenty of opportunity to pose for a photo on the bridge or from the roundabout on the other side, depending on the position of the sun. Have to be a UK citizen to go up. The news is right if you have been reading about Big Ben. If you are not a UK resident, you cannot go up in Big Ben. So, we were content to just walk around it. UK residents can get inside! And it’s Free!. A terrific visit. Contacting your MP is only an email away and the whole trip was very efficiently organised. Having gone through the airport style security, the small group we were in were led under the road and straight to the Elizabeth Tower. [Alas no cameras allowed from here.]334 steps to go! Fortunately there are a number of stops on the way to learn more about the history from an excellent guide.The mechanism room on the way up is a really interesting stop as you learn and watch the 150 year old mechanism keep time and organise the ringing of the bells. Then it’s up to bell tower. Earplugs ready we witnessed the 5pm chimes. Standing about 5 foot away from Big Ben. Fantastic! One of the best visits to any London attraction I’ve ever done. Really Classy.Truly British!

Big Ben and gambling. I returned fromLondon yesterday and as a former dweller of the city I wanted to walk along the Thames banks. What I saw was tragic and horrible: if you try to cross the bridge next to BB, you will meet more than 20 gamblers who try to lure visitors to bet in order to find a hidden ball. This is a very old and forbidden way of gambling as it is ALWAYS a set up. People who were not british (I was informed that they were from Romania or former soviet states) in groups of 3 or 4 were trying to steal passengers pretending they were strangers who were tempted to play and - what a surprise! - got allthe luck doubling their bet ( which was almost always 40 pounds). What does the police do? It is a disgrace having such a decadent image of a beautiful spot when in London! So be careful and avoid this place until you hear something has changed. There are soooo many places tovisit in this metropolis!

One of the most iconic landmarks of London. Big Ben is undoubtedly one of the three most iconic landmarks of London alongside Tower Bridge and London Eye. I heard that it's not open to public unless you have invitation to visit the clock tower. This makes it just a landmark that you possibly want to take some pictures with to keep your London memories alive forever. Not only the fact that it's a four-faced clock tower, but also its positioning at the bank of Thames helps tourist taking photographs in many ways. I'd recommend you to try different standing in front of different sides of the tower as it has huge impact on the 'look and feel' of your pictures. Of course, Westminster Bridge is a good position to place Big Ben at the backdrop, but if you have wide-angle lens, try standing at the green field located beside Westminster Abbey and also at the cross-junction situated near the Big Ben. Moreover, because of the color and materials of the tower, you'll find amazing effects if you take pictures at night.

WOW. The image of the Palace of Westminster (the official name for the building containing the Houses of Parliament) and its clocktower known as Big Ben (to everyone except pedants, who will tell you that Big Ben is in fact the name of the bell, not the tower) has become an icon of icons. It is the scene most evocative of the capital's timeless nature, and yet all is not as it seems. Although the site has been in use for almost 1,000 years -- first as a royal palace, and then from the 16th century onward as the seat of Parliament -- most of what you see dates only from the mid-19th century. It was designed in a deliberately medieval-looking, "Gothic Revival" style to replace an earlier structure that burned down in 1834. There are, however, much older sections hidden within, including the 11th-century Westminster Hall, which still boasts its 14th-century hammerbeam roof, and the 14th-century Jewel Tower .

London's iconic landmark. This is one of London's iconic landmarks and on most tourist's must visit place. Technically, Big Ben is the name given to the massive bell inside the clock tower, which weighs more than 13 tons (13,760 kg). The clock tower looks spectacular at night when the four clock faces are illuminated.As a Londoner, I pass this historic place regularly without much appreciation. Big Ben as it is known is famous the world over. Its chimes are even more famous and familiar.Here are some less well known facts about Big Ben:•Each dial is seven metres in diameter•The minute hands are 4.2 metres long and weigh about 100kg (including counterweights)•The numbers are approximately 60cm long•There are 312 pieces of glass in each clock dial•A special light above the clock faces is illuminated when parliament is in session•Big Ben's timekeeping is strictly regulated by a stack of coins placed on the huge pendulum. •Big Ben has rarely stopped. Even after a bomb destroyed the Commons chamber during the Second World War, the clock tower survived and Big Ben continued to strike the hours.•The chimes of Big Ben were first broadcast by the BBC on 31 December 1923, a tradition that continues to this day.Well worth a visit.
Big Ben. If you get a chance or opputunity Stand under Big Ben when it strikes the Hour, it is something.I Worked in The City of Lonon for 10Years and Lived near to London for 20 Years

London - Big Ben - Iconic Bell within the clock tower. Built in the 1860's Big Ben is actually the bell within the clock but for well over a century now the clock and tower itself has fashioned the name. A must see for any London visitor and quite amazing is seen from the London Eye. Listen out for the chimes and watch for the London buses flying by. It can only mean you are in the English capital, London.

Big Ben & Westminster Abbey - Makes a great morning experience. Your first visit to London would be incomplete without seeing the iconic Elizabeth Tower (also referred to as Big Ben). If you plan your visit correctly, you can hear the Westminster chimes and Big Ben ringing at the turn of the hour, as it has done for nearly 150 years. Everyone knows the sound of Big Ben, hearing it up close is one of the most memorable London experiences. A great way to spend a morning in Westminster is to arrive around 8.50 am so you can be around to hear Big Ben sound off at 9am. Then, you can make your way over to Westminster Abbey to queue for the opening at 9.30am. If you are in a group, one member can stand in the queue to enter the abbey, while the rest of your party walk across the street to Parliament Square to see the statues of important historical figures like Abraham Lincoln, Nelson Mandela and Winston Churchill. This takes around 5-10 minutes time. If it is sunny outside, you will have opportunity to take some lovely pictures of Elizabeth Tower with blue skies at your back as the light conditions are usually very good at this early hour of the day. Then it will be time to enter Westminster Abbey at 9.30am for your visit to this excellent historical attraction. Visits here will last 90-120 minutes, ending a great morning in Westminster, taking in two of London's most famous and iconic attractions.

Fantastic!. Visiting Big Ben is a must while in London. Tour inside Queen Elizabeth II Tower - Hidden Gem. We had contacted our MP and organised one of their tours inside the tower before our visit. You need to do this six months before visiting (due to security clearance) if you want to include this in your visit.Our guide was very knowledgeable, and made sure to pace our 334 step climb to the top in 3 stages. In fact the pace was done to such skill and precision we were able to see and hear Big Ben (the bell) chime on the hour - a truly memorable experience.In these days of attraction high admission costs the great thing about this experience is that it is free to UK citizens.

Smaller then what you imagine, but makes up for it in character. I had seen so many photos of the big ben and so seeing it in real life made my trip to london complete. it was alot smaller then what i imagined and the actual tower is called something different, the bells inside are called big ben so you really dont actually see big ben at all! pretty cool to tick of your list but thats about it.

Must visit selfie spot!. Visiting Big Ben made the trip feel complete!We really felt like we were on holiday and enjoyed it!Got loads of cool selfies with the big guy! And had a good walk over the bridge and around the area!

An icon of London. You must include Big Ben (which is actually the name of the bell inside the tower!) in a walking tour of London. Make sure you stay to hear the chimes on every hour and if you go at night you can see the tower and the parliament buildings lit up. The best view is from Westminster Bridge.

Big Ben London. You are not taking any step forward without visiting the Big Ben whilst in London! The clock rings every 15 minutes. Don't forget to take a picture with it! It is connected with the Parliament, a church at the back and some statues of popular people such as Abraham Lincoln lol

Iconic London Landmark. Obviously Big Ben is a must see when visiting London. With so many landmark tourist attractions nearby - such as the Houses of Parliament, 10 Downing Street and Westminster Abby - London tourists almost can't avoid it, which is good. Just be careful of very aggressive drivers, pedestrians and the occasional pickpocket.
You have to see it in real life!. Big Ben is definitely a sight for sore eyes. He is way bigger in person then a picture all ever give credit.

Iconic London. The pictures don't do this monument justice. Seeing it in person is an entirely different experience. We didn't take the tour, but walking around the outside was still worth it. Make sure to include Big Ben in your trip to London.
Best clock in the world. This was very cool to see. Seeing it on pictures is different than being there and seeing it live. It is near London eye and makes a good pictures when taking pics.

One of England's icons !. Prepare your camera because you can't go to London without taking a couple of photos for Big Ben and you can cross Westminster bridge to Albert's embankment to take extremely beautiful photos for Big Ben and the Parliament House.

Spectacular Photo Opportunities. This is a MUST DO when in London. Even if you don't get a chance to go inside the architecture is amazing. Picture opportunities abound day and night, try both. Better yet, get some pics from the London Eye across the river, pretty cool views from there too.

Stop by at the top of the hour to hear Big Ben!. We always stop by this area whenever we visit London. Go on the bridge and take more fantastic pictures with The Houses of Parliament and Big Ben behind you. There is a park beside The Houses of Parliment where one can sit on a bench and have a picnic. We were there about eight o'clock one Sunday morning and there was no one else around, it was wonderful! Westminster Tube.

Big Ben london's den. Big Ben is a great landmark in London, situated on a short walk from the historic trafalgar square. The big Ben is a marvel structure where the clock is just one part of it and the beautiful towering structure another.

Good place to visit in London. Good view of the city and the actual feel of a European city you get here. The time for visit includes walk on the bank of Thames also.

Fantastic Big Ben Clock Tower. Lived in London for eleven years & saw Big Ben most weeks. When you turn the corner or come out of the Tube as soon as you spot Big Ben you are entranced. He is magnificent, Awe inspiring. Your jaw drops each time & to listen to him chime is a very proud moment. I have seen Big Ben in winter rain & brilliant sunshine & covered at night in fireworks, & he is spectacular. You have not been to London if you have not stood outside Big Ben. I was lucky enough to see inside his mechanism & he is massive. I love Big Ben always will & when you see him you will understand why he is a National Treasure we are proud of. A must see.

New year ever @ Big Ben. That was one hell life experience was ,Thousands of ppl screaming and counting and then fire works and Big ben area looks superb that night. What an area to be walk around !!!!

Wonderful tour to see the bells. UK residents can get a free tour of Elizabeth's Tower (Big Ben's clock tower) and see the bells, go behind the clock face, and see how the mechanism works. You are taught about the history of the bell. The tour needs to be booked at least two months in advance by contacting your local MP. Tours are not open to the general public or non-resident tourists. We had a lovely time. You have to climb all the stairs to the top, but this is done by stopping off at various points, and it was fine. We did this on a very hot day in July. The highlight was seeing the bells strike on the hour.

Tour of Big Ben!. I am reviewing the tour of Big Ben (Elizabeth's Tower) I had. For UK citizens, tours are free. Simply contact your MP. (Tours to see Big Ben and to climb the clock tower by visitors are not available.) Tours to the Houses of Parliament can also be taken through the same method. Tours need to be booked at least two months in advance. It was well worth it. We climbed all of the stairs to see Big Ben and were told how it worked and were shown the gears and mechanisms and went behind the clock face. It was very informative. We went up at the end of July, and it was very hot then, but we had several stops along the way. You don't climb all steps at once. Seeing the bells get struck was the highlight.

A real crowd pleaser. We passed by Big Ben and was accompanied by thousands of other tourists desperate for a good photo opportunity.There was a small protest outside on the bridge which was under control but unfortunately did cause a bit of disruption - the police had it under control however it is good to see how democratic the UK is and allows freedom of speech.

Big Ben!. When I stepped out from the tube station and looked up... My jaw dropped.. never thought it would be that HUGE! I was just amazed at the sight and was thankful for the experience of not just seeing it in movies but in real life!

Summer and Winter. in the summer many visitors come and winter will be a little. the access to get here is very easy. To find out more you can use the bus "SIGHT SEEING OF LONDON" or who are familiar with the Hop on Hop off

London's symbol. Formally called the Elisabeth Tower, "Big Ben" is of course the nick name of this clock tower of the Westminster Palace, known all over the world. Big Ben is truly the symbol of London and the famous melody played before announcing the full hour with the right number of strikes is repeated all over the world by any number of chimes. door bells etc. The architecture is Gothic; Big Ben is recognized all over the world and the word "London" pops into your mind immediately. What more could you want from a symbol!
Breathtaking. The Big Ben was magnificent, spectacular, stunning, breathtaking, very impressive, awe-inspiring, incredible, elegant. The details of every section was just out of this world.

Big Ben and the Elizabeth Tower: The face of London. Big Ben is the name of the 14 tonne bell located in the iconic Elizabeth Tower (formerly known as the Clock Tower) that rises above the Houses of Parliament in Westminster. The tower with its four-faced clock is easily one of the most recognisable buildings in the world. It has long been a symbol for the city of London and is an attraction that all first time visitors to London should try to see. Historically, the Clock Tower was included in the reconstruction of the Houses of Parliament building in 1844. Big Ben, which is interestingly a second attempt at making the famous bell (the original cracked, was melted down and recast) rang for the first time 1858 and has reliably been providing the time for Londoners and city visitors ever since. The tower is beautifully set alongside the River Thames. You can see it clearly from many locations. We like views from across the river near the the London Eye and when approaching on Westminster bridge, where you can find many spots to stop and take unobstructed views of the tower and House of Parliament building. The ringing of the Big Ben bell occurs on the hour and is accompanied by four smaller bells which play the famous Westminster Quarters melody on the quarter hour. It is a lovely and almost calming melody and greatly enhances the experience of visiting Elizabeth Tower. As such, its worth sticking around long enough to hear the Westminster Quarters if possible. Hint: For an impressive introduction to Big Ben and the tower, use the Bridge Street exit the Westminster Tube Station. You will first see the Queen Boudica Statue. Then you'll find yourself face-to-face with the tower and its beautiful clock staring directly down on you. Its a great way to see the tower for the first time.

Unique and Very Interesting. In November 2013 my partner and I decided to have a weekend in London, the main catalyst for this idea being we had been booked in for a Elizabeth 'Big Ben' Tower Tour. Many people I spoke to before and after (including myself) did not know you could go up the tower and clock face or how to obtain tickets. Luckily my partner did. You must contact your local MP (email works perfectly and MP addresses can be found on the internet) and request tickets for the tour. This is a limited tour and they can only book you in up to three months in advance. They do most week days at 11:15 and 14:15 but not weekends. It may be to get on the tour you have to take what is available or like us miss out the first time and get one the second time of asking. Actually the lady who booked this was excellent. Having not been available for the first three months they offered, a month later she wrote back (without reminder) with a selection of times for the new third month now available, of which one we took. We were sent our confirmations and safety forms in the post and ready to go. Allow about 75 minutes for the tour and turn up on time as there are warnings people who are late will miss out.When the day comes you will need ID - photo card, ie driving licence or passport and a utility bill to prove address (this is despite already having the tickets, so do not forget them). You meet at Portcullis House, which when you come out of Westminster Underground, turn left and to the end of the pavement and turn left again (do not cross the road) and Portcullis House is on the left. There is an airport style security check here but is quick and painless. You then meet your tour guide in the lobby area. You can leave bags behind as there are many steps and it is quite tight but you will have to leave cameras in the locker provided as there are no photos at all permitted. Phones can be taken but must be switched off.You start by going through a small piece of Portcullis House, which is impressive in itself and to the left joining a tunnel that goes under the road and brings you to the door and first two steps of your journey up the tower. This is not for those who lack fitness, who have health issues or are afraid of heights. There are over 300 steps up this tower (and of course the same back down again) and it is just over 200 foot high. Be sure to take a look up through the gap in spiralling stair case for an impressive view of what you are about to climb (and back down again on the return). After a good number of spiral turns you come to room one for a small breather and more information. From start to finish the tour guide was full of knowledge and interesting facts and I do not think there was anything she did not know.Having had a little sit down it is up to the clock faces, which you get to stand behind. It is a surreal experience standing behind one of the most iconic sights in the UK, if not the world. From here it is up to the actual bell 'Big Ben'. If you are here in a winter or colder month be sure to wrap up. The bell is semi outside and the wind will get in easily, making for a very cold experience if not wearing enough. If you do the 11:15 tour as we did, you will hear the chimes at 11:30, 11:45 and 12:00 and of course the main 12:00 bell ringing. Do not worry you do get ear defenders whilst standing next to it! The views from up here are also excellent. Again you can look down to get an idea of just how high up you are but not recommended for those of a nervous disposition.Having experienced the bell at full throttle you get to go down a room and see the actual mechanics of it, which is thoroughly amazing and interesting. Then it is the long walk back down, which is easier than going up.When back at the lobby you are allowed with the passes you have to wonder around Portcullis House itself (can not access everything) but it is an intriguing design and worth a look.This is an excellent tour and seemingly quite unique as many people I spoke to had no idea you could do it. It has only been running for 10 years and only 5 years as a regular tour weekly. It was quite brilliant standing and going up such a famous landmark, all without cost and I would definitely recommend this. If you are particularly keen on clocks or how everything works machine wise, add a star and make this 5 out of 5.

A London icon. What to say about Big Ben, the large bell housed in Elizabeth Tower, formerly known as the clock tower? First off, it’s a must see if this is your first time to London. Big Ben and the Tower Bridge are the two icons that most people instantly recognise as London.Plus if you’re there, you’re also close to lots of other places to visit, like Parliament, Westminster Bridge, the London Eye, Whitehall, Westminster Abbey, and the surrounding gardens.It is possible to go up the tower and see the bell, and stand behind the clock faces, but it’s not easy. First, you have to climb 334 steps of a spiral staircase. Second, you have to be a resident of the UK, make an appointment with your MP or a member of the House of Lords that you might happen to know, and wait for the first available slot. At the time of writing, October 2013, availability will open up around February 2014.

Big Ben - Palace Of Westminster. A landmark know around the world, I had an opportunity to visit in 2012, when I was invited for lunch. It's a bit like people called the UK flag "Union Jack". Big Ben is the bell, and our flag is a Union Flag, unless it's on a boat or ship.The area around The Palace Of Westminster is meticulously maintained, but overall somewhat spoilt by the security barriers etc. but vital in today's world.A good photo opportunity from all sides and just over the river from the Millennium Wheel, no visit to London would be complete with a few pictures of a truly world class landmark.

Westminster Abbey, The Tower Of Big Ben = LONDON. Big Ben is actually the 13-ton clock, not the tower, but that is academic. It's a London icon, and when viewed (and heard!) from the Westminster Bridge, overlooking Parliament, is the quintessential London experience. The tower is officially named the Elizabeth Tower, holding the largest four-faced chiming clock (Big Ben) in the world and is the third-tallest free-standing clock tower on Earth (or so the guidebooks say). For fun, call home 2 minutes before the hour…. and let them hear BIG BEN!

Get your video camera ready. Big Ben is on the Westminster stop of the Underground, on the Circle (yellow) or District (green) line. It is convenient to see Big Ben, Westminster Abbey, and Parliament at the same time. Rick Steves' London guide has a nice walking tour and description of these sights. He also has a great suggestion to arrive around noon, get video camera or smartphone ready, and record the iconoclastic gongs for posterity---or for your "in the moment" London message. Walk onto the Westminster Bridge in the afternoon (as the sun will be to your left) for nice photos.

a must see !. "Big Ben" the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London,and often extended to refer to the clock and the clock tower.The tower is now officially called the Elizabeth Tower, after being renamed in 2012 (from "Clock Tower") to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II. The tower holds the largest four-faced chiming clock in the world and is the third-tallest free-standing clock tower.[3] The tower was completed in 1858 and had its 150th anniversary on 31 May 2009, during which celebratory events took place. The tower has become one of the most prominent symbols of both London and England and is often in the establishing shot of films set in the city.

Absolutely Fantastic Sound!. If you live in the UK, email your MP and get free tickets to climb the tower (a few months ahead) You enter via portcullis house and the tour lasts about an hour. You are in a group of about 15 and there are about 334 steps, but you stop 3 times during the climb so its very easy. You stand directly underneath the bells and hear it strike, the sound is simply unbeatable and you must hear it close up. Incredible experience. Bags are not allowed up the tower but free safe storage is provided, you need to take your passport and proof of address (bill) to be allowed admittance.

Climb the tower (if you can). Fantastic experience.. If you're a UK resident you can arrange to climb the tower by contacting your local MP and it is well worth it. You'll need to do so in advance (I think we had to do it months in advance). After clearing security you are taken in a group of about twenty and start to climb the staircase before stopping for a brief talk on the history and working of the clock. You then complete the climb to see behind the clock faces (you know they're big but can't appreciate just how big until you are standing behind one), the workings of the clock mechanism, the bells including, of course, Big Ben itself (himself?) Tours are timed (ours was and I would think that they all are) so that you are standing at the bells when they chime - very impressive (and loud but you are given ear defenders).An excellent tour and well worth the climb to see behind the scenes of this London icon.

A Must In London. While in London you have to stop by this free attraction. Big Ben, the surrounding buildings and river all make for great photo's. It's also close 2 minute walk to Westminster Abbey. Lots of bus stops are also located here.

Cannot Miss!. You can't go to London without going to see Big Ben. We got off our 22 hour plane flight, dumped our luggage at Victoria Station then walked to Big Ben and explored the surrounding areas. We spent a good hour just taking photo's and taking it all in. It's bigger than you think it is and is a stunning piece of architecture. I'll never forget the first time I heard the chimes from a distance. You truly feel you are in London when you stand next to this landmark. Other top London attractions like London Eye, Horse Guards, Downing Street, Westminster Abby etc. are all within walking distance.

A MUST!!. This was fantastic. Contact your MP and arrange a visit, it is free for British Citizens living in the UK. Fantastic and really interesting. Arranged this tour by requesting it through the local MP and you go into a ballot. Email confirmation and communication was via our MP's research assistant and they arranged for us to tour the Houses of Parliament with them after our Big Ben tour.Our guide for the Elizabeth Tower was Katherine (I think that was her name). She was superb. So enthusiastic and knowledgeable, she made the tour so enjoyable, I can only express my thanks to her.The climb is long 334 steps but broken with two stops on the way up for finding out more information. You see everything, the old hammer, the clock workings, the bells (we were at the top when they chimed 3 o'clock). You have to wear ear plugs at the top but it was brilliant to be up there when it chimes. You also get to go behind the clock faces (all of them) which was fantastic.The only downside is you can't take any photographs at all, which is a shame as I would love to show family and friends.We took our 14 year old son and he loved it. Little Ben meets Big Ben. My 9 year old son named Ben had been clamouring to meet this iconic London landmark that shared his name. Having jumped off the tube at Westminster, his face was a picture as as we emerged from the station and he saw "Big Ben" for the fast time and exclaimed, "Wow, it's even bigger than I thought!"For those that don't know, Big Ben is actually the nick-name of the bell inside the tower. The Clock Tower at the north end of the Palace of Westminster was completed in 1859. The Great Clock started ticking on 31st May, with the Great Bell's strikes heard for the first time on 11th July and the quarter bells first chimed on 7th September. The Clock Tower was renamed "The Elizabeth Tower in honour of Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee in 2012.Getting a good photo of the clock tower can be quite tricky. I tried as I crossed over Westminter Bridge but the crowds kept getting in the way. It's so tall that a close shot is almost impossible! I managed to get some good ones with my family looking tiny in the foreground from near Westminster Abbey. The best vantage point to get shots of he whole of the Palace of Westminster is from the London Eye.
Very nice for photos. Always liked to see Big Ben and we had a great day with the Big Ben. Lots of photos for us.we like to take it home with us xxx

A gender change at Big Ben?. The bells have been booming from the Victorian gothic tower since the 1860s, but there is still confusion about what is which - and why the names have become what they are.Big Ben is the name given to the second great bell cast for the tower at the end of the Houses of Parliament. It's nearly E Natural (for the musical buffs) and it stands in what was until last September called the Bell Tower. However, to mark her 60 years on the throne, it was renamed the Elizabeth Tower.Twice a day - at 6pm and midnight - its chimes are heard worldwide and live.Standing alongside Big Ben at midday may seem a quick way to end up permanently deaf, but it is one of the few free tours (yes, that's right) that can be done in London these days. What's more you can keep the earplugs that you are given.Look on the web for booking information. We did it through an MP 's office.The guide is exceptional, but starts you off worrying whether you will survive the 330-plus steps to the bell chamber. Well, at around 18 stone and aged 66, I did it yesterday, and was none the worse for the experience.(You have to walk - there is no lift)You meet your guide in the MPs new offices at Portcullis House opposite Parliament Square, then it's a short walk under Westminster Bridge to reach the foot of the famous tower.It's just over 100 steps to the first "rest camp" - about the same as most church towers, but with plenty more room and wider steps.Two more breaks are taken and each time your guide gives you more information, facts and anecdotes about the building and the rows, court actions and unusual solutions that occurred during its construction.It was in 1972 that the old copper penny was withdrawn, but a number still play an important part in the task of keeping the clock accurate to within two seconds. But go and see: we are so glad we went.

See this Up Close to Understand the Scale. BIG BEN TOUR (ELIZABETH TOWER). One of the greatest tours I have been on. The 334 steps are worth it!. Don't be too put off by the steps, it is a sprial staircase which is fairly narrow BUT you do get to rest three times (seated) on the way to the top for a good 10-15 mins when the guide will tell you about the history of Big Ben.I hadn't realised we would be close enough to touch the clock face and on a lovely sunny day standing behind the south facing one with the sun streaming in, we could see the second hand moving every two seconds. Very up close and pesonal.The rungs are still there where the gas light would be ignited each night to light the clock face for Londoners and I now know that the light at the very top (forget its name begins with A) is on when parliament is sitting at night. (So that Queen Victoria could see whether her ministers were working). Basically there are three main rooms to see; the clock faces themselves, the room housing the mechanism (really quite fascinating - a huge antique) and the bell tower. We were wearing earplugs (essential but provided) in the bell tower when the clock struck 3pm. An historical day when Margaret Thatcher died, we could see all the parliamentary buildings flags flying at half mast.I went up the tower with our eleven year old son while my husband and 7 year old son amused themselves elsewhere. When our youngest is old enough, we will definitely go back!As an earlier reviewer mentioned, email your local MP for free tickets and incorporate this with a tour of the houses of parliament (our seven year old was old enough for this one). I will review HoP separately.

Icon of London - Experienced Underwhelmingly Quickly. Having stayed at a hotel in Westminster, my girlfriend and I passed by Big Ben (now Elizabeth Tower) countless times during our holiday in London in November 2012. The hourly chime always served to remind us of our being in London!Seeing it for ourselves the first time, we felt that the tower looked shorter than we imagined it to be, but were nevertheless impressed by the amount of detail and craftsmanship that went into its construction.On a clear day, Big Ben is also very beautiful set against the blue sky.15 minutes is more than enough to take all the photos you want of this icon of London, making Big Ben somewhat of a 'something to see along the way' rather than an attraction to visit. That being said, it's close to Westminster Abbey, which most people will probably visit.Good points:- Hard to miss once you're in central Westminster.- Many good spots for photo-taking. - Hourly chimes contribute to the atmosphere.Bad points:- Unfortunately, it is not possible for tourists to visit the inside of the Big Ben. UK residents, however, can apparently file a request with their MP to visit.- Feels somewhat underwhelming to just spend 5 - 10 minutes seeing something that is so central to London's identity and simply moving on to somewhere else afterwards.Others:- Spend some time around the area to visit (even if it's just passing by) the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey. It really helps you soak in London's heritage.

The bells, the bells..... We arranged a tour of Elizabeth Tower (the name of the tower that houses Big Ben, which is the bell, not the building) through our local MP, and were allocated a time slot. You go through strict airport-style security just to get in to Portcullis House on the opposite corner where there is a small waiting room with a few seats, and toilets are available. Bags and cameras are not allowed up the tower, and mobile phones must be switched off (partly for security reasons, but also because of the time restraint - a dozen people taking photos of each other all the way up could take half a day!). There is a locked cupboard where bags and coats can be stored, although it is advisable to keep your coat on as the top of the tower is open to the elements, and it can be windy and cold. You get taken under the road and into the Tower by two guides, one at the front and one bringing up the rear. Any health and safety issues are raised before you set off, and anyone who is pregnant, suffers from asthma or vertigo, high or low blood pressure etc, are advised to stick to the back end of the group, so as not to feel any pressure. There were about a dozen or so people in our group. Although there are 334 steps in a spiral staircase, the climb is not as difficult as it sounds - the pace is relaxed, and you can take it at your own speed (hence the guide at the back to bring up the rear); also the steps are not all that steep. You also stop to rest a couple of times on the way up, with seats to relax while the guides fill you in on the history of the tower and bells. The aim is to make it to the level where the Big Ben bell is for the chime on the hour - it is extremely loud and I would recommend that you wear the earplugs that are issued to you. The whole floor vibrates, and it is an amazing experience to be up there for the chime. The view from there is pretty good too. On the way back down you get to walk behind all the four the clock faces (VERY cool!) before descending to the bottom again. You even get a certificate to prove you did it! It was well worth it!

Must See. The clock tower is in fact named St. Stephen's Tower, and the big bell inside it goes by the name of Big Ben, but most people simply call the whole package of tower, clock and bell "Big Ben". Anyway, it is perhaps the most famous symbol of London, so you shouldn't go to London without seeing Big Ben.The tower is not very tall but the four-faced clock is impressive, and the Big Ben bell sounds wonderful. So try to be there when it strikes on the hour. The best view is from Westminster Bridge, from where you'll see Westminster Palace and Big Ben together.By the way: you'll find another great view of the Big Ben clocktower from the steps to the entrance of the National Gallery on Trafalgar Square. It's a 5-10 minute walk down Whitehall, where you'll pass the Cenotaph monument, Downing Street, the Banqueting House and the Horse Guards. Lots of photo opportunities.

Hickory Dickory clock. I’ve lived in London now for nearly 25 year and every day I come into the city, I spare time for a look at Big Ben. Ok, first off, let’s get this straight, for the record. What you see is Elizabeth Tower, completed in 1859. What you hear strike every quarter, half and hour is the great bell, nicknamed by Londoners as ‘Big Ben.’ We say ‘struck’ because Big Ben doesn’t have a clapper; rather it is struck by a hammer. All UK residents own Big Ben and can tour the Tower for FREE. There are set times and bookings must be made in advance – at least four months – and through your local MP. Alas, non UK residents cannot tour the Tower – this is a UK resident exclusive. But there is an excellent virtual tour at http://www.parliament.uk/bigben. Still, the best way to experience the Tower and Bell is from Westminster Bridge, preferably on as sunny day with a nice breeze, as you gaze down the Thames, enjoying an ice cream.

You have to see it just to say you did. Checking out Big Ben should only take a few minutes of your time. It's one of those iconic landmarks that when you actually are in front of it, you're not really sure what to do or how long to spend. It's cool, hear it ring, take some pictures and then go on your way. If you want a really cool picture, walk towards the Westminstsr Bridge. There's a horse statue and if you position yourself right on the stairs you can get a super awesome, artsy photo of the statue with Big Ben directly in the background.

best place for a photo op is on the southbank. If you want a great picture of this beautiful landmark - Houses of Parliament - the best place is right across the river, at the south bank. Not too many people go there and you can take all the pictures you want without bumping into other people. You also get a full view of the building, and the clock. Most tourists take their pictures right in front of the building or on the bridge - in both cases, there are a lot of people and buses and other vehicles that block your view. If you're in London on Remembrance Day, the entire area is closed off to vehicles and, once the ceremonies are over, you can just walk on the street and take pictures up close.

Have to hear Big Ben ring out. If you are in London then you must go and hear Big Ben ring out the hour. Many assume that Big Ben is the clock and tower but it is actually the bell inside. Picturesque. As several commenters have stated, "Big Ben" is actually the largest bell inside the tower, which, until recently, was aptly named the Clock Tower. Now, it is named Elizabeth Tower, and stands opposite Victoria tower. A story you may NOT know, however, is that the original bell actually cracked during testing, and the replacement cracked three months after it was installed. In the tower, the bell was rotated an eighth of a turn and still rings today, crack and all. If you listen closely as it rings, you can hear the slight flatness and reduced quality, as opposed to the normal pitch and resonance of a large bell. This is a must see while in London. Also, cross the Thames and look back at the towers and hosues of parliament. If you have the opportunity, also see them while lit up at night.

Reminds Me of the Mona Lisa. We all know Big Ben is the name of the great bell, not the clock tower...but, given how iconic the structure has become, it is somewhat underwhelming when you first catch sight of it... Much like the Mona Lisa.That is, until you stop to look at it properly. Just like the Mona Lisa, the longer you look at the tower, the better it gets. They may not have an enigmatic smile, but its faces are still utterly remarkable to behold; 5 tonnes of iron railings and opal glass, 55 metres off the ground, with hands over 7 metres long and a 35-metre tall cast iron spire. Of course, reading statistics is pointless - go and see it for yourself!

Outstanding monument that can be seen and heard from far away ..... Big Ben is an outstanding monument on the Houses of Parliament that can be seen and heard from far away .......It is always special to cross the River Thames and look back from the London Eye to check the time on your watch and also to hear Big Ben chiming on the hour with its distinctive charm ........The clock is maintained reguarly and cleaned to ensure it always tells the correct time .......The cloch tower is over 96metres high and 12 metres square .....there are 334 steps to the belfry .....the hour hands are made of gun metal that are each 2.7metres long and weigh around 300kgs including counterweights ..... The minute hands are made of copper sheet 4.2 metres long and weigh 100kgs including counterweights that travel a distance equal to 120 miles a year .......the Big Ben bell weighs 14 tonnes and the hammer that strikes the bell weighs 200kgs ........Big Ben is one of the most famous landmarks in London - not to be missed ..........
