very very interesting. You can see this from the outside 24/7 but need to book to go in and up. Big ben is the bell, but there are several bells on top. When ringing and if you are on the platform you have to wear ear protecton it is unbelievably loud. The clock itself is not as big as you would expect and interesting in its own right. The clock faces themselves are illuminated by very large hand made bulbs and the faces are very large. There are displays giving relevant info before you go up yes there are a lot of stairs. A briliant visit if you can get in, You need to do that a long time in advance and security is stringent.

Can't come to London without seeing Big Ben.. This is another London Icon that you must stop and see. Wonderful during the day or night. Especially since it is right in the heart of the London tourist sites along the River Thames.

London. This is the image of London. It's fantastic when you walk around and see lots of people taking a picture of it on their knees so that it fits in the frame. Make sure you take a few extra pictures!

A clock and bell. It is worth a minute during one's tour of Parliment to look up at Big Ben, which is a clock with a bell called Big Ben. But since you cannot go in, there is nothing more to see. Luckily it is free.

Iconic. It's Big Ben... the only thing that would make it better is to be able to go inside. Rain or shine it's worth taking the time to see. The only thing I would reccomend is a picture form across the river (which i did not get).

Great for first timers !. If you live in london than Big Ben has long since lost any of the original magic and intensity that it had when you first visited. For tourists however, Big ben is an iconic globally recognized symbol of london and it is OBVIOUSLY worth a visit, the beautiful Neo-gothic architecture is very symbolic of London and the palace of westminster juxtaposes beautifully with the grand clock. The chiming of the bells is very loud and is quite annoying. If you have never been to london before you should definitely pay it a visit it's quite fascinating to see with your own eyes a buildig whcih has been in countless films and postcards.
Building that need to see. Been there several time. Actually, nothing special, but I still visit there every time that I arriving to London.Maybe in the future...

Amazing. lovely archetechture in the main building and the experience was out of this world. The tower itself was mindblowing and the atmosphere was great. The staff were polite and i would highly recomend this trip. It makes london special.I got annoyed as the chiming of the bells was very loud and burst my eardrums. It was an amazing experience and i would love to go again. Overall a fabulous trip, thanks to mike bridgewater. xoxoxo
Very cool to see. Nothing to take a tour on but as an iconic structure in London, it and Parliament were very cool to see as was London Bridge.
Majestic. It´s really big and majestic. it can be viewed from many parts of London. By The River Thames is a nice view for sure.

Famous Clocks. Probably the most famous iconic clock in the world located near Westminster underground station but avoid rush hour as thecareavwill be packed with computers
Great time to view early evening when Big Ben is lit lovely sight great architecture great buiding London's key landmark
Just what you would expect.. Way too many other people. Most of them are pushy. Many of them are eating something messy. Children are not looked after by anyone.

Awe inspiring. Big Ben is one of the highlights of my visit to London. When one thinks of London, one never forgets to mention Big Ben. When the quarter hour strikes, it can be heard for a great distance away.
Beautiful during the day...fantastic at night!. I've been here twice and both times i've been amazed! Amazing architecture and so beautiful when lit up at night. A must see!
Small Ben. Well known around the world but a little small and area too congested . Nearest Tube is Wesminster, but try and avoid rush hour times.
Lovely to walk around it. Impressive to see up close after seeing it so many times on the tv. We were fortunate enough to have a hotel looking out at it so got to see and hear it often

nice walk. very nice lovely walk around big ben and area, it is very large and coated in gold . it is a awsome sight and i am so glad i was able to see with my own eyes.. great view from the river tymes and from the london eye
WOW!. I've seen Big Ben in news, photos, papers, magazines but nothing prepares me when I see it up close. It's just so amazing and amazing. This is the place to be to soak in the British bug.

Great and Iconic Landmark. Definatly worth a visit if you are an avid walker like me. Also a great landmark for navigating in the Westminster area. Be sure to drop by at dusk or night, as the clock tower lights up beautifully, and linger to hear Big Ben itself strike.
Its an iconic landmark of London and well kept. Don't miss it.
Nice to go around. This was nice to walk past, one of the things I had to go to in London. One of my London souvenirs is actually of Big Ben, a nice keychain. One of the landmarks in London

Awesome. What's not to like , it's Big Ben !
Where could you see this architecture ,with its history anywhere else in the world.
What a sight!. Get on the tube, get off at Westminster and prepare yourself for some wonderful history. What a delight this was

London Olympics. Looked sharp , represented London Very well
a proud landmark, great to see on a sunny day
Have to see if u are visting London

Nice. Even though you cannot actually see Ben, since he is the bell inside the clock it was breath taking. So many times have I heard of Big Ben and to actually be there to see it with my own eyes was surreal.

It grows on you. What amazed me about the Clock Tower (Remember, Big Ben is the bell) is that it is lined with what looks like gold leaf. That's something that cannot be noticed from any photograph that I've ever seen. It makes the Clock Tower so much prettier in person than you imagined. Parliament is amazingly ornate, but the Clock Tower just adds so much beauty. For those of us from the U.S. we have so many iconic structures in our country, a tip of the hat to the people of the U.K. for such a really neat one!
Loved it!. It is a beautiful clock with enormous amount of detail. I think it looks best at dusk when the lights come on!
it is a must!!. if you dont go to the Big Ben the you haven't enjoy London.the area is the best ladmark of London... close to the Westmister Abbey and London eye....
Big Ben- the symbol of London. Big Ben is by far the most known symbol of London: elegant, impressive,imposing.All the tours will take you to Big Ben and the area is beautiful to walk.
Big Ben. Yes, an incredible icon that captures London's vibrant heart and lit up at night is truly worth the watch... But it's just a clock, you can't do anything with it apart from take pictures.

Incredible Icon!. This was our first thing to see after leaving the train station. It was beautiful. Hearing the bells chime was just amazing. Take your time, view it from across the river, and take tons of pictures. You will love reflecting on your visit.
Good old Ben. It's a standby how could you not see Big Ben. It's great at midnight and the area surrounding it is fantastic lots to do and see.

Great to See - Fantastic to Hear. We went by Big Ben many times on our three day visit and enjoyed seeing it. Once, we got lucky and heard it chime - only on the hour - and the sound was beautiful Try to time your visit to hear the Chimes.

THE MORE YOU GET TO KNOW HIM, THE MORE YOU FALL IN LOVE. It´s like a character, an illustrious inhabitant of London. Who doesn´t know its image? Anyway, getting out of Westminster tube station, it raises with majesty in front of your eyes as if you had never seen it before!
Better than expected. You can feel the power of the British Empire. Standing before Big Ben you can sense the might that the British once had...
Its a clock. Nice land mark and makes a good backdrop for pics, shame you can not get into it and walk up. Be there when it strikes for full effect.
Amazing to see in person. So iconic...it is hard to believe that you are viewing it in person! Busy area but picture taking opportunities abound.

Really nice. Been there twice now, and after five days in London we had passed in front of it a number of times.
It's a very nice site. When around that area there are many nice sites, and this is just one of them.

Not much to see, but you can't miss it. There's not much to actually do or see with Big Ben (or, Victoria Tower, as the British Parliament would like to have you call it now). But, it's an icon in Britain and you really can't miss it. It's shorter than I thought it'd be, but still an attractive clock tower.
View is outstanding.. Beautiful sunny day permitted excellent visualization. Better viewing in person that postcard shots.
What a view!. The first view of "Ben" was awesome. Then, everywhere i looked, no matter where in the city, from all vantages, there it was again. Each time, looking majestic.

great symbol of London!. it's just a clock, but you know you have arrived in London, Great views from the Thames
you can't miss it if you are visiting the Abby and parliament

Take underground at night to Westminster and exit . . .. Follow the exit signs to the House of Parliament. At night, it is a bit of a long tunnel that can be a little lonely.You'll walk out LITERALLY at the bottom of Big Ben.Our conversation as we ascended the final 15 steps out of the station exit:My wife: "Wow, look at the intricate stone work on the building in front of us."Me: "Yeah. It looks old and really cool. Wonder what it is."My wife: "Oh! It keeps going up, its tall. Look at that tower."Me: "Oh *$%&#! That's Big Ben!"We planned on seeing Big Ben at night during our first night in London. But this was an awesomely dramatic surprise.Walked across Westminster Bridge, around London Eye, and back to station. Nice safe area in early evening, still lots of tourists. Left area around 9-10 pm.

Breathtaking!. Anyone who is anyone has seen this infamous structure amidst London's skyline. It is absolutely amazing. I would highly recommend taking a river cruise in the evening so you can see Big Ben all lit up.
Amazing. Everything...history and architecture just mind blowing, beefeater tour guides very amusing and informative...nice touch

Famous must see landmark.. Photos do not do it justice. Only when you are standing there beside it, can you fully appreciate it's beauty and the extent of the detailed work involved in it's make-up. Include it in your city tour.
Fantastic Views. If you can get a tour of Big Ben via your local MP it's a once in a lifetime tour. You will need earplugs! Really fascinating and interesting afternoon
Huge!. Don't forget to look up if you are heading to Westminster Abbey. The bell chimes 4 times an hour and what a treat to hear them on the hour.
looks great.. A must see when in central London.looks a lot more impressive in real life than on the TV etc....Great.
Grand. Amazing sight. Parliament house is often open. Read local guides as to when it is open and visit. Located in Westminster, many other local attractions can be visited.

Big Ben and London, You Gotta See It!. Okay, so because we were not residents we could not tour the clock (very dissapointing when you think how us tourists are bringing much-need cash into the economy...) but a sad reminder of how terrorism has brought fear in the world. We still enjoyed seeing it "from below" and of course we had to stick around and hear it chime (it's Big Ben!) Stroll across the bridge and enjoy the river walk while yo're there.

A great timeless tourist attraction - will return. Lobe Big Ben!! An essential spot to visit irrespective of how many times you visit London.... Will return everytime I make the treck from Australia...

Big Ben, Parliment. Yeah,,, Ya got to see it. I have no idea if you could tour it or not, but to be fair I could not be bothered.Get close enough, get a good picture. I found the best photo spot was from the south side of the river. There is a foot path that goes from the London Eye all the way up to Paddington. From there you can find a quiet bench with a classic London View.

Great. Couldn't believe that I was actually hearing/seeing it. The dream of a lifetime come true. Was also able to take video of the chimming for my grandsons who had studied London at school last term

Iconic. For me, big ben perfectly captures the essence of London. On a sunny day the view is absolutely gorgeous! The building itself is quite majestic and really stands out in the middle of the modern city.

Still Standing Hanging!. Not much more says London than this Tower - Worth a visit or just admire from across the street. It looks much grander in person than on any picture I seen. Many other sites to see in the vicinity.

Disppointed. messy, crowded, lots of debris in the area, campers outside the place and security are not friendly when tourist asking for directions. Don't waste time walking that area, it's a great view from afar.
a must see to get a photo. just one of those sights that should not be missed very cool to see the clock is more incredible up close and personal. a must have photo shot

My Favorite Part of London. Not real sure what it is about Big Ben but it captivated me. I had to come back and look at him from many angles a few different times. Something about Big Ben is majestic and worth taking the time to see.
Impressive Landmark. You can't help but notice Big Ben. Well lit at night. The back end which you never see on TV is a special treat. Beautiful architecture.

Impressive area of London!. The whole area around Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament is beautiful! Lots of people milling about, however, the spaces are large - take the time to stop and look full circle! If the walls could speak, what stories could be told!

A Magnificent Site. Big Ben is nothing but magnificent! To see something such as this in person is a once in a lifetime experience that cannot be under appreciated. To walk around Central London and see Big Ben rising above Parliament is something I will never forget!

Climbing High. We were lucky enough to be able to visit the closk tower and go up to see Big Ben. There was lots of fasinating facts on the way up and it was good to see the working of the clock and the old pennies still keeping time. Iconic and unmissable
beautiful. Big Ben was sparkling with the gold details around the clock face. We took lots of pictures while walking across the bridge by Big Ben. It was beautiful!
Sunset with Big Ben. We sat at a very cool little bar on the south side of the Westminster Bridge and watched the sunset and the lights come on at Parliament. It was a very nice evening.

Cool to see. It's nice to see and photograph. One of those "I'm really in London" monuments. As far as I know there's not way to go inside the actual bell tower though, so all you can do is admire it from the outside.

St Stephens clock tower is what houses big ben. Attached to the houses of parliament, and on parliament square, you have also westminster cathedral, pall mall, hourseguards within spitting distance. I'm not that impressed with big ben, although it IS loud and also synonimous with Londo

Better than expected.. We have heard all our lives of Big Ben and have even heard the saying, "Big Ben, no big deal", but it was a big deal. We were very impressed by the sight and sound of this great landmark.

Worth the Climb. It's definitely worth booking a trip to climb into the clock tower - and if you're there as the hour strikes be ready to cover your ears!! You have to contact your local MP to arrange the visit and they get booked up far in advance so have a choice of dates ready.
SUPER!!!!. Till now, I saw Big Ben only on the picture and for me it was a great building. Now I changed my minde, this is not a great building, this is fantastic and more than fantastic!!!!!
SUPER!!!!. Till now, I saw Big Ben only on the picture and for me it was a great building. Now I changed my minde, this is not a great building, this is fantastic and more than fantastic!!!!!
a must see in London!. this is an icon that is a must see when visiting London. It is also conveniently located just across the bridge from the London Eye and very photogenic!

Wonderful sights. Saw Big Ben and all of the main attractions in London from Top of Big Bus. Yet again London did n't disappoint. Was only there for two nights, but it's my 5th visit would go back again any time.

A bit surreal... I guess it's one of those things you just have to see even though you've seen it a million times over in pictures, tv and movies. But when you do see it, it is just as you imagined...although maybe a little bit smaller. If you are on a bus I do suggest hopping off and wandering around the area as there are so many sights to see...and definitely get your own picture of what must be the best known clock tower ever!
It's Big Ben! Amazing!. Seeing Big Ben is the icing on the cake of your trip to London! Perfect pictures guaranteed everytime and recognizable the world over!
It's not a whole tower. Only a watch inside of tower is a big ben¨!! I didn't know that!! :)))Must have of LONDON!!! You can take great pictures infront od it
a royal figure. Big Ben has a very striking appearance, it stands tall and like a royal figure at one corner of the Houses of Parliament, very photogenic.
Have To See Big Ben!. Big Ben lives up to everything I've seen on television and magazines. It is so cool to actually see in person. You can't possibly make a trip to London without seeing Ol' Ben.

Iconic London. This is an attraction that most of us have seen in photos and looks very much the same in reality. If you go on any tour bus, there is no chance of missing it. If you do miss, I wouldn't consider that a tragedy

Big Ben is the bell....... Big Ben is the bell. If you are not a resident of the UK, you will not see Big Ben. Even the residents have to book in advance through their constituency to visit this attraction. I just thought clarification would be helpful. I rated this excellent as the Elizabeth Tower, which houses the bell, is still a must see.
Take your Camera!!. As soon as we got out of the underground station the Big Ben bells started to ring and it was perfect timing. Make sure you hear the bell ring!! Must see if you love taking photos
Iconic. You can't go to London and not see this iconic clock tower, by day or night it is a wonderful sight!

World famous, impressive. Amazing to see the clock tower in person. Did not get to hear Big Ben itself since it rings only for special occasions. But even the hourly bell was impressive exxpecially considering it is well over 200 yr old.
Fantastic Big Ben. How can you travel to London and not see Big Ben, when this place is lit up by the morning sun of at night when London's buzzing its a real welcome to the big city, enjoy.
Make sure too see at night. I saw at day and night. During the day its cool...great architecture...but its a big giant clock. I suggest you go at night because it is breathtaking!!
Amazing monument. Beautiful monument in the centre of the city by the River Thames....just love the atmosphere there. Highly recommended to anyone coming to London.

Dream come true. Since I was a little girl I always dream it to see Big Ben then finly I made it my dream come true I have such a good time
An excelent place and full of tourists, spectacular at night it's just wonderful to be there

Is Big Ben the clock or the bell?. Well Big Ben is actually the 14 ton bell in St Stephens Clock Tower. It is the largest bell in the chime. St Stephens Tower is Iconic and I would guess you haver seen photos of it.
Fascinating. I have always been fascinated by Big Ben. It lived up to my expectations. The best view of it was from the London Eye at night!!
Big Ben. Always has been always will be a wonderful landmark to our great capital, London. When you come out of Westminster underground it is right in front of you. Magnificent.

One word, amazing!. The first time I got to see this amazing landmark it took my breath away. Everyone has one way or another seen Big Ben in movies or in pictures. So it's a little stunning to be standing in front of this iconic building. I went with my fiancée to London so we obviously wanted to take a photograph in front of Big Ben, but it was difficult to take a picture with me holding the camera. They're always tourist trying to take photographs too so we simply asked another couple that was there trying to do the same thing. In return, we took the couple's photograph for them too. Don't be shy in asking people to take a photograph for you but just be courteous too and offer to take theirs after.
Nice to meet him. Big Ben can only be seen from the outside for tourist but you can get a nice picture from half way across the bridge

A Photo of Every Minute. Once we collated our Big Ben photos, I think there is a photo of its clock face for about every minute from 8AM through 10PM. They have named its tower the Queen Elizabeth Tower. Big Ben was cleaned and spiffed up a few years ago and looks great now. The chimes are some of the most familiar in the world.

The icon of London. I didn't go in it because they only allow UK citizens access which they have to request through their government official. This is what I learned ab Parliament. But I did take many pictures from the outside, and feel I accomplished seeing Big Ben. And it truly is an icon of London.
Only took photos. This a huge time piece...wow...you can see it for miles -- take a ride on the EYE and the views of BENNY are great !
It's a big clock. I must not get it because all I saw was a big clock! I already knew that but I was hoping for something a little more spectacular.
Big Ben. When you hear this words you know that you have to see this! So if you didn't , you should! I love Central London!

A must see while in London!!!. The Big Bend clock chime is just magical to see and to listen to it chime! Plus there is so much to see in the area: Westminster Abbey, Houses of Parliment, Hourse Guard Parade and Whitehall are all within a short walk of Big Ben.Make sure to stop to hear the chimes on the hour...........wonderful! One of life's small pleasures.
Big Ben. Every time we go to London we always go and have another look at Big Ben. My mum loved seeing it in real life instead of on the telly.
It's Big Ben!. You can't go to London and not see Big Ben. Enormous and very impressive. Loved hearing the clock strike 12!!

I love Big Ben and his tower!. My favorite thing to do in London is see the tower and listen to BigBen chime. I am always amazed at how many places you can see it from. If you stand near St Margaret's you can take photos of both the tower and the London Eye.

Big Ben is the Bell Only!. Walking from Waterloo, opposite the London Eye. The Queen Elizabeth Tower, houses Big Ben, the bell. Classic sight for the Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliment). Best photos taken on Westminster Bridge.

UK voter? Climb the tower!. If you are a registered UK voter, you can contact your MP and ask to go on a tour of the Elizabeth Tower (previously known as the Clock Tower) and see Big Ben.The tour is free but does require you to climb 334 steps. The steps are a circular staircase so it can get a bit dizzying but there are two stops on the way up and one stop on the way down.Ear plugs are provided!We were lucky enough to go on a tour that got us up to the bells in time for the midday strikes. Absolutely amazing - such a privilege and highly recommended.
Big Ben at night. We just hung out and listened to the big clock chime. Experimented taking photos at night while double decker buses whizzed by. It was a beautiful night

Stunning building. Big Ben another must have see when you visit the capital. It was very impressive esp the architecture, and Westminster at its side, just near by in sight is the London Eye too, best way to get around is on the hop on hop off bus that has a tour guide that will tell you fab facts and information about well known landmarks we were lucky too as we were passing it was doing the famous donggggg.
Impressive. Not to many words about this as of course is amazing is a shame that you cant go to visit as before and you can only see it from the street.but understandable security reasons.

Big Ben is the beacon of Westminster Palace. Marvellous for photos, but please do the Palace tour. Guides are well informed and the paintings are wonderful. House iof Commons is sharp contrast to House of Lords in terms of opulence.
See it just to say you have. Big Ben is a national icon , but Perhaps as a local I don't appreciate it as much as a tourist would as such, but get your full of pictures and move on.

Iconic!. I love everything about London. The architecture, the culture, the history... Every turn unveils a new find. There is something for everyone to see and be interested by. Big Ben is an example of this. It's iconic and stands for something. A huge tourist attractions that people flock to see. Big Ben features in some of the most world wide, well known programs and events. A must see when visiting London.

Great. I have seen Big Ben numerous time on TV but this is the first time I have seen it for real. The clock is beautifully crafted and it's really a symbol of London. You can't say you have been to London if you have not been to the Big Ben.

Elizabeth's Tower. It is in fact a big tower with a clock, but it is the Big Ben, one of England's most important landmark. I felt so excited for being there that I just enjoyed every second. Its so imponent with all that gold and so british with such an iconic architecture. You feel so comfortable with it, cause it is so familiar, but you just can't stop stairing at it, because it is so full of details. Loved it!

emblematic. Big Ben is the deep bell not the tower, the tower is st stephens tower. However this is a sight to see a clock to witness and the chimes impressive. be here and hear the hour sound and you know you are in london, rain or shine you get different impressions but both express this fair city well. the bell has an interesting story - cast at the bethnal green foundry it was made to the deisgners recipe (not what the foundry would have used) hence it cracked. this crack has created the beautiful sound we hear today

a big tower, with a clock. The clock tower (official name) and the big ben (the clock inside) are ok to watch, you should pass by once... There is not a lot more to tell about this (it's a tower with a clock).
Beautiful photo spot. Ionic London site and photo-op. It's visible from London Eye and we passed it on the hop on hop off tour.

Great for photos-go on a clear day.. When we went there were many roadworks, you can't go in or near it but it is great to get photos in front of and an iconic sight to see. Go along Birdcage walk and you can take excellent photos from the traffic island there. Wait for the lights. There are still some red pillar box phones you can get photos in too.See it while you are doing a walking tour of London you can see St James' park and Buckingham Palace too.

Big Ben. Lovely place to visit and the place arroung is amazing as well! You have to go there yourselves to watch it, there are not words to desrcibe the beauty of Big Ben! Highly recommended from me!

Big Ben Sums Up London. Big Ben just sums up London like the Liberty Statue sums up NYC. It sounds out on its own, can be seen for miles and is a truly awesome building. anyone visiting London should visit Big Ben.
Landmark of England. Sort of sums up the British ethos.-Solid and conservative,not overdone! It is the quintessential British Landmark.

Big Ben - (Elizabeth Tower). Big Ben is of course the affectionate name given to the tower but as some people sometimes point out the Great Hour Bell is called BIG BEN and NOT the whole tower - that is now called Elizabeth Tower - after out great Monarch Queen Elizabeth II

You know, the tall tower at the north end of Wesminster Abbey.... You haven't gone to London if you haven't gone to Westminster Abbey and see the Big ben. And the easiest way to go there is by the tube. Jump off in Westminster Tube Station, you will see the big ben when you feel the fresh air.

A fabulous experience.. This trip has to be arranged by your local MP. Details are found online as long as you know the name of your MP! Kids have to be 11 years old or over. This is due to the 300 odd steps to climb to the top. They are not climbed in one go - I worried that we wouldn't make it to the top but it is climbed in stages with talks on a few levels and was very easy. A couple in their early 80's managed it without looking too puffed out. A guide provides very interesting info. I just wished I could have remembered it all! The obvious highlight is the best view ever over London & of course listening to Big Ben chime at extremely close range (with earplugs provided). For security reasons you are not permitted to take photos, which is a shame as the photos would be completely & utterly awesome! We thought it was a fantastic trip that we will always remember.

My London Favourite. The building is just stunning. The architecture is just amazing. The sound of the bell is just fabulous. You can take great pictures from South Bank, just where London Eye is. The London must-do.

" An Amazing Result of Men's Creativity ". The amazing sight of the building made me appreciate the creativity of every man who contributed in the construction of the greatest London landmarks. I can compare the great architectural designs of the buillding where the " Big Ben" is to Athens and the Roman Empire. Each part of this huge structure was obviously carefully crafted specially the " Big Ben " itself ( the bell ). Indeed, it is an amazing piece of art which resulted to men's boundless creativity.

A must see attraction in London! Get your camera ready!. This is a must see! It got me excited just to see the building. Although it is somewhat confusing how this clock tower is connected to Westminster Abbey and the House of Parliament (or I think it is). We got some great photos from our double-decker tour bus and on the ground. We must have taken 20+ pics of this landmark. So glad we got to see this in real life!

It's not so big . I always imagined big Ben to be huge. It's not but it is very impressive and as our guide told us it is the bell inside the tower that is called big Ben. You have got to see this if you visit London.

A must when in London. Spectacular landmark on the banks of the Thames... We waited until the clock struck the hour just to hear the bells / chimes and we were not disappointed. Great views from all around on the embankment and the bridge.But beware of the eastern European trying to sell cheap imitations on the bridge and another pick pocket paradise !!

True English land mark. A must see when you visit London, just hearing big Ben makes me smile! Some great views from on the bridge! I love the chimes and the look ad the building and think everyone has to spend the time to see Big Ben and hear the chimes!
Beautiful. One of my favotite parts of London. See it at night that's when it is most beautiful. Don't miss if you go to london.

London's Icon. It's an amazing land mark for London, awesome architecture with its unmistakable chime, every one knows of Big Ben. The only problem I have is that there isn't a convenient place to stop and wait to hear the chimes go off.
It's an icon. There's not much more I can say about Big Ben that hasn't already been said. It's BIG BEN what more is there to say? It's sort of like a really famous rock star! Everyone knows Big Ben.
if to see one thing in london, it is "BIG BEN".. so big, breath taking, and "the" Symbol of london. but again, you can NOT visit the tower from inside,

Great and awesome architecture. Great and awesome architecture..But from my point of view, Parliament building in Budapest, Hungary is better and the best.you can take a good whole picture of the whole parliament building from the bridge.From there, also can see a good view of London eyes across the river.Buckingham Palace is also not far, just about 15-20 minutes walk across a park.The underground station for this attraction is Westminster.

Big Ben. The Big Ben is a fabulous land mark in the middle of London.It is lovely to see and you can also see it from far apart across London.When you go to the top of the London Eye, you can see that it is absolutely amazing from up above.We will be back again to see The Big Ben and The Houses of Parliament!
What's the time?. I was pleased to see the clock showed the correct time. It's always a good grin to ask a stranger the time while standing underneath the worlds most famous clock tower.
Big Ben. I have several "amazing" pictures of BIG BEN! It is there for all to see...and admire! English people are proud of this and every one who sees it should be too!

A "must see" British icon!. The Houses of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower, newly renamed in 2012 to honour Queen Elizabeth's Diamond Jubilee, are commonly thought of as Big Ben. However, London's most famous icon is a massive bell, the largest of five bells inside the clock tower. This is one of the most popuar tourists sights in London and can be seen from a great vantage point on the Westminster Bridge for good photographs.

Big Ben. I take all my overseas visitors here, it is in the centre of so much the London Eye, the Aquarium nearby, Downing Street a stones throw awy, House of Parliament, 10 min walk to Trafalgar Square and most of all it is awesome such a British landmark and soo lovely now the scaffolding is off, brilliant to see this so many times a year.

Former landmark no 1 in London. Big Ben is 96,3 meters high, and before the London Eye was built it was London's no 1 landmark. It has a lot of history since it was build back in 1858. The bell is very heavy (14,5 tonns), and therefore the name Big Ben. It's really not that exciting to sit and watch this tower, but take a picture and check off your list of travel wishes.

Incredible architecture!. The tower that houses Big Ben (which refers to the bells, not the tower itself) is a beautiful bit of architecture, with the equally-stunning Houses of Pariament as a backdrop. While you're there, be sure to look for the statues of Cromwell, Churchill, and other famous Brits. Relax in the park immediately across the street. Set your watch to the bells, which chime every 15 minutes. There's something oddly peaceful about the Bong... Bong... Bong.. on the hour.

Big Ben - Fabulous Architecture. Although Big Ben sits in a very touristy location, and attracts hoards of tourists itself, it is worth taking on the crowds to see this fabulous piece of architecture. Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament are built in a gothic style, and you have to see the detail work in person to fully appreciate it. It sits right on the Thames, so after viewing it up close, you could cross over to the other side of the river to view it from a distance. This side of the river offers the best views of the tower. The London Eye provides a great bird's eye perspective, or you could view it from below on a Thames river cruise. If those options are out of your budget, buy an ice cream and sit and watch street performers and artists (not sure if they are there year round, or were just there for the carnival that was taking place) with Big Ben as a backdrop. It is the quintessential London attraction...don't miss it!

Stunning!. I have seen it in TV series and movies and finally, I got a chance to admire the Big Ben in person! It is stunning to say the least. You have to be there to soak in the view and the sight (along with the Thames and Parliament) and of course, you need to hear the chime!

Big ben by the houses of parliament. one of the many free things to see in london a historic land mark which is well maintained and iconic for any new year celebration worth a visit and plenty of other places to visit in the same area well worth a visit if in london
Hear the chimes!. A classic London sight and a big must see! Very busy, so keep children close and watch you handbags as there is loads of people around.

Good to see. After leaving paddington station we went to see big Ben and Westminster , really enjoyed the walk around seeing downing street , the changing of the guard and stopping off to see Westminster abbey . It made such a change from just going to London to shop.
Wonderful to behold. You can get some fantastic photographs with Big Ben as the centerpiece, or even just a glimpse in the background. It is a wonderful piece of history and the London skyline.

Number One. Big Ben is the great bell in the clock tower which is approx. 96 meters in the sky. I think there are about 390 (if not more) steps to the top, shame that overseas visitors cannot climb to the top.
Symbol of London. Standing tall near parliament this iconic clock tower is a must see and make sure you are ther eon the hour/half hour to hear a chime.Really must see this when in London.

The Bells of Big Ben. Saturday Morning.Early.London.The weather is clear, mild and sunny. A perfect sightseeing day. Stepped out of the subway (sorry - the tube) and stood on a bridge over the Thames.Then it happened.I heard the chimes of Big Ben. Instantly recognizable. I looked up and there it was. One of the most beautiful sights I have ever seen.The face, so finely crafted, shines in the sun as if it were composed of a million pieces of crystal. Maybe it is. All I know is you have not lived until you have heard the chimes of Big Ben. Sometimes the best things in life are free.

London's icon!. Hard not to come here and not take several photos! I mean, when you think of London, this is what you think of, and for the first-time visitor, it doesn't disappoint. Try to come at night, when you can get some great shots of the bell tower illuminated!

Stunning. It was so great being near a well known landmark. You must visit at night to see Parliament and Big Ben illuminated. Also, if you can work out getting there on the top of hour to hear Big Ben, that's a plus!
Great London Icon. Viewed Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament from Southbank, across the Westminster Bridge over the Thames, on the closing night of the Olympics last Sun., 12 Aug.

Wow. stand so tall and proud overlooking London from the banks of the Thames just seeing big ben makes me proud to be british

PSST? GOT THE TIME. Like many londoners, big ben is the icon for london along with the tower bridge. Standing at the north side of Westminister bridge lake a sentinel it is a victorian work of art. amaizing. Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London, and is generally extended to refer to the clock or the clock tower (officially known simply as Clock Tower) as well. The clock tower holds the largest four-faced chiming clock in the world and is the third-tallest free-standing clock tower. It celebrated its 150th anniversary on 31 May 2009, during which celebratory events took place. The tower was completed on 10 April 1858 and has become one of the most prominent symbols of both London and England, often in the establishing shot of films set in the city.
Awsome. The sheer size of the clock and on every hour you can hear it peels even if you are 8 miles away. One of London's premier attractions.

Beautiful. You just cant come to the incredible city of London and ignore Big Ben. It's a majestic and wonderful clock, which sounds ever hour. It's one of the most famous icons in the entire world and you can see why - it's completely wonderful. A must see for any traveler whilst coming to London!

A must see. Impressive to see Big Ben.

Just as Impressive as it looks. The titular clock town icon of London. Big Ben is imposing and massive as it is ornate and lovely. Be sure to be nearby to hear it ring at least once whilst in the city.

Enjoy!

Big Ben is a so8und, notg a tangible conrete item, but it's one of the most famous sounds in the world and it chimes from the clock above Westminister Abbey every hour on the hour, Greenwhich Mean Time, day after day and has sone so for hundreds and hundreds of years. A London Icon. A visit to Big Ben is a must simply because it's probably the main London icon. Big Ben. Is there another bell in the world that symbolizes a nation? I think not. The clock tower which is built in Neo-Gothic style, soon to be renamed the Elizabeth Tower, houses Big Ben the bell inside the tower. Big Ben is 13.5 tons. It is made of copper and tin and cracked just 4 years after it was made. It has 7 (4 meter clock faces) and is largest four faced chiming clock in the world housed in the world's 3rd highest clock tower. Each clock face contains 312 pieces and 48 (1 meter fiqures). An inscription in Latin at the base of the clock dial reads, "Lord" keep safe our Queen Victoria the First". Big Ben also has a twitter account that tweets "Bong" every hour. Good for office chatter. Easy to get to just take the tube to Westminister station, hop off and you are there. Best photo is from the London Eye although there are many other photo opportunities. Only UK citizens are promitted inside the tower to see the clock. Submit your applications to a member of parliament. Cheers!

London’s number one iconic sight. Forget about the London Eye, London’s number one iconic sight is, and will always be, Big Ben. A worldwide icon!. Sitting dominantly over the River Thames at Westminster Bridge is Big Ben. There isn't much to do other than stand and look in awe and take a photo or two of this worldwide recognised icon. It is possible though to go inside and climb, but you can't just turn up, you need to apply to go in, i know people who have been in it, and they weren't that impressed, but it is the fact that they are one of the few that have been in.It looks completely different in the flesh, i always love to admire the gold bits on the top and the very intricate detail of the whole thing.no visit to London for the tourist would be complete without a visit to Big Ben!

Write to your MP, and get to see inside for the real visit!. I didn't realise you could visit the inside of the Clock Tower until I heard the government wanted to charge for entry, determined to see the icon of London I wrote that day to my MP and received my 'e-ticket' soon after.Our visit was amazing! The guides made the visit come alive with fascinating facts and tit-bits of information.The walk to the top is quite strenuous and is taken in a couple of stages, the first 140 or so steps end with a sit down in 'Room 2' the only room on the way to the top that is accessible, as the others are closed due to health and safety grounds (there are no toilets in the clock tower, and no lift)There is a brief talk of the history of the tower before ascending the remaining 200 or so steps to the rear of the clock faces, then on to the belfry, which seems to be well timed for the hourly chimes (10am in our case) and all I can say is WOW! The bells are so loud! You also get to see fantastic views of London while up here, an old ventilation shaft that drops to the floor (a long 64 metres down!) The BBC microphones used to broadcast the chimes across the airwaves, the repair work to Big Ben to correct the tone of the bell when a crack formed a few years after installation.The visit then progresses in to the clock room where the three parts of the clock mechanism are explained in wonderful detail - including the adjustments made with old pennies to the pendulumAfter this you receive a certificate to confirm you climbed to the top of the clock tower!This visit is easily worth the proposed fee, and it's a pity in a way it won't be introduced, as there is serious conservation work required to the clock faces, and due to a short fall in funding the 5 yearly clock face clean has been cancelled this year :o(There is no access to food and drink in either the clock tower, or the meeting point of Portcullis House, also, there are no toilets in the clock tower!

Its a bell with a clock on it.... There isn't much to say about this really... The clock tower and Palace of Westminster makes for some great pictures and looks really nice at night. Our hotel was directly across the street and when walking towards it from Vauxhall station, it was incredible. Take the time to see it when visiting London, it is free after all...Here's a big of trivia for you... Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell inside the clock tower and is thought to be named after Ben Caunt, a champion heavyweight boxer of the 1850s OR named after Sir Benjamin Hall, First Commissioner for Works 1855-1858. Nobody knows which is true.

Icon of London - try to view from different angles at different times. Big Ben is of course really the bell, but is more often used to describe the entire building at the east end of the Houses of Parliament.How can you not love this icon of London? It's not massive by modern standards, a mere 96 metres high (the Empire State Building is 448 metres and the Burj Khalifa in Dubai 828 metres tall). You can't visit it other than to view it from the outside. However, you are able to get good views from north and south of the river, all all times of day and night, and in all lighting conditions. If you are in London for a few days, it would be worth taking in Big Ben from several perspectives at different times.

it's the law. You are required to walk a block or two from Big Ben and get your photo taken with the clock over your shoulder. This right of passage is as basic as the photo of you emerging from a red phone booth, "surprised" to have your photo snapped. The challenge here is to bring originality to your photo. Most people stand near Winston Churchill's statue to snap Big Ben because it saves walking. Maybe you could wend your way along the Thames and take your photo looking back from the river? It is a challenge to your ingenuity to take a new pose, because a zillion people have gone before you. It takes a wide angle lens to get much more than just the top of the Clock Tower, otherwise it appears to lean or bend. This could prove interesting if you also are good at leaning! Actual tours of just the Clock Tower (Big Ben is the name of the 13 ton bell inside) are limited to British nationals. When Parliament considered naming The Clock Tower after Queen Elizabeth II, it was pointed out that everyone refers to it by the wrong name anyway, calling the whole thing "Big Ben", so what was the point? After you take your photo, set your watch. It's free!

Top tips for visiting Westminster, Big Ben. 1: Beware of pickpockets around the area. There are also street performers who perform gambling tricks to lure you into gambling.2: Best way to see the Big Ben is take a tube and stop at Westminster tube station (district line or Circle Line). London Eye is just right opposite the Big Ben3: If you are hungry, there is a local supermarket call tesco which is just opposite Westminster Abbey4: do not ask any suspicious tourist to take photos for you and your family/friends otherwise you might lose your camera! Stand right beside the BELL, !. This was a great day, the guide took us through some the Houses of Parliament, showing us the green leather chairs and the Speakers Seat and all the history. If you get a chance to see Big Ben grab it!. This picture is not of Big Ben. Big Ben is not the tower that is the Westminster Tower. Big Ben is not the clock. That is the Great Westminster Clock. Big Ben is the big bell inside the clock.I have seen it twice on a school party where my wife was head. It had been arranged through the local MP. But there are many other parties too. You are taken up to the top of the tower - passing the room where Emily Pankhurst was held prisoner - and you are told to be careful whilst the clock strikes the hour - round the four outside bells and then Big Ben itself. The guide gives a lecture for 15 minutes when everybody is surprised by the 15 minute peel. A great experience.

It's the Bell, not the Clock. |It's a must have photo, but Big Ben is the bell inside, not the clock tower that it is housed in. I won't bore you with the details, but if you come to London and don't stop by for a photo, what is the point. :)

Big Ben. Must do - Big Ben, Houses Of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and then walk up Trafalger Square via Whitehall, Downing Street and cut through Horse Guards Parade and The Mall. All within minutes of each other.

It's not just Big Ben. Situated right beside Parliament and opposite Westminster Abbey its one of London's nicer areas. This area isn't famous for its night-life just the stunning architecture. Have a look at the building directly opposite, not sure what it is now but it used to be Crown Court, the top floor was one huge circular court all in rich red leather! Just up the road is the changing of the guard and Churchill's underground war rooms. Cross over Westminster Bridge and on the South Embankment of the Thames where London Council used to have their offices is the London Aquarium. Take a peep at your guide or map book and you'll see there's just so much to see around this area, take the next Bridge along and on the south side is Lambeth Palace, I think this is the archbishop of Canterbury's official residence ... not 100 yards from Scotland yards famous forensic science lab. Going back to Big Ben look opposite, next to the Westminster Abbey is a large mediaeval building, in the olden days this is where all the money, gold and wealth collected by the king in taxes was kept, in the age of King Richard 1st (the Lionheart) this was used to finance the crusades to Jerusalem. There's 'Queen' Boudicca's statue on the North side of Westminster bridge and right next to Big Ben but in the grounds of the house of Parliament is a pretty little green light mounted on the railings, when an MP whose been working late wants a taxi he presses a button a the light goes on, a taxi then enters and collects him ... save shim having to stand on the street with the peasants! Go on look around, find King the statue of Oliver Cromwell who overthrew King James in the 1600's ... and what about King James? Is he depicted in such splendour? No, right opposite Cromwell's magnificent statue on the other side of the road in a grubby little alcove cut into Westminster Abbey is a bust of Charlie boy, looking straight at parliament. Its all there just a stone throw from Big Ben, and to finish on Big Ben, apart from the fact the its leaning over like the leaning tower of Pizza the whole timing mechanism is regularly tuned and balanced, not by computer but by placing old one penny pieces on one edge, the weight of these keeps everything just so ... enjoy.

When the bell tolls. If you're in the City of London you can't fail to see Big Ben, or actually the tower and the clock, immortailzed in myriad movies and novels. You can't get inside and up the tower, but make sure you're close when it strikes the hour so melodiously, and also view it at night, maybe from across the river - an awesome sight.

Great, although you never see Big Ben!. The Westminster Tower, is a landmark in London!  However, it does annoy me that everyone thinks this is Big Ben!  The bell which chimes, and can be heard for miles in London is called Big Ben.  The tower pictured is the Wesminster Tower!!!Still, it's a sight to see, and a trip to London wouldn't be complete without a picture in the album!

Personally I found it interesting to hear about the engineering behind the tower and the bell and once we got down our guide asked if we had seen the houses of parliament, as we said we had not another guide quickly showed us around while on his break. A source of a smile every day. I work in the Whitehall area and here Big Ben chime throughout the day. I physically pass it most days and have thus seen it in every weather and have had to navigate all who come to see it whether to stand and gawp, photograph or occassionally sketch or paint. Sometimes I stop being abusy commuter and become a photographer - this is almost guaranteed if I walk across Westminister Bridge, probably the most popular place because you can get three in one from here; The River Thames, The Houses of Prliament and Big Ben itself. On days I walk fromn Westminister Tube to my office of back I often see visitors who set eyes on Big Ben for the first time. It is so obviously a special moment for many of them; you can see it in their facial expression and sometimes their overall reaction. The feeling similar to the one I have experienced when first visiting othr iconic sights like Machu Picchu, Angkor Wat, my wife's home city of Halong Bay, The Pyramids and Taj Mahal. Can I really compaire Big Ben to any of these? Maybe or maybe not but it is obvious the pleasure it brings to millions and it is one of the must see sights for just about any visitor to London. Surely some are disappointed, I mean it is just a tower with a clock on, right. I guess if you look at it that way you may be but it is dammed impressive in its own right and seen on a crisp clear winter morning when the sky is blue and tourists are moderate in number is seeing it at its best. Very few who see it can ever get to climb up inside though there are a few who maage to - over forty years in London I have stll not but one day maybe. For now though I take it as a free sight and one of the pleasures of working in Westminister. I never get board of seeing Big Ben, hearing its chimes and best of all seeing the reaction of visitors who travel from all over the world. If you vsit don't miss it and look for the smiles, even if the clock fails to float your boat it will make the day of someone nearby and their smile will make yours. Enjoy.

contact your MP and you can go up the tower for free on a guided tour. This is a brilliant free attraction and worth doing, simply email yoir MP and you can go and visit the clock tower, go up the inside to see the clock working and stand under the bells as the hour stikes its absolutely fantastic.Our guide was very informative and had good presentation skills, there are over 300 steps to the top but you stop twice on the way up.First stop is a third of the way up and you go into a room for a little presentation, this is to give you a rest more than anything else. You then move up to the clock mechanism and get to see the workings of the clock, you then move to the belfry where you arrive just before the hour and actually watch the hammers stike the tune and then its big bens turn to ring the hour.Security is very tight and no photography allowed, we were searched twice and had to take passports and a utility bill too but its well worth the hassle, highly reccomended

UK citizens can visit the clock tower. If you are a UK citizen, you can request a visit inside the clock tower by making a request through your local MP and they do some background checks. Since early 2011, per current restrictions, non-UK citizens are not allowed to visit as too much hassle to go through the background checks.It is not for the faint of heart as it is several flights of stairs. They also give ear plugs so that your ears are not damaged when the bells ring while you are in the tower. There are a few rest breaks (with some history lessons to boot!) at different rooms on the way up, so you don't have to walk up in 1 straight go.Highly recommended if you are able to do so! No cost!

Impressive at night, and in daylight. Big Ben is the quintissential London attraction, while big ben refers simply to the bell, the tower which holds it is generally considered part of the attraction. It is especially impressive at night, as are most of London's attractions, and it has a sound which must be experienced! And also as a bit of interesting trivia, if you are listening to a radio in the vicinity of Big Ben, and it strikes 12, (for example at new year when the sound is broadcast on the radio) then it is heard to strike 13 times! This is because the chimes issuing directly from Big Ben are delayed due to the distance travelled, so the "thirteenth" chime is a repeat of the twelfth that you already heard just before it came over the radio.

Reservations are essential,your local m.p. may help and it is free of charge!Their was 16 people in our group and 2 guides ,we started at 09-30 and climbed the 434 steps of St. Stephens tower these are very narrow and steep but we get two chances to have a rest on the way up --much needed.The guides are very imformative,finally we made it to the top,where their are 3 bells the biggest one is "big ben" we heard the hour struck only 3 feet away from the bells.It was then down the steps to finish our tour. there were 16 people on our tour ,guides were great,the tour lasted 85 minutes. you should be reasonably fit for the steps!! Big Ben is amazing. We visited Big Ben during our trip to London and we were not disappointed. It is truly a sight to see. We found out a few days ago that it has started to lean, but we did not notice the clock tower to be leaning. If we can offer one caviat...be aware of women attempting to sell paper flowers on the bridge. They were asking for donations for a hospital at the time, but quickly arose our suspicions when they could not provide the name of the hospital to us, and furthermore, asked for paper money only. These women must work the bridge everyday, as locals just walk right by them. The Houses of Parliament is also located next to Big Ben and it is open for tours on Saturdays only. We were not able to tour the Houses of Parliament as we had made other plans, but plan to do so on our next visit to London. Located just over the bridge from Big Ben is the London Eye. Riverboat cruises are also available in the immediate area. Overall, a great way to spend a few hours.

Nice for Photos. Big Ben is a great photo opportunity and of of the iconic images of London. Note that only UK nationals can go in and climb the tower.It is located in the heart of all the main tourist attractions, so likely you will pass by it many of times. Lots (I mean lots) of people trying to take photos everywhere, so its impossible to get a shot without hundreds of others in it....can be stressful if thats what you are trying to do.If you take the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament, the courtyard as you exit as a perfect unobstructed view with no one around (since only tour guests exiting can be in that area)....its a perfect shot of Big Ben.

A great attraction to see in central london. A great attraction to see in central london quite close to London eye and westminster station
A nice place to roam around with your family, if you are interested in aquarium/ sea life that there is a fish aquarium just besides London eye

Lives up to its reputation. Big Ben is one of the most famous London landmarks, and seeing it for real lives up to its reputation. From the hustle and bustle of the eastern side to the relative calm of the western shore, you can see this iconic building from all around. Along with the Houses of Parliament it is quite stunning. An absolute must-see when in London.
Beautiful Great Pictures. You hear about Big Ben all of your life, but when you actually see it, it is amazing.

The Big Ben Experience!. This is a must see for those that are new to London. This clock towers over the city, it offers a rich history, and it is surrounded by an area that is just as interesting! We took an amazing river cruise after this attraction, and it really rounded out of view of this wonderful city!
Great monument. Didn't go up but it's so great to look at. Especially if you're into english history, the location is amazing.

Went up the Clock Tower to visit Big Ben!. My husband and I made an appointment to view Big Ben months in advance. Only residence are aloud to visit the Clock Tower and you just have to email your representative. It is free to see. We met up at the new Parliament building across the street from Big Ben and Parliament. Than after security clearance we were led under ground under the street to the Big Ben! There are 3 stages when you climb up the stairs! It is quite a climb and made me a little dizzy! We learned a lot about the history of the making of Big Ben and we saw the crack in one of the bells! It was such an amazing view from the top and I can't wait to make another appointment to climb those stairs!

Awesome. It's simply amazing to look up and realize that you are standing in front of Big Ben, which is a tower I had only previously seen in books, magazines, or on my TV/laptop screen. It's a huge and tall tower, and it's actually quite pretty, with the huge clock face. Take plenty of pictures with it, and also enjoy the chimes it makes as the clock strikes whatever hour of the day. :)
breath taking view. When you look at it, it will makes you feel that you are in some 60s movie.

Big Ben. Big Ben is situated right in the heart of London. You cant miss it, it is within walking distance of The London Eye, The national Art Museum, Buckingham Palace and many more sights. It really is beautiful to see.
Nice. It is just amazing to see it. It is very unique. there is a good

Another icon of London. Big Ben is one of those buildings that everyone recognises. Some people think it should be bigger, others are disappointed that you can't get that close to it. However if you stop and take some time to admire the Tower, you will then realise how beautiful it is. It's extremely ornate with some beautiful detailing. Many people stop right underneath it to take pictures, which is a good viewpoint but the problem here is that there are so many tourists milling around, you will get knocked and bumped around. Find a quiet spot, perhaps on the bridge and take some photos. You can also get a great view when standing in from of the House of commons.Not many people realise that you can actually get a tour of Big Ben. Unfortunately it is only available to UK nationals and has to be booked months in advance. This needs to be arranged through your local MP.This is a building you must see on your visit to London and it's near many other attractions, so you wont need to go out of your way to get there.

Beatiful Building!. It is so nice when you see one the things you always wanted to see, looking more pretty and fantastic that in the pictures, the Big Ben and all the buildings around it are fantastic!By night or by day is beautiful!I am so happy that I came to London!

must see. I think this is a must see while in london as its so iconic. Its free to viisit, makes excellent photos and is easily accessible by tube. Get off the tube at wesminister station and you're there. Very close to westminister abbey and trafalger square.

Nice for photos, an icon.. Something you should see when you're in London. We didn't go in, but we passed by it a few times and took some photos. It's just something iconic for a city like London. Just pop by and take a look.

wow factor when up close. This is one of those things that you know you have to see and expect to see, but when you get up close, you go wow. My kids just loved standing on the nearby bridge and taking pictures of Big Ben, then walking around it. My smallest one declared that this was the one thing she had always wanted to see and she was thrilled.
Just a Big Ben. It is just a Big Ben. A nice work of art and architecture. Must see if in London.
LOVED IT. A must see when in London . Its huge. Take heeps of pictures here .
Just Amazing!. Seeing Big Ben was amazing. We saw it from the London Eye and it looked good but close up is fantastic! took some fab pics!

Must see!. This is probably the postcard picture of london. the old clock, that through the centuries stand still in the middle of england's capital. take a lot of pictures, hopefully with some help from the english weather. be carefull of the common tourist traps around, since this is the place all tourists visit.

An icon, good for photos. One of the must visit place when you're in London. If not, you have not been to London! Nothing much about Big Ben though, but it's an icon of architecture. Near the london eye, and beware of pickpockets! Overall, great for photos
Symbol of London. An Old Building which London is famous on it! If you visiting London for the first time, You have to visit it!

It's alright. Be careful for thieves though. In my opinion there's nothing special with Big Ben. It's just a clocktower and the only thing you can do is to take a couple of pictures which takes like 1 minute? It's good that it's right in front of the tube station so you can go to another place quickly.One thing that I want to warn you all about is to be careful when you are at the Big Ben. When we were taking pictures of us in front of the clocktower, a couple of women approached us, giving us flowers saying that it's childrens day today and asked us to donate money. We all took out a couple of coins each to donate and they were like "No we only accept moneybills and then they just grabbed the money we had in our purses and ran away. We manage to follow one of the women for 30 minutes begging her to give our money back which she didn't. Instead she took a cab and ran away.And you won't get any help from the other people. Not even the people in the little shops and icecream vans there. They will say that they can't do anything, not even helping you call the police. But when we finally manage to contact the police they were very helpful.So be careful at Big Ben because the police told us the same thing happens ALOT to tourists there at Big Ben and probably other attractions too.

A London Icon - A great photo Op. A visit to London should include a visit to see the clock tower and hear the bells ringing.It can be spotted from Westminster Cathedral or from across the Thames.It is very ornate as you get close to it.

Little Big Ben. It is exactly as you have seen it a thousand times on postcards and on TV. Big Ben is simply stunning and kept in good shape over the centuries. A million people gather around it during the course of the year and getting a good spot to take pictured is essential. Best to view BB in the evening or early morning time.

disappointed. I was really looking forward to seeing big ben but we had a couple in their 70s on our tour who did not look fit enough to be there.You guess it of course one of them took ill only a third of the way up so everyone was told the tour was over and we were sent back down.We were offered to go on the afternoon tour or come back next week! no use if your only there for a few days i feel we treated appalingly.I think people of a certain age should a medical certificated to stay the are fit enough to go up not just there word so not to ruin everyone's experience.

Would be a crime to be in London and not see!. You have to go.. just to see it and be in the area. Look across the river and you'll see a lovely landscape. Your classic pictures of London were taken there :-p Though I wouldn't recommend paying to see the Abbey. Current price is 17quid per head.
Big Ben / Parliament Square – No words needed :D. Big Ben / Parliament Square – No words needed :DSimply … THE SPOT!!!

It just screams "London"!. Don't miss seeing Big Ben & the Houses of Parliament if you go to London. We hung out there for quite a while, listening to the clock strike the hour and walking around to see everything. It's such an interesting area and Westminster Abbey is there, too.

Not many know this but. any trip to London wouldn't be complete with out going to see big ben and not many know that if you are a resident of the UK you are able to go up the tower free of charge whilst we didn't do it this time we sure will be in the future link below with information on how to go about this http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/visitingandtours/bigben.cfm

Big Ben-Landmark Must See!. Yep! It's a big clock! What is cool is that when Big Ben chimes, one can easily weed out the tourists. When that clock chimes, London-ers (not sure if that's the correct term!) move along...business as usual, and the rest of us...well, we all stop in our tracks and look to the big clock! It's pretty entertaining. And pretty darn, well, pretty! Bottom line: you can't go to London and not see Big Ben...I think there's a law against it! Just kidding!

Big Ben(efits). Okay, so there's probably nothing about this city that's not already been written, so won't waste your time..there's something for everybody..the accent is hard to understand, but not the city! :)

A must-see (of course). Not seeing the Big Ben in London is like not seeing the Great Wall of China when visiting Beijing. While you can't actually go up the tower to see the great bell (which is actually what the Big Ben is), it's a beautiful sight to behold and one of the definitive monuments that you have to spend a few minutes taking a photo of.

A famous landmark.... OK, if it was at the middle of nowhere, you wouldn't really go to see it, would you?But it's part of Palace of Westminster aka England's Houses of Parliament building ( an intresting view), on Thames North Bank, a few steps of Westminster Abbey and with London Eye ,London Aquarium and County Hall ( housing some interesting exibitions) almost opposite. And this area definately worths a visit! Clock Tower (with Big Ben, the bell in it) is a famous London landmark, and it's a quite beautiful sight also. I wouldn't advise someone to go there just to take a few pics, but as far as the area has plenty of other attractions, if you are there, take a few minutes to have a look!
Marvelous landmark. You can't actually visit Big Ben, but it is a great site to see and photograph. It's not at all a letdown.

It's a magnificent sight!. It's funny how we associate a building with a country.When you think of England, you instantly associateBig Ben, Parliament, and Westminster Bridge with it.Seeing it live is great.The bell sound is better than in any movie.Its beautiful at night also.Take a walk to the other side of Westminster Bridgeto take some great photos too.It is a must see.

Loved Its Sound. I thought Big Ben was very cool. It is beautiful. I got to hear it ring twice at different times and thought it sounded pretty. Just be careful...its near a busy road. You should totally spend some of your time in London to hear and see Big Ben.

There's something about Big Ben. There's just something about it. Hear it chime while walking along the Thames. Looking straight up at it from the sidewalk. Another great view is from inside the fence of the Houses of Parliament (which you can visit for free!).
a precise place:)). An excelent place and full of tourists, spectacular at night when the clock faces are illuminated

Ex Libris of London. The Clock Tower, knowned as The Big Ben, is as majestic as I expected. The silhouette, the golden image, the size and all the environment around astonished me, because it was one of my dreams to be right in front of Big Ben.
